HEADLINE: Yeltsin Suggests Russian Regional Role

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 28

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin suggested today that Russia should be granted special powers to stop ethnic conflicts in the former Soviet Union.
Mr. Yeltsin raised the notion only briefly at a political conference, in an address that was otherwise focused largely on his intensifying political confrontation with the Legislature. 
 But it was the President's first public intimation that Russia sought special military powers in the other 14 former Soviet republics, all of which have declared independence.
 
Sure to Raise Protests
 Any such suggestion was certain to raise ardent protests and anxieties, most notably in Ukraine and the three Baltic states, where anything that smacks of renewed domination by Moscow is political anathema. These and other republics would undoubtedly view any special powers as a dangerous license for Moscow to impose its will on the new states.
"The world community is increasingly coming to understand Russia's special responsibility in this difficult task," Mr. Yeltsin told a congress of the Civic Union, a center-right alliance.
"I think the moment has come when responsible international organizations, including the United Nations, should grant Russia special powers as a guarantor of peace and stability in the region of the former union. Russia has a heartfelt interest in stopping all armed conflicts on the territory of the former Soviet Union."
Mr. Yeltsin did not elaborate further. His reference was evidently to Tajikistan, the southern Caucasus region and Moldova, which have fallen into bloody ethnic strife and where Russian forces are still based.
[In Washington, a State Department official said it was important to see the full text of Mr. Yeltsin's remarks before jumping to any conclusions about what he meant.]
 In Tajikistan, Russian forces have openly stepped in to close the border with Afghanistan, across which guns and gunmen have been streaming. In the other struggles, the Russian troops have remained officially neutral but have been repeatedly accused of aiding one side or another.
Mr. Yeltsin's comments followed several developments on these fronts:
*In Tajikistan, Russians were reported to have fought a stiff battle with Afghan guerrillas.
*In Georgia, the Russian Defense Minister, General Pavel S. Grachev, paid a call on Russian forces despite the public opposition of President Eduard A. Shevardnadze.
*In Moldova, the commander of the 14th Russian Army said his units would not leave until the political status of the Trans-Dniester region -- where the Russian population has declared independence -- is clearly defined.
 
A Foreign Minority
 In these regions and in other former republics, some 25 million Russians have found themselves a foreign minority. The issue is especially sensitive in Latvia and Estonia, which have passed citizenship laws restricting the rights of Russians who have settled there since 1940.
While some warring republics have sought Russian intervention, especially in Central Asia, they have done so strictly within the framework of the Commonwealth of Independent States, the vague structure to which 11 former republics still technically belong. Kazakhstan, for example, recently objected to a Russian plan to take a leading role in regional peacekeeping.
Mr. Yeltsin's dominant theme in his address was the growing political confrontation with Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, the legislative leader, and the Russian Parliament. Charging that the Deputies were pushing Russia to ruin, he declared, "I, as President, cannot tolerate such a situation any longer."
In his first major comments on the subject since returning from a brief vacation, Mr. Yeltsin said that the Parliament was now virtually a "parallel government" blocking economic changes, and that it planned to encroach further on his executive powers through constitutional changes at the next session of the Congress of Peoples' Deputies.
 
Highest Authority
 Under the existing Soviet-era constitution, the 1,000 members of the Congress constitute the highest legal authority in the land, and Congress empowers a smaller sitting Parliament to legislate between its sessions, which are held twice a year. Mr. Khasbulatov is chairman of both Congress and Parliament.
"I did not swear my oath to such a constitution," Mr. Yeltsin declared. "They are talking about refusing to separate powers. If we refuse to separate powers we will get either dictatorship or anarchy, both of which would be ruinous for Russia."
This was the first time Mr. Yeltsin had questioned the legitimacy of the Constitution, but he made no specific threats.
Still, his harsh words contributed to the actions and statements that seem to be building to a major clash. Two weeks ago Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Khasbulatov agreed to negotiate a power-sharing agreement but nothing has come of the talks, and the statements of both have become increasingly aggressive.
The struggle dates from the Congress session in December, when the executive and legislative branches resolved a fiery confrontation by agreeing to hold a referendum on a new constitution in April. Since then, Mr. Khasbulatov and most other political leaders have declared themselves against a referendum at this time.
Mr. Yeltsin has suggested that he, too, would prefer not to hold a plebiscite, but he and his lieutenants have found themselves increasingly on the defensive. Though public-opinion polls still show Mr. Yeltsin to be the most popular politician, they also show some erosion in his standing. More damaging, the polls show that less than half the electorate would turn out for a referendum, denying him the one weapon he might have.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, right, with Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi yesterday in Moscow. Mr. Yeltsin said that Russia should have special powers to deal with ethnic strife in the former Soviet Union. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Ex-Foes Trade Stories From Cold War Trenches

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 27

 BODY:
Former United States and Soviet officials who helped end the cold war presented differing views of that watershed event at a conference here this weekend that brought together former Secretary of State George P. Shultz, former Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh and many colleagues from the 1980's.
But the last generation of cold warriors, who gathered at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs, shared several perceptions. 
 In the Reagan-Gorbachev era, for instance, both superpowers were committed to arms buildups that they ultimately recognized as self-defeating.
 
Prompted by Chernobyl
 Both sides agreed that the Chernobyl reactor disaster, equivalent to only one-quarter of the blast from the smallest American nuclear weapon, gave a powerful impulse to disarmament.
They also said the personal relationship that Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev eventually built was critical to the diplomatic understandings they reached. "It created the human networks on both sides necessary for the disarmament agreements," said Anatoly S. Chernyaev, foreign policy adviser to President Gorbachev.
On the other hand for Mr. Bessmertnykh, who was Deputy Soviet Foreign Minister from 1986 to 1990 and Foreign Minister in 1991, the end of the cold war was really the end of a much longer period of ideological rivalry between East and West that had started with the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917. Mr. Bessmertnykh said that the cold warwas in fact ended by reformers around Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Reagan who realized its wasteful futility.
For the conference this weekend, the Central Intelligence Agency declassified a top-secret estimate of the Soviet Union's nuclear capability in 1982-92.
 
Justifying the Buildup
 This document, drawn up in February 1983, helped to justify both the Reagan Administration's arms buildup and its drive toward nuclear disarmament. The assessment predicted that the Soviet arsenal of 2,300 land- and submarine-based missiles in 1983 would increase "by 13 to 25 percent over the next 10 years" and that the number of deployed warheads would rise from 7,300 to between 13,000 and 21,000 by the early 1990's.
But the predicted rise in Soviet nuclear power never came about, he said, because "we got an arms-reduction process going" and the new missiles were not built.
Mr. Bessmertnykh said the Soviet leadership had shared a similar view of Washington's military intentions at the start of the Reagan era. "The same story was reported to us by our intelligence," he said, "and after a period of accommodation the United States had suddenly changed course and started an enormous buildup."
For Mr. Shultz, what distinguished Mr. Reagan from many of his conservative supporters was that he disliked nuclear weapons and wanted to use America's military strength to negotiate reductions. "Reagan was different from many of his conservative backers in that he was a leader in saying the United States must be strong, but he parted company from them in saying we must negotiate with the Soviets on the basis of that strength," he said.
Mr. Reagan had great faith in his powers of personal persuasion, Mr. Shultz went on, saying that while he might call the Soviet Union "the evil empire," he also "believed he could turn it into a good empire."
Mr. Bessmertnykh said the buildup under President Reagan caused difficulties for Mr. Gorbachev, whose arrival in power in 1985 had coincided with growing economic problems for the Soviet Union.
These difficulties were compounded by the Reagan Administration's interest in developing a Strategic Defense Initiative anti-missile shield, which Moscow saw as destabilizing because it meant the United States had less to fear from a retaliatory Soviet strike if it struck the Soviet Union first.
This led, he said, to a tug-of-war inside the Soviet bureaucracy, with the military wanting better missiles to counter "star wars" and the enemies of the cold war seeking to use the threat of a renewed arms race to push arms curbs.
The United States speakers at the conference seemed to take "star wars" less seriously. "I never believed in it," said a former Defense Secretary, Frank R. Carlucci. Mr. Shultz said the Strategic Defense Initiative was "driven by Ronald Reagan, very personal," adding that as Secretary of State, the Pentagon once refused him a briefing on "star wars" because he did not have the right security clearance.

HEADLINE: 2 Bosnian Opponents Balk At Beginning U.N. Parley

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 28

 BODY:
On the eve of a critical round of peace talks, leaders of two warring Bosnian factions signaled today that they were not yet prepared to accept the terms of a United Nations settlement.
Negotiations on ending the civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina are expected to get under way here on Monday. Radovan Karadzic, head of the Bosnian Serbs, arrived in the United States today but rejected an invitation to begin talks this afternoon with former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, who is the United Nations mediator, and Lord Owen, who represents the European Community. 
 President Alija Izetbegovic, head of the Muslim-led Government of Bosnia, who failed to attend the first round of peace talks here in early February, also disappointed the mediators by saying he planned to remain in Washington through Monday meeting with Clinton Administration officials and members of Congress.
 
Reluctance to Join Talks
 His reluctance to join the peace talks reinforced the mediators' fears that he still is not fully committed to a reaching a settlement on the basis of the Vance-Owen plan, which calls for Bosnia to be divided into 10 semiautonomous provinces.
Most of the provinces would virtually be ethnic enclaves dominated by Serbs, Croats or Muslims, and so far only the Bosnian Croats have accepted its terms. The Bosnian Government has asserted that the plan would reward the Serbs for a 10-month pattern of "ethnic cleansing" in which thousands of Muslims have been driven from their homes.
The mediators are convinced that the leaders of Bosnian factions will not return for any further negotiations if they fail to sign a peace settlement in the next few days. The launching today of an American airdrop of relief supplies in eastern Bosnia has lent a renewed urgency to the mediators' efforts. In authorizing the air mission, President Clinton said he hoped that it would improve the climate for negotiations among the Serbs and Muslims, who officially blame each other for the suffering of civilians in villages cut off by the fighting.
But both Mr. Mr. Izetbegovic and Mr. Karadezic appear reluctant to get down to serious discussions quickly on the peace plan.
 
Expected a Week Ago
 Both leaders were originally expected in New York a week ago for a second round of peace talks after an earlier visit. But Mr. Karadzic failed to arrive, saying he was worried by legal action brought against him in the United States for abuses of human rights in Bosnia. He also balked at restrictions placed on his movements by the Clinton Administration as a result of allegations that he is a war criminal.
President Izetbegovic also refused to show up unless several conditions were met, including an end to the Serbian blockade of United Nations aid convoys trying to reach besieged Muslim villages in eastern Bosnia as well as enforcement of a United Nations ban on Serbian flights over Bosnia.
Even now, he contends that he is only offering to stop briefly at the New York talks later this week on his way home from an official visit to Washington. Haris Silajdzic, the Bosnian Foreign Minister, is still described as the delegation's official leader. But Mr. Karadzic has said he will only negotiate with President Izetbegovic.
 
Hopes for Security Council
 After five months of talks in Geneva, the mediators decided to move the negotiations to the United Nations in New York at the start of the year in the hope that the Security Council would corner the leaders into accepting their peace plan.
Officials here say the difficulty of persuading the Serbian and Muslim leaders to come to New York and talk seriously has convinced the mediators that they now have at best only a few days to reach an agreement.
The mediators doubt that the factional leaders will ever agree to return to New York again if they depart without making peace this time. The Security Council is threatening Serbia and Montenegro, the remaining republics of the old Yugoslav federation, with an even tougher economic embargo unless the President of Serbia, Slobodan Milosovic, uses his influence with Bosnia's Serbs to make peace.
The Clinton Administration, which had earlier criticized the Vance-Owen plan as favoring the Serbs, has since appointed a special envoy to help the peace negotiations along. An envoy has also been sent by Russia, the only major power outside the Balkans to show sympathy for the Serbian point of view.
Mr. Karadjic is viewed as being closer to accepting the Vance-Owen plan than President Izetbegovic, who believes that the Muslims' weak military position on the ground condemns them to unfair terms in any peace settlement.
In an effort to make their proposals more appealing to the Muslims, Mr. Vance and Lord Owen are planning to offer them several revisions, officials here say. Originally the Vance-Owen plan called for both sides to pull back their heavy weapons after a cease-fire and collect them in designated areas. A United Nations peacekeeping force would be deployed to monitor compliance with this requirement.
The Muslims, who are short of heavy weapons, have already said they want stronger guarantees that the Serbs will not start using their artillery again. And the mediators now plan to ask the United Nations forces to take physical control of all heavy weaponry.
 
NATO's 10-Year Plan
 This has become feasible, officials say, because NATO wants to send up to 40,000 peacekeeping soldiers for as long as 10 years rather than the 25,000 the mediators originally suggested.
The mediators are also considering asking the United Nations Secretary General to appoint an American general to command the new peacekeeping force, with a European civilian official put in charge of the plan's political and relief aspects.
Mediators hope the proposed appointment of an American field commander will reassure the Muslims, who have found the Clinton Administration more sympathetic to their plight than was the Bush Administration or the European governments, who all supported the original Vance-Owen plan.
Finally, the mediators are willing to add additional land to two of the three provinces in which their peace plan calls for Muslims to be dominant.

HEADLINE: Savings Bonds' Rate Cut

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The 6 percent guaranteed minimum rate on United States Government savings bonds is being lowered to 4 percent, effective Monday, the Treasury Department has announced.
The Treasury said on Saturday that outstanding series E and EE savings bonds and savings notes would carry the previously guaranteed minimum rates until the end of their original maturity periods or current extended maturity periods. 
 The same schedule applies to the rates on series H and HH savings bonds: Outstanding bonds will carry current rates, but those issued after March 1 will carry the guaranteed 4 percent minimum.
The Treasury said the rate reduction is in response to substantial declines in market interest rates in the last few months.
The last change in the guaranteed minimum rate was on Nov. 1, 1986, when it fell to 6 percent, from 7.5 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S. Quit Collecting Health Data Sought by Clinton

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
In a setback for President Clinton's effort to control health costs, Federal officials have discovered that the Government no longer collects the data needed to set a health budget for each state, as Mr. Clinton promised to do in the 1992 campaign.
The discovery forecloses one method of controlling health costs and forces the Clinton Administration to seek other ways of achieving the same goal, perhaps through direct Federal regulation of prices in the health-care industry. 
 In the campaign, Mr. Clinton said he would set a national limit on all health spending, public and private. Under the overall limit, he said, the Federal Government would set a health-care budget for each state and give the states maximum flexibility in deciding how to control costs and provide coverage for the uninsured. A state would be free to design its own solutions, as long as it stayed within its budget. The state budgets were to be computed from current health spending adjusted for population changes, inflation and other factors.
 
Data Collected Until 1982
 But members of the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform, headed by Hillary Rodham Clinton, discovered last week that the Government quit collecting state-by-state data on health spending a decade ago.
The Federal Government tabulated health spending by state from 1966 through 1982, but has not compiled state data since then, apparently because Federal officials did not need such information to run the Medicare and Medicaid programs for the elderly and the poor.
Thus, the study group members said, it will be virtually impossible to establish for each state a reasonable budget that can withstand legal challenge.
At the moment, they said, states have no reliable way to keep track of health spending outside public programs like Medicare and Medicaid. Federal, state and local programs account for less than half of all health spending.
 
Large Variations Among States
 Lynn M. Etheredge, a health economist working for the President's task force, said: "We have no ability to track spending at the state level, let alone set budgets in a rational way. Even our national spending estimates are two to three years behind. It's easy to put together a numbers exercise and just say health care will be X percent of gross domestic product. But how, in fact, do you budget 14 percent of our economy? How do you make this work? The practicalities are overwhelming."
The 1982 data showed that states varied immensely in the level of spending for health care, the growth of such spending and the mix of services bought with health-care dollars. Per capita spending for health care in 1982 ranged from a low of $857 in South Carolina to a high of $1,508 in Massachusetts. California and New York ranked second and third, with per capita spending of more than $1,400 each.
White House officials said Mr. Clinton was likely to propose health spending goals and new techniques for collecting data, but not a firm budget for each state.
In the absence of reliable data on state health spending, Administration officials are seeking other ways to control costs. Confidential work papers of the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform show it is considering a wide range of "interim cost controls," including Federal limits on doctors' fees, hospital charges and private health insurance premiums. But White House officials insist that these controls will be temporary.
In addition, Paul Starr, a professor of sociology at Princeton University who is working at the White House, proposed this month that states limit the average premium paid for each person in a health insurance plan or a health maintenance organization. The payment, he said, could be set to limit total spending in each state.
 
One-Seventh of Economy
 Health spending now accounts for one-seventh of the nation's entire economy. The Department of Health and Human Services estimates national health spending each year using data from a variety of sources.
For example, the American Hospital Association provides data on hospital spending. The Internal Revenue Service provides data on doctors' incomes. Commerce Department agencies, including the Census Bureau, estimate spending for drugs and nursing homes.
But for the last decade, the Government has been making yearly estimates of nationwide health spending without trying to compute outlays in each state.
 
Large Difficulties Foreseen
 In the campaign, Mr. Clinton said he would provide health care for all Americans and curb health costs with a strategy known as "managed competition," under which doctors, hospitals and insurance companies form networks and compete for the business of large employee groups and other consumers.
Mr. Etheredge, an architect of managed competition, said it would be very difficult for Federal authorities to enforce a health budget for each state.
"I know it sounds like a simple idea," he said. "But let's just remember the Gramm-Rudman law. We set a target for the Federal Government to balance its budget. We missed by $350 billion. The Federal Government has a tremendous amount of knowledge about its programs and complete control, in principle, over its revenues and outlays. Trying to control the health-care system is going to be much more difficult than controlling the Federal budget."
Administration officials say they have discovered another potential problem with managed competition. In the first five years, they said, it will probably not produce savings for the Government and therefore will not provide the Treasury with the money needed to subsidize coverage for the uninsured. The savings, if any, will show up in later years and will be spread among consumers, private employers and private health insurers.
 
Other Limits Are Likely
 But a White House official said Mr. Clinton could propose new taxes to "recapture some of the savings" that private employers realize. The Administration is also looking for new ways to slow the growth of Medicaid, perhaps by changing the legal formula to reduce Federal payments to the states for the care of poor people.
In addition, Administration officials said they might ask Congress to eliminate special Medicaid payments to hospitals serving "a disproportionate number of low-income patients." Such payments total $16.5 billion this year, or 12 percent of expected Federal and state Medicaid outlays.
Federal officials say they do not completely understand why health spending varies so much from state to state. Experts have documented wide variations in the practice style of doctors in different parts of the country, with doctors in some states much more likely to prescribe hospital care and costly procedures.
Health spending is also affected by the ratio of doctors to the local population. But even more important is the mix of general-practice doctors and specialists. Health costs tend to be higher in places with large numbers of specialists.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

CRISIS AT THE TWIN TOWERS: STEALTHY DETONATION AND PUBLIC CHAOS
As officials announced that the twin towers of the World Trade Center would be closed at least seven days from the effects of Friday's bomb blast, executives and workers turned their aplomb and ingenuity to finding ways to carry on business. The five commodities exchanges are reopening in a smaller building and big brokerage houses have arranged alternative locations. But other tenants face uncertainty and possible large financial losses, even though state and city officials do not expect lasting economic damage or a flight of panicked tenants. A1.
BOMB REPORTED MADE OF DYNAMITE
Law-enforcement officials say that the bomb that devastated the World Trade Center apparently was made of conventional dynamite, not a tightly controlled military explosive like the plastic favored by terrorists. And Police Commissioner Kelly disclosed that investigators believe more than one person was involved. A1.
SUDDEN TRAUMA AND SLOW RECOVERY
As they gain a clearer sense of the obstacles they face, from the lack of heat to water in the basement, Port Authority officials say it will be more than a week before the World Trade Center is fully revived. B5.
Since attention is a main goal of terrorism, investigators are baffled by the silence following the explosion. None of the more than 50 callers who have claimed responsibility has presented convincing proof. B4.
Eight years ago, an anti-terrorist task force told the Port Authority that the trade center's parking garage was vulnerable to a bomb attack and should be closed to the public. Additional safety systems were also suggested. But most of the key recommendations were never adopted. B5.
With a tiny blue hard hat perched atop his head, Stanley Brezenoff has been forced to occupy the very hot seat at the helm of the disaster reaction effort. His long experience in city government has proven to be good training. B4.
Service on PATH and New York City subway lines should be fully restored, making for a fairly normal rush hour in lower Manhattan. B5.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
WINNERS AND LOSERS ON ST. PATRICK'S DAY
A Federal judge's decision about the sponsorship of this year's St. Patrick's Day Parade appears to hand total victory to the Ancient Order of Hibernians, giving them control of the parade on their own terms, and equally complete defeat to Mayor Dinkins and the Irish Lesbian and Gay Organization. But on closer inspection the lines between winners and losers become blurred in the shifting ethnic and political mix of New York City. B3.
LIBERAL IMAGE IN DISPUTE
A larger proportion of New Yorkers now own their homes or apartments than at any other time in the 20th century. Owners tend to be more politically conservative than renters, which may help explain the city's recent conflicts over traditional social values. Metro Matters, B3.
A foundation fills the wishes of hundreds of seriously ill children. B2.
 
REGION
 
HOSPITALS NO, BUT JOBS YES
As New York State struggles to close down its sprawling mental hospitals and move the resources into smaller community programs, legislators who favor the policy in theory sometimes balk when it means loss of funds to their home districts. One hospital with fewer than a dozen patients is to be closed this year, and two others are on the list for closing -- bringing angry lobbying from workers and local legislators. B7.
AWAITING THE CALL IN HARTFORD
If Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut is thinking about accepting a job in the Clinton Administration, he isn't discussing the idea with his lieutenant governor, Eunice S. Groark. She's the one who would succeed him. In Hartford, state officials say they've heard talk that the governor's wanted in Washington, but nothing's definite. B7.
Snowmobilers are splitting residents of Lewis County, N.Y., as tourist dollars compete with a desire for winter quiet. B7.

HEADLINE: The South Rises Again, Now as a Tourist Haven

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GULF SHORES, Ala.

 BODY:
Until a few years ago not many people north of Mobile had heard of this town on the Gulf of Mexico, much less thought of coming to vacation on its white beaches. But as people spread the word of a Florida-like beach resort in a state that proclaims itself "the heart of Dixie," even Yankee tourists began arriving in droves.
Today, almost four million visitors a year descend on Gulf Shores and neighboring Orange Beach, the only two cities on Alabama's 32-mile Gulf Coast. 
 That is about a million more than the total yearly visitors to Palm Beach, West Palm Beach and Boca Raton, on Florida's tonier and more expensive Gold Coast. And they are arriving here on everything from tour buses from as far away as Lincoln, Neb., to campers from the Midwest and New England.
"We'd never been in Alabama before," said Don De Nagy of Simsbury, Conn. "Then we heard about this place and decided it was worth looking at someplace different."
Intrigued, he and his wife, Doe, drove down in mid-February with a camper in tow, and on their first day here they were already checking out the four 18-hole courses.
Tourists from all over the nation have been visiting the South in growing numbers for a decade, coming not just to Florida's beaches and theme parks, but also in search of historic Dixie and mythical Dogpatch.
 
Bullish on the South
 Now, with the economy looking up -- and with a nudge expected because Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Al Gore of Tennessee occupy the highest offices in the land -- all signs point to a record 1993.
"Everywhere you look across the South, tourist fever is building," said Bud Flora, director of travel and tourism for Southern Living magazine. "Unless we get a hellacious user tax on gasoline, all the pieces are in place for the strongest tourism year ever."
That optimism is shared by tourist officials from Virginia to Louisiana because of an unusual confluence of circumstances. One of the most important is that with lower prices and many of its destinations within two days' drive of almost half the United States population, the South is the major beneficiary of the recent shift to shorter and less expensive vacations, closer to home.
"It's going to be a banner year for the South," said George Smith, director of tourism development in Mississippi, "and this state will surpass anything we've ever seen."
 
An Advertising Jackpot
 That optimism arises from the prospects of a $5 million advertising and promotion budget this year, made possible by a mother lode of money available because of taxes collected from Mississippi's six new dockside casinos. Aboard the riverboat President Casino in Biloxi one night in mid-February, Shirley and Ted Westfall from Ossipee, N.H., were busily feeding the slot machines after a nine-hour drive from central Florida. "We love to gamble," Mr. Westfall said, "so it's either here or the Bahamas."
The economic impact of tourism is especially pronounced in the South, where it is the first or second industry in each state as well as a leading source of employment. In Florida alone, sales taxes paid by tourists -- $4.7 million a day -- account for 20 percent of the total state budget. And here in Baldwin County, tourism to Gulf Beach generates more lodging tax than any of the other 66 counties in the state.
The South has long been a popular destination, especially Florida, which draws more than 39 million tourists a year, up from 22.9 million in 1982. But neighboring states have become adept at coaxing Florida-bound visitors to spend a night or a week with them.
 
Golf as Growth Industry
 "Many of our visitors are on their way to or from Florida," said Hanna Ledford, deputy commissioner of tourism in Georgia, "but that's an advantage to us, because we're getting them to spend a few days en route."
With thousands of golf courses, including more than 475 in North Carolina, golf is now a year-round activity in much of the South, to the benefit of hotels and restaurants that once closed for the winter. "It's nothing to see a husband and wife drive down here from the North on a Saturday, play golf Saturday and Sunday, then climb back in their car or truck and drive home," said Marion Edmonds, director of tourism for South Carolina.
That mobility, enjoyed also by hunters and fishermen, has improved with the completion of interstate highways.
At the same time, airport hubs in Atlanta; Charlotte, N.C.; Nashville, Orlando, Fla.; and Raleigh-Durham, N.C., have heightened name recognition among millions of passengers, making it easier to lure them back as tourists.
 
In Search of Scarlett
 Many Southern states have opened tourist offices in other countries, and foreigners are showing up everywhere: national parks in Tennessee, Revolutionary and Civil War battlefields in Virginia and Dixieland clubs in New Orleans.
Along with Americans, many Japanese tourists are following a "Tara Road" tour through the South, tracing the footpaths that Scarlett O'Hara and Rhett Butler trod -- or would have, had they not been imaginary characters of Margaret Mitchell. (The house where she wrote "Gone With the Wind" is part of the tour.)
Soon to open for its eighth season, Dollywood in Pigeon Fork, Tenn., the recreated 1880's Smoky Mountains village representing the inspiration for many of Dolly Parton's songs, expects to exceed two million visitors.
Many Southern states and resorts are being advertising in national magazines or on cable television, often for the first time. Most states are also focusing on Canadians, some 2.4 million of whom spend about $2 billion in Florida each year.
Southern tourism this year will also benefit from well-placed friends. "We spent 20 years trying to get Arkansas on the map; then Bill Clinton was able to do it in 15 months," said Joe David Rice, the state director of tourism.
 
Battlefields and Birdwatching
 Even before the Presidential campaign, Arkansas was banking on a strong 1993, thanks in large part to Governor Clinton's support in 1989 of a 2 percent tax on lodging and attractions that provided money for promoting the state.
"Before now we just didn't have money to let people know about our attractions," Mr. Rice said. "But in 1990 our tourism budget increased from $500,000 to $5 million."
The South is even benefiting from adversity. Its slower industrial development did little to improve its fortunes in the War Between the States, as that sectional unpleasantness is sometimes called, but it left Dixie a passel of historic battlefields and helped preserve much of the region as a birdwatcher's paradise and an eco-tourist's delight.
The region is also well positioned to satisfy the growing interest in history and past cultures. Kentucky, for example, just published a 72-page Heritage Tours booklet, describing tours of the Daniel Boone Trail and giving tips about finding Kentucky ancestors.
Black tourists, in particular, are flocking to the South to see the birthplaces of their forebears and sites important to the civil rights movement. Visits to the Martin Luther King Jr. National Historic Site in Atlanta soared from 500,000 in 1985 to 3.2 million in 1992, according to the National Park Service -- 700,000 more than visited either the Empire State Building or the Statue of Liberty in 1992.
 
Making Most of Olympics
 The South has been unusually adept at marketing itself as a region, with 11 states founding a nonprofit tourism-promotion agency 25 years ago, Travel South USA Travel. "We share everything, including architects for our welcome centers," said Bill Hardiman, executive vice president of the nonprofit Southeast Tourism Society in Atlanta.
In mid-February, Southern tourism directors met in Atlanta on the 1996 summer Olympic Games, which are expected to attract as many as two million tourists. "The Olympics is not just an Atlanta event, it's an event for the entire Southeast," said Bob Stewart, commissioner of the Kentucky Department of Travel Development.
But one of the biggest reasons for the success of Southern tourism, Mr. Hardiman said, is that "we have organized almost all our cities to hold special events, even cities with populations of 1,000 or less."
Louisiana cities and towns have so many events it requires a 100-page booklet to list them all. But for piquing the interest of tourists it would be hard to resist the advertisement that Tuscaloosa, Ala., has placed in the trade press: "Come See What the Yankees Didn't Burn."

HEADLINE: Executive Brief: THE PENTAGON;
USA Today Undercuts Competition in Somalia

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
A press war of sorts is heating up in Somalia, and some American troops do not like it.
Lieut. Gen. Robert B. Johnston of the Marine Corps, who commands the United States-led coalition in Somalia, has ruled that USA Today may be distributed among the 17,500 American troops, but not Stars and Stripes, the military newspaper that has accompanied United States forces into combat since World War II. 
 Capt. Bob Prucha, a spokesman for the United States Central Command, which directs the military operation from Tampa, Fla., said General Johnston, as the field commander, had decided that one newspaper was enough, particularly since it was free.
But Bill Monroe, the Stars and Stripes ombudsman, suggested in a recent column that General Johnston harbored some hidden vendetta against the newspaper or a fear that Stars and Stripes would report embarrassing complaints against the brass.
"General Johnston has some reason to keep Stripes out that we don't know about," Mr. Monroe said. "He owes the troops there some explanation."
For the last three weeks, the Gannett Company, which publishes USA Today, has donated 5,000 daily copies of the newspaper to troops in Somalia. Stars and Stripes would cost 32 cents a copy, Captain Prucha said, and the military services have groused about picking up the tab.
 
Army General to Help Lead U.N. Force in Somalia
 A two-star Army general has been tapped to be the deputy commander of the United Nations force that will replace the United States-led operation in Somalia.
The general, Maj. Gen. Thomas M. Montgomery, will be second in command to a three-star Turkish officer, Cervik Bir, when the American-led coalition under General Johnston transfers control, probably in late March.
General Montgomery, 52, is director of management in the Office of the Army Chief of Staff and is responsible for Army protocol and base operations worldwide. He is a former NATO strategist in Brussels with a reputation for a steady hand in a crisis.
Military officials say General Montgomery will have to draw on all his diplomatic acumen to help guide the multinational force through what is expected to be a rocky transition for the East African nation.
Pentagon planners estimate that the Somalia operation will cost at least $830 million through September, the end of the current fiscal year. Planners had originally put the cost at $583 million through mid-March, but the military now expects about 4,000 troops to remain in Somalia through early 1994.
 
Pentagon Seeks Buyouts To Ease Pain of Job Cuts
 The Defense Department is trying to soften the blow for thousands of civilian employees whom the Pentagon needs to cut from its shrinking payroll.
The budget that Defense Secretary Les Aspin will send to the White House by March 12 will include $100 million to entice 16,000 of the nearly one million civilian department employees to leave voluntarily rather than be laid off.
In the last two years, military planners have offered uniformed troops lump-sum payments or annuities to winnow the size of the force. Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee, has urged the Clinton Administration to offer the same kind of buyout to Pentagon civilians to ease the pain of military spending cuts.
Two other new items in this year's Pentagon budget will be $400 million to help the former Soviet republics dismantle their nuclear weapons, and $200 million for humanitarian aid. In the past, the aid to the Soviet republics has been tacked on by Congress and the costs of peacekeeping missions have come out of the operating budgets of individual services.
 
Report on Naval Scandal Is Waiting for Right Reader
 The Pentagon Inspector General's report on the assault of dozens of women at a 1991 naval aviators convention in Las Vegas, Nev., is virtually complete -- all 300 pages of it -- but there is no Navy Secretary to accept it.
Derek J. Vander Schaaf, the acting Pentagon Inspector General, said a former civilian Navy Secretary, H. Lawrence Garrett 3d, requested his report, so he wanted to submit the second of his two-part report to another civilian.
The trouble is that there is no civilian Navy Secretary, in part because the White House has been slow to nominate senior officials throughout the Government while it concentrates on President Clinton's economic plan. Adm. Frank B. Kelso 2d, the Chief of Naval Operations, is the acting Secretary.
Candidates under consideration include Ray Mabus, a former Governor of Mississippi; Beverly B. Byron, a former Maryland Congresswoman; John Dalton, a Democratic fund-raiser from Texas, and John Holum, a Washington lawyer who researched the issue of homosexuals in the military for the Clinton transition team. Mr. Holum has already turned down the position of Undersecretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness, in part because of its responsibility for dealing with gay issues.

HEADLINE: Senate Leader Would Link Clinton Economic and Health Packages

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said today that he would like to combine health-care legislation with President Clinton's economic package because "that's the best way" to assure that both proposals get passed.
Appearing on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," Mr. Mitchell suggested that Congress would probably go along with financing part of the health-care program with higher cigarette taxes. But he called a proposed $2-per-pack tax, being discussed by some Clinton advisers, "unrealistically high." 
 And Leon E. Panetta, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said higher cigarette taxes were a logical revenue source for helping pay for new health-care programs like universal health insurance.
"It's legitimate to look at a cigarette tax as part of the way to pay for health-care reform," Mr. Panetta said on the ABC News program "This Week."
Not only would such a tax produce billions of dollars to help provide universal health insurance and other reforms, he said, "but more importantly it may try to inhibit the very kind of behavior that produces health-care problems in this country."
Mr. Mitchell said he did not know whether Mr. Clinton would go along with combining his economic and health-care proposals into a single package of legislation, and he indicated he would not do so if the White House objected.
But he said, "I hope that will be the case because that's the best chance to pass health care, and that's the linchpin of the whole effort to control the deficit." He said he hoped to have a health-care package ready by May and perhaps through the Senate by early summer.
Administration officials have acknowledged that additional Federal revenues will be needed to help pay for the health-care reforms. They have said that "sin taxes" on tobacco products and liquor are among the mechanisms being discussed.
Although a sharp increase in the cigarette tax would probably meet strong opposition from the tobacco industry and lawmakers from tobacco states, Mr. Mitchell said he expected Congress to approve "some increase in cigarette taxes" as part of a health-care package.
"I think $2 a pack is probably unrealistically high," he said.
The current Federal tax on cigarettes is 24 cents a pack, while state taxes per pack range from 2.5 cents in Virginia, a major tobacco producer, to 51 cents in Massachusetts. A pack of cigarettes on average costs $1.90.
Critics of a higher tax on cigarettes are expected to argue that, as is the case with virtually all excise taxes, it would hit lower- and middle-income people hardest.
But health experts argue that a sharp increase in the cigarette tax would prompt many people to stop smoking and thereby reduce health-care costs.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press Notes;
Newspaper Ad Staffs Shift From Blues to Upbeat Tune

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
Newspaper executives are feeling better about advertising prospects, which ought to be a leading economic indicator if ever there was one.
Over the last few years, they sang such a monotonous song about how bad advertising sales were that they nearly replaced reporters as the biggest complainers in newspaper offices. 
 Kenneth T. Berents, a newspaper analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons, has surveyed industry executives since 1991 about their projections for ad sales. This year's survey, just published, shows that they expect a modest improvement in display advertising and better sales of classified advertising, which economists say can be a real sign of economic growth.
Mr. Berents' conclusion: "The advertising doldrums that have been with the industry the last several years are ending."
Last year and the year before, the newspaper executives forecast the stalled advertising growth and declines in linage that came to be. This year, instead of projecting unchanged classified advertising as they did last year, publishers told Mr. Berents that they expect growth of nearly 3 per cent. They expect slimmer, but still noticeable growth in national and local display advertising.
The projections are based on a mixture of actual sales, guesses and impressions of imprecise things, like the mood of local merchants. This year, Mr. Berents received survey re- sponses from 217 newspapers.
California publishers are the most pessimistic. Newspaper executives in the Northeast, Mr. Berents said, are the most optimistic.
In the real world, industry executives say, it is becoming nearly bearable to sit through advertising department meetings.
"The mood," said Herbert W. Moloney, senior vice president for advertising at The Philadelphia Inquirer, "is definitely better than it was two years ago and better than it was last year."
 
Gambling on Sports: Statistics Can Lie
 Houston journalists were aghast 10 days ago when KTRK-TV broke the news that an illegal gambling operation had apparently managed to alter sports statistics so that incorrect numbers appeared in at least one of the city's two newspapers, The Houston Chronicle. The tamperers' goal, it seemed, was to manipulate payoffs to bettors who wager on all sorts of statistics -- total passing yardage in football or quarterly scores, to mention a couple of possibilities.
, The Houston Post may have been aghast, but not so much that it missed the opportunity for a little competitive thumb in the eye. All over town, the printed cards on The Post's news racks proclaimed: "Post Sports Always The Right Score."
"They looked like they were trying to use this unfortunate situation," The Chronicle's editor, Jack Loftis, complained a few days ago.
After the TV news account, both newspapers reported that the police had arrested five people who were charged with being members of a betting ring. It is not clear what connections there might have been between the five and newspaper people.
The Chronicle, a Hearst Corporation newspaper that has a bigger circulation than The Post, acknowledged that there were two instances when incorrect statistics were apparently inserted through the paper's computer system and appeared in print.
The Post, owned by W. Dean Singleton's Media News Group, said it had found one error. That one, it said, was proved to be a typographical problem.
Mr. Loftis said he doesn't "necessarily believe that" The Post was error-free.
The Post's editor, Gerald Garcia, defended his paper's position. "They have to admit that their data was wrong because it was," he said. "We didn't have to admit that our data was wrong because it wasn't."
Mr. Loftis said The Chronicle is not sure how its numbers were changed. It may, he said, have been done through a computer terminal that was set up to permit open access to anyone who knew how to use it. But he said the experience had provided The Chronicle with a refresher in one of the basic lessons of the modern newspaper age: computer security is a critical concern. He said the paper had taken steps to prevent tampering from occurring again.
 
Eclipse in Baltimore Of a Onetime Star
 Michael J. Davies, the kind of newspaper publisher people gossip about, spent much of the fall deflecting suggestions that he was on his way out as publisher of The Baltimore Sun, owned by the Times Mirror Company.
But this month, he is scheduled to leave Baltimore -- resigning, he and the company say, for personal reasons, which include that his wife, Cynthia McFadden, is an anchor for Court TV based in New York.
Morale problems at The Sun, declining circulation and other problems were suggested in Baltimore as the culprits that were doing Mr. Davies in.
Times Mirror and Mr. Davies deny that he was done in at all.
In its announcement of his departure, the company spoke of his "very significant contribution" to Times Mirror, both in Baltimore and earlier at The Hartford Courant, where he was publisher for seven years in the 1980's.
Once a star at Times Mirror, Mr. Davies said he had told the company that he wanted to leave last summer. To date, however, Times Mirror has not named a new publisher for The Sun. Mr. Davies, 48, said he is not yet certain what he is going to do.

HEADLINE: REPORT FAULTS U.S. IN HANDLING RIOTS

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
A new study says that despite a history of urban riots the United States has not learned how to improve inner cities and stop the cycle of upheaval.
The riots in Los Angeles last spring underscored the lack of Federal efforts to erase the racial and economic discrimination that led to riots as far back as 1919, said the report, released Saturday by the Milton S. Eisenhower Foundation to coincide with the 25th anniversary of a widely publicized report by the Kerner Commission. 
 In 1968, the commission concluded that the United States was "moving toward two societies, one black, one white -- separate and unequal."
In its report, the Eisenhower Foundation, a Washington organization that maintains anticrime programs in several cities, said: "We can reflect, again, on the same moving picture -- now the April 1992 riots in South-Central Los Angeles. Congress and the White House misunderstood the problem. They then constructed a solution that flew in the face of what really did work."
After the Los Angeles riots, Congress passed a $1.3 billion package of small-business loans and summer jobs. Another plan, vetoed by President George Bush, focused on urban enterprise zones and drug-enforcement efforts.
Instead, said Dr. Lynn A. Curtis, author of the Eisenhower report, the Government should focus on training for high-technology jobs, affordable housing and community development banks that can finance inner-city projects.
The foundation also urged the Government to make these changes:
*Focus on drug treatment and prevention, rather than interdiction.
*Reorganize the Job Training Partnership Act to focus more on unemployed inner-city youths.
*Turn responsibility for building low-income housing over to nonprofit organizations, rather than profit-seeking developers.
*Spend $15 billion more a year in programs for inner-city youths, and an extra $15 billion in inner-city infrastructure, for 10 years.
The Kerner panel, also known as the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders, was convened by President Lyndon B. Johnson to find what caused urban riots in the late 1960's.

HEADLINE: CRISIS AT THE TWIN TOWERS: The Puzzle;
A Lack of Definitive Claim For Attack Baffles Officials

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
What is still baffling the investigators trying to determine whether terrorists were behind the World Trade Center bombing is the effective silence that has followed it.
Since attention is a main goal of terrorism, the people responsible for such acts usually find a way to make it clear that they were the ones who carried them out. But in the aftermath of the bombing on Friday at the World Trade Center, none of the more than 50 callers who have claimed responsibility have presented convincing proof. 
 "What has appeared to be lacking is a definitive claim of responsibility in which a group demonstrates that they were the ones who committed the act," said a senior Federal official involved in the investigation.
 
Earmarks of Terrorism
 Yet at the same time, Federal officials and private experts said, the explosion bore many of the earmarks of a terrorist attack, including the size of the explosion and the choice of a symbolic target.
Although it came without warning and apparently did not involve the use of plastic explosives, they said, those facts certainly do not disqualify the bombing from being a terrorist attack.
"Fewer than half of the major terrorist bombings have been preceded by warnings," said Brian Jenkins, a security consultant who is a leading authority on terrorism. For instance, in the 1983 attacks on the United States Embassy and Marine barracks in Beirut, no warning was given. He added that while terrorists have used plastic explosives like C4 and Semtex in high-profile airplane bombings, they have more often used less sophisticated explosives in other attacks.
"Just because it's not Semtex, doesn't mean that it's not terrorist," Mr. Jenkins said today after Federal officials confirmed that they had found no evidence of plastic explosives in the rubble beneath the World Trade Center.
Apart from terrorism, the authorities are continuing to look into the possibility that an employee's grudge or some other factor might have been behind the attack on Friday, and experts said such a cause remained a strong possibility.
 
Evidence of Planning
 But they stressed that their reviews of past terrorist acts revealed more similarities with the World Trade Center bombing than differences. The choice of the target, the size of the blast and the success in attracting widespread attention, they said, all suggested that the attack had been carefully planned.
"If the motive was publicity, they've certainly gotten everyone's attention," said Bruce Hoffman, who heads a terrorism studies group at the Rand Corporation, based in Santa Monica, Calif.
As Mr. Hoffman acknowledged, the missing link in that theory is that whoever carried out the attack has not yet made clear what cause he was seeking to advertise.
As many as one-third of all terrorist incidents worldwide ultimately go unclaimed, experts believe. But in many of those cases, the choice of target or similarity to a continuing campaign makes the purpose of a terrorist act plain.
But some Government experts said today that it may be too soon to expect those responsible for the attack to come forward. "The idea that terrorists always run out and confess their deeds to the world is simply not true," said a Government official involved in the investigation.
The official noted that in the deadliest terrorist attack to take place on American soil -- the 1975 bombing that killed 11 people in a terminal at La Guardia Airport -- no one ever explicitly took responsibility. The authorities later concluded that Croatian nationalists had been responsible. The officials noted that the terrorists used dynamite, rather than plastic explosives.
The experts said the light weight, concealability and destructive force of plastic explosives had made them favored terrorist weapons.
 
Bombs in Small Places
 In notorious cases like the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am airliner over Scotland and the bombing two years earlier of a Trans World Airlines jet between Rome and Athens, the malleability of plastic explosives has allowed terrorists to conceal bombs in hiding places as small as a portable radio and under an airplane seat.
In their deadly 1983 attacks against American targets in Beirut, however, pro-Iranian terrorists used nothing more advanced than thousands of pounds of high explosives packed into ordinary trucks.
But experts say access more than tradecraft determines what kind of explosive will be used. In their 1989 car bombing of Colombia's secret police headquarters in Bogota, which killed 52 people, the traffickers relied upon 1,000 pounds of dynamite.
More than by the technology used, terrorism experts said today that the most important clue about the World Trade Center attack was the apparent skill with which it was carried out. "If you don't accept the fact that there was a good deal of sophistication involved," said Neil Livingstone, a security consultant, "whoever did it has to be one of the luckiest people in the world."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Renter-to-Owner Ratio Shifts, and With It the Political Climate

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
IF reports of its death are greatly exaggerated, liberalism may be ailing in New York City because of shifts in a sensitive sociological index: the ratio between condos and condoms.
A larger proportion of New Yorkers now own their homes or apartments than at any time in the 20th century. And owners, rendered less mobile physically and less liquid fiscally by their stakes in real estate, tend to be more politically conservative than renters. Liberal leadership also has been diluted by divisions between black and Hispanic politicians and between white liberals and blacks and by the ascendancy of white liberals in the political establishment. 
 As the share of property owners has grown, the city has been riven by conflicts over what are loosely described as traditional social values -- values that have been put to the test as government usurped New Yorker's personal prerogatives by making condoms available to public school students, teaching tolerance and acceptance of gay and lesbian life styles, and ordering that a gay and lesbian group be allowed to march behind its own banner in the St. Patrick's Day parade.
That those decisions have provoked a vocal backlash could mean several things: the group that once proclaimed itself the silent majority has found its voice again; the group is not a majority at all but has just become louder for the time being than other minorities; New York's reputation for liberalism, like the reports of its demise, has been greatly exaggerated, a possibility raised by the conflicts that culminated in last month's 4-to-3 vote by the Board of Education to dismiss Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, or it could mean all of the above.
The board's voting majority, blithely dismissed by some critics as a Gang of Four, "probably reflects where that population is," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo acknowledged the other day.
"I don't think New York City was ever as liberal as its reputation," Mr. Cuomo said. "I don't think that was ever true. Manhattan has always been very liberal. Queens is not. I will grant you that political power has been mostly Democratic, but I would not say that it has been overwhelmingly liberal."
Not since John V. Lindsay has a self-avowed liberal running with the imprimatur of the ideologically accommodating Liberal Party been elected Mayor. "I do not know what else Mr. Lindsay's victory established," said William F. Buckley Jr., the Conservative Party mayoral candidate whom Mr. Lindsay defeated in 1965, "than that people do scare easily and that New York is a very 'liberal' community."
The following year, though, New Yorkers disproved the second part of Mr. Buckley's thesis, rejecting a referendum on Mr. Lindsay's decision to place civilians on the board that reviews complaints against the police. And in 1969, Mr. Lindsay was re-elected only because a Republican from Staten Island and a conservative Democrat who lived on the Bronx border (one of his home telephone numbers was listed in Westchester, giving a new dimension to the dismissive phrase "outer borough") split the opposition. That conservative Democrat, Mario A. Procaccino, had bitingly dubbed Mr. Lindsay's supporters the "limousine liberals" who, from their economic isolation in Manhattan, preached dogma for others to practice.
Mr. Procaccino, who, in defending his record on racial tolerance, once boasted, "my heart is as black as any man's," was considered more conservative than Abraham D. Beame of Brooklyn, the Democrat whom Mr. Lindsay defeated in 1965 and who succeeded him in 1973. That they were actually closer ideologically on many social issues, if not in stature, had been suggested earlier by Mr. Buckley. The differences between the diminutive Mr. Beame and the statuesque Mr. Lindsay, he had said, "are biological, not political."
Four years later, New Yorkers elected Edward I. Koch, a self-described "liberal with sanity" -- a characterization that his critics questioned on both counts. In 1989, Mr. Koch lost to David N. Dinkins, who, like his once and future Republican rival, Rudolph W. Giuliani, strained to depict himself as Mr. Lindsay's spiritual heir. But Mr. Dinkins, a proud product of Harlem's Democratic machine, also embraced a typically conservative totem -- law and order -- in promising to be the city's toughest mayor on crime.
What is a liberal, anyway? To Irving Kristol's definition of a neoconservative as a liberal who was mugged by reality, Tom Wolfe countered that "a liberal is a conservative who has been arrested." In a 1992 New York Times/CBS-TV News poll last fall, most New York City adults described themselves as politically moderate. About the same proportion called themselves conservative as liberal. Last fall, New York Democrats, tired of losing, embraced a presidential candidate who failed or fudged the customary liberal litmus tests.
Party loyalty and philosophy have been subsumed again by concerns over government's ability to deliver services and to butt out of matters in which it may not belong. That is neither new nor unique.
If any major city rivals New York's reputation as a liberal bastion, it is San Francisco. In the last municipal election there, the liberal establishment and its incumbent Mayor were defeated by a former police chief who promised to get tough with problems ranging from panhandlers to potholes. His election was a vivid reminder that even in a progressive city, concerns about condos and condoms may mean that pragmatism in the defense of property and pristine puberty is no vice.

HEADLINE: LOWVILLE JOURNAL;
Snowmobiles: Comparing Liabilities and Assets

DATELINE: LOWVILLE, N.Y.

 BODY:
THE message painted on a plastic-covered bale of hay is simple: "No Snowmobilers! Keep Out!"
That is a succinct summary of one side of a winter-sports debate here in Lewis County, where many people are tired of the constant whine of snowmobiles in their backyards and on local roads. 
 "My husband and I can't enjoy our visits to our camp because dozens of snowmobiles cross our land every weekend," said Nancy Baker. The Bakers own 776 acres in the town of Osceola, where more than 200 inches of snow falls annually and hundreds of snowmobilers ride each weekend.
"We can go out and talk to them, but they just yell at us" or make obscene gestures, she said. "Then they still go through our land."
On the other side of the debate are those who run businesses that rely on the patronage of snowmobilers: grocery stores, bed and breakfasts, motels and bars.
"Our best business is in the winter," said Martin J. Beyer, owner of the Ridgeview Motor Lodge here.
Lewis County is on the Tug Hill Plateau, a fringe of the Adirondacks about 50 miles east of Lake Ontario, and the moist winds off the lake produce a huge amount of snow. By Friday afternoon, all the lodgings in Lewis County are filled. Trucks and trailers pull in carrying sleds with license plates from Ohio, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts and Vermont. "They hear there's great snow in Lewis County and just come," said Karen K. Delmonico, executive director of the county Chamber of Commerce.
Elected officials, caught in the middle, have another concern: insurance for snowmobilers. It used to be provided through an arrangement between snowmobiling associations and the Lewis County Board of Legislators. Then the county decided to provide coverage only for its own roads, telling towns and villages that insurance on local roads was up to them.
In January, the town of Lowville closed its roads to snowmobiles until it could determine whether its insurance policy would cover the operation of snowmobiles on its roads.
The insurance company said the town would be covered until April 6, when its insurance policy expires. The town is waiting for a decision from insurers on the costs of covering snowmobilers in a new policy.
Based on the news about the insurance and protests from businesses, the Lowville Town Board decided on Feb. 18 to reopen the roads until April 6. Just three days later, a snowmobile and a car collided.
The towns of Leyden and Lyonsdale closed all their roads. The Lyonsdale clerk, James M. Szewczyk, said the board "does not plan on opening the roads in the near future."
"I could care less if every bar, motel and restaurant went broke," said Ed Campany, a Lowville resident. "My concern is taxes. If it is going to cost more to have snowmobilers then we don't need them."
But Mr. Beyer, the lodge owner, said the opponents of snowmobiling should have to prove that it is costing the county extra money.
"You can say it, but you haven't proven it," he said.
This February a committee of local businessmen, county and regional government officials and local law enforcement personnel began a study of the economic impact of the snowmobiling industry here.
Earlier this winter, Mr. Beyer did his own study. He asked a group of out-of-state snowmobilers to "keep a tab of every dime they spent in Lewis County over a three-day stay." Using those numbers, he said he calculated that snowmobilers from out of town spent $1,261,250 on any given week.
Lynn Truesdell, president of the New York State Snowmobiling Coordinating Group, representing about 120 snowmobile clubs in the state, is a believer in what snowmobilers do for the economy. And he is not sure that local governments will get what they want by restricting the sport.
"You can close the roads from here to heck-won't-have-it, but accidents are going to happen," he said.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Economic Plan Finding Respect From Corporate America

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
When he was running for President, Bill Clinton had relatively little support from business outside the Silicon Valley and a few traditionally Democratic corners of Wall Street. But as President Clinton, he is being surprisingly well received in corporate board rooms across the country.
Since Mr. Clinton presented his economic blueprint to Congress and the nation 12 days ago, he has crisscrossed the country to meet with business leaders and seek their support. And so far, he seems to be getting it -- even though the program will inflict pain on many rich business executives and on their corporations. 
 "It behooves everybody, businessmen and average individuals alike, to really make this work," said Roberto C. Goizueta, chairman and chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company, echoing a theme voiced by many executives in interviews the last few days. "If he succeeds, we all succeed. If he fails, we all fail."
Attitudes may change as more details of the program come out, or as executives have a better chance to weigh its consequences. For now, though, many executives say that any dissatisfaction they have over parts of the program is outweighed by the leadership Mr. Clinton has shown in addressing problems like the Federal budget deficit and health care.
"There are some things in the program that bite our company hard, and this is going to hurt today," said Vernon R. Loucks Jr., chairman and chief executive of Baxter International Inc., a health-care company. "But there isn't going to be a future if we don't get these things solved.
"I didn't vote for Clinton. But there is real deficit reduction in this program, and if we are disciplined enough, we could be pleasantly surprised three or four years from now."
Business leaders said their respect for Mr. Clinton began to rise at the economic summit meeting he held in Little Rock, Ark., in December. At that two-day meeting, some executives said, Mr. Clinton, then the President-elect, exhibited a broad understanding of many of the nation's economic problems.
"I have been impressed by this man," said Harold R. (Red) Poling, chairman and chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, who has met with Mr. Clinton three times since the election, including at the Little Rock meeting. "In my meetings with him, he exhibited a broad knowledge of a wide range of issues. He listens very carefully and is very much a people-oriented person. He pays attention to what you are saying, and he takes the time to do it. That not only impresses me, it literally amazes me."
Mr. Clinton's theme of shared sacrifice, which he struck in his speech to a joint session of Congress on Feb. 17, has also altered many executives' attitudes.
"The talk about shared sacrifice and fairness had an awful lot of appeal to the population and to the business population," said Paul H. O'Neill, chairman and chief executive of Alcoa.
 
Impact of Perot
 Ian Arnof, president and chief executive of the First Commerce Corporation, Louisiana's largest bank holding company, struck a similar theme: "My sense is they are trying to put as much on the table as they can and to spread the cost as much as they can. His speech made a lot of sense."
Mr. Arnof said that business executives in his part of the country had paid more attention to Ross Perot's reaction to the Clinton proposals than they had to that of Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve.
"It appears that Perot has not been unhappy with what Clinton has been doing," Mr. Arnof said. "That has given him some more credibility."
Because the White House and both houses of Congress are controlled by Democrats for the first time since Jimmy Carter was President, at this juncture business would seem to have little tactical choice but to try to work with Mr. Clinton rather than confront him.
 
Concern Over Health Costs
 A key test for many executives will be whether the President's health-care package alleviates what has become a millstone for many companies and to what extent it would be financed by a large tax increase.
"I know how much Intel pays per employee for our health plan every year," said Craig R. Barrett, chief operating officer of the Intel Corporation, the semiconductor giant. "And by simple math, it tells me it will cost $60 billion to $100 billion to provide universal health care. That is a big enough number to make me worry, and it smells like a big tax increase."
But for now, such concerns seem to be outweighed by the Clinton persona and the President's active approach to managing the economy, which is seen by some as providing aid long overdue to the private sector.
"There is a realization among business people that they want someone who is engaged in the activities of the economy," said Gail Fosler, chief economist at the Conference Board. "We reached the limits of laissez-faire economics after the first term of the Reagan Administration. The ideology of allowing business to compete totally without Government support is so in contrast with what businesses are encountering in the global marketplace that it creates a demand for a President who is engaged in making the U.S. economy the world's most competitive."
Mr. Barrett of Intel said "the true measure will come when we see how responsive Government is to being a fast-moving, just-in-time Government to the threats we in industry face. If Government can't move the regulatory environment and the bureaucracy with the speed the business world needs, the incentives this plan is offering us won't mean much."
 
Some Lingering Doubts
 Indeed, even as business, like much of the nation, seems ready to give Mr. Clinton the benefit of the doubt and its support, doubts about the man and his program linger. And skepticism about Congress remains deep-seated.
News accounts of the details of how the economic program took shape, for example, are a nagging source of worry for some executives. From those reports, some said, they saw a President who had too quickly allowed political arguments to dampen the degree of sacrifice that is necessary.
"I have one lingering uneasiness that the President's sense about what to do will be tempered by those who know too much about political suicide," said Mr. O'Neill of Alcoa. "I told him at the economic conference in Little Rock he ought to act like he was going to be a one-term President, and that by doing that, he would insure himself a second term."
Mr. O'Neill said he was bothered by Mr. Clinton's retreat from supporting a freeze on cost-of-living adjustment increases on Social Security checks.
Similarly, Mr. Barrett at Intel said he was annoyed that billions in financing for the supercollider and space station projects were left intact, apparently for political reasons.
 
Hope for Further Cutbacks
 Calls for more spending cuts were a frequent refrain.
"There would be more support for a more aggressive attack on spending," said William D. Ruckelshaus, chairman and chief executive of Browning-Ferris Industries and a former official in the Nixon and Ford Administrations.
Jerry J. Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, credits Mr. Clinton with courage in proposing "a real budget deficit effort" and in changing the terms of the debate on that issue. But he predicted that the relatively minor annoyances business executives are now finding in the President's program will be eclipsed by much more profound ones when companies finally look at the fine print of the Clinton program. Its provisions are particularly onerous for small businesses, he said.
"The business tax burden is a lot larger than either business or the White House appreciates," Mr. Jasinowski said. "Business taxes are three times greater than the incentives the program is offering. And the biggest tax increase of all is on subchapter S corporations, who file individual tax returns."
According to Mr. Jasinowski, a third of the nation's 300,000 manufacturing concerns fall into this category. Under the Clinton program, their Federal income taxes would rise to just under 40 percent, well above the 36 percent level the President is asking larger companies to pay.
"The program needs to be restructured," Mr. Jasinowski said, "and Congress may substantially improve it."
That thought also occurred to Mr. Ruckelshaus.
"We could be looking at the reverse of what happened in the early 1980's with Ronald Reagan," he said, recalling that Congress tacked on far more tax cuts than Mr. Reagan had originally asked for.
"Once it is O.K. politically to talk about cutting, and the President has led the way," Mr. Ruckelshaus said, "it may be that Congress may be receptive to it and go ahead and take on these programs."
