HEADLINE: MUCH BOSNIAN AID MISSED ITS TARGET

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 1

 BODY:
Two-thirds of the relief supplies dropped overnight Sunday into a besieged area of Bosnia and Herzegovina may have failed to reach hungry civilians, and some may have fallen into the hands of Serbian fighters, United States officials said today.
Using satellite photographs, the officials said they had determined that one-third of the bundles, parachuted from high altitudes, had reached their intended destination in a mountainous and partly wooded area within walking distance of Cerska, in eastern Bosnia. 
 But around Cerska, doubts were raised that even one-third of the supplies had reached the intended target. Surveys of radio operators in eastern Bosnia, for example, failed to turn up a single one who knew of a pallet's being recovered from the first United States airdrop.
[Three Air Force cargo planes dropped tons of food and medical supplies over eastern Bosnia again early Tuesday, The Associated Press quoted the military as saying. "The airdrop missions were completed without incident," said a statement from Rhein-Main Air Base, the American installation outside Frankfurt.
[The statement said the target of the second airdrop was the town of Zepa, which had been designated a high priority location by the United Nations. The planes dropped 18.6 tons of food, amounting to 21,312 meals, and a half ton of medical supplies, the Air Force said.]
 
Some Land Near Serbian Forces
 In Sarajevo, the Bosnian capital, a Vice President, Zlatko Lagumdzija, said this evening that the supplies from the first airdrop were in the hands of Serbian units besieging Cerska. The Serbian commander in Bosnia, Gen. Ratko Mladic, confirmed that at least some supplies had landed in areas controlled by his troops.
Pentagon officials in Washington said it was not clear where the bundles that were not seen in satellite photographs had landed. They said it was possible some had landed in or near the drop area but had not been seen.
"The airdrop was successful," Defense Secretary Les Aspin and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said in a joint statement. "We can confirm that many of the bundles landed in clear areas within the identified drop zone," they added, and "the other bundles landed in or near the drop zone, but we are unable to confirm exact landing points."
From the beginning, the Administration has acknowledged that the purpose of the airdrop was more political than humanitarian, and that the intention was to bring the warring factions to the negotiating table.
Pentagon officials also chose to drop supplies from 10,000 feet, knowing that much of the food and medicine might not reach its destination. Today, however, United States officials seemed troubled by reports that only a small portion of the aid might have been delivered to those in need.
The planes were buffeted by strong winds over the drop site, which one Pentagon official said was only about 1,000 feet by 2,000 feet.
 
No Ethnic Criteria
 The operation is intended mainly for the estimated 200,000 Muslims under siege by Serbian nationalist forces, but United States officials, anxious to avoid the appearance of partiality, say they want to supply civilians of all ethnic backgrounds.
The airdrops are expected to continue on an almost nightly basis, with three to five planes each.
A military spokesman, acknowledging the problems, said: "Some may have fallen on the Serb side, and some may have gone to previously Muslim areas that were just captured by the Serbs. Some may have gone into the mountains or places people can't get to.
"What would be ideal is if we could get a call from someone in Bosnia who would tell us, 'I'm eating one of your meals and it tastes good.' So far we haven't heard anything like that."
 
The Target, the Cargo
 Although United States and United Nations officials at first refused to say where the supplies for the first airdrop had been dropped, several said later that the three planes were aiming at Cerska.
Reports from Cerska said no aid was received there. A radio operator there speculated that flight crews might have been misled by fires in a Serbian-controlled zone.
"Houses were burning in some of the recently captured territory," said the operator, known as Edin. "Maybe they thought it was a signal to drop there."
Military spokesmen in Frankfurt said the planes dropped a total of three 760-pound crates of medicine, mostly first-aid items like gauze and bandages, and 27 crates of food.
Even before the mission, current and former Pentagon officials cautioned that the standard procedure for an airdrop is to do it at low altitude, in daylight, with spotters on the ground; the Bosnian airdrop failed on all three counts.
But General Powell insisted that the airdrops be carried out at high altitude to minimize the risk to the crews from antiaircraft weapons.
 
Praise From Europeans
 Despite the uncertainties, many European politicians and commentators praised the airdrop. But in some capitals, including London and Paris, praise was mixed with suggestions that the operation was aimed as much at publicity as at assistance to hard-pressed civilians.
"The British and other Europeans are wrong to be quite so sniffy about the exercise," said The Independent, a leading British daily, in an editorial. "The effort will have value if some people are fed who would otherwise have starved."
Several newspapers said Washington was taking the lead because Europe had failed to do so.
"Although one can argue about the long-term value of this relief operation, it is clear that the phase of helplessly lamenting the death and starvation of human beings is over," said one of Germany's largest newspapers, Die Welt, in a front-page commentary. "The American action came not a day too soon. It puts western Europe to shame."
Germany praised the operation, and according to senior German officials Bonn may decide as early as Wednesday to offer direct support.
The French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, defended European governments against charges of inaction.
"It's a good thing the Americans have joined the Europeans in an affair that interests the whole world," Mr. Dumas said in a radio interview. "Bravo! The Americans have come to lend a hand. But let's not forget what the Europeans are doing." Many of the United Nations peacekeeping troops, who face considerable personal risk, are from NATO countries.
Few analysts expect the airdrops to alter the balance of power in the Balkans, or even to feed large numbers of people. They say that even if the airdrops are successful, they will not help Bosnia's besieged Muslims.
"The delivery of large amounts of food does not change the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina," said the Prague newspaper Mlada Fronta. "Politicians are still not able to answer the most important question, which is whether the Muslims will be able to survive anywhere.
"It requires only a normal amount of cynicism to realize that within a certain time, we will see thousands more Bosnians forced from their homes as a result of ethnic cleansing. But now they will have full stomachs and American chewing gum in their pockets."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Serbian Leadership Silent
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 1 (Special to The New York Times) -- The United States airdrop of relief supplies in eastern Bosnia signaled a new phase of international involvement in the Balkan war. But the Serbian leadership, which has been blamed for the worst of the violence, let the step pass without comment.
The Government-controlled television reported on the mission and quoted European newspapers warning of the possible dangers, but there was no official comment from the President of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic.
"I think people generally understand the move as a sign of growing American military involvement," said Predrag Simic, director of the Institute of International Politics and Economics, which is close to the Yugoslav federal Government.
"I doubt whether the aid will have much practical effect," he said. "But it could have the effect of dragging the Americans into further fighting. All three sides have reason to try to shoot down a plane because whoever actually did it, the Serbs would be blamed."
Svetozar Stojanovic, a foreign policy adviser to Dobrica Cosic, the President of Yugoslavia, said Mr. Cosic had asked Army commanders not to fire at the C-130 cargo planes.

HEADLINE: Senior American at U.N. Leaves, Trading Accusations With Chief

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 1

 BODY:
The senior American on the staff of the United Nations stepped down from his post today, though not without a final barbed exchange with the man who dismissed him.
Dick Thornburgh, a former United States Attorney General whose post is to be filled by a Clinton Administration nominee, surrendered the position of Under Secretary General for Administration and Management, releasing a report listing what he sees as the United Nations' administrative weaknesses and blaming some on Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali. 
 In his report, Mr. Thornburgh accused the Secretary General of weakening staff morale by downgrading officials in his department and undermining efforts to improve efficiency by not allowing him to dismiss unneeded employees.
"Managers simply must be allowed to terminate those not measuring up to 'the highest standards of competence and integrity' contemplated by the Charter," he wrote.
 
Consulting Contracts Faulted
 Mr. Thornburgh also criticized the Secretary General for awarding "costly consulting contracts to high-level officials following their retirement or termination of services."
And he attacked his decision to split up the organization's economic and social work among three new Under Secretaries General, telling Mr. Boutros-Ghali the decision "compromised your laudable goal of reducing the number of high-level appointments."
He also called for the appointment of an inspector general to investigate "fraud, waste and abuse" by United Nations staff, dismissing the Joint Inspection Unit, which is supposed to perform this function, as ineffectual.
But the Secretary General replied pointedly through his spokesman that while he appreciated the report, he also wished Mr. Thornburgh had done more to correct these deficiencies while he was in a position to do so instead of complaining about them now.
 
Criticism Is Returned
 "This is the first written report of this type he has received from Mr. Thornburgh during his tenure," the Secretary General's spokesman, Joe Sills, said today. "It is thus the first time the Secretary General has seen a number of these proposals or comments that Mr. Thornburgh has made. Of course he welcomes and appreciates them. But he does also feel that perhaps some of them could have been dealt with during the past year, during Mr. Thornburgh's tenure."
Shortly after taking office, Mr. Boutros-Ghali said he wanted the very top posts in the organization to be "political," meaning that those who filled them would be appointed by him and would serve at his pleasure.
But by failing to renew Mr. Thornburgh's one-year contract and agreeing to give his post to a Clinton Administration nominee, the Secretary General has now implicitly accepted that the incumbent Administration in Washington has the right to fill one of these top slots.
The Secretary General had wanted the incoming Administration to swap posts, suggesting that instead of the United Nations' chief administrator, it name the Under Secretary General in charge of information, who would be Mr. Boutros-Ghali's personal spokesman. But President Clinton felt it would be easier for him to keep his pledge to pay America's United Nations dues if he can tell Congressional skeptics that an American is overseeing administration and management.

HEADLINE: CRISIS AT THE TWIN TOWERS: The Overview;
INQUIRY IS PRESSED ON CAUSE OF BLAST AT TRADE CENTER

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
Federal and local authorities combed parking receipts, reviewed videotapes from an underground parking garage and examined intelligence files yesterday for clues to the explosion that killed at least five people at the World Trade Center on Friday.
Although investigators were still unable to answer the two central questions -- what kind of bomb caused the blast and who set it off -- Federal officials said they were beginning to focus more heavily on the possibility of the explosion being the work of foreign terrorists. 
 Law-enforcement and intelligence officials said they had information suggesting a possible Serbian connection to the bombing, although there was no indication that any Serbian suspects have emerged. "Someone with Yugoslavian connections has come up," said one law-enforcement official.
Investigators also were reviewing about 30 thefts of explosive material of at least 300 pounds each around the country in the last four years.
 
Many Workers Return
 The investigation continued as New York City worked to return to the normal routine shattered by the blast on Friday, and the Federal Government said it would help ease the economic pain with Small Business Administration loans. Although the twin towers at the Trade Center will probably remain closed for at least a week, about a third of the 50,000 workers at the entire complex were back on their jobs.
Transportation was nearly normal, with commuter traffic lighter than usual, and restaurant, theater and hotel business apparently unaffected. But a certain nervousness remained: 95 bomb threats around New York City were reported yesterday by 6 P.M., more than nine times the normal total.
In downtown Brooklyn, four bomb threats caused evacuation of thousands of workers, creating huge traffic tie-ups for most of the morning. Mayor David N. Dinkins and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly met with security personnel of major corporations, calling for calm but urging them to re-examine their security plans.
The Small Business Administration approved emergency help to hundreds of small businesses that have been affected by the blast, many of which may qualify for low-interest loans of up to $500,000 to cover expenses. Other interest-free loans were being made available through the state's Urban Development Corporation. Other agencies were directed to expedite claims of those victimized by the blast and others thrown out of work.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo vowed to be the first tenant to return to the complex and hailed the city's spirit as a triumph over adversity. President Clinton, in New Jersey, took the occasion to rally New Yorkers and "discourage the American people from overreacting to this." He said he was urging New Yorkers "to keep your courage up and go about your lives."
The authorities said a second World Trade Center employee has now not been accounted for. They identified him as King McGee Jr., 55, who works for California Bank. Mr. McGee's neighbors described him as a kindly, generous man and said his son had been to their building on West 145h Street yesterday, asking if anyone had seen him.
Despite the continuing reluctance of police and Federal officials to discuss the investigation, several new developments emerged yesterday.
 
An Unusual Twist
 In one unusual twist, after days of accounts that there was no security camera operating in the garage, James M. Fox, the assistant F.B.I. director in charge of the New York office, said there was a videotape camera mounted at one or more of the garage's three entrances.
He said it "just came into our possession" and appeared to offer tapes of cars entering and exiting the garage, which has public and commercial entrances on West and Liberty Streets. "It's being reviewed and copied," he said. "We'll know soon."
He did not explain why the existence of a tape that could prove vital only emerged yesterday. Given the selectivity with which details of the case have been parceled out or withheld, it was possible that the existence of a tape had been kept secret for some investigative purpose.
Among the things a videotape could show, he said, was a vehicle whose springs might be sagging under an immense weight that could have been the bomb. Both Mr. Fox and Mr. Kelly have said they do not know what kind of vehicle, if any, carried the bomb or what the bomb consisted of. An estimated 500 to 1,500 pounds of dynamite were used, investigators have said.
Investigators believe dynamite was the likely explosive because of the discovery of nitrates, but some close to the case have heard it described as a possible mixture of fuel oil and fertilizer. No evidence has been found to confirm use of a more compact and moldable plastic explosive called Composition 4 or Semtex, favored by international terrorists.
 
A Note of Caution
 But other investigators in the teams of F.B.I., police and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms yesterday cautioned against ruling out any explosive until further tests of the site. "Finding nitrates at a place where an explosion took place is like finding soot at a fire scene," one said, adding that plastic explosives also produce nitrates.
Impeding the investigation, Commissioner Kelly said, was the "secondary collapse" of a garage wall, requiring a further delay of two to three days before the site could be shored up for entry by experts. Some evidence was collected by a robot yesterday, an investigator said.
But other tips have multiplied, Mr. Fox said. "We have some information from individuals outside reporting the activity of vehicles that we found quite interesting," he said. He declined to be more specific.
He said that of about 50 callers who gave tips, a dozen came from people present at or around the garage Friday. "I'd say three or four of those were very interesting and leads that we're pursuing right now," he said.
Other leads, Mr. Kelly said, came from the practice of taking license-plate numbers of drivers who parked their cars on the public level of the garage, known as B-2, where the blast likely originated.
While some law-enforcement officials have said that the use of dynamite in the bomb -- as opposed to harder-to-get plastic explosives -- was a sign of unsophistication, several current and former Government officials today took issue with that assessement.
 
'Does Not Excuse Terrorists'
 L. Paul Bremer, who headed the State Department's counterterrorism operations in the 1980's, noted instead that many terrorist groups have frequently used dynamite in car bombs. "The fact that it's dynamite does not excuse terrorists," Mr. Bremer said.
Mr. Bremer and other experts said the lack of a credible claim of responsibility before the blast remained the biggest mystery in the case. "For a terrorist, there's not much use in doing this unless you make it known that you did it," Mr. Bremer said.
But Mr. Fox added that it was possible that the bomb misfired, exploding before the group had a chance to make a phone call claiming responsibility. Asked if the bomb might have been planted overnight, he said: "We already have some pretty good raw information and intelligence that we're analyzing and working on right now that would lead us to the conclusion that you're suggesting." But he said: "At this time I have no idea whether it was brought in an hour before or a week before."
Others who spoke to investigators on the case said yesterday that they appeared to be on to something, although no one would say what it was. Mr. Fox acknowledged yesterday that his mood picked up markedly between Friday and Saturday night.
The focus on Serbians, who might be angry over United States policies in the former Yugoslavia, reflects the investigators' strong suspicion that the bomb may have been the work of political terrorists even if they have yet to find clear-cut evidence pointing to any particular group.
 
Organized Into Teams
 Investigators have ruled out few possibilities, though they seemed to be discarding the possibility that a disgruntled or deranged person detonated the bomb. One group of investigators has organized themselves into teams, each assigned to examine whether the bomb could have been set by a different terrorist organization, most likely Middle Eastern and European extremist groups.
Agents in several states have questioned registered owners of vehicles parked at the Trade Center lot. Those interviews, along with the questioning of building employees and telephone calls made to a tip line are helping to create a composite profile of activity in the parking area before the blast.
In Albany, Mr. Cuomo, who has an office on the 57th floor of 2 World Trade Center, said: "I think this has been good for New York. I think the demonstration of strength, the demonstration of cohesion, the demonstration of intelligence by New Yorkers and their public employees showed the way the city should work."
"I will lead my people back into that office" in the Trade Center, the Governor said, adding that he hoped it would not take more than a week.

HEADLINE: The Price of Worker Health Care

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Managed health-care programs, including some that use the ideas under study by Hillary Rodham Clinton's White House commission on health policy, helped to moderate medical inflation last year, according to a national survey of employers released yesterday. But health expenditures per employee still rose by 10.1 percent, or more than three times as fast as overall living costs.
Several employee-benefits executives said in interviews that national legislation was still needed to shield corporate profits from high health-care costs for employees. 
 The cost of health benefits, on average, is 50 percent of corporate net earnings, according to the survey by the Foster Higgins benefits consulting firm. The survey included responses from 2,448 large and medium-size employers. Questionnaires were sent to the 500 largest American companies and also distributed to members of employer health-care coalitions across the country.
Health-benefit costs in 1992 averaged $3,968 an employee, an increase of 10.1 percent from a year earlier, the Higgins survey said. Costs rose 14.2 percent for traditional fee-for-service health plans, 8.8 percent for health maintenance organizations and 10.5 percent for other "preferred provider" plans that offer incentives for patients to use designated doctors and hospitals.
Costs were highest in the Middle Atlantic States and New England and lowest in the Rocky Mountain States and the Southeast.
The New York metropolitan area had the highest costs, averaging $4,852 an employee for traditional coverage, followed by Philadelphia, $4,696; San Francisco, $4,531; Los Angeles, $4,350, and Chicago, $4,245.
About half of the employees surveyed were in some type of managed-care plan, including 26 percent in H.M.O.'s. Thirty percent of the companies no longer offer traditional fee-for-service coverage, compared with 24 percent in 1991.
Mrs. Clinton's commission is reportedly considering proposals for a version of managed competition in a national health-care plan. President Clinton has endorsed the concept in general terms.
Although the Administration has not yet defined it, advocates of managed competition say health-care users should be combined in large purchasing groups. The advocates say the groups could force H.M.O.'s and other hospital and doctor organizations to compete by cutting prices and improving services. Other proposals include reducing tax breaks for health coverage for employers and employees, and placing limits on health spending, nationally or by states.
"Managed care is part of the solution, but it is not the whole solution," said John Erb, a principal in New York with Foster Higgins. He noted that enrollment in health maintenance organizations was still relatively small, even though public policy makers have been promoting these prepaid health plans for 20 years.
 
'Still Too Much'
 Sharon Canner, a health-care policy specialist at the National Association of Manufacturers, said that "unless there is some force to make managed competition happen, the change for the better is just going to take much too long, while corporate profits erode."
"Three times inflation is still too much," she added.
Dr. Mary Jane England, president of the Washington Business Group on Health, an association of large employers, said, "It is clear from the survey that managed care makes a difference." But she added that costs were often shifted from one type of health plan to another, because people who have serious illnesses often insisted on keeping physicians outside a company's health maintenance organization or other managed-care plan.
She said that there should be "managed competition in the entire health-care system," but that it should include a provision that would let employees go outside the system if they were willing to pay more for the privilege.
About 5 percent of the employees in the survey were enrolled in such flexible programs, which are called "point of service" plans. They included 36,000 telephone workers at the Bell Atlantic Corporation, the regional telephone company.
Tenneco Inc., the Houston-based diversified energy and manufacturing company, recently started a similar program for 25,000 salaried employees, whose medical costs had been increasing by 16 percent annually, said Kim Bacon, Tenneco's benefits director.
At Bell Atlantic, Gary Simko, strategic planning manager for employee benefits, said medical costs rose about 10 percent in the point-of-service plan last year, by preliminary estimates. The increase was about half what the company had expected.
 
Questioning the Findings
 But Rhoda Karpatkin, president of Consumers Union, an advocacy group that favors a government-regulated health-care system like Canada's, said the managed-care record had still not justified a national move to managed competition.
A single year of slower growth in health costs "isn't a sufficient basis for policy making," she said.
"Nineteen ninety-two was a highly unusual year," Ms. Karpatkin continued. "There was a tremendous amount of self-consciousness about charges on the part of hospitals and doctors. It is possible they moderated their increases because of adverse publicity."

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Corporate Medical Costs Keep Rising" tracks average costs per employee for all types of health plans since 1984. Also tracked are the annual percent increases in average employee costs compared with changes in the consumer price index. The latter graph begins in 1989 and runs through 1992. (Sources: Bureau of Labor Statistics; Foster Higgins Health Care Survey 1992/Indemnity Plans)

HEADLINE: Insurers Help Bear Blast Costs

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Insurance companies will pick up at least some of the costs to businesses in the World Trade Center affected by last week's blast, though many companies will find that it will take months before the damages are assessed and they can collect.
Although it is far too early to assess the total cost of the disaster to insurers, some insurance experts predicted that their losses could easily exceed the $300 million in business and property damage caused by a large flood last year in downtown Chicago. But losses are not expected to approach the $17 billion figure associated with Hurricane Hugo. 
 "Right now, people can only grasp at numbers," said Hugh Strawn, director of catastrophic services for the Property Loss Research Bureau, a trade association in Schaumburg, Ill.
 
 
Small Business Loans
 Small, uninsured businesses in the New York City area affected by the blast received good news yesterday when the Small Business Administration approved a request by Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York for economic injury disaster loans. Hundreds of businesses -- from small newsstands to elegant restaurants -- are expected to qualify. The agency will review claims based on a formula that will compare businesses' losses to their size.
For tenants at the World Trade Center, losses may involve damage to offices or computer equipment, which are typically covered by property coverage. But far greater losses will be caused by interruptions to a company's business and costs related to temporary relocations.
Steven Goldstein, a spokesman for the Insurance Information Institute, a trade group in New York City, said many companies were insured against losses caused by interruptions to their businesses. In some cases, they may also be covered for costs related to temporary relocations, like computer rentals.
Mr. Strawn said that business interruption insurance typically covered a percentage of lost profits -- which can vary depending on the insurance policy -- caused by dislocations. Companies with well-developed contingency plans usually receive discounts on the premiums.
 
Claims Will Take Time
 Insurance experts said most large commercial policies would cover losses caused by a bomb, even if it was planted by terrorists.
But it may take some time before claims are paid. Jack Daly, a spokesman for the ITT Hartford Insurance Group in Hartford, said adjusters could still not get into policyholders' offices to inspect for damage. Once that happens, it will probably take two to three weeks to pay off on smoke damage claims.
Payments on business interruption claims could take considerably longer, because it is up to the policyholder to support claims of lost revenues with documentation, Mr. Daly said.
"They have to produce their books and records," he said. "It is a lot of hard work for the policyholder."
Under the plan announced yesterday by the Small Business Adminstration, small businesses in the New York City area that have been economically damaged by the blast or its aftermath may qualify for low-interest loans of up to $500,000 to cover business expense, said Jill Finnie, an S.B.A. spokeswoman. Businesses need not be situated in the World Trade Center complex to qualify for the government loans. The loans are intended to cover operating expenses that are not currently being met because of losses stemming from the disaster, Ms. Finnie said.
The loans carry an interest rate of 4 percent, and can be paid under terms that can be extended up to 30 years. There is no cap on the number of loans available, but they are available only to the uninsured or those who cannot get conventional loans, Ms. Finnie said.
 
 
Port Authority's Position
 Businesses whose claims exceed their coverage levels, or who do not receive disaster assistance, may look to the Port Authority to help cover losses. Barry Weintraub, chief financial official for the authority, said it had not yet received claims from tenants, but did not rule them out.
"If companies move against the Port Authority, it will be adjudicated in some way," he said. "We will discuss it, and if we are deemed to be liable we will cover it."
Mr. Weintraub said that the Port Authority had about $600 million in coverage to pay for property damage and interruptions to its own business. He said the complex was insured by a consortium of domestic companies.
He said there was no estimate as yet of damage to the structure, but added that the Port Authority's business-interruption losses were likely to exceed $5 million for each week the complex is closed.
It is also possible that insurers may eventually turn to the Port Authority to reimburse them for claims they have paid to their policyholders. Such lawsuits typically require a showing of neglience to succeed, Mr. Strawn said.
The Port Authority has acknowledged that it did not take all of the security measures against terrorism recommended by consultants in 1985.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The World Trade Center Crisis
Insurance will cover at least some of the cost of lost business from the blast at the World Trade Center. Some predicted that losses could easily exceed the $300 million caused by a large flood last year in downtown Chicago. [D1.]
The Port Authority's bond ratings should not be affected by the explosion and loss of revenue at the trade center, which has $1 billion in insurance to cover losses. [B5.] 
 New York's five commodity exchanges reopened, as the mechanism that sets prices for many products resumed. [D20.]
Employees of companies in the trade center returned to work in fits and starts, scrambling for space and extra equipment. [B4.]
 
The Economy
Anxiety is growing about the staying power of the economic expansion. But most economists and business executives are counting on solid growth of about 3 percent or so this year. [D1.]
New economic reports on manufacturing, consumers and construction suggest that the economy's growth is slowing. [D2.]
Company health expenditures per employee rose 10.1 percent last year despite help from managed health care. [D1.]
Tax revenue from tobacco and alcohol has fallen by millions of dollars nationwide, with New Jersey leading the trend. [A1.]
 
Companies
Macy will close 11 Macy's, Bullock's and I. Magnin stores, continuing to shrink under bankruptcy protection. [D1.]

International

Markets

HEADLINE: Optimism Is Being Tempered a Bit

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
A burst of post-election optimism about the economy, reflected in rising stock prices and a sharp upward turn in consumer confidence, has lately given way to a string of so-so economic reports, a spurt of fresh anxiety and new questions about the staying power of the economic expansion.
Even the Commerce Department's announcement last week that the economy had grown a sensational 4.8 percent in the fourth quarter of 1992 -- a full percentage point above its previous estimate -- did little to assuage doubts, since almost no one believes that that pace will hold.
 
No Forecasts of Recession
 Despite worrisome signs of weakness, few experts see recession on the horizon. In fact, most economists and business executives are counting on solid growth of about 3 percent or so this year, far slower than in the fall but a full percentage point higher than in 1992. 
 That viewpoint was supported by a fresh crop of economic reports yesterday -- on manufacturing, consumers and construction -- indicating that growth has fallen off the rapid pace of late last year. [Page D2.]
The latest figures follow another round of layoffs by large companies and visions of higher taxes, both of which have undercut consumer confidence. Bearish investors have been snapping up bonds instead of stocks, as market analysts lower their forecasts for corporate earnings. And President Clinton's critics on the left and right cite economic fragility in trying to alter his proposals.
There is no question that the outlook holds significant risks. Businesses' reluctance to hire is holding down incomes. Painful corporate overhauls will continue for years. Exports, which have been growing briskly, appear likely to weaken as recessions drag on in Japan and Europe. Construction is hobbled by empty office buildings and half-rented shopping malls. And the shrinking military budget is taking a toll from California to Connecticut.
But the $6 trillion American economy is a lot like a supertanker -- once it starts sailing, it takes more than a few misfires to shut the engines.
"Most of the indicators people look at suggest that the economy is showing signs of sustainable recovery," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
Much of the extreme queasiness in the financial markets is probably a simple case of nerves. Investors, after all, are known for alternating bouts of nail biting and euphoria.
This time fears of a slowdown could help avert a slump, by keeping a lid on inflation expectations, and, thus, on interest rates. "The bond market's reaction to the President's proposals has been much more supportive of the economy than we expected," said Roger Brinner, chief economist at DRI/McGraw Hill. "It's great news for housing, investment and international competitiveness because it has halted the appreciation of the dollar."
Long-term interest rates and inflation are now the lowest they have been in two decades. Productivity has spurted. Crucial sources of middle-class discomfort -- falling house prices, shrinking net worth and heavy debts -- have receded as problems. And the rebounds in consumer spending, housing and business investment appear to be continuing.
As for the concerns about the depressing effects of the higher taxes and spending cuts the President is calling for, the pain is not scheduled to start for more than a year. In fact, the program is intended to be slightly stimulative at first, swelling the deficit somewhat this year.
"We want insurance against the recovery's stalling out," Ms. Tyson said, referring to the plan to spend quickly an extra $31 billion.
Also, some economists point out, the mix of tax increases and new spending might not hurt overall consumer spending.
"People ignore the fact that higher taxes on the affluent are more likely to come out of saving than consumption," said Paul McCulley, chief economist at the Union Bank of Switzerland. "And more Government outlays tend to put money in the hands of people who spend all of their incomes and more."
The bigger worry, a number of executives say, is the Administration's evident enthusiasm for ambitious social legislation, from raising the minimum wage to mandating business training programs.
"There is a whole package of things lurking in the background that are making people -- especially medium-sized companies -- concerned about the cost of permanent employment," said Mitchell S. Fromstein, president of Manpower Inc.
What follows is a look, sector by sector, at the latest data on the economy's momentum:
HOUSING (STRONG): Mortgage rates are almost one percentage point lower than before the election, and buyer traffic suggests that home buying, which dipped during an unusually cold January, will resume with vigor. Housing was already reviving strongly last fall and so was single-family-home construction, which continued to grow in January. Existing-home sales, which slid during January's cold, were nonetheless 15 percent higher than a year earlier.
CONSUMERS (SLOWING DOWN): Consumers have been spending faster than pay has been rising, and their faith in the economic expansion remains wobbly. Sentiment surveys have shown a dip in confidence in recent days. So while consumers are expected to remain moderate in their buying -- as the January data suggested -- merchants and retail consultants say they see no real retreat.
In autos, the sales pace is significantly faster than last year's. Johnson Redbook's weekly surveys of store sales found February's figures to be higher than January's. Wage income is growing modestly and saving is up. "We'll settle into sustained but very moderate growth in consumer spending," said Randall Gebhardt, a consultant at Fitch Inc., a marketing company in Columbus, Ohio.
BUSINESS INVESTMENT (STRONG): Business's drive to improve efficiency -- as well as the availability of high-technology products at irresistibly low prices -- has produced an unparalleled surge in equipment spending. Spending has climbed nearly 17 percent in the last year after adjusting for inflation. Orders for capital equipment are near a record high and, thanks to resurgent profits, the pool of money to pay for all this has never been bigger.
INVENTORIES (RESTOCKING AGAIN): Inventories remain extremely lean, and executives say they need to restock a bit just to keep up with sales. Factories are busier, and industrial production has been rising briskly. According to a survey of executives by the Cahners Publishing Company in Newton, Mass., four out of five businesses foresee higher sales in the next three months and more than two-thirds plan to raise production.
EXPORTS AND IMPORTS (RISKY): Exports have been booming and were one factor in last fall's ebullient growth. American products are highly competitive and growing third world economies have been scooping them up. But the economic slowdowns in Germany and Japan, along with the stronger dollar, pose a big risk. Growth in Germany and Japan is not likely to resume until next year, and growth in the third world has turned less vigorous. At the same time, rising spending here will bring in more imports.
JOBS (GRADUAL IMPROVEMENT): The labor market is -- almost imperceptibly -- on the mend. Workers are working more hours. Payroll job growth has been running at 90,000 a month for the last three months. State data suggest that payrolls may be expanding a bit faster. Unemployment is down to 7.1 percent from 7.7 percent. More important, despite the layoff announcements by some well-known companies, jobless claims have declined steadily from the mid-400,000's to the low 300,000's.
"Nobody says things are just booming," Mr. Fromstein of Manpower said. "On the other hand, there's steady growth, and it will come through in terms of plans to hire for the second quarter."

HEADLINE: Phnom Penh Journal;
In Destitute Land, Doctor Builds Dream Hospital

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, March 1

 BODY:
Dr. Beat Richner is a 45-year-old Swiss pediatrician. He is also a cellist, a writer and teller of tales and illustrator. Combining these talents with an enduring commitment to Cambodia's children, he has created something precious in this battered and deprived country -- a modern, well-equipped, spotlessly clean and fully staffed hospital.
In the consensus of Cambodian doctors and international aid workers, the Kantha Bopha Hospital is the best in Cambodia. Less than a year ago it was a derelict complex, not used since the Communist victory in 1975, mounds of rubble around a hollow shell. 
 Dr. Richner left the hospital when the Khmer Rouge took the city. But back in Zurich he could not rid himself of a sense of guilt for having deserted his patients, their families and his colleagues to the terror of the Pol Pot regime. "I had a bad conscience for having left here," he said.
Although he made a successful career as a pediatrician and concert artist, Dr. Richner said in his heart Cambodia remained a painful, open wound. "I had not finished this," he said.
 
Confronting a Catastrophe>
 He came back in December 1991, soon after the Paris agreement for a peaceful settlement of the conflict reopened this reclusive country to outsiders, and was asked by the Health Ministry to restore the hospital, which the United States had built.
"I had no idea of doing something here," he said. "I just wanted to see it."
But Dr. Richner was shocked by the hospitals. "No water, no electricity, no drugs -- a catastrophe," he said.
Compared with the hospitals elsewhere in this nation of perhaps eight million people, those of the capital are luxurious. Recalling a visit to the only hospital in Kompong Thom Province north of here, Dr. Pung Chhiv Kek Gallabru, a Cambodian physician who returned from France to organize a human rights group, said, "You could put all the equipment of the operating room into one small box."
Most Cambodian medical services, nonexistent in the years when the Khmer Rouge ruled the country, were provided by Vietnamese, Soviet and Eastern European doctors after the Vietnamese invasion that toppled the Khmer Rouge in 1979. The Vietnamese, impoverished themselves, withdrew first, and the collapse of the Western Communist governments left Cambodia largely to its own devices.
Physicians, all civil servants in a country that retains many aspects of Communism, receive monthly salaries of less than $20, despite high inflation. As a result, said Dr. Yit Sunnara, chief pediatrician at Kantha Bopha, doctors spend only a few hours at their jobs and earn their living in illicit private practices or in nonmedical trades.
Drugs are virtually nonexistent in purely Cambodian hospitals, where they are supposed to be free of charge. In the few hospitals supported by foreign medical teams, large quantities are stolen by the staff to supplement their salaries.
Dr. Richner decided that his duty was to restore Kantha Bopha. Without any assurance of financing, he signed a contract to do so. "It was a little bit naive," he said, but added that he had been encouraged by friends in the Swiss Government and large companies to believe they would finance the work. They declined.
Dr. Richner vented his disappointment to a mass-circulation magazine that had come to interview him on his 20th anniversary as a well-known performer under his stage name of Beatocello. While playing his cello, he tells or sings the tales that he writes, some funny, some sad, some both. Behind him as he performs are his own illustrations, flashed onto a screen.
 
An Outpouring of Help
 The interview brought an outpouring of contributions. Switzerland's largest circus staged a gala as a benefit, starring Dr. Richner. He played benefits throughout his country. An anonymous contribution of $333,000 arrived at the bank.
"Three days ago, an anonymous woman from Basel sent 400,000 francs," Dr Richner said -- about $265,000. "Now I can pay for this construction," he said, pointing to a surgery wing and a maternity building being restored.
About $4.6 million has been contributed so far, he said.
The hospital is equipped with modern medical technology not found elsewhere in Cambodia. There are 105 beds, and about 300 outpatients are treated daily. No patient has yet paid for any service, Dr. Richner said.
He has also used the contributions to pay his staff of 140 -- 23 doctors, 75 nurses, medical technicians and maintenance workers -- substantial supplements to their Government pay.
"The motivations for working here are electricity, water and medicines, and economic benefits." Dr. Yit said. "We need to live."
 
Specialists From Switzerland
 Five nurses, two technicians and an inventive Swiss who has installed water supply, drainage and electricity are on the staff. "The foreigners here must also educate the Cambodian staff, otherwise they would only be stealing jobs," Dr. Richner said.
Swiss specialists come on regular rotations to treat and to teach. Dr. Richner also teaches at the only medical school in the country. Physicians from throughout the country come to attend pediatrics workshops.
Relaxing on a porch overlooking the surgery and maternity buildings after his morning round of the wards and daily meeting with his doctors, the pediatrician laughed quietly.
"Everybody told me it was too difficult," he said. "So I stopped thinking and started to dream. And now it's reality."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Forced to flee the victorious Khmer Rouge in 1975, Dr. Beat Richner found that being torn away from his patients left a wound that would not heal. Able to return in 1991, he has turned the rubble the Pol Pot regime left of the Kantha Bopha Hospital into Cambodia's foremost hospital. With Dr. Yit Sunnar, chief pediatrician, he examined an infant brought to the crowded reception room. (David Portnoy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Several Sets of Data Suggest Slower Growth

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
A fresh crop of economic reports yesterday -- on manufacturing, consumers and construction -- suggests that the economy's growth is slowing from the snappy 4.8 percent annual rate of last quarter.
Investors reacted by buying bonds and selling stocks, a typical reaction to signs of a slowing economy. 
 Economic weakness could make it easier for President Clinton to sell his program for additional deficit spending this year to insure against another downturn. As for forecasters, they had already been looking for economic growth to ease from the recent torrid pace as businesses finished replenishing inventories and consumers settled down after their holiday buying.
"Economic growth should stay healthy despite some moderation in consumer spending," said Mickey Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities Ltd.
David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services, concurred. "There's nothing in today's data to contradict a 3 or 4 percent first-quarter" growth rate, he said.
The consensus among economists, based on the data available so far this quarter, is that growth is running at about a 3 percent annual rate.
Following are the economic reports released yesterday:
 
 
Purchasers' Report
 The nation's factories, after a fast-paced January, expanded activity at a slower rate in February as the rise in new orders slackened. That could be inferred from the index of purchasing managers, which is based on a monthly poll of corporate purchasing executives. The February index slipped to 55.8 from 58.0 in January.
"That's still strong," said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the National Association of Purchasing Managers' business committee and an executive at Pitney Bowes in Stamford, Conn. The rise in the index in January "was to the highest level since 1988, probably not a level that could be sustained," he said.
Any index number over 50, he noted, is a sign that manufacturing is expanding; any number over 44.5 indicates that the economy as a whole is growing. Forecasters watch the poll because, while unofficial, it is the first measure of real economic activity in the previous month, preceding the Government's monthly employment data by at least several days.
The survey showed an increase in industries that were expanding -- 16 in January versus 13 in February.
 
Consumer Spending
 Consumers pulled back in January, the Commerce Department said. Their spending rose three-tenths of 1 percent that month, compared with eight-tenths in December. Adjusting for inflation, consumption actually dipped one-tenth of 1 percent, the first decline in several months.
"That's not a beginning of a trend," Mr. Levy said. He expects spending to ease in real terms from last quarter's fevered pace of 5 percent, but only to 3 percent or so.
Consumers have grown less confident in the economy. Since the President presented his economic plan in mid-February, the University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment has dropped 6 points. But most economists are not alarmed.
"Confidence, while off its peak," Mr. Levy added, "is still solid; employment and incomes are rising, and mortgage refinancing is freeing up more disposable income."
The Commerce Department also said personal income grew five-tenths of 1 percent in January after jumping a full percentage point in December. Wages and salaries climbed six-tenths of 1 percent, twice the pace of inflation.
 
Construction
 Construction spending fell 1.3 percent in January, compared with December, falling to an annual rate of $430.8 billion. Spending on public construction fell 4.9 percent to $114 billion, the Commerce Department said. Private construction flattened out at $316.8 billion. With commercial vacancy rates still high, though improving, business building fell again. But single-family-home construction rose to $131.4 billion from $129.6 billion in December.
 
Home Sales
 Sales of existing homes fell a sharp 6.4 percent in January, the National Association of Realtors reported, but few economists took that to mean the housing recovery was in trouble. Sales are still 15 percent higher than a year earlier and unusually frigid weather may have kept prospective buyers at home.

(Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Plans No Big Borrowing Shift

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said yesterday that he was not planning any drastic shift to short-term Government borrowing.
Although he did not provide any precise details of the Government's future borrowing plans, Mr. Bentsen's comments might prove disappointing to some traders and investors. Some of the recent surge in the price of the 30-year bond has been based, traders said, on expectations that the Treasury would further reduce the size of the regular quarterly 30-year auctions, shifting Government borrowing to shorter-term issues. 
 In last month's quarterly auction, the Treasury cut the 30-year bond sale by $1 billion, to $9.25 billion. A year earlier, the Treasury had lopped $2 billion off the size of the regular auction.
"I think we can do some shift," Mr. Bentsen told reporters in Washington. But he added, "I do not propose any dramatic, radical shift."
There has been some speculation in the Treasury market that the Treasury might not even sell any 30-year bonds in the next quarterly auction in May. This speculation is based in part on the fact that President Clinton's deficit-reduction proposal includes savings of $11.5 billion over three years from savings from debt management. When asked about achieving these savings, Mr. Bentsen said that if that amount was not achieved, the Administration would adjust the projections in the budget.
 
Trade Center Ripples
 Mr. Bentsen's comments came at end of a trading day that was still recovering from the effects of Friday's explosion at the World Trade Center. Although the explosion sent ripples through the bond market, it was not seriously disruptive.
The prices of Treasury bonds and notes rallied in what some traders estimated was a slightly more active Monday than usual. The rally brought the yield on the 30-year bond, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, down to 6.84 percent, from 6.90 percent on Friday, and just above the 16-year low of 6.82 percent reached a week ago Tuesday.
The absence of one of the market's major dealers -- Cantor Fitzgerald -- left some investors with less information to trade on. Cantor is a matchmaker for investors who want to buy and sell fixed income securities and is also a leading source of active bond price information for the market. But the explosion at the World Trade Center closed Cantor's offices.
Some portfolio managers said that the liquidity or ease of trading the market was reduced somewhat. A few portfolio managers were left a little in the dark because they did not have the price and interest-rate data from Cantor Fitzgerald. And some who trade through Cantor had to go to primary dealers to make trades.
"There is a little bit of caution on the part of some retail accounts because Cantor is their main source of information," said Matthew Alexy, a government-trading strategist at the First Boston Corporation.
But other managers said that unless there was a need to make a lot of trades during the day, there was no problem. "With our perspective of a longer term we do not have to know the price from second to second," said Curt Hollingsworth, a portfolio manager for Fidelity Investments in Boston. He also said that alternative sources, like Bloomberg and Govpx, gave him a satisfactory picture of market activity.
Officials at Cantor, which has moved its operations from One World Trade Center to several temporary locations, said yesterday that part of their fixed-income operations would be restored by today and the rest would be back on line tomorrow.
Joel Kazis, managing director at UBS Securities, said, "'most of us are used to looking at Cantor but the market doesn't stop when they are out of business." He is a primary dealer in the Treasury market and can get the prices from the other four major brokers in the business.
 
Data From Govpx
 The absence of Cantor gave Govpx, a rival that also distributes bond market prices to investors and traders, the chance to be seen by many potential clients who might not have been interested in the past. The firm, which was begun in June 1991 by the four rival brokers of Cantor Fitzgerald, authorized its distributors, which include Bloomberg, Knight-Ridder and Reuters, to send the Govpx data to 85,000 terminals in trading rooms around the country. Govpx has paying customers with 3,000 terminals now.
"It was an opportunity for people to try Govpx in the time of need," said Laurence Jones, the president of Govpx.
 
Port Authority
 In the wake of the World Trade Center explosion, the price of Port Authority bonds was off slightly in light trading. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey owns the World Trade Center.
But municipal bond traders said there was no rush to sell the bonds. In addition, Barry Weintrob, the chief financial officer, said the Port Authority intended to go ahead with its scheduled sale of $100 million in bonds tomorrow.
"No one is looking to dump their bonds," said Monica Wieboldt, a portfolio manager for municipal bonds at the Dreyfus Corporation. She said she saw an offer to sell about $2 million of the Port Authority 6 percent bonds due in 2028 in the morning. But she and other traders said that was not much activity given the circumstances. Late in the day, the bond was off about 1/2 a point.
 
Treasury Market
 While Treasury prices rose across the board, the yields were still a little above the low levels of last Tuesday. For example, the 10-year note rose 15/32 to yield 5.94 percent, down from 6.01 Friday but up from 5.89 percent last Tuesday.
In the weekly auction of Treasury bills, the average discount rate rose to 2.97 percent on three-month bills and fell to 3.05 percent on six month bills. Following are the results from the auction:

HEADLINE: Restoring an Ancient Landscape: An Innovative Plan for the Midwest

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
INTERIOR SECRETARY BRUCE BABBITT'S announcement two weeks ago that he would try to prevent endangered-species crises by promoting the long-term health care of whole ecosystems may signal a new era in Federal conservation policy. But the concept is already built into a number of ambitious ecosystem protection efforts that have lately been undertaken across the country.
Almost as Mr. Babbitt spoke, in fact, scientists, conservationists and government officials from throughout the Midwest gathered in Chicago for a long-planned three-day meeting to develop a recovery plan for one of the nation's largest and most threatened ecosystems: a vast expanse of oak-studded savanna that once intertwined with the open prairies in a diverse mosaic of biological wealth reaching from the Great Lakes to Texas. 
 Before Europeans arrived in America, the oak savannas carpeted some 30 million acres of the Midwest, including half the landscape in places like southern Wisconsin and northeastern Illinois. In many places, the savannas had the aspect of a tidy, open picnic grove; in others they were brushier, with hazel bushes much in evidence. Naturally occurring fires killed most trees, but enough tough young oaks survived over the years to provide the ecosystem with its keystone plant species.
An unusually rich array of wildflowers and grasses, suited to partial sunlight and able to pop back up quickly after a fire, formed a thick green carpet under oak canopies. Butterflies that are rare today flocked to the plants. Both bison and deer, depending on location, grazed and browsed in the savanna-prairie mosaic.
The fires ceased with farming and development, and invading trees and alien plant species like European buckthorn filled in and choked savannas not plowed or covered by subdivisions. Now less than 1 percent of high-quality oak savanna remains, in fragments that biologists say are too small and scattered for many of the species that live there to survive in the long run. But hundreds of thousands more acres exist in degraded and biologically impoverished form, their ecological character destroyed and most of the many species that once lived there long gone.
Scattered restoration experiments have shown that these choked and degraded tracts can be revived and that much of their biological diversity will then return, scientists say. The Chicago group worked out a preliminary plan for restoring sufficient acreage to assure the ecosystem's long-term health, and is now turning to the task of working with public and private landowners to put it into effect.
"We cannot preserve species unless we preserve the entire system which supports those species," Dr. Alan Haney, the dean of forestry at the University of Wisconsin at Stevens Point, an organizer of the savanna conference, told the participants.
This is the heart of the approach being advocated by Mr. Babbitt and pursued on a number of fronts, and Dr. Haney said the approach marks "a radical change in the way we look at our natural resources."
The object of the approach is to practice preventive medicine on ecosystems and their entire array of species rather than wait until it is necessary to prescribe painful emergency treatment on a crash basis when a single species becomes endangered. By that time, according to the theory, an ecosystem has become so degraded that options for protecting species are narrow and there is little leeway for compromise between economic and conservation interests.
By intervening earlier on an ecosystem-wide basis, say proponents of the approach, it is easier to make acceptable tradeoffs between the ecology and the economy while avoiding confrontational politics and lawsuits.
In this way, Mr. Babbitt said, it might be possible to avert "national train wrecks" like the one that occurred when logging interests and conservationists collided in the spotted owl controversy in the Pacific Northwest. The ecosystem approach, said the Secretary, is "clearly an idea whose time has come."
But can the approach work in practice?
 
Program in California
 The results for both species preservation and economic health may not be seen for some time. Two initiatives similar in concept to the savanna plan, however, are encouraging conservationists to believe that diverse interests can at least band together in the cause of ecosystem preservation and recovery.
In California, state, local and Federal agencies are joining with landowners to preserve the coastal sage scrub ecosystem that stretches from Los Angeles to San Diego. This is a formerly extensive but now shrinking assembly of shrubby, chaparral-like flora and associated fauna. Many of its species, among them a bird called the California gnatcatcher, are approaching but have not yet reached federally endangered status.
Some 70 private landowners and many local governments have formally enrolled 200,000 acres of land in the project; the ecosystem consists of 250,000 to 350,000 acres. The state hopes to put the plan, which will be legally binding, into effect later this year.
The project is the first concrete step undertaken under a new statewide conservation policy that divides California into 10 contiguous bioregions. Each has its own ecological character and its own council of state, local and Federal representatives to coordinate long-term planning for both conservation and economic development. An explicit purpose of this arrangement is to promote preventive, ecosystem-wide conservation of multiple species.
 
Efforts in Texas
 A similar effort in Texas seeks to accommodate both the ecology and economy of the biologically rich hill-country region. In the Austin area, the Nature Conservancy has brokered a plan by various governmental and private interests to acquire and assemble ecologically rich tracts of the regional ecosystem into a 60,000-acre preserve around which development can proceed.
In some cases, developers are giving up land in exchange for the right to build elsewhere in the county. The arrangement is part of a larger hill-country strategy in which several large "core" preserves are being set aside and surrounded by buffer zones of ecologically friendly activity, including ecotourism ranches. The Nature Conservancy is also pursuing this general strategy in more than 40 other places in the United States.
Mr. Babbitt, who describes the group's conservationists as "surely the leaders" in trying to balance biodiversity concerns with economics through the ecosystem approach, has conferred on the matter with John C. Sawhill, the conservancy's president.
The Secretary said he did not yet have a "good fix" on the fledgling Midwestern savanna plan, which in any case is being co-sponsored by the Environmental Protection Agency. But he said he had been briefed in detail on the California project and considers it "an important, important demonstration of how these concepts might work."
Douglas P. Wheeler, California's Resources Secretary, suggested that while Interior officials were "taking a hard look" at his state's program, the Endangered Species Act needed to be modified to accommodate the ecosystem approach.
"The whole notion of ecosystem planning is far more advanced today than when the law was enacted in 1973," said Mr. Wheeler.
The Endangered Species Act requires that a conservation plan be put in place for a single species already listed as endangered. But it does not require preventive programs for entire ecosystems with all their species. The law is up for re-authorization this year, and Mr. Babbitt, whose department enforces the act, said he thought it should be re-examined, possibly by an independent private commission.
In the meantime, other public and private organizations are pressing their own ecosystem recovery plans. The Chicago savanna conference in late February is a major example. The conference was sponsored by the Environmental Protection Agency, the University of Wisconsin at Stevens Point, the Nature Conservancy and Northeastern Illinois University and was attended by experts from many other agencies and groups.
Scientists argue about how the savanna should be defined. A broad rule of thumb is that the tree canopy covers 10 to 80 percent of the ground in a savanna, while the prairie is essentially treeless and the forest canopy is essentially closed. Some experts assign the term woodland to denser concentrations of savanna oaks short of closed forest.
But whatever classifications people impose, there is no sharp demarcation; plant and animal species find their favored habitats along a prairie-to-forest continuum, with many making their primary home in the savanna by any definition. As they actually arrange themselves on the land, savanna, prairie, wetlands and sometimes even forest are so intertwined that it is virtually impossible to separate them.
That complicates the conservation effort, as does the fact that changing climatic factors caused the savannas and prairies to shift their positions on the landscape. Both the mosaic aspect of the ecosystem and its dynamics, it was decided at the conference, require the conservation of large enough slices of the landscape to accommodate all the interrelated parts and the shifts they undergo; small, isolated remnants of savanna will not do the job.
The preliminary recovery plan, some features of which are still being refined as a result of the Chicago discussions, calls for identifying large acreages of overgrown savanna on public land that can be restored to something approaching their condition before European settlers arrived. These might serve as "core" reserves, said Steve Packard, the science director of the Illinois Nature Conservancy, another organizer of the conference.
In addition, he said, many private holdings like farms and timberlands contain degraded savanna that could be restored as buffer zones without interfering with economic uses of the land. All these tracts would be stitched into a network containing perhaps 5 to 10 percent of the original savanna. That is thought by some scientists to be sufficient for long-term maintenance of the ecosystem.
The organizers of the conference are just starting to develop a mechanism for putting the plan into effect. It might consist of a regional "recovery team" of scientists, agency representatives and conservationists negotiating land-use arrangements.
 
Strategy of Restoration
 Once the arrangements are in place, the basic restoration strategy is to start to reintroduce burning on a controlled basis. In some types of savanna, experiments have already shown, this is sufficient to allow the savanna to re-emerge.
In others, like the classic tall-grass, black-soil savanna of northeastern Illinois, it is necessary not only to burn out invaders but also to re-sow the savannas with seeds from the past. When this is done, as a Nature Conservancy restoration project directed by Mr. Packard in the Chicago area has shown, the savanna can rebound spectacularly.
But some savanna species have disappeared already. "We have no idea whether that number is a few dozen or a few hundred or even a few thousand," Dr. Haney said. As time passes, he said, continued development and invasion by exotic plants may cause more species to disappear, and it will become more difficult to restore the landscape.
"This is the last decade or two when you can do this," Mr. Packard said. "The communities are disintegrating."

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
The Impetus for Havoc in Apartheid's Demise

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
South Africa's President, F. W. de Klerk, is the target of "Apartheid's Last Stand," tonight's "Frontline" report on his country's tense present and dangerous future.
With the help of vivid news clips, the hourlong program recalls the hopes raised by what the narrator calls "a special relationship" between Mr. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela, the leader of the African National Congress. But critics make a case that for several years the white Government has been stalling negotiations and encouraging clashes between black groups to discredit Mr. Mandela and his movement. 
 Mr. de Klerk is portrayed as a realistic politician who has been compelled to negotiate by international sanctions that have severely hurt South Africa's economy. Whether he is an accomplice of white hard-liners, particularly in the powerful security establishment, or is just unable to control them, is left unsettled.
Mr. Mandela, who is treated with the reverence he has long enjoyed on American television, is pictured as being under pressure from more radical elements in his organization as well as from the Zulu Chief, Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, the leader of the conservative Inkatha Freedom Party.
The well-edited program, which includes interviews with Mr. de Klerk, Mr. Mandela and Mr. Buthelezi, begins and ends with affecting scenes of black South Africans learning to vote. Those are the only optimistic moments in this portrayal of a profoundly divided land.
 
Murder, Rape and DNA
PBS, tonight
(In the New York area, Channels 13 and 49 at 8)
Fans of "Nova" who get the feeling tonight that "Hard Copy" has invaded their public channel should not kick the television set. It's the producers of "Murder, Rape and DNA" who deserve the boot. Apparently trying to juice up their report on DNA typing, the latest thing in forensic medicine, they have resorted to the re-enactments common to true-crime shows.
If you can ignore those banal scenes, with their creepy lighting and dreadful music, you can learn how technicians go about comparing a gene found, say, in sperm at the scene of a rape with the genetic makeup of a suspect. The results cannot prove that you committed a crime, but they can prove you did not commit it.
One beneficiary, whose case leads off the hour, is a San Diego man who was suspected of raping his 8-year-old daughter. The girl said at first that a stranger had climbed through her window and carried her to his car. But social workers and sex-abuse therapists kept at her for months until she changed her story and said her father did it. Only analysis of a semen stain belatedly noticed on her nightshirt cleared him.
Other cases, too, are reviewed tonight, alas with other re-enactments. The narrator says DNA typing is being hailed as "the most important forensic breakthrough since fingerprinting," but the prospect of a national DNA data bank of the genetic makeups of people who have been convicted of sexual assaults and other violent crimes troubles civil libertarians. Unfortunately, that interesting issue is mentioned only in a postscript to a program devoted mainly to crime stories.
Whether the producers were driven to use re-enactments because the process of DNA typing, mostly a comparison of dots on a computer printout, does not make for visual excitement, or whether they were attracted to the subject in the first place by its appeal to audiences who go for tales of rape cannot be decided even by DNA testing. Either way, "Nova" stands indicted on suspicion of the worst.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Irresistible Events, Immovable Networks

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
When the International Olympic Committee holds negotiations in the third or fourth week of July to sell network TV rights to the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, a timetable that was announced yesterday, Olympic cash requirements will clash with radically altered network fiscal realities.
And the outcome will probably be a bellwether for how tightwaddish the networks will be in their coming talks with major league baseball, the National Football League and National Basketball Association (unless one of the three beats the Olympics to the negotiating table). 
 The I.O.C., negotiating on behalf of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, wants more than the $401 million NBC paid for last year's Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, and the Atlanta committee has said it wants upward of $550 million. Inside the I.O.C., anything less than $500 million will be deemed a disaster.
The Atlanta committee needs cash, especially to build the recently approved Olympic stadium, and because its sponsorship money is not flooding in.
Sadly for Atlanta and the I.O.C., NBC and its partner, Cablevision, lost over $100 million on Barcelona and no network has ever paid above $401 million. Despite ABC's flirtation with Turner Broadcasting to make a joint bid for Atlanta, ABC is best known for its refusal to bid on certain money-losers.
CBS, known for breaking the network bank in 1988 with its inflated $1.06 billion bid for major league baseball, has been chastened and is unlikely to bid ravenously for Atlanta as if its prime-time schedule depended on it.
Billy Payne, president of the Atlanta committee, who makes a smiley-face figure seem dour, insists that the lure of the centennial Summer Olympics, shown live from the East Coast of the United States, provides all the added value any network could possibly desire to bid more than $500 million.
"We're having no trouble convincing people they're worth more than Barcelona," he said. "We have an idea of the value; they have an idea. We will get what we need and they will pay no more than they need to."
That may be a contradiction in terms, because if a network pays no more than it needs to, Payne will not get what he wants. Not in this market, where baseball TV rights are expected to be cut in half, and pro football's hierarchy struggles internally over whether to grant networks financial relief or gamble on an improving economy.
Yes, perhaps, a live East Coast Olympics is alluring. But it is not worth $100 million to $150 million. Maybe half of that.
The I.O.C. hinted yesterday that it would do what is necessary to enhance the value of Atlanta TV rights. Richard W. Pound, chairman of the I.O.C.'s TV committee, told The Associated Press that the organization is "certainly ready to consider new approaches which could lead to more television coverage of more Olympic events for wider American audiences."
 
N.H.L. Goes Network
 Two of the first hires by Gary Bettman, the National Hockey League's new commissioner, are from TV: Steve Solomon of ABC Sports, as senior vice president, and Glenn Adamo, a former NBC producer, as vice president of broadcasting.
What a brainstorm! TV pros for the once TV-deprived league!
Solomon and Adamo started yesterday, with the decided advantage of having the ESPN cable deal in place since October, rather than the previous cablecaster, SportsChannel America, which reached a third of ESPN's 60 million subscribers and whose quality was about half of ESPN's.
"We want to take a look from top to bottom at how the game of hockey is telecast," said Solomon. "We're analyzing the game on television to improve the sport at home and bring the excitement that is clearly in the arenas."
Solomon is the sedate executive, a 21-year ABC veteran. Adamo is a hyperkinetic former producer, who played hockey at the University of Connecticut.
"It's time to be innovative and showcase the sport better," he said. "The game has to be more user-friendly on TV, where the casual fan can be entertained and find out things he didn't know before."
Adamo will examine ESPN and local telecasts as a prelude to creating league-wide uniformity in the televised look of the games, from camera angles and lighting to graphics and player features.
The overriding goal: get as close to the action as possible to turn those helmeted players into heroes. (He's read the N.B.A. TV manual.) ESPN is doing much of what he wants to see done, as does the MSG Network, Adamo said.
But no cablecaster yet does it all. "Years ago, it used to be one-camera coverage," he said, "but now with remote-controlled cameras and gadgets, we want to make games sound and look better."
Both Adamo and Solomon say that a future goal is to increase network exposure, which now consists entirely of the All-Star Game, on NBC, and five Stanley Cup games that will appear for the first time this season, on ABC.
"The good news is this isn't a new business where we have to learn what to do," he said. "I'm a broadcaster by trade and a hockey fanatic by love."
Adamo added, tongue in cheek, that one of his first tasks is to aid in the discovery of new broadcast phraseology to replace the hackneyed "Score!" or "He shoots! He scores!" or "Shot! Score!" when a player, uh, scores.
"There must be another way to say it," he said.
