HEADLINE: Observer;
Fork In the Logic

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
"White man speak with forked tongue," observed several generations of Hollywood Indians, all of whom seemed to know what they were talking about even though present-day moralizers would probably convict them of political incorrectness in the first degree.
To this day the words come back to me whenever I contemplate the history of American racial relationships. All unwhite Americans would surely be better equipped for survival if they had grown up in homes with that antique Hollywood-Indian wisdom framed in needlepoint over the velveteen settee. 
 It is my belief that nothing is so politically incorrect that childhood's uncorrupted mind cannot extract a nugget of enduring wisdom from it. For years, among the bits of wisdom tacked up on the inside of my skull has been a warning from that hopelessly politically incorrect Chinese detective, Charlie Chan.
Chan was afflicted with an impetuous son who habitually jumped to the wrong conclusion about whatever his father happened to be investigating. Reprimanding this silly young man one Saturday afternoon at the Capitol Theater in Belleville, N.J., Chan said:
"He who speaks before thinking is like man who fires gun in dark room."
"Words to live by!" I must have instantly said to myself, mounting them in the back of my skull, for they still come back to haunt me whenever I feel the urge to tell the world why some wretched President simply won't do or, as in today's case, why the present President's wife may think with forked brain.
Heeding the wisdom of Charlie Chan, I have thought about this matter in minute detail, including the difficult question whether to refer to the President's wife as the First Lady. My decision: absolutely not. The word "lady" is odious to language watchers of the feminist movement, which feels protective of the President's wife.
Feminist lingo usually resolves these difficulties with the word "person," but it would be silly to call the President's wife "the First Person." As every survivor of sixth-grade grammar knows, the first person is "I" -- "we" in the plural -- and the instant you, dear reader, suspect another sixth-grade grammar lesson is afoot, you will turn this page into a paper airplane and sail it out the window, right?
In short, this subject has been thought out according to the precept of Chan. This emboldens me to suggest that the President's wife needs to get the fork out of her thinking about health matters.
She is, of course, in charge of creating a sensible health-care program. It is a costly proposition, and speculation encouraged by the Clinton people is that new taxes on tobacco and alcohol will be required to finance the program.
Why, then, has the President's wife banned smoking in the White House? The inevitable publicity flowing from her example is bound to be yet another blow to cigarette sales.
She obviously hopes to reduce cigarette consumption while counting on increased tax revenue from smokers to pay for health-care reform. Raising the tax while simultaneously trying to cut the number of people who will pay it suggests that the health- care financing problem has not been thought out with the thoroughness Charlie Chan would have insisted on.
In Hollywood-Indianspeak, it is forked logic.
Its political wisdom is also questionable. If the health-care program is to be financed by cigarette smokers and cigarette smoking is forbidden in the White House, what are we to think except that the White House is unwilling to pay its fair share of the bill?
Fairness, Stephanopoulos! What about fairness? Fairness demands that the White House smoke its fair share.
Charlie Chan might suspect there is more afoot here than meets the eye. It is comforting to think that clean-living, non-smoking, non-boozing folks can get a nice new health-care program free by riding on the backs of smoky and vinous sinners.
It's doubtful that the Clinton people really believe this. Surely they are toying with us on the matter of health-care costs, hoping to hold down the bad tax news until their economic program can be enacted.
Meantime, consistency might impel the President's wife not only to drop the cigarette ban in the White House but to urge all Americans to lighten their tax burden by lighting up.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1502 words

HEADLINE: Social Investment Programs: Comparing the Past With the Promised Payoff

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
Were Bill Clinton to place a personal ad to support his vision of government, it might read something like this:
"Dynamic young President seeks contributions for social investments. Pay now, prosper later. Data to prove it on file." 
 Indeed, Mr. Clinton has called his emphasis on investment "the most fundamental change" he seeks in government. And he comes armed with studies that he says show that a dollar spent today on things like preschool programs and vaccines can save $3 or even $10 down the road.
"That's a good investment no matter how you measure it," he said in his recent address to Congress.
 
Some Notable Successes
 Few analysts doubt that some government programs have proved to be productive, even if measured narrowly, in economic rather than humanitarian terms. Two centuries of a public education system that has consistently produced taxpayers may offer one example; many scholars believe that the G.I. Bill of Rights, which filled universities with veterans after World War II, offers another.
But recent decades have also shown spottier records for dozens, if not hundreds, of social programs similarly justified as investments. And behind most of the figures that Mr. Clinton cites are mounds of social science research that leave even the best-informed scholars squabbling about whether the anticipated savings are real or imaginary.
"In the abstract, the talk about investment makes a lot of sense," said Douglas Besharov, a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, who is skeptical of the President's arithmetic. "But give me a break: Nobody really believes these numbers."
Some of the "investments" Mr. Clinton advocates involve new programs. He wants apprenticeship plans that would give high school students technical skills. He also wants national service programs that would allow college graduates to work off their student loans.
Since these programs do not yet exist, evaluating their potential as investments is a theoretical pursuit, not an empirical one. The Job Training Partnership Act, a Federal training program, was justified on similar grounds, but one recent study found that it actually lowered the earnings of young men.
In other cases, the President is seeking to expand some of the nation's most scrutinized programs, like those that train mothers on welfare or tutor preschoolers. Many of these programs were created under earlier Administrations, which hoped to help people with them but not necessarily to save money.
While there are mounds of data about how some of these programs have performed, there is also much disagreement about what the data mean.
Perhaps no program is praised more lavishly by those who believe in the idea of investment than Head Start.
"We all know it saves money," says Mr. Clinton, who has proposed an increase in spending to about $7 billion a year in 1998 from current levels of $2.8 billion. "For every dollar we invest today, we'll save three tomorrow."
But his projected cost savings do not come from a Head Start program. Instead, they derive from a study of just 58 students in another early childhood education program, called the Perry Preschool, in Ypsilanti, Mich.
 
30-Year Track Record
 Researchers have continued to track the students, who enrolled in the program in 1962. Comparing them to a group of similar students who did not attend the school, they found that a significantly higher number of the Perry graduates finished high school and attended college. The students were also less likely to receive welfare or get arrested.
The researchers, Lawrence J. Schweinhart and David P. Weikart, arrived at the three-dollar figure by calculating what taxpayers would have spent on things like criminal justice, welfare and special education if the students had not gone to the preschool. Extrapolating in a recent article, they said the nation could achieve a "net annual profit" of $31 billion a year by enrolling all poor children in similar programs.
There is one catch: The Perry Preschool results have not been replicated in Head Start, which includes 1,300 programs of widely varying quality.
Consultants for the Department of Health and Human Services reviewed 210 Head Start studies in 1985. They found that the program does improve the cognitive performance of preschoolers, but that most of the effects wear off after two years.
The consultants did find that Head Start graduates remained less likely to fail a grade or to be placed in special education classes, but noted that "this finding is based on very few studies."
Citing this research, Mr. Clinton's critics say his promise of cost-savings is a hoax. "Three years later, you can't tell a Head Start child from a non-Head-Start child," said Mr. Besharov, who supports additional financing for the program but warns against grand expectations. "Few of us would make investments with our personal money with the kind of evidence that underlies these assertions."
Mr. Schweinhart contends that the Perry students have fared better because they received more intensive services. He said the program spent about twice as much per student than the average Head Start program does today, and provided them with more teachers, a better curriculum and more intensive home visits.
Although he says that "there's no reason on earth" the results could not be reproduced if Head Start received the same support, other scholars contend that large programs rarely replicate the results of the models they are based on.
The President's claims are open to similar questioning when he says that "we will save $10 later for every $1 we spend" on immunizations. Virtually every scholar who has studied immunization has concluded that it saves money. In 1988, the Office of Technology Assessment reviewed 15 such studies, and found cost savings that ranged from $3 to $25 for every dollar spent.
But Dr. Walter Orenstein, director of the immunization division at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, said most of those studies assumed that the clinics and personnel to deliver the services were already in place. By contrast, he said, the nation now needs to expand its clinics, which will drive up the costs of immunization.
He also said that some of the $300 million that Mr. Clinton is proposing to spend could go to vans and other outreach services. This is much more expensive than simply giving a waiting patient a shot.
"It's hard to say that if we add another dollar we'd save $10; clearly, it takes more to get the last kids vaccinated," he said. "But my guess is that it's still likely to remain cost-effective."
Mr. Clinton has also been enthusiastic about the investment potential of training programs for women on welfare, pledging to quadruple their financing to about $4 billion a year. Some of these programs have proved cost effective, more than paying for themselves by generating lower welfare costs and higher tax receipts.
But the successes have been modest. Three years after signing up for Project Success, a program Mr. Clinton ran as Governor of Arkansas, participants were still earning an average of only $1,422 a year, in addition to whatever welfare payments they collected. That was an average of $337 a year more than women who had not joined the program, but hardly the makings of a social revolution.
 
A Matter of Evaluation
 The President's challenge will be not only to finance the programs that work, but also to terminate those that do not. His record on this score is too new to judge.
But skeptics contend that hundreds of government programs continue to thrive despite poor results because they develop followings among the bureaucrats who run them and the contractors who profit.
"Look at the spending on public schools," said Irving Kristol, co-editor of The Public Interest, a journal of public policy. "It goes up and up and up, and the results go down and down and down. Unless we can see some results, how can you call it an investment?"
Mr. Kristol substitutes a different word for Mr. Clinton's investments: "spending."
As a real investor, the President might also insist on more rigorous evaluation of government programs, to discern which ones work and which do not. Mr. Schweinhart, the preschool evaluator, said most government bureaucracies resist such evaluations "because it runs considerable risk of making your program look bad."
Mr. Clinton's enthusiasts argue the significance of his oratory cannot be found in quibbles about his numbers. They believe that a nation in need of skilled workers can no longer afford to let a substantial number of its citizens fail, and that there is enough research to support the view that government programs can make a difference.
Though scholars debate the numbers, said Lisbeth Schorr, a lecturer at Harvard University, "as long as we know we're going in the right direction, we have to make the investment because the alternatives are so expensive -- to both government and society."

HEADLINE: Clinton Offers Tuition Aid Linked to National Service

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 1

 BODY:
President Clinton today outlined a plan for a national service program for college students that combined broad ambitions, high ideals and a modest beginning.
The program, which would begin with a 1,000-student pilot project this summer and expand to 100,000 by 1997, would allow students to help pay off their tuition debts by working as teachers or police officers, or with the homeless. 
 Speaking to a wildly enthusiastic Rutgers University audience on the 32d anniversary of President John F. Kennedy's founding of the Peace Corps, Mr. Clinton called on young Americans to "answer the call to service" at home with the same spirit that an earlier generation answered Kennedy's call for service abroad.
But reflecting some of the economic constraints that Kennedy did not have to worry about, Mr. Clinton insisted that he was not proposing the creation of another "entitlement" program. He vowed that his initiative could be built around state and local institutions and would not require establishment of a costly Federal bureaucracy.
 
A Role for Congress
 But he did not explain how, as the details are being worked out by his advisers. Congressional approval would be required, at least for financing.
The President declared that in return for tuition loans "we'll ask you to help our police forces across the nation, training members for a new police corps, that will walk beats, and work with neighborhoods and build the kind of community ties that will prevent crime from happening in the first place; we'll ask young people to work to help control pollution and recycle waste, to paint darkened buildings and clean up neighborhoods, to work with senior citizens and combat homelessness and help children in trouble."
Mr. Clinton said national service "is nothing less than the American way to change America."
To buttress his call to service, Mr. Clinton marshaled some very new and some very old political messengers. After his speech, he ducked into the men's locker room and taped an interview with Tabitha Soren of MTV for broadcast tonight. In the interview, Mr. Clinton repeated that he favored higher taxes for cigarettes: "Smoking ought to bear more of the cost of the health-care problems that it causes."
 
Shriver Approves
 While Mr. Clinton was performing for MTV behind the scenes, a voice from the past, R. Sargent Shriver, Kennedy's brother-in-law and the first director of the Peace Corps, was brought to the press room by White House aides to put the stamp of approval on Mr. Clinton's initiative.
Mr. Shriver provided not only the expected endorsement but some sobering contrasts between the Kennedy era, when the problem of getting people to serve seemed to be just a shortage of will, to the Clinton era, when the problem is also a shortage of money.
"This program is appropriate for today, as opposed to when we started the Peace Corps," Mr. Shriver said. "The reality today is that most people getting out of college have incurred large, large debts. The climate is different, but I think this is true: Young people are still idealistic. They have not been given a chance. With the budgetary restrictions that now exist, it means it is going to be very difficult to get it to a huge size. That doesn't mean it shouldn't be started, but with the shortage of money now one has to be satisfied with achieving modest goals."
Mr. Clinton emphasized that because of budget and bureaucratic constraints his program would begin with a $15 million, eight-week "Summer of Service" program for roughly 1,000 teen-agers from poor neighborhoods or broken homes in up to 10 communities.
 
What They Might Do
 Participants would help health-care providers administer immunization programs for young children, tutor illiterates, teach recreational programs to children at risk of dropping out of school and test neighborhoods for risk of lead paint.
Summer of Service participants would receive a minimum-wage stipend and a post-service benefit of $1,000 to be applied to education or training. Mr. Clinton has asked Congress to finance the program as part of the $31 billion in spending on roads, bridges and communication links he is proposing to spur the economy.
The tuition-for-service program would also begin small, with $389 million in scholarships for about 25,000 students in the first year, growing to $3.4 billion by 1997, when the program is expected to include more than 100,000 students, according to the White House. Mr. Clinton has already asked for the financing as part of the economic recovery package he presented to Congress.
As outlined by Mr. Clinton, the program would work like this: students would fill community service jobs for a set number of years for part or all of their tuition, for either college or certified technical training. They could perform the community service before college, and earn part or all of their tuition in advance, or borrow directly from the Federal Government and pay it back slowly as a percentage of their income, through payroll deductions or as part of their income tax filings.
In his campaign manifesto, "Putting People First," Mr. Clinton proposed to "scrap the existing student loan program and establish a National Service Trust Fund to guarantee every American who wants a college education the means to obtain one."
In his speech in Madison Square Garden accepting the Democratic nomination, Mr. Clinton declared: "We'll say: everybody can borrow the money to go to college. But you must do your part. You must pay it back -- from your paychecks, or better yet, by going back home and serving your communities."
To prevent the establishment of a huge bureaucracy, Clinton Administration officials want it based around existing community-service projects, which would be certified as authentic by the Government, and then be allowed to enroll a set number of graduates for jobs and be partly reimbursed for their salaries by the Government.
Many listeners echoed the idea of service -- and saving money. "I thought his speech really energized everybody," said Jackie Frank, a 20-year-old junior. "We were just saying a lot of people are going to become a lot more involved, and with being able to earn tuition for it is a great way to do it."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Struggles To Unify Attack On Clinton Plan

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
When President Clinton returns to Capitol Hill on Tuesday, this time as the invited luncheon guest of Congressional Republicans, he may feel as though he is eating in the Tower of Babel, with everyone speaking a different economic language.
Traditional Republican conservatives argue for reducing the Federal deficit by making specific cuts in programs they consider wasteful, like rural electrification. Reaganite supply-siders steam about proposed tax increases, arguing for growth over austerity. And still other lawmakers say they are content to criticize the broad outlines of the Clinton economic policy and hope that the fractious Congressional Democrats will themselves pick apart the details of the package. 
 The Republicans' first formal meeting with Mr. Clinton, along with their first challenge to a piece of the Administration's economic program on the Senate floor, will give them their best opportunity so far to slow down the Administration's public relations steamroller.
But some Republicans express concern that their many voices at Tuesday's lunch may only help promote the impression that the President has offered the only coherent program for growth and deficit reduction. "We won't be in perfect harmony," Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, a ranking Republican on the Finance Committee, predicted in careful understatement.
 
Uniting Against Stimulus
 To counter that danger, Republicans say they will try to concentrate on one thing they all oppose: the President's $16.3 billion plan for a short-term economic stimulus, which they contend would unnecessarily increase the deficit. They will also criticize Mr. Clinton for relying on tax increases while making no significant reduction in net spending.
The most optimistic Republicans hope to enlist enough conservative Democrats on Tuesday to pass an amendment offered by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, to force Federal spending cuts as a means of paying for a $5.7 billion extension of emergency unemployment benefits that Mr. Clinton has urged. Without the cuts, the added benefits will increase the deficit.
"It would show we are here as players," said Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the Republican whip.
Republican lawmakers have been grappling for a consistent legislative approach. While they strongly oppose what they view as Mr. Clinton's traditional Democratic approach of taxing and spending, they do not want to be seen as agents of gridlock.
 
Hopes on Senate Panel
 The Republicans need to regain unity if they are to have any chance of challenging Mr. Clinton's economic program. Unless the President stumbles in making his sales pitch, their best hope appears to be in the Senate Finance Committee, where they hold 9 of 20 seats. If they can unite there and win over a few Democrats on some important tax votes, they might still have an impact on the final legislation.
Mr. Dole and Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House minority leader, met this afternoon to come up with a united Republican strategy, or at least to present a united face to the public. The two leaders agreed to assemble House and Senate Republicans from the Budget, Appropriations, Ways and Means and Finance committees this week to formulate common economic positions.
"I don't know whether you bridge the gaps entirely," Mr. Dole conceded in an interview after the meeting. "But if you don't stick together you are not much of a player around here. We have some who want an alternative package, some who don't. Some want no taxes. So we're not there yet."
The party's cacophony reached a particularly discordant pitch last week when two leading Senate Republicans offered differing visions of how the party should oppose the Clinton economic policy. Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a 1996 Presidential hopeful, announced he would propose an amendment to the Clinton budget capping domestic spending and eliminating the need to raise any Social Security, income or energy taxes.
 
Dole's Differing Strategy
 Mr. Gramm told reporters he opposed efforts by some Republicans to develop an alternative budget, with specified cuts, because "if we put a full-blown substitute out there, we're going to allow the President to do what he wants to do -- to change the subject."
Mr. Gramm added that he was confident the Republican Senate leadership would back his amendment, suggesting he had come up with the party alternative. But almost as he spoke, Mr. Dole rose on the floor to outline a far different program.
Mr. Dole said he wanted to cut about $100 billion from Mr. Clinton's proposed $178 billion in new domestic spending, while Mr. Gramm's amendment would cut all of it. Then, over the weekend, Mr. Dole said he wished Mr. Gramm had waited before proposing the amendment, and pointedly said he planned to talk to Mr. Gramm.
To complicate matters, Jack F. Kemp, the former Housing Secretary and another potential Presidential candidate, offered a third economic alternative. Dusting off some Reagan-era proposals, Mr. Kemp proposed to spur economic growth by reducing payroll tax rates, increasing the personal tax exemptions for families with children and indexing capital gains taxes, depreciation allowances and corporate tax rates.
 
Then There's the House
 "I have not heard any unanimity at all," said Senator James M. Jeffords, Republican of Vermont. "There is no coalescing between either the supply-siders or the cutters."
Meanwhile, Senate and House Republicans have been slow to coordinate strategies. Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, ranking Republican on the Budget Committee, has been busy compiling a list of budget cuts, an effort some Senate Republicans fear could draw the ire of special interest groups away from the President onto their party.
"It may well be that Kasich and the House Republicans will introduce their own plan," Mr. Chafee noted. "We have enough trouble getting a solidified position out of 43 Republican Senators without getting into complete lockstep with the House."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bob Dole, second from left, the Senate minority leader, and Robert H. Jim Whittinghill, far left, Mr. Dole's deputy chief of staff, and Billy Pitts, far right, an aide to Mr. Michel, listened. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: States Have Problem With 'Sin' Revenue: There's Less Sinning

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 1

 BODY:
To the dismay of lawmakers who have religiously depended on revenue from "sin taxes" on tobacco and alcoholic beverages to help balance state budgets, people are sinning less.
Across the Northeast and much of the nation, revenue from taxes on tobacco and alcohol has fallen by millions of dollars in recent years, driven down by health concerns, changing social mores and the opportunity to make cheaper purchases elsewhere -- legally or illegally. 
 New Jersey has the happy or unhappy distinction of being a leader in this trend. In the proposed 1994 budget that he presented last month, Gov. Jim Florio adjusted the estimated income from 1993 taxes on cigarettes and alcoholic beverages from $357 million to $333 million. And the administration now projects that revenue from sin taxes will drop $17 million more in the 1994 fiscal year, which begins on July 1.
In New York, officials are expecting revenue from alcohol taxes to fall by $6.6 million in the new fiscal year, to $229 million, and cigarette and other tobacco tax receipts to tumble by $32 million, to $525 million.
In Connecticut, revenue from cigarette taxes for 1992-93 is expected to approach but not exceed the nearly $63.8 million the state made in 1991-92. Income from alcohol taxes is expected to fall at least $2.5 million from the $23 million of a year ago.
If the decline continues as expected, tax officials say cash-poor state and local governments will be forced to raise other taxes, impose new ones or cut services.
Even as states are beginning to realize the limitations of sin taxes, Federal officials are growing more interested in them. On Thursday President Clinton strongly suggested for the first time that he would propose higher taxes on tobacco to pay for his health-care program, saying that "bad health habits" had cost the country a lot of money.
"The golden goose of sin taxes is just about cooked," said Ronald Alt, a senior research associate with the Federation of Tax Administrators, based in Washington. The federation is a nonprofit group representing tax agencies in all 50 states, the District of Columbia and New York City.
 
Smaller Part of State Revenue
 "Excise taxes generate much smaller percentages of state revenue then they did 10 to 20 years ago," said Mr. Alt, citing statistics from the United States Census. "Excise taxes fell from providing 26 percent of budget revenue for the states in 1972 to 16 percent in 1991."
Besides alcohol and tobacco, excise taxes are imposed by various states on gasoline, telephone calls, heating and electricity, car registrations and, in New Jersey, Atlantic City casino profits. But alcohol and tobacco taxes have historically been the easiest to raise, in part because religious teachings have long singled out drinking and smoking as sins.
Many people trace the beginning of the drain on sin taxes back to 1964, when the Surgeon General's report cited health problems caused by cigarette smoking. More recent reports have addressed the dangers of alcohol, especially to pregnant women.
Other factors have resulted in a precipitous drop in the number of drinkers and heavy smokers over the past five years: restrictions on smoking in restaurants and workplaces, an increase in anti-smoking education programs, and a trend among younger adults for less expensive drinks with lower alcoholic contents, like wine and beer over bourbon or vodka.
 
Taxation as a Curb
 Anti-smoking groups, like the American Lung Association, and some insurers argue that sin taxes should be raised even higher, not to raise money but to force people to stop or at least sharply curtail smoking and drinking. In the case of young people, they say, an added economic burden may be enough to keep them from starting the habit. If their theory is true, the next generation of politicians would not be able to depend on sin taxes.
Tax officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut say that higher sin taxes do force some people to give up cigarettes or alcohol. But in many cases, especially with smokers, a person might simply cross the border to a state with lower taxes to stock up on tobacco products.
Residents of southern New Jersey routinely drive across the border into Delaware to buy cigarettes, which are taxed at 24 cents a pack with no sales tax. In New Jersey, the state tax on a pack of cigarettes is 40 cents, plus a 6 percent sales tax. Still, some New York City smokers cross the Hudson River to stock up on cigarettes in New Jersey to avoid their local 47-cent tax on cigarettes (39 cents state, and 8 cents city) and 8.25 percent sales tax.
Mr. Janschewitz, the Connecticut tax official, describes the practice as "border hopping" and complains that it costs the state millions in revenue.
 
Big Bootlegging Trade
 "We only have 15 police officers to patrol the borders, and until we erect a wall around the state there is not going to be any effective means to keeping someone from hopping across the border to Massachusetts or New York State to take advantage of lower rates," he said.
In New York, bootlegging, hijackings, warehouse thefts and the counterfeiting of cigarette tax stamps are big business, said Karl E. Felson, a spokesman for the New York Department of Taxation and Finance. He said there is also an increasing problem with untaxed cigarettes being smuggled from Indian reservations.
The erosion of sin taxes as a reliable and easy source of income could not come at a worse time for budgetmakers and politicians who have traditionally used them to avoid imposing or increasing more politically unpopular taxes on incomes and sales.
In a report due for release this month, the Council of State Governments, based in Lexington, Ky., calls sin taxes "a worn-out tax source" and warns states to begin immediately to look for new sources of revenue to pay for health care, schools, prisons and other costs.
 
'May Be Fooling Themselves'
 "States looking for cash may be fooling themselves by turning to tried and true taxes," Doug Olberding, a research associate with the council, wrote in February in the group's magazine, "State Government News." "Old standbys like the cigarette, motor fuels and traditional sales tax are likely to leave states spinning their wheels when it comes to generating future revenue growth."
The council's report has already generated controversy, because it was fully financed by Philip Morris, the tobacco company. But even greater anger was provoked by the report's conclusion that state and local governments should begin to impose taxes on service industries.
"When you get your hair cut, the barber may be paying sales taxes on the supplies he is using, but there is no tax on the haircut itself," Mr. Olberding said in an interview. He said the same rationale should apply for the services of an automobile mechanic, a person who writes a computer program or the one who designs an advertising campaign.
"I kind of got it from all sides," said Mr. Olberding, "advertising organizations, labor groups, the American Lung Association. There are a lot of political and practical problems to taxing services, but it is something states are going to have to look at."
 
Taxation's 'Cash Cows'
 Until recently, Connecticut depended on its sales taxes and taxes on cigarettes and alcohol to provide most of the income to run the state.
"Up until 1991, the sales tax was the workhorse, but the sin taxes were looked at as the cash cows," said A. J. Janschewitz, a spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Revenue Services. "They could be racheted up fairly politically painlessly. The idea was we are going to impose more taxes on things that are bad for you."
But even after its tax on a package of cigarettes reached 45 cents, the highest of any state, Connecticut went on to impose its first state income tax two years ago.
Revenue continues to drop from sin taxes, which together with gift taxes, a tax on oyster beds and several other minor taxes account for 15 percent of Connecticut's revenue.
"It is hard to say which well we are going to turn to when the sin taxes well starts to go dry on us," Mr. Janschewitz said.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 3, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about taxes on alcohol and tobacco misstated the financing of a report by the Council of State Governments. It was supported partly, not fully, by Philip Morris, the tobacco company.

HEADLINE: CRISIS AT THE TWIN TOWERS: Vignettes;
Going Back to Work, or Then Again, Maybe Not

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
The chic wore "I Survived Terror at the Towers" T-shirts. The disgruntled waited on hourlong lines to retrieve winter coats, wallets and keys under escort from offices in the twin towers. The cognoscenti at the commodity exchanges trafficked in rumor. "Saddam Hussein is behind this," a man called to a friend in an elevator. "That's what's circulating on the oil floor."
And then there were people like Cynthia Ortiz. 
 She conquered her fear of another bomb. She rode the PATH train from Jersey City, falling into a hush as everyone else did when the train entered the World Trade Center station. But when she reached her unheated office at Dean Witter, Discover & Company, she hadn't even had time to change out of her sneakers before finding that other, more essential employees from one of the closed twin towers had taken over her desk.
"When we came in to work today the supervisor said we shouldn't have come in," said the 22-year-old clerk, roaming the chaotic trade center concourse hand-in-hand with her co-worker Lisa Vazquez from the Bronx. Both were giddy and bewildered by their unexpected day off. "We don't know what to do," she wailed. "We're used to coming to work."
Three days after a bombing trapped thousands of workers in the chaos of collapsing floors, stuck elevators and smoke-filled, dark stairwells, a third of the 12-million-square-foot World Trade Center complex was open and thousands back at work. Many more employees milled about, almost as a statement of pride and grit even if there was nothing for them to do.
"It's New York. It's just a typical day in New York," said Daniel Fanelli, a clerk in the Sugar, Coffee and Cocoa Exchange, who was smoking in the impromptu smoking corner that had sprung up in the lobby of 4 World Trade Center since fire marshals had banned smoking in the building.
People were even, well, nice. "The people are very kind. I think more kind," said Elena Kachkina, selling coffee and pastry at the fast-food shop Sbarro, and surprised that customers wanted to linger and chat.
 
Time for Coffee Now
 Business was off through much of lower Manhattan yesterday. But not for everybody. At the Essex World coffee shop at Liberty and Church Streets near the trade center, it was like the golden days of the 1980's.
"Business dropped 50 percent since the crash of '89," said Tasso Mouhteros, 38, an employee. But yesterday, counters and tables were packed for breakfast and lunch as the disaster left people with time to kill.
"If we have to wait for a bomb to go off, that's pretty sad. It's horrible," Mr. Mouhteros said. But he added, "Everybody was joking today, 'Let's have another bomb.' "
Friday was the unexpectedly busy day for J.R. Tobacco, a cigar store at Broadway and Vesey Street. "It was like Christmas in here," said the manager. "One guy came in, he walked down 70 flights of stairs. He had smoke on his face, and he bought a box of cigars."
 
Tables of Experts
 The Big Kitchen, a sprawling room on the concourse level of the World Trade Center, was a cafeteria. But now it's a one-stop-shopping, 24-hour command center for the hard-hatted forces marshaled from Government agencies and private firms to repair the damage to the bombed complex.
Bleary-eyed and sustained by countless cups of coffee, they plot strategy over blueprints and shout commands into walkie-talkies in a room that looks like a crowded convention hall -- complete with dozens of tables adorned with signs like "Plants and Structures," "Asbestos" and "Otis Elevator."
"We're trying to compress decisions and implementation into a very difficult time frame," said Frank Lombardi, an assistant chief engineer at the Port Authority who is overseeing more than 10 engineering firms and contractors.
Officials said they initially faced difficulties organizing their efforts because they lacked computers and files that were in Port Authority offices in the towers.
Paul S. Marchese, chief of planning and design at the World Trade Center, said that over the weekend, he had to send police officers to offices around New York City to retrieve blueprints of the center. The plans have proved so vital to the repair operation that clerks have been making copies of them around the clock. A basic set is about 100 pages long and 2 inches thick.
"Within minutes of the explosion, we lost every system we had," said Mr. Marchese, who by yesterday morning had slept only six hours since the explosion. "We were just crippled. Everything was on computers upstairs in the towers. We were pulling drawings out of the archives."
 
Not Perfect Timing
 Just three days after the bombing downtown, there in Times Square yesterday was a five-story hot-air balloon of Arnold Schwartzenegger brandishing three sticks of dynamite in his left hand and a gun in his right.
For pedestrians who usually seem unfazed by the preachers, the peddlers and the beggers, it was too much. "I think it's pretty sick, absolutely crazy," said Tim Camroy. "I think it's terrible with what happened at the World Trade Center."
"Oh my God," said one woman as she stopped in front of the puffed-up Schwarzenegger, which was dressed in Ostrich boots, blue jeans, red T-shirt and brown leather jacket. "That's awful."
The balloon is a prop for "Last Action Hero," a movie in production by Columbia Pictures. Chance Helburn, a production assistant, called the timing a coincidence. "It's too bad," he said, "but this has been planned to be here for months."
 
Opportunity Knocks
 The World Trade Center explosion may be a disaster for many. But not all. Faster than an express subway, entrepreneurs have descended.
"I see a building blow up in the heart of the world, but I also see opportunity," said Ronald Bowman, who leases office space at the Newport Financial Center in Jersey City and who began working to steal companies from the complex within 45 minutes of the blast. "Where there's adversity, there's also opportunity."
Lumbermen, cleaners, electricians, promoters, salvage experts, office-supply salesmen -- all had the same dream of a fast dollar. There were several T-shirt makers. Their words were slightly different, but the idea was the same: "I Survived Terror at the Towers," or "I Survived the Twin Towers Disaster."
Most scoffed at any suggestion they were benefiting from others' misfortune and described themselves as commercial Darwinists, businessmen fighting to survive. "As much as I feel the pain of the loss of life, I'm in the business of leasing space," Mr. Bowman said. "I don't pretend to be benevolent."
Several real-estate salespeople and owners of commercial buildings bought ads in yesterday's newspapers touting their properties. Sylvan Lawrence Company advertized space in the nine downtown properties it manages and prepared a mailing to all of the World Trade Center's tenants.
Many leasors said they would accept short-term deals in the hope that a brief stay would lead to a long-term relationship. "A doctor who does a job with minor surgery is the one you'll go to if you need a major operation," said John Brod, managing director of Koeppel Tener Riguardi, which ran several ads for space.
And The New York Post, which is in the process of being acquired by Steven Hoffenberg, ran a four-inch-by-two-inch ad offering World Trade Center companies "computer-ready space, with phone and fax equipment, and support staff" at the paper's plant in lower Manhattan. Needy readers were instructed to call Hirschfeld Realty, whose primary owner is Abraham Hirschfeld, at a number accompanying the ad. Mr. Hirschfeld has announced he will be an investor in The Post. But the number was wrong. Post operators referred inquiries to the classified advertising department, which also gave a caller the wrong number.
Karla Kaudatzky, an agent with Galbraith Riverbank, which manages 90 West Street, said walk-in trade has been so heavy that she expects to sign several tenants by the end of the week. And in the best news for commercial property owners, she said she thought she could avoid the up-front concessions that became de rigueur during the recession.
"What happened in the World Trade Center puts us in a better position to negotiate harder," she said.
William Goldstein, the World Trade Center's deputy director for capital programs, said that while the explosion is a blow to the region's economy, which is just emerging from the recession, reconstruction and repair of the complex will pump millions of dollars into the depressed construction trades. "It's not exactly the way we wanted to prime the pump, but there's a lot of work to do," he noted.
 
Big Business Headaches
 And then there were the big businesses. The ones with workers suddenly scattered at temporary quarters all over the metropolitan region.
At Eurobrokers, a money broker at 1 World Trade Center that gives major banks and securities dealers a market for borrowing and lending dollars, the lack of direct phone lines in temporary office space was costing business, said Keith Riehl, chief financial officer, who was answering the phone yesterday at one temporary office in the New York Telephone building at 100 Church Street.
Eurobrokers uses its office-to-office lines to call customers instantly, avoiding the regular telephone system, Mr. Reihl said. "We normally have anywhere from 400 to 500 direct lines," he said. "It's possible we'll get some on Wednesday or Thursday. But our customer will be talking to someone else that got hold of him sooner, and he'll trade with him."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 4, 1993, Thursday

An article on Tuesday about people who returned to work after the explosion at the World Trade Center referred incorrectly to the company that manages 90 West Street, an office building in lower Manhattan, and to an agent for the company. The company is Galbreath Riverbank; the agent is Karla Kudatzky.

HEADLINE: Cyclicals Fall, as Dow Slips 15.40, to 3,355.41

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Transportation stocks and other cyclical issues fell sharply yesterday as investors struggled to spot the implications of the latest economic statistics against the backdrop of President Clinton's budget proposal.
After an initial rally, apparently animated by gains in the bond market, the Dow Jones industrial average retreated, ending the day with a decline of 15.40 points, to 3,355.41. The Dow transportation average, meanwhile, plummeted 33.44 points, or 2.2 percent, to 1,484.66. 
 Trading was a relatively light 237 million shares, as some traders and money managers moved from the World Trade Center and others were distracted by the commotion.
More than five Big Board issues advanced for every four that declined, as the pullbacks in cyclical issues accounted for the drops in most market averages.
The truckers, airlines, metals, papers, computers and chemicals that fell tended to be among the stocks most sensitive to the economy. Yesterday's batch of economic figures suggested slower growth than at the end of last year, but strategists were cautious about blaming these numbers or President Clinton's plans for the market's performance.
 
'Revelations' Come Slowly
 "We're in a period of confusion," said Byron R. Wien, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley. "Unfortunately, the stock market is open every day, but revelations about what the new plan means to the economy come only slowly."
Among transporation issues, the Xtra Corporation, a trucking company, fell 2 points to 83 7/8; Federal Express 1 7/8, to 54 1/2; Delta Air Lines 1 5/8, to 47 5/8, and Ryder System 1 1/2, to 27 3/4. Proposals for higher energy taxes deepened the declines, analysts said.
The damage was widespread among heavy industries, as the USX steel group fell 2 3/8, to 34 7/8; Inland Steel 1 3/4, to 20 3/8; International Paper 1 1/8, to 63 1/8, and B. F. Goodrich 1, to 41 3/4.
Some analysts pointed out that the economically sensitive stocks until recently have run ahead of the rest of the market, and were now pulling back.
"You have increased the gap between the cyclicals and noncyclicals to an unsustainable level," said Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist at Kemper Securities. "We are probably in the process of filling the gap."
 
Tobacco Stocks Off
 The threat of a higher Federal tobacco tax to pay for changes in the nation's health-care system continued to afflict tobacco stocks, with Philip Morris off 1 7/8, to 65 1/4, and RJR Nabisco off 1/8, to 8 3/8, both on heavy volume. Medical stocks, however, staged a comeback.
Some negative reviews from analysts pounded stocks including Compaq Computer, off 3 3/8, to 41 7/8, and H & R Block, off 3, to 38 3/8 -- in the middle of tax season, yet. Microtest Inc., which supplies computer networking equipment, fell 7 points, to 7 1/2, after reporting slower sales and increased competition.
 
Nasdaq Composite Down
 A broad retreat in the major computer issues pulled the Nasdaq Composite index down 1.26 points, to 669.51. Dell Computer fell 1 5/8, to 30 1/2; Adobe Systems 1 5/8, to 43; Oracle Systems 1 1/4, to 31 1/2; Microsoft 1 7/8, to 81 1/2, and Intel 1 1/4, to 115 1/4.
The smaller Nasdaq stocks finished virtually even, however, as the Russell 2000 gained 0.02 point, to 222.43.
Friday's explosion at the World Trade Center slowed activity even among many brokerage firms that were not forced to find new quarters themselves. Thomas Gallagher, the head of trading at Oppenheimer & Company, spent much of the day figuring out how to accommodate the visiting staff of the mutual fund group that his firm used to own. That group is now normally based in the World Trade Center, which is just across the street from Oppenheimer's offices.
Mr. Gallagher spent much of the day away from the trading desks, but had few regrets. "This was just to be neighborly," Mr. Gallagher said. "Next time, it could just as well be our building."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Digital to Show New PC's, Expanding a Product Line

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

 BODY:
The Digital Equipment Corporation, continuing its effort to become a major competitor in personal computers, will display a new family of machines today.
The new DECpc MT line extends the family of computers the company introduced last summer -- machines that Digital is designing and building itself. In some of its previous efforts to sell personal computers, Digital bought and resold machines from other companies like Tandy and Olivetti. 
 The new systems, all based on the Intel 486 microprocessor, are more powerful and expandable versions of the LP line of personal computers that Digital introduced last summer. They are also designed to be quiet and compact for machines of their power class.
 
On, Not Under, the Desk
 Enrico Pesatori, vice president and general manager of Digital's personal computer business unit, said the new machines included increased storage capacity, expansion slots and a larger power supply, all built into a 17-inch-high box that fits on a desktop. A system this powerful generally must be built as a much larger box or "tower" that sits under or next to a desk. The machines also have a two-speed fan, for quieter operation when the computer is not running at full capacity.
The MT machines will sell for between $2,350 and $2,800, $250 more a system than DEC LP machines.
Mr. Pesatori, who arrived at Digital from Zenith Data Systems four weeks ago, acknowledged that Digital was still a relatively minor force in the personal computer wars.
"We're a slice of the pie," he said, "but a slice for someone on a diet."
 
No. 7 in PC's
 Daniel Ness, a researcher with Computer Intelligence, a La Jolla, Calif., market research firm, said Digital had made significant inroads in the personal computing market in just a year, leaping from 22d in market share to 7th. He added, though, that Digital held only 2 percent of the market.
Mr. Pesatori predicted that the company would probably rank as high as fifth in the personal computer industry in two years.
Neal Hill, a consultant with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., said, "Digital is starting to really leverage its strength." He said Digital engineers had always built machines with an emphasis on superior design and engineering.
Mr. Hill added that Digital was able to offer prices competitive with those of low-priced direct-mail distributors like Gateway 2000, a feat he described as "quite stunning for a large company like Digital." He predicted that Digital would generate $1 billion in personal computer revenues this year, "which makes them a serious player."
"This," Mr. Hill said, "is probably the first of many aggressive strokes we will see from Pesatori."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The World Trade Center Crisis
Damaged World Trade Center buildings may have to remain closed for a month, which would intensify problems for 350 banks, brokerage houses, law firms and other tenants. [Page A1.] 
 Questions remain over which businesses displaced by the trade center explosion qualify for Government assistance. [B6.]
 
The Economy
More signs of a slackening recovery were reported. Leading indicators edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent in January and sales of new homes posted their biggest drop in 11 years. [D1.]

International

HEADLINE: Neediest Cases Drive Ends With Surge

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Despite a grinding recession that has provoked fears of growing hardship, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended its 81st annual campaign on Sunday with its second-highest total ever. Nearly 14,000 donors from around the world helped the appeal raise $4,469,034.47.
The fund initially fell sharply behind the last campaign's pace, but it gained ground over the last month. The surge is a testimony to the compassion of readers who responded to predictions that thousands of people might go without food, clothing, shelter and health care if the campaign did not reach its goal. 
 In the end, the fund fell short of last year's appeal, a record $5,083,550.81, but it passed the 1990-91 effort, which took in $4,439,093.47.
"Thanks to a vigorous spurt in donations during the last few weeks, the drive ended with the second-best year in our history," said Arthur Gelb, president of The New York Times Company Foundation, which administers the Neediest Cases. "On behalf of all the benefiting charities, we are grateful to our contributors who made this possible."
 
Reflected in Lives
 But the numbers do not tell the whole story. The success of the Neediest Cases campaign is reflected in the lives of people across New York City -- from Rene P. Velez of Brooklyn, who has taken enormous strides in conquering mental illness, to Alice Jones of Harlem, who has drawn strength from the Children's Aid Society as she rears her two grandsons.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was founded in the early years of this century by Adolph S. Ochs, then the publisher of The Times. He reasoned that if the newspaper's readers knew about the suffering around them, they would be eager to give.
He was right. The fund has raised tens of millions of dollars since then from hundreds of thousands of donors who felt that they could not turn their backs on New York City residents facing daunting challenges.
This year's total included dozens of checks from people who were honoring the memory of Patrick Daly, the principal in Red Hook, Brooklyn, who the police said was slain in the crossfire of a drug dispute. Others paid tribute to Arthur Ashe, Thurgood Marshall and Audrey Hepburn, all of whom died recently.
 
Praising Donors
 The 1992-93 appeal ended on Sunday, but additional donations will be accepted throughout the year and recorded in the next campaign, which will begin in late November. The Times pays the fund's expenses, so all contributions go directly to seven charities in New York City.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Serves Clinton Familiar Doubts

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
He ate birthday cake with the House Republicans. The Senate Republicans fed him a Big Mac and fries.
It was all smiles on both sides of the aisle today as President Clinton made his first trip to Capitol Hill to confer with Republican lawmakers, and they expressed their gratitude with his beloved junk food. 
 But beyond the conviviality and the french fries, the meetings ended with the Republicans' repeating their familiar misgiving about the President's economic plan, which, they say, is too laden with tax increases and too light on spending cuts.
 
Clinton Seeks Consultation
 Conferring first with House Republican leaders, and then over lunch with Republican Senators, Mr. Clinton said his aim was "to consult," not negotiate, over his economic program. At both sessions, participants said, the President delivered brief get-acquainted messages and then opened himself to questions on everything from the economy to health care to welfare reform.
It is virtually unheard of for a President to go to Capitol Hill expressly to call on lawmakers from the rival party. Congressional veterans said they could not recall a similar session in recent years.
And many Republicans seemed pleased, even grateful, for the attention. "The President of the United States is a charming fellow," said Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee.
 
Warning Amid Friendly Talk
 The participants said the talks were cordial, with Mr. Clinton often calling members by their first names. But the Republicans did not hold back in questioning elements of his economic program, particularly the proposed energy tax. And they warned him not to combine it with his health-care package, a move that many Republicans complain would create enormous tax increases. White House officials had said they were considering that combination idea to help ease the programs' passage through Congress.
After the session, some House members said Mr. Clinton suggested that he had not proposed more budget cuts because they would not have been acceptable to Congressional Democrats.
"The message was, and the real point of the story is," Mr. Kasich said, "is that he indicated frustration with being able to get any spending cuts through this Congress."
But White House officials denied that Mr. Clinton had put out that message. "We haven't had a vote yet on it," said Howard Paster, the chief Congressional liaison. "There's no way he would have expressed that. What the Congressmen are expressing was that they made it clear to him that his interest in cutting the deficit was real, and he wants Congress to join him in doing that."
Despite such different interpretations, White House officials and Republican lawmakers alike pronounced the meetings a success. But no one was willing to say that Mr. Clinton had won converts to his economic plan.
 
Toward Understanding
 "He made a lot of friends he already had," said Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader. "But converts? I think that wasn't the purpose of the session."
Mr. Paster said: "I'm not sure we came away with any votes. But I'm sure we came away with people understanding Bill Clinton better. And we hope some votes as well."
Administration officials said the goal of the meeting was more than winning support for the economic program. They said that they were confident they had a majority of House Democrats supporting the plan and that what they were now seeking was the support of a handful of Senate Republicans who might be needed for a majority in that chamber.
One Republican whose vote Mr. Clinton may be able to win, Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, said he was impressed with Mr. Clinton's presentation. "He was in great form," said Mr. Hatfield, the ranking Republican on the Appropriations Committee. "He handled it in a Q-and-A format, and he spoke in a straightforward way with great knowledge of the issues."
Leon E. Panetta, the White House budget director who was a veteran House Democrat, said he did not expect support for the economic program among House Republicans. But he said that their backing did not really matter.
"In the Senate," Mr. Panetta said in an interview, "the question becomes: How many Democrats will you lose? If you can't hold the Democrats together, there may be a point where you have to begin to negotiate with Republicans."
 
Other Goals Suggested
 But Senator Daniel R. Coats, Republican of Indiana, suggested that the President had more ambitious goals in mind in his visit to Capitol Hill. "He doesn't necessarily need one Republican vote in order to pass this program," Mr. Coats said. "But he needs to determine whether he needs to work with Republicans on longer-range issues like health care, like welfare reform, like a second-year budget. He obviously runs the risk of reaching out to Republicans with additional spending cuts only to lose people on his side."
The spectacle of Mr. Clinton clowning around with Republicans may be short-lived. Those he met with included some of his harshest critics, like Mr. Dole and Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, and they will no doubt return to that role soon enough.
For the cameras, it was all fun and games. First, Mr. Clinton presented a vanilla-frosted cake with a Capitol dome and blue sparklers to Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader, on his 70th birthday. Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore joined about 50 Republicans in singing "Happy Birthday" and then the President said, "I realize this is against my best interests, but I'm going to invite you to make a wish."
Mr. Michel responded, "I don't know if your economic plan is going to be like cutting a piece of cake or not."
The President then gave Mr. Michel a copy of a black baseball cap worn by the Chicago Cubs in 1914, and said, "We're both long-suffering Cubs fans."
He then strolled to the Senate side of the Capitol, where the Senate Republicans presented him with a $250 check for the jogging track he is building at the White House. They also gave him a huge veto pen to signify their support for a line-item veto.
In addition, Mr. Dole gave Mr. Clinton a book, "Murder in the Senate," by Senator William Cohen, Republican of Maine.
Noting that he had already read the book, Mr. Clinton said, "The guy who got killed is a Democrat, though."
To which Mr. Dole responded, "So, it had a happy ending."
Beneath the gags, the Republicans raised several serious topics. "Concerns were raised about some of the defense cuts, afraid of what it might mean to our ability to be able to defend our country and protect our freedom," said Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma. "There were concerns raised about the energy tax and how expensive it would be, and how many jobs it would cost. And on the overall economic package, as far as it being weighed too heavily on taxes."
Careful not to be too critical or too complimentary, the Republicans were perhaps waiting to see just how committed Mr. Clinton is to listening to lawmakers on hostile turf.

HEADLINE: Albany at Odds Over Revenue Figures

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 2

 BODY:
Only 29 days before the start of the new fiscal year, the Governor, the Assembly Speaker and the State Senate majority leader have yet to agree on how much money the state has to spend, much less how to spend it.
All three now believe that the state's economic prospects are improving somewhat and that revenues for the 1993-94 fiscal year will exceed the original projection made in January by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. 
 But the three estimates are separated by hundreds of millions of dollars, and the first political skirmish of this year's budget battle is expected to be defined by how the competing projections are reconciled.
Whatever revenue estimate is accepted, the state still will face a significant budget gap for the fiscal year that begins on April 1, leaving state leaders to negotiate heavy cuts in spending and increases in taxes and fees.
 
Proposal From Weprin
 Legislative and gubernatorial aides predicted today that they would agree on a revenue number relatively quickly. But even if they put that dispute to rest, their broader talks on the budget could be muddied if Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin proposes raising personal income tax rates for top wage earners.
Assembly officials said today that Mr. Weprin, a Queens Democrat, is considering such a proposal, which would mirror the tax increase envisioned by President Clinton. Mr. Cuomo and the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Long Island Republican, have vowed to oppose increases in the state's broad-based taxes.
The Governor's Budget Director, Patrick J. Bulgaro, announced today that he believes the state will collect $501 more in revenues for its general fund than the $31.5 billion in spending outlined by Mr. Cuomo in his Jan. 19 budget proposal. Most of the change in the estimate was generated by slightly more optimistic projections of personal income tax and sales tax collections, he said.
The Democratic Governor also announced today that the Federal Government had agreed to give the state an additional $200 million in Medicaid reimbursement for services provided by state psychiatric hospitals.
If all of that money is applied to the state's budget gap for the next fiscal year, the shortfall would shrink to $3 billion from $3.7 billion.
 
Disparity in Estimates
 The Democrats who control the Assembly said last week that they believe the state will collect $550 million in extra revenue. The Republicans, who hold a majority in the Senate, released a study on Monday putting the number at $749 million.
On paper, at least, the varying numbers can be attributed to the dismal science of econometrics, in which fractional differences in forecasts of gross domestic product and personal income growth can skew revenue estimates by hundreds of millions of dollars. But they also reflect the fiscal politics being played out in the Capitol among Mr. Cuomo, Mr. Weprin and Mr. Marino.
Mr. Cuomo, who is anticipating a tough re-election campaign in 1994, hopes to persuade voters that he used fiscal prudence to guide the state through a brutal recession. After having to borrow to avoid deficits at the end of four consecutive years, the state finally is running a surplus this year. Mr. Cuomo would like to showcase another surplus next year if he runs for re-election.
But legislators, almost by political definition, typically are more interested in providing services to constituents than in fiscal restraint.
The Assembly Democrats want more spending to soften some of the cuts Mr. Cuomo has proposed in social services and education programs. The Senate Republicans badly want to protect suburban schools from the $52 million reduction that Mr. Cuomo has proposed in education aid, to eliminate new taxes and fees, and to safeguard a dedicated transportation fund that Mr. Cuomo wants to raid.
 
Clear Political Opening
 But by embracing a revenue estimate that is higher than that projected by the Democrats, the Senate Republicans gave Mr. Cuomo a clear political opening that he is exploiting with relish.
"They might just as well have taken a wooden plaque with bronze letters on it that spell out 'I am a spender' and nail it to their foreheads," Mr. Cuomo said at a news conference on Monday.
Mr. Cuomo has cautioned against spending the new revenue recklessly. He maintains that only $202 million of the $501 million in new money can be considered recurring revenue, generated by a growing economy that the state can count on year after year.
 
Increase in Surplus
 The rest, he says, actually reflects an increase in the surplus for the 1992-93 fiscal year. Most of that tax revenue was generated by New Yorkers who received bonuses or took capital gains in late 1992 in anticipation of higher Federal tax rates in 1993.
Mr. Cuomo said today that the state should consider using some of the nonrecurring revenue as a reserve to cover losses incurred from the bombing of the World Trade Center and to pay anticipated judgments in a number of pending lawsuits.
He said his priorities for the recurring revenue would be to raise aid to education, minimize proposed cuts in Medicaid reimbursements for personal-care attendants, soften increases in a variety of fees and eliminate a tax on high-priced hotel rooms that may be driving tourism away from New York City.

HEADLINE: Defining the Suburban Borders of the Global Village;
A Fight for the Soul of Fairfield County Turns on What's on the Cable Television Dial

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
Are they Connecticut Yankees or displaced New Yorkers?
Consider Peter Justinius of Wilton, a 46-year-old antiques dealer and actor waiting here for his 8:06 A.M. train to Grand Central. "Without New York, Fairfield County is nothing," he said. "This is strictly a bedroom community." 
 Then ask Scott Cronin of Stamford, a 34-year-old restaurant manager who was taking the 8:51 north to New Haven. "I haven't been to New York City in six months," he said. "I could care less."
So goes the battle for the soul of lower Fairfield County, a long-running fight that erupted anew last month in a dispute over what television stations the county's residents will be able to watch on their cable system -- those from New York City or Connecticut.
 
Wealth and Prestige
 For decades, towns like Greenwich, Darien and Westport have been seen as paradigms of suburban wealth and prestige, all tied to the high-paying jobs of New York City. But many here say they are tired of being considered no more than a satellite of the nation's largest city. They also complain of being dismissed by legislators in Hartford, and residents elsewhere in Connecticut, as an island of wealth and big-city attitudes.
What Fairfield County wants, apparently, is an identity of its own. By many measures -- where they live, work, pay their taxes, shop and socialize -- people here are becoming less reliant on New York City.
"This is not an extension of New Yorks," said William Raveis, the owner of a large Fairfield County real-estate agency. "It's Connecticut. What was a quaint bedroom community 20 years ago has evolved into its own entity."
Those sentiments are not unique to Fairfield County. From Huntington, L.I., to Red Bank, N.J., the region's suburbs are growing less dependent on New York City for jobs, shopping and entertainment.
"There is a broad national pattern around every big city in which the urban cores have become much less important than they were 25 years ago, because jobs and people have moved out," said Kenneth Jackson, a professor of history at Columbia University and author of the 1985 book, "Crab Grass Frontier: The Suburbanization of the United States."
Nonetheless, he added, the links between New York City, Fairfield and the region's other suburbs are stronger than most.
"Manhattan is, as always, the country's most important downtown, and the suburbs will always be tied to it," he said. In the case of Fairfield County, he added, "an interdependent regional economy may be coming into conflict with Yankee independence."
What has sparked the current round of introspection in Fairfield County may come as a surprise -- cable television. In mid-February, the cable company serving the county, Cablevision Systems, said it planned to eliminate stations emanating from Hartford, Waterbury and New Haven, because much of their programming duplicated shows available on stations in New York.
Years ago, the announcement might not have caused a stir, because the airwaves of Fairfield County have always been bombarded by New York broadcasters. The county has no television station of its own, and long before the advent of cable and satellite dishes, Fairfield viewers simply turned their antennae south.
 
'Area of Dominant Influence'
 New York's dominance in Fairfield is demonstrated by market research. Since the inception of television, Fairfield and suburban counties stretching from eastern Long Island to south-central New Jersey, and the Pennsylvania border have been included by the broadcast industry in New York City's "Area of Dominant Influence."
The marketing concept is employed by advertisers and broadcasters to target their audiences and budgets. It is based on research by the Arbitron Company of Manhattan, which tracks how much time people across the nation spend watching television, and which stations they watch.
In its most recent report, for the year ending February 1992, Arbitron said it found that Fairfield County residents devoted 57 percent of their viewing hours to New York City stations, 22 percent to Connecticut stations and 19 percent to cable networks.
The New York City broadcasters' market share here, although dominant, was smaller than in most of the New York region. The same Arbitron report found that viewers in Westchester County, where there are few other options, spent 85 percent of their viewing time watching New York City Stations. The reaction to Cablevision Systems has been a firestorm of protest. Elected officials in Hartford said they would be cut off from their Fairfield constituents and many viewers said they already had too little access to Connecticut television news and were not about to see what remains of it disappear.
"More and more, Fairfield County has been identified with what is happening in the rest of Connecticut, and the news, sports and programming from our state is critical," said Richard Blumenthal, the Connecticut Attorney General, who lives in Stamford.
 
Petitioning State Regulators
 He has petitioned the State Department of Public Utilities Control to revoke Cablevision's franchise.
Last week the company offered a compromise: it would retain four of the five Connecticut stations it had planned to eliminate, but those stations must forgo payments they are entitled to under a new Federal law.
Analysts of Connecticut government say one reason for the intensity of the dispute is changes in state policy that have made the news from Hartford more important.
Chief among them is the imposition of a personal income tax in 1991. The tax was opposed most bitterly in Fairfield County, where many high-income New York City commuters had elected to live to avoid the income taxes of New York and New Jersey.
"Twenty years ago, you would have been right to say people in Fairfield focused on New York City and their own towns," said Harry Harris, vice president of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association, a business group in lower Fairfield County. "Now, they are looking for more information about their state. The income tax has only increased their interest."
Fairfield County's new interest in the affairs of its own state is also being fueled by the recession, and a widespread conviction here that officials in Hartford have shortchanged the county in spending for roads, bridges and other public projects.
"There has always been plenty of money for highway construction around Hartford, but very little at this end of the state," said Jacquelyn Durrell, the First Selectman of Fairfield.
 
A Split Personality
 By some measures, Fairfield County's split personality shows no signs of changing. State studies of commutation patterns show that the economic lifeline to New York City is as strong as ever.
In its most recent study, the Connecticut Department of Transportation looked at changes in commutation between 1985, when the region was in an economic boom, and 1990, when it had sunk into recession. It found that the number of people commuting into New York City from most parts of Fairfield County had increased 11 percent, to 33,975.
The only declines were in the county's most affluent towns, and the state attributed the downturn to deep cuts in executive employment on Wall Street and among companies in Manhattan. New York-bound commuting was down 30 percent from Darien, 22 percent from Westport and 13 percent from New Canaan.
But workers living elsewhere in the county streamed into New York City in far higher numbers, the report said. Manhattan-bound commuting rose 245 percent from Bridgeport, 68 percent from Danbury and 43 percent from Stamford.
The study also found large increases in the number of people living in Fairfield County who commuted to jobs elsewhere in the county. Experts said those increases continued a trend of more than 20 years, since dozens of corporations moved their headquarters, research and development operations or marketing operations into the county, mainly from New York City.
 
Divided Allegiances
 As the commuting data suggest, the county's residents remain divided on their allegiances. Mr. Justinian, the Wilton actor and antiques dealer, said he moved with his wife from Boston to Wilton in 1985, and has since become so captivated by New York City that he visits Manhattan at every opportunity.
"I want everything I can get from the city -- the news included," he said. "Cut me off from New York and I don't know what I would do."
But to many others, such big city ties are loose, frayed or completely undone.
"This is much less of a bedroom suburb than it used to be," said Joe Andrews, owner of Peter's Old Mill Deli, across from Westport's expansive beach on Long Island Sound.
Mr. Andrews, whose customers often include writers, advertising executives, actors and others with a distinctly New York City orientation, says he has nonetheless avoided entering Manhattan for 30 years.
"I'm happy to be surrounded by a mix of people, including folks from New York," he said. "But this is Connecticut, and this is where I want my news."
