HEADLINE: For Schwarzenegger, a Defusing

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Sensitive to the fact that New Yorkers are just a bit skittish about dynamite blockbusters these days, the producers of a new Arnold Schwarzenegger action film have defused a 75-foot-high balloon of their star that straddles the Armed Forces Recruiting Center in Times Square, replacing two sticks of dynamite in its left hand with a lawman's badge.
"There's not going to be explosives, there's going to be a badge," the chairman of Columbia Pictures, Mark Canton, said yesterday. "We want to make a strong statement about supporting the right people at this time. After all, Arnold's character is a hero." 
 The balloon, which serves as a promotional device for the movie but is also integral to the script, was erected on Monday afternoon but was deflated within hours amid concerns about the symbolism of the dynamite. With the dynamite replaced with a badge overnight, the balloon was reinflated yesterday, with a gun still in the right hand.
 
Small Consolation
 The defusing of the balloon may be small consolation to the estimated 12,000 drivers who have enough difficulty negotiating the crossroads of the world in a normal evening rush. But city officials believe that the filming of the movie "Last Action Hero" in Times Square over the next seven days is worth the inconvenience.
As Mayor David N. Dinkins said in a statement, "I believe this film project, which represents a return of the big-budget, major studio production to New York, is a turning point for the future of movie-making in our city." The Mayor conceded that there would be disruptions.
With production under way yesterday afternoon, Edwin Campos -- known as "Papa Smurf" to other bicycle messengers -- had to weave his way through backed-up, detoured cars. "Yeah, it's a bit uncomfortable," he said during an unscheduled stop, "but there is no traffic jam a good biker can't get through."
A spokesman for the city's Transportation Department, Joseph DePlasco, said all the Times Square street closings over the next seven days will be between 3 P.M. and 4 A.M. Today, 43d Street will be closed between Avenue of the Americas and Eighth Avenue, 44th Street will be closed between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, and Broadway will be closed between 45th and 43d Streets.
Tomorrow, Friday and Sunday, 42d Street will be closed between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. And on Monday and Tuesday, Seventh Avenue will be closed from 45th to 42d Streets, and 43d Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenues.
The official pleasure over production of a major movie in the city signals an end to a movie-making dry spell induced by an eight-month labor dispute in 1991 between the studios and film unions.
 
'New Economic Landscape'
 Pointing out that the unions eventually "gave back over 30 percent of their compensation package," the city's Commissioner of Film, Theaters and Broadcasting, Richard Brick, said yesterday that there was a "new economic landscape" for film makers in New York.
Mr. Brick pointed out that Columbia would spend in "excess of $3 million" during the film shooting. And Mr. Canton predicted that "if it goes well, which it will, it will be revitalizing to the film industry's potential for working in New York."
All well and good for the movie industry. But until they met with city officials last week, executives in the theater business were nonplussed at the prospect of streets blocked to ticketholders driving into the area.
"Specifically, we objected to the closure of 44th Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue," said Gerald Schoenfeld, chariman of the Shubert Organization. In what Mr. Schoenfeld called "an amicable resolution," the city and Columbia agreed to keep that street open.
Not so fortunate yesterday was Ricardo Brooks, who sells used paperbacks on Seventh Avenue. To accommodate the movie crews, a police officer had ordered Mr. Brooks to pack his books, fold his table and move on. Wondering if a business opportunity wasn't presenting itself, Mr. Brooks said, "I wouldn't mind somebody paying me to leave."

HEADLINE: THE TWIN TOWERS: Disaster Relief;
Recovery Aid Is Offered, But Not All May Qualify

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
With 350 businesses displaced by the World Trade Center explosion, local government agencies are preparing to distribute disaster relief in the form of small business loans, but major questions remain over who will qualify for another, Federal program.
New York City and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday they had dedicated a total of $5 million to help businesses cover the costs of finding temporary quarters through loans of up to $50,000. Officials said that they intended to approve the applications within 24 hours and that those who applied yesterday would begin receiving checks today.
 
Program Restrictions
 But a larger, Federal program, administered by the Small Business Administration, appeared to exclude financing for many companies operating in relocated offices after the explosion. The program is intended to provide low-interest financing of up to $500,000 to help small companies pay their employees and cover their expenses during disasters when they cannot operate. 
 Officials said that interest among the World Trade Center tenants in both of the government loan programs was likely to grow, because of the new assessment that the center's twin towers will be closed for up to a month. Many tenants had expected to return to the towers next week.
A spokeswoman for the Small Business Administration, Denise Scarpinsky, said the Federal agency would hold an informational meeting about its program tonight, from 7 to 9, in the World Trade Center concourse.
 
Service Center Open
 The agency said its representatives would also operate a service center in the concourse to accept loan applications from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. on Thursday, Friday and Saturday this week, and from Monday through Saturday next week.
Ms. Scarpinsky said it was not known how many businesses would qualify because the Small Business Administration, while familiar with the demands of natural disasters, had little experience aiding victims of a disaster like Friday's bombing.
Retailers and others who have been forced to shut down in the World Trade Center complex and elsewhere in Manhattan because of the explosion are expected to qualify, she said, because they will experience shortfalls in meeting payroll and other expenses.
 
Some Disqualified
 But for companies that continued operating, Federal assistance appeared unlikely yesterday. Ms. Scarpinsky said guidelines for her agency's program of "economic injury disaster loans" would disqualify those who are seeking to offset the cost of renting alternative office, transferring employees to other cities or leasing equipment temporarily.
The Federal loan program is being offered because New York City and its suburbs were declared an economic injury disaster area by President Clinton, at the request of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, on Monday. Assistance programs from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which are routinely available to victims of floods, hurricanes and other natural disasters, have not been offered.
Information and loan applications for all of the government programs are being dispensed at the former Alexander's Department Store in the World Trade Center concourse. For the New York City and Port Authority program, a processing center was set up yesterday to receive applications in the World Trade Center concourse.
 
Secured by Deposits
 New York State and Port Authority officials said yesterday that 270 of the 350 displaced companies would qualify for their loan program as small or medium-size businesses. The loans carry 4 percent interest and must be repaid within a year.
Although money for the program has been provided by the city and the Port Authority, it is being administered by New York State. Vincent Tese, Governor Cuomo's chief economic adviser, said the displaced companies would qualify with almost no questions asked because their loans will be secured by security deposits the companies have already paid as World Trade Center tenants.
He said 12 companies applied for the loans yesterday, seeking a total of $220,000. The amount companies receive will depend on how much space they lease; large tenants can get up to $50,000, but smaller tenants will see less, based on their square footage.
One of the 12 companies that applied yesterday was World Trade Jeweler, a jewelry store that has operated for five years on the concourse level under Tower 2. Alan Shabot, the store's owner, said he applied for the maximum that he was allowed, but it amounted to only $20,000 because he leases only 1,000 square feet of retail space.
"I think they are doing a heck of a job," Mr. Shabot said, adding that he expects to pick up his $20,000 check today and use part of it to cover the salaries of employees who have been idle since the explosion.

HEADLINE: Campus Journal;
For a Black Woman, Space Isn't the Final Frontier

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HANOVER, N.H.

 BODY:
As the first black woman to venture into outer space, Dr. Mae C. Jemison knows how it feels to boldly go where no one like herself has gone before.
The astronaut, who is also a medical doctor and a chemical engineer, has spent most of her 36 years entering arenas traditionally dominated by white men. 
 When people discouraged her, as they did from the time she was a kindergartner on Chicago's South Side to her collegiate days as a chemical engineering major at Stanford University, she ignored them.
"I never did believe there were these differences," Dr. Jemison said of racial and sexual stereotypes. "I always assumed I would go into space ever since I was a little girl. I would have applied to be an astronaut if there had never been a single person going into space."
That attitude is precisely what led Dartmouth College to invite Dr. Jemison to its Hanover campus, where she has been teaching a course on space-age technology and developing countries this term. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration granted her a leave of absence to accept a fellowship offer from Dartmouth and to live here and give lectures; it was her idea to teach the course.
"She has provided exactly what I was looking for," said Carol Muller, associate dean of the Thayer School of Engineering, who nominated Dr. Jemison for the fellowship. "I wanted someone who would be upbeat and inspirational who could acknowledge that there are barriers for women in science, but be a living example of not letting those stand in her way."
Whenever Dr. Jemison speaks to the college's 4,272 undergraduates about her experiences aboard the space shuttle Endeavour in September 1992 or about the need for all nations to participate in space exploration, her credo is clear: "Don't be limited by others' limited imaginations."
Although Dr. Jemison's main message to students is to believe in themselves, her presence on campus and in the classroom has served to underscore the importance of role models in undergraduate education, particularly for women and minorities interested in science and engineering.
Her class focuses on the potential use of satellite and telecommunications technology to improve health care in West Africa. As a medical officer for the Peace Corps in Sierra Leone and Liberia, Dr. Jemison was responsible for the corps's health-care delivery system in those countries.
Ms. Muller said Dr. Jemison's course had attracted more women and minorities than any other undergraduate course in engineering.
"Women usually make up about 25 percent of students in that building as opposed to half, and minorities are usually underrepresented in engineering," Ms. Muller said. Of the 29 students enrolled in the class, 13 are women and 12 are black. They include students majoring in fields as diverse as English, government and religion, as well as engineering.
Mark Harrison, a junior government major, said that he took the class primarily because he was interested in solving "real world" problems but that, as a black man, he was also intrigued by Dr. Jemison's accomplishments.
"There are few black doctors that you actually meet, and here's this black woman who is a doctor, an engineer and an astronaut," Mr. Harrison said. "It's inspiring to see that there aren't any fields where we are limited."
Despite many barriers having fallen, Dr. Jemison said people's image of scientists had failed to change. She recalled her kindergarten teacher's dismissive attitude when she told her she wanted to be a scientist. "You mean a nurse," Dr. Jemison recalled the teacher as saying.
Dr. Jemison said such responses would have to change if Americans wanted to be among the world's leaders in the next century. By the year 2000, less than 25 percent of the nation's high school seniors will be white males, she said, citing a 1987 report, "Workforce 2000," by the Hudson Institute, a research organization based in Indianapolis.
"If you don't want to be fair or ethical about it, there is a very crucial economic reason to encourage more women and minorities to pursue careers in the sciences," Dr. Jemison said. "I want to make sure we use all our talent, not just 25 percent."

HEADLINE: In Barrage of Ads, Stein Strives for Surge in Polls

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Stuck so far behind in early polls that he is fending off speculation that he may abandon the race, City Council President Andrew J. Stein is planning to open his bid for mayor with an extravagantly expensive media campaign that will bring the era of talk show politics to New York City.
The barrage of campaign commercials, Perot-style "infomercials" and audience participation specials -- which a Stein strategist said was likely to cost as much as $2.5 million over the next three to four months -- will coincide with the City Council President's formal announcement of his candidacy later this month. It promises to be one of the most expensive early openings to the New York mayoral race ever. 
 The city's political experts, who have been surprised by Mr. Stein's poor showing in public opinion polls, call the early media campaign a make-or-break move. Such tactics, they note, are usually employed by political unknowns striving to build a public image.
 
Confidence of a Year Ago
 Mr. Stein shrugs off his early problems, pointing to President Clinton as a model of how a candidate can come from behind. "In a way it's good it's sort of my turn for taking a lot of stuff in February," he said the other day, "because I'd rather have that in February than April or May or June."
Just a year ago, Mr. Stein, ever ambitious, but no longer the brash upstart of Manhattan politics, seemed near the pinnacle of his career, poised to challenge a struggling Mayor. He was so confident he talked of running on both the Democratic and Republican lines.
But after months as the presumptive challenger to Mayor David N. Dinkins, Mr. Stein has failed to pick up momentum. A number of early samplings of the public mood show Mr. Stein consistently running about 30 percentage points behind the Mayor among Democrats, hovering at about 20 percentage points to 50 percentage points for the Mayor.
Some potential supporters, including several who backed Mr. Dinkins in 1989, say cautiously that they are waiting to see if Mr. Stein can mount a credible candidacy. And while Mr. Stein has raised $4.7 million -- the most of any of the mayoral contenders -- his fund raising relies on a relatively narrow circle of rich business executives and longtime friends of his family. His parents gave him one-sixth of all the money he raised over the six months through January.
 
Vying for Liberal Nod
 Having made peace with Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former Federal prosecutor, has no challenger for the Republican nomination, although he and Mr. Stein are contenders for the Liberal endorsement.
In another blow to Mr. Stein, Herman Badillo, a former Bronx Borough President, has decided to enter the Democratic race. "Any anti-Dinkins vote that doesn't go to Andy, hurts Andy," said Norman Adler, a political consultant.
For months, politicians and consultants have speculated that Mr. Stein would drop out of the race. Now they say he might still withdraw if his media campaign does not produce results. But he insists that he is in the race to stay.
"I feel honestly that nobody is better prepared to be mayor than me," he said, so eager to show confidence that he hectors doubters. "You will see that we will be within six or seven or eight points by the middle of April. You can count on that."
The Stein campaign will borrow the talk-show tactics of the Presidential race, reaching out for viewers who warmed to Bill Clinton on the Arsenio Hall show, or called Ross Perot when he appeared with Larry King. Philip Friedman, Mr. Stein's campaign consultant, said 15-minute to 30-minute Perot-style "infomercials" were being planned, as well as audience participation specials and call-ins.
The television campaign will be supplemented by a book of prescriptions for the city's ills. The commercials are meant to reintroduce Mr. Stein and frame what he describes as crucial issues -- from crime to the economy to the need to reorganize city government -- in a way that will appeal to a target constituency.
Mr. Dinkins is expected to hold onto most of the black voters who make up about 30 percent of the Democratic primary electorate, and Mr. Stein is expected to do well among whites outside Manhattan. The swing groups are Hispanic voters and liberal whites, among them homosexuals, feminists and professionals.
 
'Needs a Second Chance'
 Mr. Stein, who is 48 years old, has been in the public eye for 25 years ever since he won an expensive East Side Assembly race, with financial help from his father, Jerry Finkelstein. He went on to become Manhattan Borough President and then City Council President, a job that is being renamed and diminished.
In the crucial last year, he has not worn well. A poll of 844 city voters conducted by the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion in February found that 48 percent of those polled had an unfavorable impression of Mr. Stein, up from 28 percent in September. "It shows that Stein needs a second chance to make a first impression," said Lee M. Miringoff, who directs the Marist poll.
Mr. Stein has ordered extensive polling and anaylsis in recent months. In the focus groups, some participants called him a rich kid manipulated by his father, or criticized his intelligence or toupees. "People have a slightly negative perspective and we find it in focus groups and polls," said one campaign aide, who spoke on condition that he not be identified.
But the findings have made the campaign take heart because the negative impressions are vague and personal and not tied to a stand on issues or performance in office. "You just see the whole shift in the dynamics when people hear me, they see me, they hear my views and they feel my personality," Mr. Stein said. "Basically, people just don't know."
He plans to speak about education, crime and the city's economy, issues that appeal to an array of interest groups. He will try to present himself as a Clinton-style untraditional Democrat with issues like privatization of city services, government reorganization and Civil Service reform.
Still, Mr. Stein will have the advantage of being the first well-financed contender to enter the mayoral race. In the six-month period that ended in January, Mr. Dinkins had raised about $3 million and Mr. Giuliani $2.25 million. Mr. Stein, alone among the three, has refused to abide by voluntary limits on contributions and spending and thus will not be eligible for matching public funds.
Although Roy Innis, president of the Congress of Racial Equality, announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination on Sunday, neither Mr. Dinkins nor Mr. Badillo have said when they would formally declare their candidacies.
For now, many of the people Mr. Stein cites as potential supporters are waiting to see whether he can get his campaign moving. "There's no question about the fact that he has nowhere to go except up," said City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, who said he expected to stay neutral in the Democratic primary.

HEADLINE: Layoffs and Factory Closings Shaking the Japanese Psyche

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 2

 BODY:
For years the popular mythology in Japan has been that plant closings and corporate layoffs were quintessentially American. Humane Japanese companies would rather accept losses than cast an employee into the street.
But throughout the country the dreaded phrase these days is "kata tataki," or "tap on the shoulder." Not only are industrial workers getting the tap, but even employees of the richest and seemingly most secure companies. 
 The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, which during Japan's boom was by some measures the world's largest corporation, said it was eliminating 30,000 jobs over the next several years, and many other companies are hinting they are next. With the dam now broken, no one doubts that more cutbacks are on the way.
The problem has been coming to the surface for months, dribbling out in late-afternoon corporate announcements and in tales seeping from the vast, cluttered rooms where Japanese managers and engineers and secretaries wend their way among battleship-gray desks.
 
Turning Off the Lights
 A group of lawyers who set up a telephone hot line in Tokyo last month to field complaints from aggrieved workers discovered the lengths to which some companies were going to force out employees protected by Japan's much-admired "lifetime employment" system. Among the hundreds of callers was a 51-year-old manager of an audio equipment maker who said he had been relocated to a basement office and then given no work. When he did not get the hint, the company dimmed the lighting week by week. He finally quit.
 
From Software to Saws
 Then there was the 44-year-old computer software manager in Tokyo who told the lawyers that he was redeployed to a distant subsidiary in Ishikawa Prefecture and given a new title, "education director." His job, it turned out, was to supervise his fellow workers, who had been handed saws and told to begin cutting down trees. He is still at it.
If there was a single moment that seemed to shake the national psyche and mark the end of a chapter in the postwar era, it came at the end of the daytime shift a few days ago at the Nissan Motor Company's Zama plant, a symbol for 30 years of the Japanese economic miracle. That was when the plant manager made a surprise announcement over the loudspeakers that the huge assembly line would shut down over the next two years. The 2,500 assembly workers would have a clear choice -- move to other plants, some of them far away, or quit.
"For Japanese workers the closing of a plant is something completely alien," a senior auto executive said, asking not to be identified because the subject is something no one in his company will discuss, except behind closed doors. "It is something that happens in the U.S., or on the other side of the earth. And now they are finding themselves stunned. They are saying, 'My God, it is at my doorstep.' "
 
Bad for America?
 The result could be as bad for America as it is for Japan. The Clinton Administration, Japanese officials say, will face a far chillier reception than ever before if it assembles a list of trade demands. With things this bad, Japan's industrial planners contend, they have little chance of twisting concessions out of Japanese companies.
Even the programs to close the trade gap with the United States seem imperiled. In Osaka, the industrial heart of the country, a $1.1 billion trading center is rising from an artificial island in Osaka Bay. But it has become a symbol of the turn of fortunes because with retail sales down sharply almost no one is interested in stocking the products from the United States and other nations that will be displayed in nearly four million square feet of floor space.
"These are the first signs of more to come," said Sozaburo Okamatsu, the director general of the international trade bureau at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. "The bubble hid a lot of restructuring that was overdue."
 
Business Blames Government
 Business executives, in contrast, blame the Government, saying it ignored the signs for far too long, and then stepped in with an economic stimulus plan that was too late and paltry.
Government officials say that the announcements sound far worse than they really are, and point to unemployment numbers, around 2.3 percent of the work force, that have barely budged. But workers and unions say the numbers are an elaborate fiction: The first layoffs hit part-time workers, mostly women, who are not counted in the figures; the second wave is a forced-retirement program aimed at workers 45 to 55 years old. Most of them have held only one job their entire lives, and are not likely to start looking for new work now.
"We have had recessions before, and sometimes blue-collar workers have been forced out," said Yosuke Minaguchi, the leader of the lawyers' group. "But this time is different. These are the white-collar graduates of the best universities who have had unquestioned loyalty to their companies over the last two decades or so."
In a few cases, the outcry surrounding the ouster of longtime employees has forced companies to back off. The management of TDK, a maker of magnetic tapes and electronic parts, had to withdraw a plan to force out older employees. The same happened at Pioneer, which was taken aback by the publicity surrounding its decision to dismiss more than 30 managers.
Employees at the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the maker of Panasonic electronics, say the pressure to retire early or move to an affiliate company is on. At Matsushita, according to one employee, people are left with little more to do in a new job after getting the tap on the shoulder than stare out the window.
The latest kata tataki victim is Matsushita's president for the last seven years, Akio Tanii. What first appeared to be a voluntary resignation was later seen as a palace coup, engineered by the founding Matsushita family.
 
Bush Trip Recalled
 Such events have led some Japanese to say what some foreigners have argued for several years: In the "bubble" of the 1980's the Japanese got arrogant and lost their usually unerring sense for the fundamentals.
Asahi Shimbun, one of Japan's largest newspapers, reminded readers that only 13 months ago the same auto makers that are twisting in the wind today had faced off against their American counterparts during President George Bush's trip to Japan. At the time, it noted, the companies "were not completely free from a sense of satisfaction for having climbed to the top of the world's automotive industry."
Similar humblings have come to normally conservative companies and banks that took wild risks in the stock and currency markets. The leadership of Showa Shell Sekiyu K.K., the Japanese subsidiary of Shell Oil, just resigned after revelations that management had lost $1 billion in bad currency trades. Yomiuri Shimbun, Japan's largest daily, said in an editorial that companies had deluded themselves and "consequently lost sight of their main purpose."
The experience is shaking Japan in many ways, said Robert Orr, a professor at Temple University's campus here and a longtime student of Japanese politics. "The salary scales are heavily weighted toward people over 50. So when you force them out early, you give them far smaller retirement packages."
 
The Export Solution
 Japan has had downturns before, of course. But in the past, there was always a clear solution: export more. Politically, that is the one thing Japan cannot do now, not with a trade surplus that has soared to record levels with the world, and near-record levels with the United States.
The situation is only worsened by the recent strength of the yen, which makes exports all the more expensive. Theoretically, imports should be getting cheaper, but Japanese consumers have made it clear they are in no mood to buy.
The Government has been debating several strategies, including a tax cut. But the Ministry of Finance has opposed it, arguing that in their cautious mood, Japanese consumers would simply put the proceeds into a savings account. That would leave Japan with a significant budget deficit, and nothing to show for it.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Radio-Frequencies Bill Advances

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
The House of Representatives today approved a bill that would require the Federal Government to free a big block of radio frequencies for commercial technologies like wireless pocket telephones and palm-sized computers.
The measure sailed through by a vote of 410 to 5. A similar measure has been introduced in the Senate, but Congressional Democrats may still find themselves on a collision course with President Clinton over how the new frequencies are handed out. 
 In his package of economic proposals, the President called for auctions that would sell rights to the airwaves to the highest bidder. The Administration says that these auctions could produce $4 billion in revenues over the next five years and that market-like bidding would lead to more rational use of the radio spectrum.
But the bill's sponsor, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, remains worried that auctions would cede control of a valuable and scarce public resource to big corporations with deep pockets.
The Government now awards licenses at no charge, either through luck-of-the-draw lotteries for services like cellular telephones and paging, or through long and complex comparative hearings for television and radio stations.
Both processes have been criticized by Democrats and Republicans as inefficient and as bonanzas for speculators who obtain licenses at no cost and resell them. Still, many lawmakers are hesitant to embrace auctions as the only alternative.
Debate over the idea of auctioning the airwaves has stalled the bill to free new areas of the spectrum, which is otherwise a popular piece of legislation.
 
Previous Stances
 The Bush Administration argued that no bill to reallocate frequencies should pass unless it authorized auctions. House Democrats sidestepped the issue, approving bills in 1990 and 1992 that were silent on the question. The Senate last year became bogged down over the question, with senators trying to craft a compromise that would authorize an experimental auction on a small block of frequencies.
The Administration entered the fray last week with a letter to Mr. Dingell that criticized the House bill for its silence on the auction question.
"This bill raises a number of substantial concerns," wrote Carol C. Darr, the Commerce Department's acting general counsel, who argued that auctions would bring a much-needed change to the current system.
The letter stated that auctions would encourage efficient use of the radio spectrum, because "assignments would be based on economic value to the user, as expressed by a willingness to pay." It also stated that auction revenues would help reduce the Federal budget deficit and that the auctions could be designed to give special consideration to entrepreneurs and nonprofit groups.
 
Some Shift Detected
 Mr. Dingell and his colleagues may be softening. In a letter last week, Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, a co-sponsor of the bill with Mr. Dingell, said he was "committed to considering an auction proposal" that would protect the public interest.
But he also demanded that the Administration put forward a detailed proposal that would leave room for cash-short small businesses and prevent companies from abusing the process.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Sociological Musings on Some Women's Search for Fellowship

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman

 BODY:
IN this age of collapsing sexual stereotypes we are about to tread on dangerous ground, examining the rise and glory of Wowee, which stands for Women of the World Eating Everything. It was almost three years ago that Eve Bigelow and her old Harvard roommate, Lucy Dineen, decided that what they needed was a forum where women could meet regularly and talk about the world.
"Ever since college it seemed that our men friends had club lives, with eating clubs and sports teams," said Ms. Bigelow, a fund-raiser for the American Civil Liberties Union. She got the idea soon after she came to New York from Egypt, where she had tried to teach poor farmers to raise rabbits. "We felt we needed something of our own." 
 At the first meeting, in August 1990, the six women who showed up decided to recruit women to attend monthly gatherings to be organized around some country or geographical area. A book might be assigned as a focal point for discussions and members would prepare and share foods associated with whatever region was chosen. They decided to call themselves "Cold Soup, Hot Ideas," but that very quickly gave way to Wowee.
The idea blossomed. By now there have been close to 30 meetings and more than 35 women, mostly in their late 20's and early 30's, have become involved. Last year when Ms. Dineen moved to Boston, she opened a chapter there and it is also thriving.
Just how comfortable the Wowee women have grown with the format and with each other was made clear at a regular monthly meeting last week.
This time the subject was Cuba. The assigned reading was "The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love." The 15 women who showed up brought many variations on rice and beans. There were also Cuban cigars for after dinner. Afro-Cuban jazz came from the CD player.
After chatting on matters personal and professional, the women gathered in a circle and began talking about the book, about Cuba. Were the macho qualities of the musicians in the book culturally accurate? What would happen when Castro eventually left the scene? Would Cubans stream here in greater numbers than the Haitians? Should they be welcomed even when they were no longer fleeing Communism? How did Cuba intend to encourage tourism while trying to keep its citizens away from the visitors?
It was good conversation but for this interloper the most striking thing was not the talk so much as the women themselves and the quality of their relationship. No one was scoring points, no one was embarrassed about not knowing something or about saying something that proved wrong or mistaken. The women, who included a graphic designer, several business executives, an economist who finds investment capital for third world women, two television producers and one assistant district attorney, were the kind of caring achievers featured in ads for The Gap.
Not to mince words, they were world-class humans. Yet their gathering was not so much sophisticated as homey, more like a quilting bee than a cocktail party, an assembly of friends, rather than of networkers or competitors.
And now -- and here is the pardoxical part -- this quality has gained Wowee the respect and even envy of the very clubby men whose own socializing had first inspired Ms. Bigelow. In a tongue-in-cheek but nonetheless admiring gesture, the men, among them husbands, boyfriends, former boyfriends and just friends of the Wowee women, have organized MEAT, which stands for Men Eating American Things. What they do is to try to get together to eat steak, drink beer and talk sports.
One of the main MEAT organizers, John Solomon, said that he had become fascinated with Wowee. "They were ready to read books just to talk with each other, they cared enough to cook for each other," said Mr. Solomon, who works as a program planner for Lifetime, a cable network that specializes in women's programming. "They really worked at their social life, really took pains for it. Would men do that? I don't think so. In fact the only time I see my men friends on any regular basis is at a weekly basketball game."
MEAT's first meeting was held at a steakhouse. There was also a summer cookout that was not badly attended. No books were discussed. Since then other meetings were considered but never materialized because nobody got around to calling anybody.
In January, a breakthrough was attempted, as MEAT and Wowee tried to hold a joint meeting on Vietnam at Ms. Bigelow's apartment. It turned out that the men were outnumbered 18 to 5 because the MEAT man in charge of invitations stumbled. The few who came brought no food, just beer, and had not done the reading. Ms. Bigelow's husband, John Baxley, said he thought it was a great idea but he had to leave to play a gig with his band, Foggy Notion.
What's this prove? Maybe just that women don't need to keep score as much as men do.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off as Outlook Dims For Lower German Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled lower on world currency markets yesterday as prospects dimmed for lower interest rates in Germany.
Gold prices rose worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $329.80 a troy ounce, up $1.20 from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold added $1.05 an ounce, to a late bid price of $329.40. 
 Dealers said the currency market had been full of anticipation that the Bundesbank would lower interest rates at a meeting scheduled for tomorrow. But the latest indications from the central bank are that rates will remain unchanged, at least in the near term.
Demand for the dollar was "muted largely after the speculators gave up on the Bundesbank easing rates," said Raja Ramachandran, an analyst with Technical Data in Boston.
James Maccario, chief dealer at the Bank of Boston, said there was virtually no reaction to a Commerce Department report showing the Government's chief economic forecasting gauge inched up a tenth of a percent in January. A separate report showed new-home sales plunged 13.8 percent in the same month, the biggest drop in 11 years.
"People aren't worried," Mr. Maccario said of the home sales figures. "It was an aberration" that may have resulted from bad weather, he said. Mortgage rates, which are at the lowest level in decades, are expected to spur buying in coming months.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 118.50 yen, up 0.07 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 117.73 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 117.73 yen, from 118.70 yen on Monday.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.4480, up from $1.4389 late Monday. In New York it cost $1.4485 to buy one pound, more expensive than Monday's $1.4385.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.6400 German marks, down from 1.6545; 1.5225 Swiss francs, down from 1.5375; 5.5640 French francs, down from 5.6116; 1,562.00 Italian lire, down from 1,571.00, and 1.2468 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2491.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
No Letup in New Municipal Issues

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The tax-exempt municipal market withstood another rush of new issues yesterday, with prices showing little change.
About $2 billion of new bonds were sold yesterday as the pace of sales seemed to show little slack after new issues set a record of $16.37 billion in February. That record total, however, barely surpassed the $16.04 billion set in February of last year, according to the Securities Data Company. 
 Donald Carey, director of municipal financial products at the First Boston Corporation, said the aggressive pricing of a $131.2 million issue by the Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York set the tone for a good day in the market. The issue, whose lead underwriter was Goldman, Sachs & Company, was oversubscribed, which allowed the price to be raised and the yield cut by 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
Tax-exempt bonds issued by New York State, New York City and other issuers in the state have been in demand recently because of their triple-tax-exempt status and the threat of higher Federal income tax rates.
Mr. Carey said the demand for municipal bonds was still being driven by the threat of higher tax rates. At the 36 percent top rate that President Clinton has proposed, a tax-exempt yield of 5 percent is equivalent to a taxable yield of 7.81 percent. And the yield would be 8.28 percent if a 10 percent surtax was added for taxable incomes exceeding $250,000 a year, bringing the effective top rate to 39.6 percent.
At the current top tax rate of 31 percent, the taxable equivalent yield of a 5 percent bond is 7.25 percent.
Mr. Carey also said that the higher-interest-rate bonds issued in the early 1980's were being paid off and that cash coming into the market would continue to give municipal bond prices support for some months to come.
Today, the market will be faced with an unusual new issue -- a $1.1 billion sale of bonds to pay for the design and building of a toll road in Orange County, Calif., by the San Joaquin Hills Transportation Corridor Agency, underwritten by First Boston. The principal and interest on the bonds will be paid off by the tolls from the road. The $2 initial toll will be one of the highest in the nation.
In the Municipal Assistance Corporation issue, the tax-exempt yields range from 2.50 percent for a bond due in 1994 to 4.10 percent in 1998, 4.80 percent in 2003 and 5.30 percent in 2008. For investors in the 31 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent yield would be about 3.62 percent for a bond due in 1994, 5.94 percent in 1998, 5.94 percent in 1998, 6.96 percent in 2003 and 7.68 percent in 2008. In the 36 percent tax bracket, the yields would be 3.91 percent, 6.41 percent, 7.50 percent and 8.28 percent, respectively.
 
Treasury Market
 Treasury prices were little changed yesterday. Traders said that after the rally on Monday brought the yield on bonds and notes back near their recent lows, investors and traders might settle into trading within a range until the February employment data are released Friday.
In the secondary market, the price of the 7.125 percent 30-year bond was up 2/32 , to 10322/32 , to yield 6.83 percent, down from 6.84 percent Monday. The 16-year low, reached a week ago Tuesday, was 6.82 percent.
The Cantor Fitzgerald Securities Corporation, a leading brokerage firm in the bond market, was still out of service yesterday because of the explosion at the World Trade Center on Friday. The firm matches buy and sell orders and is an important source of bond price data.
Since the explosion, the firm has been scrambling to find alternative office space. Dow Jones & Company, which distributes Cantor's price information to the market through its Tele-rate service, provided some space. And Salomon Brothers gave Cantor the space to build a temporary trading floor that is expected to be finished today.
Robert M. Mercorella, a managing director of Cantor, said yesterday, "We are hopeful that by tomorrow we are back in operation in government securities."

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Money Market Accounts Lower

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The average yields offered by banks on money market accounts and certificates of deposit for the week beginning today are down modestly compared with those offered the previous week, particularly among accounts with the shortest maturities and those at commercial banks.
According to The Bank Rate Monitor, the average yield on a six-month C.D. in the New York area has fallen a little less than the average decline for the same maturity at 20 big banks nationwide. The average decline for a New York money market account is also less than the decline at the 20 banks nationwide. 
 Average discount rates were mixed at the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills this week, with the three-month bill up and the six-month bill down. The auction is widely regarded as a harbinger of rate changes at banks.
The average rate at auction on Monday for a three-month Treasury bill was 2.97 percent, up a basis point, and the six-month bill was 3.05 percent, down a basis point. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
According to The Bank Rate Monitor's latest survey, the average New York-area money market account is down about 2 basis points, to 2.60 percent. Certificates of deposit are also down an average of 2 basis points, with a three-month C.D. yielding 2.71 percent and a six-month C.D. at 2.91 percent.
For the second consecutive week, the Chase Manhattan Bank is among the New York banks posting the sharpest change. Its money market account yield is 16 basis points lower at 2.17 percent.
Midlantic Banks, based in Newark, has lowered the yield on its three-month certificate of deposit 15 basis points, to 2.60 percent, while Carteret Federal Savings, based in Morristown, N.J., cut 10 basis points from the yield on its six-month certificate, to 3.15 percent.
Outside the New York market, yields at 20 large banks are down, with the average yield on a money market account falling 4 basis points, to 2.58 percent, and a six-month C.D. declining 2 basis points, to 2.94 percent.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Philadelphia's new convention center draws hotel chains' interest.

BYLINE: By David J. Wallace

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
HOTEL operators have been maneuvering for position in downtown Philadelphia in recent months in anticipation of the opening of a new convention center this summer.
Several hotel companies new to the city are examining opportunities in a market generally considered underserved, and renovation programs are in progress at two big downtown properties. 
 On Feb. 23, Holiday Inn Worldwide announced a $9.5 million rehabilitation of the city's third-largest downtown hotel, the Holiday Inn-Center City, at 18th and Market Streets, which it bought from VMS Realty. The company also brought in a new general manager to run the 445-room operation, which is the company's third hotel in downtown Philadelphia.
Only three blocks away, a $10 million renovation is under way at a property owned by Bell Atlantic Properties Inc. The former 288-room Radisson Hotel at 18th Street and the Ben Franklin Parkway will reopen in mid-April under the Embassy Suites flag.
"We just feel Philadelphia is a strategic market for our company," said John Tarantini, Northeast regional vice president for Holiday Inn Worldwide. "It's in a strategic corporate market that's undergoing tremendous growth."
Both properties are situated amid the city's busiest downtown business district and only a 15-minute walk from the new Pennsylvania Convention Center. The new center, with 432,000 square feet of exhibition space, will open in phases beginning in July and will be followed in early 1995 by the city's largest hotel, a new 1,200-room Marriott hotel.
The convention center stretches from 10th to 12th Street, between Arch and Race Streets near the Reading Terminal Market. Its opening will cause the city's hotel tax to rise from 5 percent to 6 percent in July, as the city repays its portion of the $500 million price. The Marriott is under construction on Market Street between 12th and 13th Streets.
Nevertheless, 3,000 additional hotel rooms are needed downtown in the next 10 years for Philadelphia to reach its potential as a convention destination, according to a report last month by the Philadelphia City Planning Commission. With only 7,000 rooms, the central business district has among the lowest number of hotel rooms of any big city in the nation.
Many of the city's newest hotels are also the most expensive. Luxury hotels like the Ritz-Carlton, the Rittenhouse and the Hotel Atop the Bellevue, which were opened in the last few years, charge as much as $200 a night.
Peter Tyson of Peter R. Tyson & Associates, a hospitality consultant in Kennett Square, Pa., said the timing of new construction depended on the convention center. More than two million hotel-room nights have been booked for the center's commitments through 2002. The largest customer is a 1997 national meeting of the Lions Club International, estimated to use 9,000 rooms.
Mr. Tyson emphasized the crucial role played by the center. "Even the finest companies -- the Hyatts, Westins, Marriotts -- are finding it impossible to get traditional financing for acquisitions, let alone new construction, in a city that does not have a proven track record as a convention center," he said. "Many of these companies find it more palatable to gain entry by coming into a market by taking over franchisers and without diluting the market by adding more rooms."
Speculation has been widespread over whether the Hyatt Corporation, Westin Inc. or other companies that have no hotels here will enter Philadelphia. Many have been here before, when the city was a big convention destination even without a designated convention center, Mr. Tyson said. Several large hotels were torn down or converted to other uses, removing thousands of rooms from the city's inventory.
One of the city's most popular hotels has been a Comfort Inn about two miles from downtown near the rapidly developing waterfront. So new hotel construction need not be in the central business core, Mr. Tyson said.
In 1991, Philadelphia had 24 million visitors, divided evenly between business and leisure travelers, the planning commission report said. But hotel occupancy rates have been below the 65 to 75 percent break-even point of most properties. The city's rate was 60 percent in 1991 and 63 percent last year. And average room prices have declined. A study by PKF Consulting Inc., which specializes in the hotel industry, found that the average daily room rate peaked in 1990 at $91.75 a day but dropped to $88.50 last year.
Occupancy is expected to reach almost 90 percent for the short term until the Marriott opens, a change that could make up for three lean years, said John Indrieri, general manager of the Four Seasons Hotel-Philadelphia and president of the Greater Philadelphia Hotel Association.
"You can't just bank on conventions," Mr. Indrieri said. "We've got small companies that generate 3,000 or 4,000 room nights each year. The question is whether there's a long-term need. I expect to see another 800 or 1,000 rooms, but when it comes is critical."

HEADLINE: Good Choice for Hemisphere Job

 BODY:
After a false start, the Clinton Administration has come up with a sound nominee to be Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs. Alexander Watson is a seasoned career diplomat who served as U.S. Ambassador to Peru and most recently as Deputy Chief of Mission at the United Nations. As important, putting him forward means the Senate confirmation hearings will not be dominated by snarling exchanges about Fidel Castro and the future of post-Castro Cuba.
To avoid that prospect, the Clinton team backed away from a Cuban-American it had initially considered for the same vital post. Mario Baeza, a Wall Street lawyer who specializes in privatizing state-owned enterprises, was denounced as soft on Mr. Castro by Cuban-American hard-liners in Miami. Mr. Baeza's critics never gave him the courtesy of a hearing, pointing up the deep emotions stirred among Cuban-Americans in Miami and elsewhere. 
 Cuba is but one of a dozen countries that contend for Washington's attention. Huge Brazil is beset by a collapsing economy and corruption scandals that brought down its President. Democratic Venezuela has been rattled by attempted coups. A peace accord in El Salvador might come unstuck if its Government fails to purge the armed forces. Nicaragua's freely elected President, Violeta Chamorro, is challenged on every side, including former contras. Peru under an erratic President is still besieged by Shining Path guerrillas, Colombia by drug lords, and so forth.
In Havana, a failing tyranny stumbles toward history's dustbin. Fidel Castro could hardly have sounded wearier in his remarks to the foreign press last week: "This has been a very long race -- too long. . . . I feel I am a slave to the revolution." Since seizing power in 1959, he has tormented eight U.S. Presidents. Now with the collapse of Communism, Cuba has lost its arms suppliers, its trading partners and its ideological bearings.
The safest, wisest course for Washington is to let Cuba fester, and shun actions that could be construed as treating the island as booty to be devoured by emigres hungry for old privileges. The cool, professional eye of an Alexander Watson offers the promise of keeping Cuba, and the rest of the hemisphere, in maturer perspective.

HEADLINE: Twilight in Italy

 BODY:
Almost every day, new disclosures link Italy's political and business leaders to a vast web of organized corruption. Inflated public contracts awarded in exchange for kickbacks have cost Italy's taxpayers tens of billions of dollars. The scale of wrongdoing has outraged even the famously cynical Italian public, feeding demands for fundamental changes in the cozy arrangements by which Italy has been run for more than four decades.
Those changes could begin as soon as next month, when a referendum will be held on changing the proportional representation system for parliamentary elections. The idea is to encourage something like alternating two-party government in place of the permanent coalition rule that has virtually invited financial backscratching. 
 In the past, drastic change might have alarmed Washington. The coalition formula was devised, with American encouragement, largely to exclude Italy's Communist Party, the largest in the West, from a governmental role. But the days of American meddling in another democracy's politics are, mercifully, over. With the Communists, now renamed, in confused retreat, non-Communist Italians no longer have any reason to feel inhibited about cleansing and democratizing an inbred and dysfunctional political system. Paradoxically, Communism's collapse may have opened the door to genuine political revolution.
The upheaval began a year ago when investigators uncovered a kickback scandal in Socialist-run Milan. Revelations of political corruption quickly multiplied, embracing Socialist leaders in other cities of the industrial north. The scandal then swept up leading Christian Democrats, many rooted in the rural south and some reputedly tied to the Sicilian Mafia.
These two parties make up the core of the coalition that has long dominated the Government. Smaller coalition parties have also been trapped by the scandal, along with business leaders for whom kickbacks became the key to winning government business in an economy half-owned by the state.
The political beneficiaries of the scandal so far are regional parties, like the northern Lombard League, and the southern anti-Mafia Network Party. Prime Minister Giuliano Amato, a Socialist, is trying to hold the line with electoral reforms and accelerated privatization. But increasingly, Italy's postwar system seems headed into the political twilight. Americans can hope that a more democratic dawn is near.

HEADLINE: Economy Grows, Food Stamps Rise

 BODY:
What's with the United States economy?
It grew at a 5 percent clip at the end of last year. But an unusually large number of the unemployed have been permanently laid off and have no job to reclaim as the economy recovers. Consumer confidence is high. But the number of people collecting food stamps -- 26.6 million, more than 10 percent of the population -- has reached record numbers. 
 A safe conclusion is that the economy continues to recover, but too slowly to bring down unemployment much. That's why President Clinton's call for a short-term stimulus package still makes sense.
Growth during the last three months of 1992 was fast-paced. But judging from data released during the last week, the economy slacked off after December. Adjusted for inflation, consumer spending -- the usual engine of recovery -- fell in January; so did construction and home sales. And the Government's chief forecasting index rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in January.
Persistent unemployment explains why food stamp use has risen to an all-time high. The two million workers who have been unemployed for more than half a year are exhausting their life savings, thereby becoming eligible for food stamps.
Critics of the President's plan, not all of them Republicans, say Mr. Clinton should junk his stimulus program because it's unnecessary and delays cutting the deficit. Their case is unpersuasive. The President's $30 billion package is too small to harm the economy even if it picks up steam on its own.
Indeed, Mr. Clinton could easily justify a package at least twice as large as the one he actually proposed. But at least he's heading in the right direction. The stimulus will offset some of the recessionary impact of the tax hikes and spending cuts he proposes to cut the long-term deficit.
There's another reason to support Mr. Clinton's stimulus package. For the most part, the components are designed to spur long-term growth. The money would be spent on mass transit, education of poor children, childhood immunizations, youth training, environmental research and other worthy projects. Mr. Clinton decided to accelerate spending on the projects just in case the economy needed an extra nudge this year and next. Based on confusing data, that's a wise insurance policy.

HEADLINE: Perot Continues His Campaign, On Capitol Hill

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
Mr. Perot came to Washington today, trailed by a throng of cheering, laughing, applauding acolytes, to give Congress the road-tested message that when you get right down to it, the Government's problems are all very simple. It bore all the earmarks of a Frank Capra movie until one lawmaker began suggesting that he was long on pomp and arrogance, and short on solutions.
At that point, the set piece about the common man who takes the political kingpins down a notch got twisted inside out, and Ross Perot's true role as the potent vote-getter who commanded a fifth of the support in the Presidential election became apparent. 
 The Texas billionaire alternately bristled with indignation when his wisdom was challenged and apologized meekly when confronted with misstatements or stretches in the truth.
 
Addressing Congressional Panel
 Mr. Perot came to Capitol Hill largely at his own instigation, to advise a joint House and Senate panel drafting a plan to streamline Congress. The appearance was the latest event in a recent string of pep rallies, speeches, talk-show appearances, interviews with reporters, mass mailings and, soon, television specials intended largely to promote his citizen organization, United We Stand, America.
Mr. Perot repeated that ritual today, pounding away at the evil of the trillions in Government debt, warning that citizens "feel that our Government and some of our Government officials are for sale," and demanding that Congress shrink itself and the rest of the bureaucracy substantially, in the style of General Motors and Sears.
If it demurs, he hinted, his new citizen's group will hold it to account. "I urge you, on behalf of millions of ordinary people who are out there earning a living: stand on principle," he said. "Don't compromise. You will have their support. I can guarantee you. I can deliver if I have to."
Noting that Americans "want details, not sound bites," Mr. Perot spoke for close to an hour. But little of his lecture dealt in any detail with the problems of Congress. To the contrary, he repeated his diagnosis of the nation's ills, starting with deficit-cutting and moving to condemnations of lobbyists, bloated campaign budgets, rapacious foreign competitors and their lobbyists and, not the least, President Clinton's first month in office.
 
Criticism of White House
 His off-the-cuff testimony was peppered with barbs aimed at Mr. Clinton, softened every so often, and ever so slightly, by observations that the new President must be getting bad advice or has been too busy to learn the truth about Government.
Mr. Perot scoffed at the assertion that the Clinton White House had been cut by 25 percent, saying someone gave the President "phony numbers" that did not note that the personnel budget had shrunk by only 5 percent. He attacked Mr. Clinton's plan for a $30 billion economic stimulus, saying that "the average citizen has figured out that if $4 trillion" in deficit spending "didn't jump-start our economy, additional Federal expenditures of some magnitude being considered now are not the answer."
He criticized Mr. Clinton's depiction of increased taxes on Social Security benefits as a budgetary expense, blasting "the strange language of Washington" and concluding: "Let's call a dog a dog and an elephant an elephant." And he poked light fun at the President's advisers, saying he had "begged" Mr. Clinton to put businessmen in control without success. At one point, he described the Government's energy-policy strategists as "poets, philosophers and beekeepers."
"Not one of them has ever run a business or created a job, far as I know," Mr. Perot said of Mr. Clinton's top staff.
For one listener, Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, that apparently did it.
"Ross, I like you a lot," Mr. Reid said, peering down at the witness. But he added, "you gave us 45 minutes of sound bites and 5 minutes of details.
"These statements, they're just not factual. 'The President doesn't have anybody to create jobs.' I don't know who works for him, but I know I've met his chief of staff, who's from corporate America just like you are. I bet he's created a lot of jobs."
Mr. Reid was referring to Thomas F. McLarty 3d, Mr. Clinton's oldest friend and a former chief executive of Arkla, a vast utility holding company.
The Senator then sharply dressed down Mr. Perot for what he said were other misstatements, about the nature of the 1990 agreement that capped Federal spending levels and the reasons for an increased deficit since then.
 
Bolstered by Applause
 "You've been giving a lot of advice here today to us," he said. "And again, I tell you I listen to a lot of advice you give. But let me give you a little advice: I think you should start checking your facts a little more, and stop listening to the applause so much."
Flustered and angry-looking, Mr. Perot challenged Mr. Reid to pin down his misstatements, asserting at one point that Mr. McLarty's business tenure at Arkla was marked by "problems," and telling Mr. Reid bluntly at one point: "You're ducking my question."
Bolstered by applause from the crowd, he eventually forced the Senator to concede that one basic argument about the fuzziness of Federal budget figures was correct.
But other Senators chimed in, more gently, in Mr. McLarty's defense. Senator David Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat, said Mr. McLarty had created thousands of jobs, and Senator David L. Boren, the Oklahoma Democrat who heads the streamlining panel, echoed that view. So Mr. Perot backed down.
"He is a fine man," Mr. Perot said. "I regret that anything came up where people felt they had to fall on their swords to defend him."
Representative Lee Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who is co-chairman of the panel with Mr. Boren, said later that Mr. Perot's testimony, however barbed and unspecific, was helpful.
"If you look at most of the testimony we've had so far in this committee, it's mostly technical," he said. "So it's good to get the perspective of a non-expert."
Later, appearing on CNN's "Larry King Live," Mr. Perot was more direct about how he expected Congress to reform itself. He called for lawmakers to surrender use of private gymnasiums in House and Senate office complexes, to give up cut-rate haircuts and lunches, to abolish preferred parking spaces in Washington garages and at Washington National Airport, and to forswear all junkets and other trips by lawmakers and their staffs.
"Once they think it through, they will realize it's not right," he said. "People patching holes in the street provide tax money for that -- and that's not right."
Mr. Perot also said he had talked to President Clinton about other reforms, but declined to discuss the conversations, saying that was the President's prerogative. Asked whether he would answer a call by Mr. Clinton to aid the Administration's own version of Federal reform, Mr. Perot first wavered, then seemed to rule it out.
"On too many occasions, our Government has just wanted to use me as, I call it, a poster boy, for show; I don't want that," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 4, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about Ross Perot's appearance before a Congressional committee misstated a measure of Government deficit spending in some editions. What totals $4 trillion is the accumulated Federal debt; the Federal budget deficit is the difference between receipts and outlays in one year.

HEADLINE: THE TWIN TOWERS;
OPENING OF TOWERS UNLIKELY TO OCCUR UNTIL NEXT MONTH

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS

 BODY:
Port Authority officials yesterday all but abandoned their hopes of a quick reopening of the twin towers of the World Trade Center, saying the buildings, damaged in a powerful explosion on Friday, may now have to remain closed for a month.
The revised estimate comes as officials have gained a greater understanding in recent days of the length of time it will take to complete the painstaking task, step by step, of shoring up foundations, repairing other structural damage and restoring emergency power and fire control systems. 
 The presence at the site of investigators, who must compete with repair crews for access to the most severely damaged areas of the bombed-out underground parking garage, is also slowing the repair work, officials said.
 
Length of Exile
 An extended shutdown would intensify the housing and financial problems for the 350 banks, brokerage houses, law firms and other tenants of the World Trade Center that have been displaced by the bombing, and it could aggravate the impact on the Port Authority itself.
Representatives of government agencies and companies with offices in the World Trade Center said the problems for their businesses would escalate as the length of the exile grew.
As other companies began to make plans for a prolonged exile from the buildings, Federal agents continued to sift through the rubble for clues and stepped up surveillance of suspected terrorists. But they gave no indication that they were close to solving the case. [Page B7.]
 
Overly Optimistic
 At a news conference in Manhattan, Stanley Brezenoff, the executive director of the agency, acknowledged that the Port Authority's initial estimate that the reopening of the buildings could happen "in excess of" a week had been overly optimistic.
"It does appear that 'excess' was a bit of an understatement," he said. "I'd like to believe we can do it in less than a month."
City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, in a report released yesterday, said that companies and government agencies stood to lose an estimated $692 million if the World Trade Center were to be closed for just a week, and that the figure could increase to $1.07 billion if the buildings were to remain shut for a month.
Most of the losses, the report said, would be in the costs of lost business, repairs and relocation. The report said the daily costs would begin to decline as companies adjusted to their new situations, and that some of the losses would be made up by insurance claims. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has about $1 billion in property and liability insurance on the World Trade Center, the Comptroller said, which would more than cover the $20 million it would lose in monthly rental charges.
But the economic impact on the city as a whole may be less severe. Bruce Steinberg, a New York City economist, said that there was currently a surplus of office space in New York, and that most displaced tenants would be able to find alternative quarters quickly. The most significant impact may come, he said, from tenants who decide to relocate outside the city. Other city industries, such as tourism, appear not to have been seriously affected by the bombing.
Asked if tenants might decide to move out permanently when faced with a month's dislocation, Peter Yerkes, a spokesman for the Port Authority, said, "In terms of looking ahead to what might happen in a month, it's hypothetical." He stressed that the Port Authority was trying to help tenants find alternate space, offering them interest-free loans for expenses like security deposits, and helping them get access to computers and vital records.
Some executives were clearly worried. Alfred A. DelliBovi, president and chief economic officer of the of New York, said that the bank's paper records were still in the building, and were vital to its daily business.
"If the delay is more than two weeks it will be a severe disruption and very expensive," Mr. DelliBovi said. He added that about 50 of the bank's 100 employees had been moved to an office building in Piscataway, N.J., and some were commuting from as far away as Long Island.
 
$100,000 Reward
 At City Hall, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced a $100,000 reward -- the largest municipally financed reward in the city's history -- for information leading to the capture and conviction of those responsible for the bombing. Later in the day, Port Authority officials said they would match the city's offer.
"Those responsible will be caught, and, we promise, punished severely," the Mayor said. "That is a priority of this Mayor, this City Council and this City government."
One of the two trade center workers who had been reported missing turned up safe yesterday. King McGee, 55 years old, of Manhattan appeared at his company's temporary offices, the police said. Mr. McGee had been reported missing on Monday by his son, said Officer Andrew McInnis, a police spokesman.
But tensions remained high inside areas of the World Trade Center that have been reopened, and the police reported hundreds of bomb threats.
In an apparently unrelated case, the Nassau County, L.I., police arrested a 28-year-old man whom they said had called the New York City police earlier in the day, claiming a bomb would go off in the World Trade Center. Officer Peter Lambert, a spokesman for the Nassau police, said that the man, Kerry O'Brien of Franklin Square, claimed that he had phoned the threat to call attention to the world AIDS crisis.
 
Acess to Bomb Crater
 Port Authority officials explained yesterday that the reopening of the towers would take much longer than anticipated because the repair work must be done in a process that requires one task to be all but finished before the next can begin. For instance, investigators must gain access to the bomb crater before smashed conduits and pipes can be fixed, officials said. And the repair of those structures must be under way before repair crews can get to work on fixing the smoke detection systems and backup power supplies.
Law-enforcement officials say it will be the weekend, at the earliest, before the damaged structure of the parking garage has been sufficiently strengthened to permit crews to reach the center of the bomb crater, considered an essential element of the investigation.
Because many of the safety and support systems are common to the two towers, officials said that it is likely the reopenings of the buildings would come in quick succession. However, the reopening of Tower 2, where the smoke damage was less severe, would probably precede the opening of Tower 1 by some short period of time, they said.
Some with offices in the World Trade Center, who have by necessity been forced to innovate again and again in the aftermath of the bombing, said they would try to cope with the latest setback to their attempts to restore business as usual.
"I'm not surprised by the longer delay, because I didn't see how it was possible to install all of the safety features in one week," said Don C. Becker, the publisher and president of the Journal of Commerce, a financial newspaper that moved its editorial employees to the offices of its parent company. "We are not badly off because our printing plant and composing room are in New Jersey. If the delay is more than a month, we'll be like the relatives who came for a week and stayed for a year."
Over all, the insurers with potentially the largest liabilty for claims arising from the disaster are syndicates associated with Lloyd's of London and London-based insurance companies, said Barry Weintraub, the chief financial officer for the World Trade Center. All together they could be responsible for $300 million in liability, property and business interruption claims, he said.
Lloyd's syndicates and London-based companies are responsible for the first $100 million in liability claims, said Mr. Weintraub. After that insurance shifts to a consortium of domestic insurers and two Bermuda-based companies, the X. L. Insurance Company and the Ace Insurance Company.
"We have begun receiving liability claims," said Mr. Weintraub.
As for coverage for property damage and lost business revenue, the first $10 million in coverage is held American Home Assurance Company and the Home Indemnity Company, said Mr. Weintraub. Additional layers up to $600 million are held by 11 different domestic insurers, Lloyd's of London syndicates or London based insurers, he said.

The caption with a front-page picture by The Associated Press in some copies on Wednesday, showing a young man comforting two women at the funeral of a victim of the explosion at the World Trade Center, misidentified the man. He was Michael Garofalo, not Ernest DiGiovanni.
