HEADLINE: Turning the Desktop PC Into a Talk Radio Medium

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 3

 BODY:
Talk radio is coming to desktop computers.
Within a few weeks, a Virginia-based entrepreneur plans to begin broadcasting a weekly 30-minute radio talk show on Internet, the global computer network that links together more than 10 million scientists, academics, engineers and high-tech industry executives. 
 Listening to such a program via computer instead of a radio might seem merely a digital curiosity. But many computer scientists and telecommunications experts believe it signals the first step in a transformation in which national and even global computer networks will fiercely compete with -- or even replace -- traditional television and radio networks that broadcast over the air or transmit by cable.
 
Listen Now, Listen Later
 Many desktop computers, including some of the less expensive models found in the home, now have speakers and software that permit sound effects. When the new program, to be called "Internet Talk Radio," makes its debut, Internet users will be able to obtain it as a file of computer data, just as they might "download" from the network a research report, data about a scientific experiment or any of thousands of other data files.
Listeners with sufficiently sophisticated gear can listen to the program as it is transmitted or choose to store the data in their computers and play it later. Listeners with less sophisticated equipment can hear it only after the data have been received and stored. Either way, the program will be divided into segments, so those Internet users who wish can select only parts of the program listed in a menu -- taking the book reviews, for instance, while passing up the week's news.
"We're not all going to start listening to radio on our computers yet," said Paul Saffo, a computer industry analyst at the Institute for the Future, Menlo Park, Calif. "But this is pregnant with possibilities. It's proof that the era of mass media is past."
 
For the 'Real Time' Crowd
 Initially, the new digital radio program will be targeted at the programmers and technically minded researchers who spend their days sitting in front of advanced computers writing or manipulating software and who have the high-speed connections to Internet that permit listening to the program in "real time" as it is received, while continuing to do other tasks on the machine.
But the new multimedia technology is viewed as gradually having a much broader audience as computer networks evolve from primarily a means of carrying business or scientific data into a new digital medium that will increasingly compete with conventional media like television, radio and newspapers.
There are no technical reasons why a video version of a program could not be carried on Internet, except that some portions of the network do not currently have sufficient carrying capacity. Those limitations are likely to disappear, however, as more of the network links are upgraded to fiber- optic circuits under efforts like Vice President Al Gore's "data superhighway."
"It's a brilliant idea," said Nicholas Negroponte, director of the Media Laboratory, a computer research center at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "All of these guys -- newspapers, radio or television -- are really in the same business. We've always thought video or audio or data are different businesses. But today, when you radiate bits, those bits don't have to have a specific medium attached to them."
Blending the power of the computer with conventional radio or television could create an intriguing new media that will give viewers or listeners more control over what they receive while allowing them to interact with the media in a manner not now possible. Conceiveably, any Internet user could create his own audio or video program and and make it available on the network, just as the creator of Internet Talk Radio plans.
 
'Random Access Radio'
 The program is the brainchild of Carl Malamud, a 33-year-old economist and writer in Alexandria, Va., who helped pioneer a computer network for the board of governors of the Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Malamud is the author of a number of technical books on computer networks.
Attempting to capture the "feel" of popular radio programs such as National Public Radio's "All Things Considered," Mr. Malamud said he believed that he could successfully aim a commercially financed show at engineers and technically minded computer-network users by filling a gap left by the trade newspapers.
"I call this random access radio," he said. "Our listeners can start, stop, rewind, or otherwise control the operation of the radio station."
Mr. Malamud said the program already had three commercial sponsors: Sun Microsystems Inc., the computer work station manufacturer; O'Reilly & Associates, a technical book publisher, and Computer Literacy, a Silicon Valley bookstore chain.
The program will be aviable to network users in the United States, Europe and Japan.
Each weekly half-hour program, which will be taped and transmitted later, will be built around an interview with a person widely known in the computer network field -- or, as Mr. Malamud said he was dubbing the section, the "Geek of the Week." He said the main feature would be accompanied by a number of smaller segments that would include computer network news, gossip, book reviews and even restaurant reviews sent in by users of the computer network.
"My view is that desktop broadcasting is an easy thing to do," he said.
 
A Presidential Feed
 "Internet Talk Radio" is based on a series of emerging technologies being used experimentally by many Internet users. They have been recently experimenting with digital video conferencing, telephone calls and even music broadcasting over the computer network.
For example, during President Clinton's visit last week to the Silicon Valley computer maker Silicon Graphics Inc., a digitized version of the video feed of the event to the news media was simultaneously transmitted to employees so they could watch from their computer work stations. The same digital data stream was also accessible to Internet users with hardware sufficient to receive it.
The data file comprising the entire half-hour program will require 15 million bytes of computer storage space, the equivalent of about 15 good-sized novels. Such a file, while a mere morsel for a powerful work station, would occupy a significant portion of most home computers' storage capacity.
 
Getting Started
 Listening to the program as it is being transmitted requires a computer network capable of supporting a stream of data of 64,000 bits a second -- a rate that is higher than conventional personal-computer modems but well within the reach of standard office computer networks, which can send data at speeds of up to 10 million bits a second. A less sophisticated computer with a modem that receives data at 2,400 bits a second would require almost 14 hours to receive the entire program. But more sophisticated and lower-cost technology expected to be on the market soon would make such broadcasts available on home computers.
"Internet Talk Radio" will be transmitted in an audio format that has become a standard in the world of high-powered work stations. For personal computers, assuming they are equipped to handle sound, various adapter products on the market would allow the program to be heard.
Mr. Malamud said that his files would initially contain only audio, but there is no limitation against adding additional computer instructions to expand the power of the digital audio.
"I'm looking at equipment that lets me put signals that would do things like allow you to move to the beginning of the next question or the next time the speaker changes," he said. "Another possibility is to run multiple sound tracks for translations or annotations of an interview."
Mr. Negroponte said the rapid growth of the Internet was largely being ignored by the big players in publishing and broadcasting. Internet has expanded so quickly that even network officials cannot say with precision how many users there are. The best estimates indicate a global audience of more than 10 million computer users routinely exchange information and read electronic mail using the network.
"The big players are asleep at the wheel," Mr. Negroponte said. "This network is growing 15 percent each month. It's not just hackers anymore."

HEADLINE: A.M.A IS SOFTENING STAND ON CHANGES IN HEALTH SYSTEM

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
Fearful of being left out of the debate on reshaping the nation's health-care system, the American Medical Association has told the White House that it will drop its long-held and formidable opposition to some proposals favored by President Clinton.
In return, A.M.A. officials said, they are asking for a seat at the table as the policy group led by Hillary Rodham Clinton works out what promise to be sweeping changes in medicine. 
 In a letter sent today to Ira Magaziner, Mrs. Clinton's righthand man on health care, the group signaled its willingness to support the idea of "spending limits" on health care, to accept a National Health Board to review prices and practices in medicine and to accept that large "managed care" organizations like preferred-provider groups or health-maintenance organizations may be a large part of the health-care system in the future.
 
Some Caveats Expressed
 The A.M.A. put caveats on some of these items and repeated its opposition to other items under discussion by the White House, like the proposal for a "global budget" that would set a strict limit on the amount the nation spends on health care.
But the A.M.A. did offer to support a cap plan, probably less restrictive than the global-budget approach, under which doctors would accept national or regional health-care spending limits if they can help set them.
Robert Boorstin, a White House spokesman on health care, said today that the White House "welcomes the participation of the A.M.A., as we always have." He said the A.M.A.'s shift showed that a "consensus is being formed that there has to be immediate change, and that it is coalescing around the principles that the President's plan is being built on."
An A.M.A. spokesman today said that it is a "reasonable reading of the proposal" to say that the overall spending limits would be at the level of inflation in the rest of the economy. Last year, that was 2.9 percent, while inflation for doctors' fees and other medical costs was 6.6 percent.
 
Requested in Return
 In return for its concessions, the A.M.A. is asking that practicing doctors be represented on the White House health-care group and that a number of proposals be considered, including curbs on malpractice suits, assurance that some patients will still be able to choose doctors and the freedom of doctors to negotiate fees with any government board setting budgets.
The letter to Mr. Magaziner marks a "major change, a quite different approach for the A.M.A.," said one association spokesman.
It was an especially significant shift for an organization that has been viewed as responsible for killing a number of health-care proposals in the past. The medical association, with its more than 290,000 members and its lobbying budget of tens of millions of dollars, could have posed a substantial obstacle to a Clinton package, and its support could add momentum to attempts to press the package both before the public and in Congress.
In the past, the association and allied doctors have been credited with killing health-insurance proposals in the Administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt, defeating President Harry S. Truman's national health program and halting President Jimmy Carter's hospital cost-containment measures.
 
New Climate in Capital
 But in the new climate in Washington, according to various A.M.A. officials, the group worried that it was being left behind as Democrats on Capitol Hill, other medical organizations and the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association have embraced "managed competition" and some limits on price increases.
The A.M.A. proposal was delivered to the White House today, after last-minute changes were made Tuesday night to back away from some more specific proposals, like expressing a willingness to freeze fees for a short time if asked by the Administration.
The letter offered to join in the "shared sacrifice" by others in health care when the final proposals for change are made in May. It said that the A.M.A. proposes a "new partnership" with the Government.
"We know that status quo must go," wrote the A.M.A. executive vice president, Dr. James S. Todd, but he also warned the White House that doctors have so far been excluded from shaping the new package, and that "any reform system will fail without the support of the profession."
 
What Clinton Wants
 The main elements of the Administration package include keeping costs down, reforming insurance rules, letting people choose their doctors and keeping the quality of health care high, Mr. Boorstin said.
The A.M.A.'s offer is widely seen as an attempt to regain leadership. Others, most notably the American College of Physicians last fall, have been quicker to support some of the Clinton proposals.
In addition, the American Academy of Family Physicians and the American Nurses Association have led the way with offers to support a ceiling on medical spending imposed by the Government or a national health board.
Many doctors have been the beneficiaries of huge pay increases and realize that they are likely to be targets for anger and budget-cutting if they do not offer to make sacrifices now. Between 1983 and 1991, the mean income of doctors has gone from $88,000 to $170,000 per year, according to the A.M.A.'s own figures. The lowest-paid doctors are family physicians, making $111,000 per year; the highest are surgeons, at $234,000 per year.
 
'Share Our Knowledge'
 Dr. Todd said the doctors' group "wants to be part of the center of the picture, a significant player. We want to share our knowledge."
The offer to the White House goes beyond the positions the group has been willing to take in the past on several counts. The group has come around to the view that managed care -- in the form of preferred-provider organizations or health-maintenance organizations, in which doctors are on staff, rather than acting as self-employed free agents paid on a fee-for-service basis -- is an acceptable model for health care as long as it is possible for some doctors to continue to operate on a fee-for-service basis.
There was some suspicion expressed about the proposal by others in Washington. Ronald Pollack, director of Families USA, a not-for-profit health-care advocacy group in Washington, and a health-care expert who advised the Clinton campaign, said that his guess was that the A.M.A. proposal was something of a Trojan Horse. "They are trying to say as many pleasant things as they can say," he said.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Fund Yields Mixed As Assets Shrink for Week

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA

 BODY:
Yields offered by money market funds were mixed in the latest week, and assets fell as investors chose to make larger commitments to the stock and bond markets.
The average yield on tax-exempt funds fell. Taxable funds were up very slightly. 
 According to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report, assets of tax-exempt money funds fell by $925 million for the week, to a total of $101.6 billion. The average number of days left to maturity of securities held in fund portfolios was 55 days, up from 51 days last week. "They're extending out on the yield curve as well they should be," Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donoghue, said.
The seven-day simple yield was 1.82 percent, down 6 basis points from last week, while the seven-day average compounded yield was 1.84, also down 6 basis points. The 30-day simple yield was at 1.92 percent, down 5 basis points. The 30-day compounded yield was at 1.94 percent, also down 5 basis points from last week.
 
 
Top Local Funds
 The top funds among tax-exempts in metropolitan New York were AIM Tax-Exempt Cash Fund of Connecticut, with a seven-day compounded yield of 2.13 percent; Vanguard New Jersey Tax Free/Money Market Portfolio, with a seven-day compounded yield of of 2.22 percent, and Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compounded yield of 2.14 percent. In general, all the tax-free fund yields were down from last week, Mr. Frank said.
Among tax-free funds with assets of more than $100 million, Dreyfus Basic Municipal Money Market fund led the nation with a seven-day compounded yield of 2.54 percent.
Assets in taxable money market funds were down by $17.3 billion, to $476.8 billion. Of the $17.3 billion reduction, $15.5 billion came from money market funds owned exclusively by institutional investors, Mr. Frank said. "There could be a billion dollars' worth of the public doing the same thing, but that's not important" compared with the size of the institutional outflow, he said.
 
 
Stocks and Bonds Favored
 "This week, money was going back into the stock and bond markets" and out of money funds, he noted. Apart from the outflow activity, little was happening in the money fund segment because the Federal Reserve "is holding tight," Mr. Frank said.
The seven-day simple yield on taxable funds was up 2 basis points, to 2.71 percent, while the seven-day average compounded yield was up 1 basis point, to 2.74 percent. The 30-day simple yield was unchanged at 2.72 percent, while the 30-day compounded yield fell by 1 basis point, to 2.75 percent, essentially the effect of rounding numbers.
The number of days to maturity of securities held in taxable money market funds was unchanged over last week, at 61 days.
The top general purpose money fund with assets of more than $100 million was Olde Premium Plus Money Market Series, with a seven-day compounded yield of 3.53 percent.
The top government-only money fund was United Services Government Securities Savings, with a seven-day compounded yield of 3.55 percent. "That's unusual," Mr. Frank said, explaining that general purpose funds typically outperform government funds.

Markets
Long-term interest rates dropped to record lows again as traders appeared to accept the probability of modest economic growth with low inflation. The 30-year Treasury bond continued its two-week rally, dropping in yield to 6.78 percent. [Page D1.]
Stocks rose as equities became more attractive to investors than bonds, which have fallen to record-low yields. The Dow gained 3.51 points, to 3,404.04, and other indexes gained. [D8.]

Mexico's state oil company wants to become a modern oil giant with foreign help. But Pemex's self-imposed ceiling on production has limited its role as a major source of export revenue. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Northeast Leads Other Regions of U.S. in Home Foreclosures

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
The Northeast states continue to lead the nation in the number of people losing their homes for failing to meet mortgage payments, a trade group said today.
California and other Sun Belt states are catching up, said the group, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, registering some of the sharpest increases in what economists call perhaps the most telling indicator of individual households in economic crisis. 
 "This is the highest we've ever seen," Thomas E. Hylinski, a first vice president in charge of residential lending at People's Bank, one of Connecticut's largest mortgage lenders, said of the number of Connecticut residents who were losing their homes.
 
Foreclosures in New Jersey
 In its quarterly report, made public here today, the association said that lower interest rates had buoyed many family budgets as homeowners refinanced mortgages and reduced their monthly payments and that throughout much of the country the numbers of late mortgage payments had fallen to an 18-year-low.
But the group said that in the Northeast and in Southern California, where hundreds of thousands of jobs have been lost in the aerospace industry and across a wide swath of white-collar jobs, lower monthly payments had not been enough. Those areas, perhaps by coincidence, also have some of the highest housing prices in the nation, meaning that laid-off homeowners, carrying bigger mortgages than they might elsewhere in the country, have a shorter time to sink or swim.
In New Jersey, for example, 2.44 percent, or nearly one in 40 residential mortgages, was in some stage of foreclosure in the last quarter of 1992, by far the highest rate in the nation, according to the Mortgage Bankers' survey. Massachusetts was second, with 1.8 percent, followed by Connecticut at 1.73 percent. New York and New Hampshire were tied for the fifth highest rate at 1.52 percent.
Foreclosure, when a lender actually begins taking back a property, is always the last resort, economists say, after monthly payments have been missed for at least three months and far longer than that in many cases. With prices of houses falling in many parts of the country, banks have been reluctant to take back properties that they will then have to try to resell. They say the high foreclosure rate also indicates the persistence and depth of the economic downturn, since people who lose their homes have generally exhausted their savings.
"It's really a sure sign of distress," said Emanuel Tobier, a professor of economics at New York University. Professor Tobier said that the rate of late mortgage payments, or delinquencies, are the "first bell," in gauging the degree of economic turmoil in any one region, or in individual household. "Foreclosure is where the curtain comes down," he said. "It's a very drastic step."
And while mortgage lenders said they expect the Northeast to continue to lead the nation in repossessions through this year, other regions that fell later into the recession are catching up fast.
 
Setbacks in West
 Among new foreclosures begun in the last three months of 1992, Arizona led the nation with 52 hundredths of a percent of all the surveyed residential mortgages entering foreclosure in just one three-month period, the mortgage lenders group said. California showed one of the sharpest increases in the number of mortgages in foreclosure, nearly doubling in 1992, to 98 hundredths of a percent, the report said. The Mortgage Bank numbers are based on a survey of 16.1 million mortgages, representing about one-third of the total residential mortgages in the country.
There were some indications that what had been an improving trend through part of 1992, even in the Northeast, has perhaps stalled. The group's report said that in many Northeastern states, the percentage of delinquent mortgages, defined as late by 30 days or more, had fallen through the first three quarters of 1992, raising hope that economic recovery and lower interest rates would carry the region out of its housing slump.
But then, in the fourth quarter, the numbers began to climb again.

HEADLINE: U.S. Upset With Japan On Chip Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
Clinton Administration officials say they are dissatisfied with Japanese compliance with a 1991 trade agreement on computer chips, but the Administration -- and the domestic semiconductor industry -- is leaning against imposing any immediate sanctions.
Because of their importance to the automobile, consumer electronics and computer industries, computer chips have long ranked among the most contentious trans-Pacific trade issues. 
 Washington trade experts are awaiting the Administration's reaction to statistics on Japanese compliance as a signpost of the Clinton Administration's trade policies toward Japan. It is widely expected that when the figures are released on March 19, Japan will fall short of the import target in the agreement.
 
Trade Official Comments
 Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, took a tough stand tonight when asked a question at a dinner for semiconductor industry executives. "We're going to enforce these agreements," he said. "We have to or we shouldn't have entered into them in the first place."
Afterward, Mr. Kantor emphasized that no decisions on sanctions had been made. "There are just a number of options available to us -- I have not ruled out anything nor have I ruled anything in," he said.
But other Administration officials said that nobody in the Cabinet or the industry was pushing for trade sanctions to match the punitive import tariffs once imposed by President Ronald Reagan. Although attitudes could easily change, the Administration's inclination seems to be to take a cautious approach when the figures are released and gauge the reactions of the American public and the American and Japanese industries.
President Clinton owes a debt to Silicon Valley because of its early support for his candidacy last year. The President is also trying to give his Administration a high-technology image.
The importance the Administration places on the industry is evident at this week's lobbying meeting here of the Semiconductor Industry Association. The annual meeting, which never attracted a Cabinet official during the Bush Administration, has been addressed by two Cabinet officials. Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown preceded Mr. Kantor, telling the group on Tuesday night about the technology aspects of the Clinton budget.
President Reagan imposed steep import tariffs in 1987 on some Japanese power tools and color television sets in retaliation for what were seen as Japanese restrictions on computer chip imports.
 
The Pact's Impetus
 The 1991 pact canceled the Reagan-imposed tariffs and set an informal target for the Japanese to purchase 20 percent of their computer chips from abroad by the end of 1992. Imported chips accounted for 15.9 percent of the Japanese market in the third quarter, and appear to have gained some market share during the fourth quarter, according to preliminary figures compiled by the semiconductor industry.
James A. Norling, the president of Motorola's semiconductor products division and the chairman of the Semiconductor Industry Association, said that a call for sanctions remained possible. "There would be a handful of options, and that would be one of them," he said.
The industry might not press for sanctions, he said, if Japan pledges that its foreign chip purchases will average 20 percent of the market this year. To meet that goal, Japan would have to increase its foreign chip purchases through the year, ending above 20 percent.
The Administration of George Bush kept the 1991 semiconductor agreement deliberately murky to avoid the look of managed trade. The agreement states that the targets are "neither a guarantee, a ceiling nor a floor on the foreign market share."
Partly departing from his speech, Mr. Kantor also delivered tonight an impassioned description of the suffering of American men and women who lose their jobs because of import competition. "The result has been a rising tide of resentment, a feeling among many Americans that they were getting the short end of the stick," he said.

HEADLINE: Passage of Health-Care Bill Seen as Unlikely This Year

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that Congress was unlikely to pass a comprehensive health-care bill this year, despite strong urging by President Clinton and the Senate majority leader.
Mr. Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat whose panel has written a large portion of the nation's tax and health laws, said Mr. Clinton's health legislation would probably be too big and too complex to combine with the President's economic package. But he and other lawmakers expressed confidence that Congress would pass a health-care bill to the President's liking next year. 
 Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, proposed Sunday that the health-care measure be attached to a giant bill raising taxes and cutting Federal spending. Such a combination would have procedural advantages for the Administration. The Ways and Means Committee will handle the tax changes and some of the spending cuts proposed by Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Rostenkowski said he had told Hillary Rodham Clinton that he would bend in the wind "like a palm tree" in his efforts to accommodate the Clinton Administration's wishes. But in view of the complexity of health-care legislation, he said, "it would be extremely difficult to get it done this year."
 
White House Reaction
 Informed of Mr. Rostenkowski's views, George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said tonight: "We know that passing a comprehensive health-care plan is difficult, but it's also necessary. We look forward to continuing to work with Chairman Rostenkowski and the rest of the Congress to pass real health-care reform as soon as possible."
Asked if all the legislative work could be completed this year, Mr. Stephanopoulos said, "We certainly hope so, and that's our goal."
The information about Mr. Rostenkowski's views came from James M. Jaffe, a spokesman for the Congressman, who said: "Rosty thinks that health-care reform is basically a two-year job. He feels it would be legislatively and logistically a real long shot to do it all this year."
In an impassioned address to Congress last month, Mr. Clinton said efforts to strengthen the economy would fail unless Congress took bold steps to revamp the health-care system "this year -- not next year, not five years from now, but this year."
In the Senate, Mr. Mitchell and the President would gain significant procedural advantages if lawmakers combined a health-care bill with a deficit-reduction measure. Senators generally cannot wage a filibuster against a deficit-reduction bill, known as a reconciliation bill, because there is a 20-hour limit to debate on the bill, including amendments to it.
A group of more than 50 liberal Democrats from the House and the Senate today introduced a bill that would establish a system of national health insurance financed mainly by the Federal Government. The bill would provide care for all Americans in two years by raising taxes, scrapping most private insurance and authorizing the Government to pay most medical bills.
The main sponsors of the legislation, Representatives Jim McDermott of Washington and John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, and Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, said they would cooperate with the White House. While acknowledging that Congress would probably not pass a measure exactly like their bill, they said they hoped it would influence the debate.
"Managed competition is the creation of the Jackson Hole Group," said Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio, a co-sponsor of the bill. "And what is the Jackson Hole Group? It consists of the people who are profiting most from the system as it is: insurance companies, hospital associations, drug companies."
Under the bill, states would have authority to design and run their own health-care programs. But the Federal Government would prescribe a minimum package of benefits and would set a budget to limit health spending in each state. One entity in each state would collect all insurance premiums and pay all medical bills, using Federal money for the most part.
Where Mr. Clinton would require all employers to provide or obtain health insurance for their employees, the Wellstone bill would break the link between insurance and employment.
 
Cigarette Tax Rise Urged
 In a separate action, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Representative Michael A. Andrews of Texas, both Democrats, proposed increasing the Federal excise tax to $1 for a pack of cigarettes. The tax is now 24 cents.
They would use 80 percent of the new revenue to help finance health care for people who are now uninsured. The Administration is considering similar proposals, including one that would raise the cigarette tax to $2 a pack.
The Federal Government collected $5 billion in tobacco taxes last year. Senator Bradley estimated that the proposed tax would generate an additional sum of $8 billion to $10 billion a year for the Government. There is bipartisan support in Congress for increasing the tobacco tax to pay for health care, but the amount of the tax is uncertain.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen was noncommittal when asked today if the Clinton health-care proposal should be attached to the economic program. "I'm not about to tell the leadership of the Senate or the House how to package this thing," he said. "We're going to keep our options open."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Mazda Ends Idea of a Ford Pact for Europe

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 3

 BODY:
The Mazda Motor Corporation said today that it had given up the idea of establishing joint European automobile production with the Ford Motor Company because the two companies could not agree on a plan.
The decision, the latest setback among hard-pressed Japanese automobile makers, could make Mazda the only major Japanese manufacturer without a plant in Europe and could lead to restrictions on its sale of cars there, in light of increasingly stringent quotas on imported Japanese vehicles. 
 "It definitely puts a tarnish on the company for the long term," said Peter Boardman, automobile analyst for UBS Phillips & Drew International in Tokyo.
 
Needs a Partner
 Because of its weak financial condition, brought about in part by the steep slump in Japan's automobile market in the last two years, Mazda cannot afford to build a European factory on its own. Mazda has already had to scale back other plans, including a luxury line and a dealer network in the United States.
Sumitomo Bank, which has supported Mazda in the past and even saved it from near-collapse, cannot help much now because it is weighed down by bad loans as a result of the collapse of Japan's speculative economy of the late 1980's.
Since October 1989, Mazda had been negotiating with Ford, which owns nearly 25 percent of the company. While specifics were never announced, there has been speculation that Mazda wanted to produce small cars at a Ford factory in Germany.
 
Ford Has Its Own Problems
 But analysts say it has become evident in recent months that Ford was reluctant to agree to joint production because the European automobile market is in the midst of a downturn. Ford itself suffered heavy losses in Europe last year and does not want to see a competitor strengthened.
Toyota and Honda opened European factories last year, joining Nissan, which has been producing in Britain for six years. One goal is to get around "voluntary" quotas on Japanese car exports to the European Community that were agreed to in 1991. Just this week, community negotiators were in Tokyo pressing the Japanese Government to agree to a reduction in exports for 1993 because the overall market in Europe is expected to shrink further. No agreement on the quota was reached.
Mazda, which sent 283,000 cars to Europe in 1992 out of its total exports of 801,000, said it was exploring other options for production in Europe. While there have been reports of Mazda's talking with French auto makers, analysts say it might not be easy for Mazda to find a partner, because many European auto companies already have links with other Japanese companies or have taken strong anti-Japanese stances.

HEADLINE: U.N. Boycott Has Belgrade Angry at U.S.

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 3

 BODY:
With consumer prices tripling each month because of economic sanctions against Serbia, Panaskeva Babic's pension of 155,000 dinars a month is not enough to live on.
On Tuesday she stood in front of a bank offering to spare someone the misery of standing in line all night to pick up a monthly interest payment, a service for which she was asking 10 German marks, or about $6.50, the value of her monthly pension. 
 The few private banks pay 200 percent a year for deposits in dinars, and about 50 percent for deposits in marks, rates that attract so many customers that all-night lines are unavoidable.
"If I'm lucky enough to find someone, I'll be here for the next 24 hours," Mrs. Babic said, as she wrapped her scarf tight against the snow beginning to fall from a leaden sky. Her son was in his last year at the university, she said, and unless she did this they could not survive.
 
Who, Exactly, Is the Bad Guy?
 The sanctions that cause many of the miseries suffered by Mrs. Babic are intended to pressure the government of Serbia and its president, Slobodan Milosevic, to stop encouraging militant Serbian nationalists in war-ravaged Bosnia and Herzegovina.
But in conversations on the streets, people are more likely to vent their frustration on the United States and the European countries for supporting the United Nations sanctions than on Mr. Milosevic and his government.
"Why are Serbs called pigs in your newspapers?" one woman with a baby demanded after accosting an American the other day on a six-hour bus journey from Budapest. She insisted that The Chicago Tribune had used the word, though the source of her protest apparently was an editorial cartoon depicting Serbs as pigs.
"All we hear is 'Serbia, Serbia, Serbia,' " said Alexandar Mitrovic, a Yugoslav Airlines steward thrown out of work by the effects of the embargo. "Serbs have suffered, too."
Belgrade does not look like a capital at war, and officially neither Serbia nor the Yugoslav federation is waging one. (Of its original six republics, only Serbia and Montenegro remain.)
But armed militiamen in battle fatigues occasionally walk the streets, which are nearly empty of traffic. Hardly anyone can find gasoline, or afford the little that is available at $4 a gallon.
Grocery stores have few imported goods, but local supplies seem more than ample, though the stores raise their prices daily. This week, a quarter-pound of coffee cost 31,000 dinars, one-tenth of an average monthly salary.
The sanctions have clearly made Serbs aware that they are in a grave crisis.
"Very soon the people will have to rise up, because they cannot live," said Radoslav Stojanovic, a leader of the opposition Serbian Democratic Party. Two years ago, on March 9, 1991, thousands of people did demonstrate against the Serbian government, which has since been returned to office with a comfortable election majority.
But Mr. Stojanovic acknowledged that the sanctions had made many ordinary Serbs more willing to support Mr. Milosevic and his defiant nationalism, rather than try to overthrow him.
 
'Gringos Go Home'
 "Western sanctions include culture and sports events," he said. "The people wanted to have basketball and soccer world championships here, and Milosevic can say the West and the United States prevented that -- and the people will believe him."
Hostility toward the United States does seem to be on the rise in a country that long looked to America as a protector. The United States Cultural Center in the center of Belgrade was stoned last month, and "Gringos Go Home" is spray-painted on the walls.
Yet the sanctions have clearly sobered those in ruling circles here.
"The sanctions have begun ruining us economically," said Svetozar Stojanovic, an adviser to President Dobrica Cosic of Yugoslavia. "If the purpose is to ruin us and also the regime here, the sanctions are working very well."
According to the adviser, sanctions are also inflicting pain on the country's neighbors, as Mr. Cosic found during a recent trip to Romania.
"The Romanians tell us they count their losses in the billions," he said. All traffic on the Danube has been held up for a week because Serbian barges have been barricading the river to protest the embargo, and Mr. Cosic promised during a visit last week to try to get them moved. They were still there this week.
 
Who, Exactly, Is in Charge?
 President Cosic has little real power. Mr. Milosevic controls the national television and it is he, not Mr. Cosic, that the Serbian militants in Bosnia and Croatia seem ready to follow.
But the President's adviser asserted that "Milosevic has not much more leverage on them than we do." But he said pressure on the Serbs had made them more willing to accept a compromise to end the fighting in Bosnia.
Milovan Djilas, the 81-year-old former Communist leader who spent nearly 10 years in Tito's jails, said he also found grounds for some optimism in the way Serbia had acquiesced in President Clinton's decision to airdrop relief supplies to the mostly Muslim villages in eastern Bosnia that are under siege by Serbian forces.
"Nobody can come out against aid to civilians, even if they oppose it in secret for the Muslims," Mr. Djilas said.

HEADLINE: San Salvador Journal;
As Workplace Buddies, Wartime Foes Forge Peace

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, Feb. 26

 BODY:
When Hector Antonio Barrientos Lopez bums a cigarette from one of his fellow apprentices, the two often marvel that the simple, amicable exchange can occur between two men who fought on opposite sides in the civil war that ended a year ago.
"One of us will always say, 'Who's going to believe this?' " Mr. Barrientos, a former guerrilla, said as he paused in his task of hand-painting letters and designs on wall plaques in a workshop in the heart of San Salvador. 
 Sometimes, said Martin Edgar Realagano, a former Government soldier, the brief conversations during breaks will turn up the information that two men had taken part in the same battle -- on opposite sides.
The shared work and collegiality at the Cooperative Association of Artisan Production are among the many signs in El Salvador that peace is succeeding after 12 years of war between left and right.
The workshop, which combines training with a production and sales operation for the plaques, is the creation of David J. Wiesenfeld, a California idealist who set up the project, which he characterizes as his own foreign aid program, with little money and big hopes.
 
Hand-to-Mouth Existence
 The workshop lives hand to mouth. Occasionally, Mr. Wiesenfeld has obtained money from the Agency for International Development and its Canadian equivalent; the rest of the income comes from an informal network of Americans who have come through El Salvador or worked here in recent years and send back orders from their companies or organizations after they return home.
"I've found out that our Government is not set up to deal with one person with a dream who wants to make a positive contribution," said Mr. Wiesenfeld, who is deeply frustrated at not being able to obtain sustained financing through the big United States foreign aid program in El Salvador.
The workshop currently has 12 apprentices -- all disabled war veterans from the army or the guerrillas' Farabundo Marti Front -- receiving a small allowance and five salaried teachers. Many more apprentices would like to join, some recommended by their former guerrilla or military organizations.
"I haven't promised permanent employment to the apprentices after they finish their 1,000 hours of training," Mr. Wiesenfeld said. "But I have said I will try to absorb them the best that we can. Much depends on whether we can get better distribution of our plaques in the United States."
Until he came to Central America soon after finishing an engineering degree, the 38-year-old Mr. Wiesenfeld's main work experience had been as a volunteer fireman in his hometown, Carmel-by-the-Sea. After some years in Guatemala, he found his way to El Salvador in 1987 and was impressed by the handicrafts, which he thought displayed a Salvadoran aptitude for detailed lacquer painting on wood.
 
Matching Skills and Market
 Remembering how his fellow firefighters used to order plaques for their offices and trucks and to give as awards, he thought he could organize something that would match the skill with a market.
All the design work on the plaques is painted by hand by the apprentices from patterns created by the teachers. They use automotive body paint, which Mr. Wiesenfeld says gives the highest gloss.
For the apprentices, the workshop is both a place to unwind from the experience of a war that left all of them with some kind of disability and a place to begin to think about what the future may hold for them.
"This helps create emotional stability," said Luis Alonso Recinos, another former guerrilla at the workshop.
Mr. Barrientos, who is 28 and carries a fragment of an army grenade in his head, said, "In the process of transition we need a lot of support from friendly countries."
Eventually, he hopes to get a scholarship through one of the reconstruction programs that would allow him to study business administration, a field that has become all the rage among former guerrillas since their leaders embraced free-market economics.
"It's not easy to insert yourself into civilian life after spending years in clandestine existence," he said, adding that he was pleased at how much had been accomplished in just a year of peace.
"Before, the Farabundo Marti Front had no possibility of peaceful political activity," he said. "Now it does. Our people are not being persecuted."
 
Their Common Bond
 Mr. Realagano, a 30-year-old former army corporal who lost his right leg in combat in the Usulutan area in 1986, said the fact that everybody in the workshop was disabled created a common bond transcending the politics of the past.
He said the association of disabled army veterans, of which he is a leader, was beginning to deal with the grouping of disabled former guerrillas to advance their common need for pensions and job training.
He said one high-ranking army officer had called the disabled soldiers Communists for dealing with the former enemy.
"But if we are in a process of reconciliation," he said, "we have to learn to relate to all Salvadorans."
"I haven't found it difficult to work alongside people from the Marti Front," he added. "The ideology of the armed forces made us hate them, especially when a comrade fell, but now there is no reason to continue to hate them. We are brothers of the same blood."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In 1987, David J. Wiesenfeld, center, came to El Salvador, where he was impressed by the handicrafts. He has turned that fascination into a struggling business, which, in addition to producing laquered plaques for export, employs apprentices who a few years ago fought each other in civil war. (Luis Romero for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Rates Fall Again To Lows

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates dropped once more to record lows yesterday, leading some analysts to say that the credit market is not being driven by daily developments but by a shift to a long-term view that sees only modest economic growth and low inflation.
The 30-year Treasury bond continued its two-week rally, which has seen long-term yields fall a third of a percentage point and crash through the 7 percent barrier. Yesterday, the yield dropped to 6.78 percent, from 6.83 percent on Tuesday, as prices surged. Yields on other Treasury issues also declined again. 
 "When you see markets do this sort of thing, you have to step away from the daily events," said Robert DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers, referring to the sharp rallies in Treasury prices.
 
A 'Fundamental Adjustment'
 "This is a market that is making a fundamental adjustment in its long-range view of inflation and growth," he said. "It all has the look of close your eyes and go."
One of the changes that could come with this new view is the shrinking of the so-called inflation premium or hedge that is incorporated into long-term interest rates. Since the high inflation rates of the late 1970's, this premium has been about four percentage points. But with more confidence in stable low inflation, the premium could fall to it historical levels of 3 percent or a little less, pulling long-term rates down with it.
This change in view has been coming for some time, as the falling long-term rates over the last year indicate. But President's Clinton's economic proposals to reduce the deficit has given it an added vibrance.
Economists and analysts think that his proposals, with spending cuts and tax increases, will prevent any sharp surge in economic growth during the recovery and keep the economy moving at only a moderate pace in the next several years. All of this would mean low inflation.
 
Yields of 10-Year Notes Fall
 The price of the 30-year bond jumped 24/32 , to 10414/32 , as the yield dropped to its lowest point since 30-year bonds were regularly issued 16 years ago.
The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note dropped to 5.87 percent, the lowest since early 1972. The yield was down from 5.92 percent the day before. The yield on the five-year Treasury note dropped to 5.04 percent, a level not seen since March 1971.
There was no big economic news yesterday to start the rally, although weaker-than-expected 10-day auto sales did help, traders who looked for daily causes said. Other analysts said that there still seemed to be a lot of cash in mutual funds as new money was coming in from the public. And this money is being pushed into the bond market
Robert D. Sbarra, a managing director at Carroll McEntee & McGinely, said that the rally also got impetus from the tax-exempt municipal market, where refinancings of old, higher-interest bonds picked up steam as interest rates declined. As part of this refinancing, state and local governments buy Treasury securities with the new low-interest-rate loans to pay off the old ones.
But Mr. Sbarra also agreed that bigger forces were at work. "The market," he said, "is clearly in a mode where nobody wants to fight it."
 
Port Authority
 Traders said that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey did not pay any premium or penalty because of the World Trade Center explosion when it sold $100 million of new tax-exempt bonds yesterday.
The competitively bid issue was won by a syndicate lead by Merrill Lynch & Company. The total interest cost for the Port Authority was 5.44 percent. The aggressiveness of the bidding -- which shows that the competing syndicates are not worried by the financial consequences of the damage to the trade center -- was reflected in the tightness of the bids. The second-lowest total interest cost bid was 5.446 percent, according to Barry Weintrob, the chief financial officer of the Port Authority.
"It has been important that the Port Authority has been so forthcoming about what is going on," Paul Kuhns, a director of the national municipal syndicate at Merrill Lynch, said. The issue, which was also attractive because it is noncallable, has yields ranging from 5.15 percent in 2008 to 5.30 percent in 2012 to 5.439 percent in 2038.
 
Toll Road Bonds
 Investors willing to take the risk of betting on the successful completion and use of a 15-mile toll road in Orange County, Calif., were well rewarded yesterday. The yield on the 30-year tax-exempt bonds sold by the San Joaquin Hills Transportation Corridor Agency was 6.881 percent, higher than the yield on taxable Treasury bonds. This yield is equal to 9.97 percent at the current top Federal tax rate of 31 percent.
But the investors may be taking a risk. There have been problems in road projects whose bonds are paid off with toll revenues, including the Chesapeake Bay Bridge and Tunnel, the Calumet Skyway in Chicago and the West Virginia Turnpike. Others, like the New Jersey Turnpike, have worked, however.
The $1.1 billion issue, which was underwritten by the First Boston Corporation and included several kinds of bonds, was rated BBB by Fitch.
According to a Fitch analyst, Andrea R. Bozzo, Fitch believes the project will be able to pay off the bonds because of "the need for the facility to alleviate the congestion in the county and to accommodate future development." The toll road is scheduled to be finished by March 1997.

HEADLINE: Airbus's Latest Flies Into the Storm

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMBURG, Germany, March 3

 BODY:
With President Clinton's attack on Europe for subsidizing its aircraft builders still echoing here, the European Airbus consortium today introduced the A321, which it touted as a new airplane made without government support.
But much turned on definitions, as has always been the case in the long-simmering dispute between the United States and Europe about whether unfair European government subsidies are costing jobs and profits in American aerospace. The 186-seat A321 is not, by most measures, a new aircraft at all. It can also be argued that the plane is subsidized nearly as much as Airbus's five other models. 
 The A321 introduction hereis just the latest skirmish in more than two decades of battles between the United States and Europe over the manufacture of commercial jetliners, one of the world's largest industries.
 
 
Assertions by Clinton
 Statements by President Clinton last month at the Boeing Company reignited a debate over whether government aid to Airbus Industrie amounts to unfair subsidies that are working to eliminate American jobs, as the President said, or is Europe's only way of competing with an American aerospace industry that has benefited from decades of Government spending on military and space programs.
 New or not, subsidized or not, the A321, which will be delivered to airlines starting next year, will compete with Boeing's planes.
It will make it more difficult for the McDonnell Douglas Corporation of St. Louis, the world's third-largest builder of jetliners, after Boeing and Airbus, to stay in the business. And it will further cement Airbus's remarkable success in bringing together the industries of four nations to make Europe a powerhouse in aircraft manufacturing, with all of the jobs, technological prowess and export strength that entails.
"This is an outstanding example of what the Europeans are capable of achieving when they work together," Jurgen E. Schrempp, the chief executive of Deutsche Aerospace A.G., the German partner in Airbus, told an audience of goverment officials, aerospace and airline executives and journalists here.
"On such a beautiful and important day," Mr. Schrempp continued, to considerable applause, "I will refrain from commenting at all on the totally unjustified, and, I might add, uncalled-for noises from America on the Airbus issue."
 For the A321, Airbus raised on its own, from nongovernment sources, the $480 million needed to develop the plane. But it is nothing more than a slightly larger version of the five-year-old A320, and shares the older plane's basic designs and all of its important technology. In developing the A320, the consortium received low-interest loans of $1.7 billion from the governments of France, Germany, Britain and Spain.
Since it was founded in 1970 by partners from those four countries, Airbus has grown to capture 30 percent of the aircraft market outside the former Soviet Union. It now competes in every part of the market except for 747-sized jumbo jets.
Its primary victim in America has not been Boeing, as the President suggested, but rather McDonnell Douglas, which in the last several years has won less than 10 percent of new aircraft orders and is dogged by speculation -- denied by the company -- that it will quit the jetliner business. Boeing has so far maintained its market share of roughly 50 percent, but increasingly finds itself going head to head with Airbus in selling its planes to airlines. In many of those cases, Boeing is losing.
Boeing and McDonnell Douglas have also been battered by declining Pentagon spending. President Clinton's remarks came after Boeing said it would eliminate more than 25,000 jobs because of a lack of new orders and the cancellation of existing ones.
 
 
Different Type of Aid
 It is debatable whether, as President Clinton suggested, the job losses at Boeing are largely a result of unfair competition from Airbus. But Airbus has clearly benefited from government aid of a type that is not available to Boeing or McDonnell Douglas in the United States.
"It's not a simplistic situation of Airbus's accounting for all the losses," said a Congressional staff member who spoke on condition of anonymity. "But Airbus has played a significant role in the decline of the U.S. aerospace industry. If you look at who is best able to weather the storm, it's probably the consortium that gets a signficant amount of government aid."
Mr. Clinton's statements have done nothing to dull Airbus's competitive zeal. "In October of '85, there was a President of the United States, Ronald Reagan, who began to speak out about Airbus, and at that time we had 15 percent" of the market, said Jean Pierson, Airbus's chief executive. "Now we have 30 percent, and maybe someday we'll have 45 percent."
Airbus officials said that the consortium had received roughly $1 billion in loans to develop its first plane, the 250-seat A300, which entered service in 1974. The consortium got another $1 billion for its next plane, the A310. In the case of the first two planes, the government loans accounted for all of the development costs. Airbus received $1.7 billion in government development loans for the A320, or 75 percent of the development cost. For its most recent designs, the long-range A330 and A340, it received a total of $3.5 billion in loans, accounting for 60 percent of the development costs, the executives said.
The total of $7.3 billion in loans rises to roughly $13 billion when interest is included, they said. Without such support, they said, it would have been impossible for Europe to become a competitor in commercial aerospace. Banks and other financing sources would never have made loans of that size.
Airbus executives said that all of the loans were being repaid and that in some cases the governments that lent money to the consortium would also receive royalty payments based on the number of airplanes sold. Last year, the executives said, Airbus repaid $700 million in loans, and plans to repay between $900 million and $1 billion for the next several years, with the loans scheduled to be paid off completely around 2006.
 
 
Lucrative Research Contracts
 The European Community says that Government support for aerospace in the United States amounts to considerably more money, just in a different form. A study commissioned by the community said government payments to American aerospace companies amounted to more than $33 billion in the last two decades, in the form of research contracts -- from the Pentagon and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration -- that yield commercially valuable technical advances.
"I'd prefer to have a European NASA and its research contracts than loans that I have to repay," Mr. Pierson said.
Boeing and McDonnell Douglas have long contended that Airbus has an unfair advantage because of its direct government support. Boeing executives attributed their loss last year of a $3 billion, 50-plane order from United Airlines to Airbus's ability to offer financing terms that Boeing, without government aid, could not afford to match.
But both companies gave grudging support to an agreement to limit subsidies that was negotiated last summer between the European Community and the United States. The agreement did nothing to address the issue of loans or subsidies already granted. It did, however, limit direct government financial aid to 33 percent of development costs on future programs, and capped indirect aid in the form of government contracts to 3 percent of industrywide sales, or 4 percent of a company's sales.
 The agreement was also praised by Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a top economic adviser to Mr. Clinton, in her book "Who's Bashing Whom? Trade Conflict in High-Technology Industries," published last fall. In the book, Ms. Tyson noted that the agreement had several loopholes, including one allowing either side to ignore the aid limits if the survival of an aircraft manufacturer was at stake. But, she wrote, "the 1992 agreement is a noteworthy accomplishment for both sides and a major improvement" over a previous and largely ineffectual accord signed in 1979.
Neither Mr. Clinton nor Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, has given any indication of wanting to renegotiate the deal. But with technological leadership and high-paying jobs on the line, some members of Congress are pressing the Administration to be more aggressive. Senator John C. Danforth, a Republican from Missouri, the home state of McDonnell Douglas, introduced legislation last month calling for the Commerce Department to study whether it should impose countervailing duties on Airbus planes sold in the United States.
There are also pressures within the United States to avoid a trade war over aircraft. American companies are big suppliers to Airbus, including the two leading jet-engine manufacturers, the General Electric Company and the Pratt & Whitney division of the United Technologies Corporation, and industry executives said they would oppose any trade barriers. Airlines in the United States are among Airbus's biggest customers, and they have benefited from the competition Airbus has brought to the business, in terms of improvements in reliability, operating costs and technology, as well as price.
There are also signs that Boeing and McDonnell Douglas themselves do not want to push the subsidy argument too far. McDonnell Douglas has been seeking a foreign partner, and Boeing is heavily involved with aerospace companies in Japan.

HEADLINE: Pemex: Mexico's Hesitant Oil Giant

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
After decades of isolation from foreign influence, Petroleos Mexicanos is reaching out for all sorts of help from foreigners as it tries to make itself into a modern oil giant in the image of an Exxon or a Shell. But the transformation has run into an unusual self-imposed barrier that is sidelining the company as a major source of new export revenue for a nation that badly needs to earn more dollars.
Pemex, as the state-owned company is known, is offering petrochemical plants for sale to foreigners, hiring American companies to drill wells, shedding tens of thousands of workers and selling off many secondary operations like those making valves, pumps and ships. And it has even come close to doing the unthinkable under Mexican law: pledging oil as collateral for foreign loans -- a practice outlawed after Mexico nationalized the industry in 1938.
 
No Export Expansion
 In Mexico's grand vision, the most important goal is to increase exports of manufactured goods greatly to pay for a huge influx of American products. Until that happens, Pemex remains the nation's biggest export earner, bringing in 30 percent of all the dollars that Mexico received in 1992 from its sales abroad. 
 But ask Pemex officials what they are doing to increase production and sell more oil to foreigners -- thus helping to keep the nation's finances afloat -- and the answer comes back that Pemex has no intention of raising exports.
"We do not want a policy of greatly expanding production, or anything like that," Francisco Rojas, general director of Pemex, said in an interview, setting forth a policy not so bluntly stated before by a high Government official. "For the moment," Mr. Rojas added, "the official policy that has been defined for Petroleos Mexicanos is to produce enough oil to supply the internal market while maintaining exports at their present level."
Pemex has been an instrument of Mexican policy from its birth in the late 1930's, after the Government threw out foreign oil companies as exploiters and made Mexican oil -- finding it, pumping it, refining it and distributing it -- a state enterprise. Currently, Mr. Rojas said, the Government does not want to make Mexico overly dependent on oil revenue, as it was in the early 1980's, when oil prices collapsed and foreign debts went unpaid.
But others argue that Mr. Rojas's statements are disingenuous, masking the real problem: Pemex lacks the skill and technology to expand oil production and exports, even if it wants to do so. "Maybe he is making a virtue out of a necessity," said George Baker, an oil consultant in Los Angeles and an expert on Mexico.
What's more, for all of Pemex's reaching out to foreigners for help, the Constitution and Mexican law prevent it from offering the one reward that would draw heavy investment and technology from American oil companies. The companies would come, they have made clear, if the payoff for their risk is a share of the oil they find and produce.
"Over the short term, if Mexico wants to maintain strong economic growth, it must have more oil exports to pay for the imports that are needed to industrialize the country," said Rogelio Ramirez de la O, an economic consultant and one of the growing number of Mexicans who argue that the oil rules born in the 1930's have outlived their original justification.
The rules are in fact beginning to erode, even without a public break with the past. Foreign lenders, for example, will hold title to a refinery soon to be built in Salina Cruz that will be operated by Pemex, as Mexican law specifies, but not owned by it until the $1.4 billion construction loan is repaid. And by early March, foreigners will lend $300 million to Pemex under a new procedure, supervised by Citibank, that comes closer than in the past to pledging Mexican oil as collateral, Pemex officials acknowledge. Mexican law prohibits such pledges.
"This will be the first refinery within Mexico not owned by Pemex," said Ernesto Marcos, the company's chief financial officer, referring to the proposed refinery in Salina Cruz. "But there are 40 or 50 offshore oil platforms that we rent, just as we will rent the refinery until we own it. We have always done this, but we are doing it much more now."
Reaching out for help seems inevitable for a company that is trying to modernize. That takes investment capital, and Pemex has been left with very little after annually paying over half of its revenue to the Government to finance the federal budget. Last year, for example, Pemex took in nearly $25 billion from sales, but the Government drew from the state oil company more than $15 billion, or 20 percent of all federal revenues.
 
U.S. Oil's Approach
 Very little remains after such taxes for modernization, exploration and new refineries. One way to raise more revenue would be to drop the remaining restrictions on foreigners, the approach advocated by American oil industry officials. Having sold off many state companies and having endlessly promoted private enterprise as the engine of Mexico's economic growth, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari should now extend his philosophy to the oil industry -- offering oil as payment to foreign companies for risky investments, American oil officials say.
The American industry has often raised the hope of greatly increased Mexican exports -- they now account for 7 percent of total American oil purchases -- to make the United States less dependent on Middle East oil. Pemex production is 2.67 million barrels a day, of which 1.4 million barrels is exported, half of it to the United States. Maintaining this level and keeping pace with domestic consumption requires a production increase in 1993 of only 40,000 to 50,000 barrels a day, Mr. Rojas said.
Without more oil export revenue, Pemex is finding other ways to raise money abroad, taking on more than $800 million in net new debt last year, and bringing the total foreign indebtedness to $7.2 billion by December, Mr. Marcos said. Inevitably, some of the deals skirt the constitution.
A trust being set up by Citibank, for example, has sold $300 million in bonds, the money to be lent to Pemex. The collateral will be the payments that creditworthy companies like Exxon, Shell and Amoco will make, starting in March, for 21,000 barrels in daily oil shipments. Normally, these payments would go directly to Pemex, rather than to a trust that will then turn them over to Pemex.
"Pemex is not the debtor, the trust is," Mr. Marcos said, explaining that a bondholder cannot seize oil if his bonds are not repaid.
 
Consequences for Economy
 The Pemex policy of not increasing exports has major consequences for the Mexican economy. American goods and money are flooding into this country and Mexico's trade deficit is rising.
One way to shrink this deficit is to sharply increase oil exports, which now account for 30 percent of Mexico's total annual sales abroad.
But Mr. Rojas argues that the oil solution would make Mexico too dependent on oil revenue from abroad. That was the case in the early 1980's, when a steep drop in oil prices devastated the Mexican economy. Now, the Salinas Government is taking a different gamble -- that exports of manufactured goods, particularly from the many American companies setting up shop here, will rise soon enough and in large enough quantities to shrink the trade and current account deficit.
"I believe that everyone in Mexico would be very content if oil's relation to the total economy declined," Mr. Rojas said.
Meantime, Pemex has freed up revenue by cutting costs, the most important cut being a reduction in workers in recent years to 124,000 from 210,000.
And faced with too little refinery capacity, Pemex is completing an agreement with the Shell Oil Company to refine some Mexican crude in the United States. Still, Mr. Rojas is uneasy. The company has earmarked $3 billion this year to increase oil production, he said, but "if I could dispose of resources as I saw fit, perhaps we would decide to spend $1 billion more."
And what would he do with the extra $1 billion? "We could for example build the new refinery" in Salina Cruz, he said, without borrowing so much for it. And some of the money might be used "to increase our oil reserves."

HEADLINE: In a Victory for Clinton, the Senate Votes to Extend Jobless Benefits

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
Democrats defeated the first Republican challenge to President Clinton's economic program in the Senate today. They held ranks against a proposal that would have offset the cost of extending unemployment benefits with spending cuts.
The 57-to-43 vote along party lines came after the Senate Democratic leadership held its conservative members in line by presenting the issue as a test of their loyalty to the new President and his economic policies. 
 Senior Democrats said the results were a sign that they will be able to deliver the votes necessary to pass the rest of Mr. Clinton's program. The defeat left Republicans openly frustrated at not being able to slow the Administration's momentum, which they contend is based on a popular misconception that the Democrats are as interested in cutting spending as they are in raising taxes.
Still, there will be several more major votes on spending cuts as well as on taxes on energy and Social Security in the next few months, and those votes may prove more difficult for the Democratic leaders to hold onto the conservative Democrats.
 
Benefits Through Oct. 2
 The Senate passed the benefits extension 66 to 33, with 10 Republicans joining 56 Democrats in support. But the crucial vote was not on that issue but on the Republican proposal to require the Government to cut jobs and other administrative costs to offset the cost of the extension.
The unemployment compensation bill extends benefits through Oct. 2 for 1.8 million Americans who have lost their jobs involuntarily. Under the bill, such workers receive either 20 or 26 weeks of Federal benefits once they exhaust state benefits. The average benefit is valued at $173 a week. The House already passed the measure, and Mr. Clinton has promised to sign it.
The previous three extensions over the past year and a half were paid for by tax increases and accounting gimmicks to avoid increasing the budget deficit. The current extension will increase the deficit by $5.8 billion over two years.
"I find it discouraging," said Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, "that in their first vote out of the box the Democrats, who have talked this strong line about the deficit, say, 'Let our children pay for this $5 billion program.' The bad old ways have not disappeared."
 
Democrats Unite
 No conservative Democrat spoke against the Republican amendment, which called for an acceleration of many of Mr. Clinton's own proposals to streamline the Federal government to pay for the extension.
Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, said after the vote that he and two or three other conservative Democrats discussed the possibility of voting for the Republican amendment. But when Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, rose to the floor and said, "Those who vote for this amendment are voting to torpedo the president's economic program," the conservatives held the line, Senator DeConcini said, because they concluded that the Republicans were merely trying to embarrass Mr. Clinton.
"I spoke to my Democratic conservative colleagues, and said I'm not going to get sucked into this one this early on," Mr. DeConcini recalled. "We want to be with Clinton and we want him to do well, even though some of us still have problems with the taxes and how we insure that the deficit really comes down."
The vote offered Republicans a prime opportunity to drive their argument that Mr. Clinton offers little more than lip service to the cause of cutting the budget deficit. Opinion polls and tallies of constituent phone calls indicate that voter concern over the debt and deficit spending has increased since the extension votes last year.
"Never have I served in a year when cutting spending before we increase taxes has been more in vogue," noted Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas. "We ought to bring some of the President's savings that he wants to implement on Oct. 1 forward to the present to pay for this extension of unemployment benefits."

HEADLINE: THE TWIN TOWERS;
Port Authority Is Unaffected In Bond Sale

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Reflecting continued investor confidence in the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey despite Friday's bombing at the World Trade Center, the authority yesterday sold $100 million in new bonds without having to pay higher interest than other large tax-exempt issuers.
The sale, which had been scheduled weeks ago, had been eagerly anticipated this week to gauge Wall Street's feelings about the financial outlook for the Port Authority, which relies heavily on its ability to sell bonds to finance its operations. 
 If major investors had feared serious long-term financial problems, the Port Authority would have been forced to pay a premium in the form of higher interest rates.
But demand for the bonds was more robust than expected, and analysts said the interest costs paid by the Port Authority was no higher than it would have been before last Friday's bombing.
"In the aftermath of the World Trade Center disaster, I think the yield was less than the Port Authority expected to pay," said Paul Kuhns, a director in the municipal markets division of Merrill Lynch and Company, which submitted the winning bid for all of the $100 million in bonds, paying 5.440 percent interest. He described bidding for the bonds as "very aggressive."
 
No Change in Ratings
 The auction came a day after the nation's two largest credit-rating concerns, Standard & Poor's and Moody's, issued reports saying that they had not changed the authority's rating because of the bombing.
Both agencies said the Port Authority was certain to sustain losses running far into the millions of dollars.
But because of its vast financial resources, both said they expected the agency to cover its losses without having to raise tolls, cut services or sharply increase its debts.
"It appears unlikely that total losses associated with the tragedy would seriously jeopardize the authority's ability to pay debt service," said Standard & Poor's.
Port Authority officials said this week that it has insurance covering $600 million in losses. Even if it takes as long as a month to reopen the two towers of the World Trade Center, that amount of insurance should be enough, according to Moody's.
