Iowa has spent the last few years quietly building a fiber-optic communications network like the high-tech computer, voice and video "data highway" proposed by President Clinton. [D1.]

HEADLINE: THE TWIN TOWERS: The Scene;
Surprises in a Crowded Courtroom

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

 BODY:
At 7:45 P.M. yesterday, Mohammed A. Salameh, gaunt in a light grey sweat suit and white running shoes, entered a courtroom at the United States Court House in Manhattan to stand accused of participating in what the Federal prosecutor, Gilmore Childers, called, "the single most destructive act of terror ever committed on American soil."
The din of 200 reporters, lawyers and clerks quieted to an instant hush as Mr. Salameh rubbed his wrists when his handcuffs were removed. He glanced quickly behind him, searching the packed courtroom, then shrugged. 
 A half-hour into his arraignment, Mr. Salameh, who is 26, stunned the courtroom by instructing his defender, Robert E. Precht, to ask that he be freed on $5 million bail. Mr. Precht also seemed surprised by his client's request.
Minutes before, Judge Richard Owen concluded his reading of the complaint against Mr. Salameh by saying that the defendant should be held without bail "on the ground that he blew up the World Trade Center and killed five people."
Hearing that, as well as that he faced a possible death penalty, Mr. Salameh placed his fingers on his temples, then gesticulated emotionally during a whispered conference with his lawyer.
 
Bail Is Denied
 Mr. Precht, who met Mr. Salameh just before the arraignment, said that his client professed innocence and said that he would be able to put up $50,000 in cash and arrange for 10 financially responsible people to co-sign a personal recognizance bond.
Mr. Precht said that Mr. Salameh was a "devout Muslim" who had lived in this country five years and was faint with hunger from fasting during Ramadan.
Judge Owen denied bail and ordered that the defendant be fed on arrival at the Metropolitan Correctional Center behind the Federal courthouse.
 
Translated Into Arabic
 During the court proceedings, Latif Onsi, an Arabic interpreter who works for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, translated into Mr. Salameh's ear as the judge advised him of his rights and read the charges against him. Ten courtroom artists furiously sketched the defendant's beakish nose, hollow cheeks, cropped beard and the sideways tilt of his head.
The complaint against Mr. Salameh said that on Feb. 23, he rented the Ford Econoline E-50 van with Alabama plates that investigators believe was used in the bombing of the World Trade Center a week ago. It said that Mr. Salameh was caught after he tried to reclaim his rental deposit -- $400 -- saying the van had been stolen. The complaint said that he had even visited a Jersey City police station to report the theft of the van.
The complaint added that dogs trained in detecting explosives "responded positively to a closet space" at the Jersey City apartment listed as Mr. Salameh's home address on the van rental form.
"Whatever that means," Judge Owen said.
 
Crush of Observers
 Mr. Salameh was arrested yesterday morning at the Ryder rental agency in Jersey City and transported to the F.B.I. offices at 26 Federal Plaza in Manhattan. He requested a lawyer, but spent the afternoon without seeing one, said Mr. Childers, the deputy chief of the criminal division in the Southern District.
Mr. Salameh was not questioned but was "involved in evidentiary testing," Mr. Childers said. He did not elaborate.
About 3 P.M., while Mr. Salameh was with the F.B.I., paralegals, law clerks and reporters began gathering outside Courthouse Room 506. Stephen Hoffman, 25, a paralegal with the Transit Authority had dropped by after delivering papers to the Courthouse.
"I said, 'Why not? I'm here,' " he said. "It's the first big thing that really happened around me since I moved into the city from Long Island."
 
A Wait for Answers
 Allan Pearlman, a motions law clerk for the United States Court of Appeals, said he was willing to wait several hours to get first-hand information about the highest profile case in town.
"We might get more answers here than what William Sessions gave at the press conference," he said.
The wait was particularly long because Mr. Precht, the defender, did not learn until early evening that Mr. Salameh was his client. He reserved time to meet with him and explain the complaint against him.
The courtroom was impatient but not tense. Rebekah Boyer, a courtroom artist, said it had peripherally occurred to her that the hearing itself could be the target of terrorists.
"But basically I don't feel nervous that I'm going to be bombed," she said, "because I tend to show a real lack of imagination."

HEADLINE: Factories See Decline in Orders

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
New orders for manufactured goods dropped sharply in January, the Government said today, while the number of people applying for unemployment benefits jumped late in February.
Economists said that the two measures of economic activity, although not cause for alarm, suggested a slowdown in the recovery's pace. 
 A big drop in demand for new aircraft helped pull factory orders down 1.3 percent in January, to a seasonally adjusted $254.9 billion. It was the sharpest fall in monthly business since a 2.2 percent drop last August, the Commerce Department said. But it did not erase completely December's 6.1 percent rise in orders.
In a separate report, the Labor Department said the number of applicants for state unemployment benefits climbed by 26,000 in the third week of February from the previous week, to 351,000. That was still 100,000 lower than the average rate of applications a year earlier.
A further indication of employment trends will come Friday, with the release of jobless data for February.
 
A 'Moderating Economy'
 "The overall picture is one of a moderating economy," said Lynn Reaser, an economist with the First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles.
The economy, still recovering from the 1990-91 recession, expanded by a strong 4.8 percent annual rate in the final three months of 1992, its most vigorous performance in five years.
Ms. Reaser, however, estimated that the nation's gross domestic product, which measures all goods and services produced, was growing at only a 2.9 percent rate in the first quarter.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York, said the weakening in the economy grew more pronounced last month. "In addition to the recent increase in initial unemployment claims, car sales plunged and consumer confidence fell," Ms. Schaja noted.
Weak job growth is a major concern cited by the Clinton Administration in its proposals to stimulate the economy in the short run and cut the deficit over the longer term.
By one measure in the Labor Department's weekly report -- the four-week moving average for initial claims that irons out seasonal fluctuations and holidays -- the job situation was about flat or slightly better in February.
It showed jobless claims on average inched down to 334,250 in the week that ended Feb. 20 from 334,500 the previous week.
But Ms. Reaser noted that job creation was a more significant gauge of economic health and that it continued to be sluggish. The number of jobs created monthly in 1993 will likely average 130,000, an improvement from 50,000 a year ago but far below the 300,000 a month in most post-World War II recoveries, she said.
There were some positive signs in the factory orders report.
Manufacturing inventories fell for a fifth straight month in January to $378.03 billion and were at the lowest level since March 1989, when they were worth $375.45 billion. The low level of stocks of unsold goods suggests companies may soon need to increase production to meet demand.
The factory orders report also showed orders for transportation equipment dropped by 8.5 percent in January, after a 24.6 percent surge in December. Within that category, aircraft, missiles and parts orders plunged by 32.3 percent, after a 62.9 percent December jump.
Excluding transportation, factory orders fell only one-tenth of 1 percent in January, after increasing in December by 3.6 percent.

SECTION: Section B; Page 4; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 625 words

HEADLINE: THE TWIN TOWERS: The Clues;
Vital Evidence in Towers Bombing Found Early in the Investigation

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
It was late Sunday afternoon, Feb. 28, when the team of 10 investigators first moved cautiously into the blast area beneath the World Trade Center, looking for clues to what might have caused the deadly explosion two days earlier. What they found there that day, only minutes after they entered, has proved to be crucial to the case.
The search team, one of two groups that went down that afternoon, was made up of the most senior investigators from the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and the New York City Police Department's bomb squad. Two were bomb squad detectives; the eight others were from the bureau, including two explosives technicians, each with a military explosives background, two forensic chemists and four crime scene investigators. 
 Their mission: to do swabbings and to find areas that would be good for locating evidence.
Armed with flashlights, a camera and evidence collecting kits, the group headed directly for level B-2, near the ramp to B-1 -- the area directly beneath the ballroom of the New York Vista Hotel, where the blast had left a huge hole. This, according to investigators who were at the site that day, was the most likely site to have been the bomb's origin.
 
Heaps of Debris
 Moving through piles of mangled vehicles, ducking pipes and beams that had fallen in the blast, they scanned the heaps of debris, looking for heavily damaged and blasted car parts -- the most obvious evidence of a vehicle that might have held a detonated explosive.
The investigators, who spoke only on condition that they not be identified, said that as the group of 10 broke apart to explore, four investigators, including the two bomb experts from the Federal bureau, Joseph Hanlin and Terry Byer; an A.T.F. agent, Kevin Washington, and a police bomb squad detective, Donald J. Sadowi, moved across the B-2 floor near the crater.
A large, grossly mangled piece of metal lying in pile of debris on the ramp caught the beam of one of their flashlights. Mr. Hanlin, the bomb expert, kneeled down, picked it up and turned it over. It was a piece of a heavy frame -- clearly, the investigators agreed, part of a truck or van. Inspection of the piece revealed a series of numbers stamped into the metal -- numbers that could be used to trace vehicle.
"This is something we need to take," Mr. Hanlin told the others, who quickly agreed.
 
Pieces of a Van
 The piece of frame, or chassis, was carted out on a gurney. It was one of less than a dozen pieces that came out that afternoon -- all of bits of what investigators later determined was a Ford Econoline van that had been rented from a Ryder rental company in Jersey City and later reported stolen.
During the two hours, other investigators, including John Goetz and David Sherman, found other pieces of shattered metal, each with partial identification numbers that were later traced back to the van. At about 5:30 P.M., the group emerged from the garage, having been warned that the chunks of concrete had not yet been stabilized, and they turned their evidence over to laboratory technicians.
The next day, almost certain that the mangled piece of frame would prove invaluable, one of the investigators went to the laboratory and extracted the number himself. He then turned it over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which tracked the part to a rental van, and finally to New Jersey and Mohammed A. Salameh , who was arrested last night and charged with participating in the bombing that left five dead and more than a thousand injured.
In the four days between that initial discovery, the 10 investigators were reassigned to other, smaller teams to continue examining the site. The principal evidence, however, had been found.

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall on Signs of Weaker Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stock prices retreated a bit yesterday despite another surge in bond prices as new reports of economic weakness put pressure on the market.
Health-care and technology issues were among the notable losers. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 5.13 points, to 3,398.91.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 1.92 points, to 447.34, while the Nasdaq composite index lost 3.19 points, to 680.73.
 
Trading Volume Eases
 Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 234.2 million shares, down from 277.4 million on Wednesday. Advancing issues led decliners by 967 to 931 on the Big Board.
The stock and bond markets reacted differently yesterday to Government reports that factory orders were weaker than expected in January and that jobless claims increased in the latest period. Traders in both markets are also awaiting today's report on the nation's employment in February.
"The Dow and the Nasdaq were basically impacted by the weak economic data, which prompted the rally in the bond market, since those same numbers had just the opposite effect on stocks," said Robert C. Walberg, and equity analyst at MMS International, a Wall Street economic analysis and research firm.
Still, some traders said, further declines in stocks may be limited by falling interest rates. Yesterday, the rally in bond prices pushed the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds as low as 6.68 percent, before it edged back up to 6.73 percent. As yields in the bond market have been falling, some investors have turned to stocks in hopes of higher returns.
Mr. Walberg of MMS showed no concern about yesterday's market pullback. "We believe that low interest rates, low inflation and market sentiment are all still decidedly bullish," he said. "And we continue to expect new all time highs on the major market indexes by early spring."
 
Health-Care Weakness
 A factor weighing on the Nasdaq composite index yesterday was the downgrading of a couple of health- care stocks. U.S. Healthcare down 3 1/2, to 43, and Utah Medical down 2 1/4, to 16 1/2, suffered at the hands of analysts who revised their recommendations. U.S. Surgical, which was not downgraded, fell in sympathy as the stock dipped 2 1/2, to 58 1/2, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Other stocks weighing on the market included Intel, which fell 1 1/4, to 118 5/8, and Salomon Inc., which dropped 2, to 39 1/2. Salomon yesterday disclosed a pretax operating loss of $250 million in January and February that some analysts said might have been linked to bond trades that bet against a decline in interest rates.
Philip Morris fell 1 1/4, to 65 3/8, as Prudential Securities cut the rating on its stock amid talk of possible tax increases on cigarettes.
Nike, which began falling out of favor with investors about two weeks ago when it announced that earnings would be hurt by a slowdown in the European economy, dropped 3 1/4, to 71 5/8, yesterday.
Most retail stocks bounced back, posting only minimal declines. Wal-Mart and the Gap both fell 7/8, to 32 7/8 and 32 3/8, respectively.

HEADLINE: THE TWIN TOWERS: The Complaint;
Starting With Debris

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the complaint against Mohammed A. Salameh filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

 	 	 		. . .	 	On Feb. 26, 1993, an explosion occurred in the garage area beneath the Vista Hotel, located at the World Trade Center complex in New York, N.Y. (hereinafter "explosion site"), causing massive destruction and the death of at least five individuals.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 
 While collecting debris from the explosion site, the explosives expert has identified components of a vehicle which contained the explosive device. Among the components that the explosives expert has identified is a part of the vehicle displaying stamped numerical and alphabetical impressions from the manufacturer of the vehicle which he recognized as a portion of the manufacturer's vehicle identification number ("VIN").
Using the partial VIN as well as other information gathered during the crime scene investigation concerning characteristics of the vehicle which contained the explosive device, a fellow Special Agent of the FBI reconstructed the complete VIN of the vehicle which contained the explosive device.
A VIN history check revealed that the vehicle identified by that particular VIN was a Ford Econoline E-350 Van bearing Alabama license plate number XA 70668 (the "van"). A check with the Alabama authorities revealed that the van is registered to the Ryder Truck Rental Co. ("Ryder") in Alabama. Further investigation revealed that on or about Feb. 23, 1993, the van was rented for a one-week period from an office located in Jersey City, N.J., by an individual who identified himself as Mohammed Salameh.
On or about Feb. 26, 1993, approximately two to three hours after the bombing, Salameh returned to the Jersey City Ryder office. At the time, Salameh stated that the van had been stolen from a grocery store parking lot the night before (Feb. 25, 1993). Salameh requested a refund of a cash deposit he had left for the van but was told by a Ryder employee that he had to report the theft to the police and produce a copy of the police report in order to obtain a refund.
Later that evening, an individual identifying himself as Salameh entered a Jersey City police station and spoke with the desk officer. The individual told the desk officer, in substance, that the rental van he had been using had been stolen the previous evening. The individual further stated that he had attempted to report the theft the previous evening, but had been unable to because he did not have the license plate number of the van.
On March 4, 1993, Salameh returned to the Jersey City Ryder office. At the time, a Ryder employee identified Mohammed A. Salameh as the individual who had rented the van which was used in the World Trade Center bombing. Shortly thereafter, the defendant was arrested.
In connection with the rental agreement for the van, Salameh provided the telephone number (201) 435-7501 as a contact number, which further investigation revealed is subscribed to by Josie Hadas, 34 Kensington Ave., Apartment 4, Jersey City, N.J. A search warrant was executed this afternoon at this location, and special agents of the FBI recovered, among other things, a letter addressed to the defendant, tools and wiring, and manuals concerning antennae, circuitry and electromagnetic devices. A law enforcement officer trained as a bomb technician has examined these materials and has concluded that they constitute evidence of a "bomb maker" at the location. Lastly, a dog trained in the detection of explosives responded positively to a closet space within the apartment.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Mr. Lizzard, Following His Dream

BYLINE: By Charles Strum

DATELINE: ALPINE, N.J.

 BODY:
WHAT man has not wanted to live the imagined life? To fly like Chuck Yeager or Michael Jordan. To dance like Fred Astaire in a ballroom clinch with the girl of his dreams. To own a saloon and buy drinks for all his friends. To step off the treadmill, slip the bonds of 9-to-5 capitalism and give the soul some breathing room.
A show of hands, please? 
 Very good. Now, how many have actually dared to put the rose in their teeth and leap up on the table?
Only one? Way in the back? That clean-cut, slightly pear-shaped young man with the California king snake around his neck.
Naturally. It is Mr. Lizzard.
Once, Mr. Lizzard was merely Mark E. Wellington, a pleasant enough fellow with a contracting business and an acknowledged inability to spell simple words like lizard (one Z, according to the dictionary; two Z's, if you are Mr. Lizzard). Today he is a man living his compulsion: to share the joy of reptiles, which helps him get across the more urgent message that mankind is imperiling the environment.
This self-taught naturalist with the controlled but infectious enthusiasm of Indiana Jones has turned a lifelong hobby into a livelihood, which is not quite the same thing as a job.
"My main goal is to be independently wealthy and come and go as I please," Mr. Wellington said the other day, standing in the kitchen of his cozy Victorian cottage in this almost-rural reservation of large estates. "But if you have to work, this is a hell of a good choice."
It was not that Mr. Wellington disliked the contracting business all that much, although that was only the most recent of his mainstream vocations. Contracting required meeting someone else's expectations. Being Mr. Lizzard -- this is, admittedly, a fine point -- really requires meeting only one's own expectations. After all, people call on Mr. Lizzard because he is Mr. Lizzard, not because he is Mr. Mammal or Mr. Conifer, although he knows something about them, too.
His is the heart of the collector, the boy who raised mice, who built customized bookcases for his room with a glassed-in tarantula cage in the center. The teen-ager whose high school had to hire him part time to take care of the science lab he had stocked himself.
Skipping college, except for a brief stretch studying environmental science in Maine, Mr. Wellington went to work for his father, a millionaire industrialist. Later, he sold real estate. Finally, he joined his father and a brother restoring historic brownstones in Jersey City. Then the recession arrived, creating enforced leisure.
"That's when my daughter asked me to bring Petey the rat to school," he said.
Mr. Wellington did 10 minutes with Petey, a household pet. The rest is history. A day at school for Mr. Lizzard runs almost $500, plus expenses; a small birthday party goes for $145.
While his two daughters, ages 10 and 6, have accepted his menagerie, his marriage foundered on the rocks of the work ethic.
"My wife couldn't tolerate anything unsteady," he said, bringing out a favorite T-shirt. It depicts a snake coiled around a snake fancier, and it reads: "My wife says that if I buy one more snake she's going to leave me. Boy, am I going to miss her."
Don't be misled by Mr. Lizzard's disdain for the time clock or elbow grease. He has constructed a nifty climate-controlled herpetology den just off what was once the living room. He spends at least $100 a week for heat, light, frozen mice and rats (snake nourishment) and sundries for 30 reptiles, some tarantulas and a skunk. And schlepping reptiles all over New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania is no picnic.
"I'm searching for mellow, legal, nonpoisonous, well-traveling animals," he said. "That's why snakes are good." They are easily transported in a retrofitted beer chest with a hot water bottle in it.
His appearances are entry-level natural science workshops.
"It's hardly anything other than, 'We're having fun, and look at this, and we're part of the food chain.' Everybody pets and touches. No scientific names." He talks about the interrelatedness of air, water, food, animals. And he paints a grim picture.
"My basic thing to the kids is: 'If we continue what we do to the environment, we're all all going to be dead.' O.K., I'm not too harsh. We're not going to be dead next week or next year. But how would you like it if your grandchildren had to go out with a gas mask on?"
His dream is to have a big green Winnebago, with someone to drive him and someone to set up his shows.
"Then I would go out and talk to the kids," he said. "I would be dead if I had to get a desk job."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bond's Yield Down to 6.73%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market rally that doesn't want to stop kept moving ahead yesterday, as the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond dropped to 6.73 percent, from 6.78 percent on Wednesday.
And for a time yesterday, shorter-term interest rates also declined sharply, giving an indication that some investors and traders expect the economy to slow enough to force the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates again. 
 Early in the day, the price of the 30-year bond was up about 1 1/4 points, and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 6.68 percent. This is the lowest interest rate since 30-year bonds began to be issued regularly 16 years ago and the lowest interest rate on any long-term bond since the Treasury issued a 20-year bond with a 6.75 percent coupon in January 1973.
 
 
Some Steam Is Lost
 But in the afternoon, the run-up lost a little steam, analysts said, because the rally had come so fast and because the February employment numbers, which will be released this morning, always give traders and investors a pause. In late trading, the price of the bond was up 22/32 , to 1052/32 .
There were also questions about how long the rally could continue. Peter Woll, an analyst at Municipal Market Data in Boston, expressed caution even as he acknowledged that the rally had already trampled those who were cautious.
"There is some concern this market is getting itself overblown," he said. "But we have been in and out of that camp for the last 100 basis points" of the decline in long-term yields.
 
 
Counting on Fed Easing
 In the morning rally, shorter-term yields on everything from three-month Treasury bills to two- , three- and five-year notes were swept lower. The discount rate on three-month bills fell to 2.88 percent (it ended the day at 2.91 percent) and the yields on two-year notes fell to 3.67 percent. Three-year notes fell to 4.07 percent, and five-year notes to 4.90 percent. (They ended the day at 3.72 percent, 4.16 percent and 5 percent, respectively.)
"At one point, it was beginning to price in a Fed ease," said Charles Lieberman, the director of financial market research at Chemical Securities, referring to how the market would respond to the expectation of a cut in interest rates by the Fed.
If today's employment report is weak, short rates could fall again. Mr. Lieberman is expecting a weak report, with an increase of only 50,000 in nonfarm payroll jobs. The consensus forecast is 126,000, according to Bloomberg Business News.
Two factors are accounting for the somewhat surprising drop in short-term yields. One is that economists and analysts do believe that President Clinton's deficit reduction will slow the growth of the economy, becuase he will be raising taxes and cutting government spending.
In addition, there has been a string of recent economic reports -- including a jump in initial jobless claims in late February, a January decline in factory orders and weak February retail sales -- that were weaker than expected.
"When I put that all together, I think that things might be slowing more than people think," said Stephen Slifer, the financial market economist at Lehman Brothers. And if you see a weak employment number tomorrow, the market will begin to expect it."
Mr. Slifer says he thinks the Federal Reserve will have to ease in the future as the economy continues to grow at a sluggish annual pace of around 2.5 percent. But Mr. Lieberman does not expect the Fed to ease, saying the economy is not heading back toward a recession.
 
 
Other Bonds
 The rush to refinance corporate and municipal debt at these unexpectedly low interest rates kept sales of new issues moving yesterday. There was about $2 billion of new corporate issues, including $200 million of 50-year bonds sold by Texaco Inc. This was the first 50-year bond ever sold by an industrial company, according to John Hewitt, the company's senior assistant treasurer.
The bonds, which are not callable for 20 years, were priced to yield 7.59 percent, which was 89 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the 6.70 percent yield on the 30-year Treasury bond at the time of the sale.
Mr. Hewitt said that the company got interested in the idea at the urging of Salomon Brothers, the lead underwriter, as the yield on the 30-year bond moved toward 6.80 percent. "We felt there was value in the bond for Texaco," he said, noting that the company could call the bonds in 20 years.
For investors who have been losing higher-interest-rate bonds as they have been called and refinanced, the 20-year protection against such a call was an attractive incentive. Robert Kleinert, the head of the fixed-income syndicate at Salomon, said the bonds were in such demand that the issue was increased to $200 million, from $150 million.
In the municipal market, prices were up about 3/8 point, according to Mr. Woll, after being up as much as 3/4 point. He said demand was strong enough for new issues that most were repriced yesterday to lower the yields. A sale of $579 million of revenue bonds for the New York Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority were repriced to yield from 2 percent in 1994 to 5.4 percent in 2015.

HEADLINE: Stocks Gain Allure as Bonds Lose Their Luster

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
A continued plunge in interest rates to the lowest level in decades is causing many money managers to make fundamental shifts in their investment strategies, flocking to stocks in search of the high returns that bonds had previously provided. Their enthusiasm has propelled some market averages to within inches of new highs this week, with stocks regaining all the ground they lost two weeks ago as President Clinton presented his proposed budget.
The consequences go far beyond the investment community. The stock market's vigor, if sustained, can help companies sell stock to pay down debt, expand and, often, add employees. 
 "All the things happening in the financial markets are extraordinarily constructive for corporate America," said Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch, referring both to lower interest rates and increased stock issuance. "The cost of capital has really come down dramatically in the last year. By many measures, it's lower for American companies than Japanese companies."
Although some money managers say stocks are already expensive, many consider the alternatives so unrewarding that they are willing to take some chances. Yesterday, the yield on the 30-year bond dropped to 6.73 percent, down from 6.78 percent the day before. [Page D13.]
"When bond yields are down in the 6 or 7 percent range," said Andrew R. Harmstone, who manages more than $2 billion for J. P. Morgan, "you get paid more to take on extra risk with stocks."
Although short-term thinking often rules the markets, the managers of pension funds and some other large investment pools move cautiously in changing their mix of stocks, bonds and cash -- the general term for risk-free but low-yielding investments.
The nation's 1,000 largest pension funds intend to put 55 percent of their assets into stocks, up from a goal of 52 percent a year ago, according to a survey conducted in January by Callan Associates, a financial consulting firm, as the plunge in bond yields was still gathering momentum.
With pension funds controlling more than $2.7 trillion in assets -- an amount nearly twice the national budget -- even a slight shift can make the markets jump.
For these money managers, the migration to stocks parallels the course already taken by individual investors. Individuals fled their low-yielding money market accounts and certificates of deposits to become net buyers of stocks in 1992 for the first time in 30 years.
 
An Uncertain Trend
 It remains uncertain how long the shift into stocks will continue. Some investors consider stock prices much higher than corporate earnings can support. Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.13 points, to 3,398.91, though bond prices rose.
President Clinton and his aides have claimed credit for the fall in interest rates, saying that investors are confident that their plans to cut the Government deficit will succeed. A lower deficit, with less Government borrowing, readily translates into lower interest rates.
The 6.7 percent interest now available on the Treasury's highest-yielding, 30-year bond falls far short of the returns many money managers have promised to deliver.
To meet a target of 8 3/4 percent, the $72 billion California Public Employees Retirement System appears likely to be among those switching money from bonds to stocks. "With yields well below 7 percent, it makes you look at other alternatives," said DeWitt Bowman, the fund's chief investment officer. The prospect for enhancing these yields with further gains in bond prices is limited, he added, explaining, "The bond market can't go to zero."
California's fund assesses its basic stance only once a year.
Stocks are more risky than bonds, with their returns varying more widely from year to year. But over the long term, stocks return about 10 percent annually, several percentage points more than bonds and much more than cash.
Changes by a few large money managers, sometimes taking place step-by-step over days or weeks, can sometimes result in jagged market reactions that have little apparent relation to the day's news.
Analysts saw major institutions shifting from bonds to stocks on Tuesday afternoon, when the Dow Jones industrial average jumped about 30 points, or almost 1 percent, to pass the 3,400 mark in the last hour.
The Dow now stands about 1 percent below the record of 3,442 set on Feb. 5, with such broader market indexes as the Standard & Poor's 500 even closer to their highs. Stocks have recovered since their mid-month fall despite a round of weak economic reports and Mr. Clinton's calls for larger tax increases on corporations and individuals than he had previously specified.
While such events might normally depress stock prices, the bond market shot high enough to more than compensate, analysts said. Besides believing that the deficit might shrink, many investors say that slower growth, with low inflation, will also keep bond prices high.
 
'A Pretty Narrow Tightrope'
 Some strategists, however, see rising risks in both stock and bond markets. A sharp reversal in bond prices, raising the available yields, would probably drag the stock market down, they say. Although low inflation and slow growth have given many bond investors confidence, a change in these conditions could cause interest rates to rise.
"All that's holding the market right now is interest rates," said David Borger, the research director at Wilshire Asset Management, which invests for many pension funds. "You're walking a pretty narrow tightrope if you're trying to make money in stocks and you're not a believer in bonds also."
Investors have recently bought record volumes of new shares, though the market's volatility has blocked a few issues. Companies that raise money by selling stock, instead of selling bonds or borrowing from banks, have greater flexibility.
For a company struck by recession or increased competition, cutting dividends conserves cash, even at the cost of angering shareholders. Missing a bank payment or defaulting on bonds can throw a company into bankruptcy.

HEADLINE: Two European Giants Fail to Stop Their Slides

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 4

 BODY:
Two huge European companies Philips N.V. and Groupe Bull S.A. -- today announced substantial losses for 1992 as well as plans for new layoffs, underscoring the difficulties Europe has had pulling itself out of recession.
Philips, Europe's largest consumer electronics company, posted a $489 million loss. The company, based in Eindhoven, the Netherlands, said it would lay off as many as 15,000 workers this year from a work force of 250,000. 
 Groupe Bull, a French computer maker, reported a $892 million loss and said it would lay off 3,000 people this year.
Together, the two dismal performances illustrate the deepening recession in Europe, where unemployment is rising and business confidence is slumping as industries including steel and autos grapple with a deepening economic crisis.
 
No Recovery in Sight
 Philips, which had reported a profit of $608.6 million in 1991, said its slump was chiefly the result of sharp price declines on products like color televisions, a stagnating market, excess capacity and currency instability in Europe. The company said also that it could not provide earnings predictions for 1993 because of the current uncertainties.
"The group management committee does not expect a recovery of the world economy during 1993," Philips said. "Prospects are relatively better in the United States, but Philips's main markets in Europe show no signs of improvement."
The company's 1992 loss came on sales of $31.8 billion, which were up 3 percent, compared with $30.9 billion for 1991. Europe accounted for 60 percent of Philips's sales last year, and the United States and Canada accounted for 21 percent.
 
Prices to Keep Falling
 "Philips is in trouble, and the outlook for their businesses, particularly in Europe, is poor," said Andrew Haskins, an electronics analyst at James Capel in London. "Falling volume and falling prices will continue to be the trend in consumer electronics in Europe in 1993."
Consumer electronics accounts for about 37 percent of Philips's total sales.
The company said it took a $652.2 million restructuring charge for 1992 mainly to cover the cost of planned layoffs in its consumer electronics and components sectors. It declined to say when the layoffs would be completed.
 
A Disappointment for Bull
 Bull's earnings report showed a decline from 1991, when the company posted a $585 million loss. While Bull's chief executive, Bernard Pache, and other top officials emphasized that the company had narrowed its operating loss in 1992 to $121 million, from $205 million for the previous year, the results were clearly a disappointment. Bull, which owns Zenith Data Systems in the United States, had planned to break even on its operations for 1992.
The $892 million loss for 1992 included a special provision of $462 million. More than half this sum will be spent to cover restructuring costs, including the probable layoffs this year of about 3,000 of the company's 35,000 employees. Bull has already cut 3,500 jobs in the last three years.
Sales fell 9.8 percent last year, to $5.7 billion. The company, which provided its own dollar conversions for its results at an average 1992 rate of 5.294 francs to the dollar, said one- third of the decline in sales was a result of currency fluctuations.
"Revenues were also affected by recessionary economic conditions worldwide, continued industry turmoil brought on by structural changes and pressures caused by aggressive price wars in personal computers," Bull said in a statement.
In a telephone interview, the company's chief financial officer, Jacques Lebhar, said prices for microcomputers had fallen by 50 percent last year in Europe.
 Bull's results were in line with the general slump in the European computer business. Manufacturers including Olivetti of Italy and Siemens Nixdorf of Germany have recently reported substantial losses in the face of stiff competition, plunging prices for personal computers and a European recession.
"Business is bad almost everywhere in the computer industry, and the Bull results are hardly surprising," Mary Tonnaire, an analyst at Dataquest in Paris, said. "The price war will continue into 1993 and the winners will be those, like Compaq, who can adjust most quickly."
Philips, under its president, Jan Timmer, who took over in mid-1990, has concentrated on its core consumer electronics business, divesting itself of its information systems division and some other interests. A question mark still hangs over this strategy.
New products such as the Compact Disk Interactive (CD-1) -- a compact disk player that combines sound, images and graphics -- and the digital compact cassette have yet to make an impact, and analysts predict that they will not contribute to profits before 1994 at the earliest.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jan Timmer, president of Philips N.V., at the announcement yesterday of his company's $489 million loss for 1992. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: As Expected, Retailers Post Slow February Sales

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
The nation's retail chains reported yesterday that sales sagged in February compared with the same month last year. Analysts attributed the dip mostly to bad weather, which kept shoppers home, and to consumers' concerns over the economy.
Sales had been expected to drop after a very good Christmas season and a surprisingly strong January. Retailers usually spend February stocking spring merchandise and eliminating winter goods, so the month is often a lackluster one.
 
Suggests a Slowing Recovery
 Still, the latest figures disappointed some analysts and offered further evidence that the recovery has slowed since the start of the year. 
 The Salomon Brothers retail index, which follows monthly sales of 22 big retailers, showed that sales in stores open at least one year fell 1 percent in February. That compared with a 5.4 percent increase in January over January 1992. In December, retailers reported the strongest increase for a holiday season since 1988.
Other recent surveys have shown a drop in consumer confidence in the economy. Economists have noted that shoppers' pay increases have lagged behind their increased spending.
Jeffrey M. Feiner, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, attributed February's sales showing to bad weather as well as heavy promotions a year earlier that improved those sales figures. He also cited President Clinton's announcement last month of his economic plan, which includes tax increases to help cut the deficit.
 
Clinton's Effect Debated
 The plan "caused some uncertainty among consumers wondering whether it would have a really negative impact on the economy, on their own pocketbook, and so on," Mr. Feiner said.
But he sounded a note of optimism. "While this month was disappointing, that is due to what we believe to be nonrecurring or abnormal factors," Mr. Feiner said. "With more normal weather in March, we expect to see a pickup in sales. It is our opinion that underlying consumer demand still remains relatively favorable."
Edward Johnson, director of Johnson Redbook Service, a publication of the brokerage firm Lynch, Jones & Ryan that monitors retail performance, was less certain about the effects of the Clinton plan.
"The stores are saying that they think that the Clinton tax measures have hurt the consumer, but they can't be sure because of the weather," he said. "They don't know how much was the weather and how much was Clinton."
 
Leap Day's Impact
 Another factor in the disappointing numbers was the fact that the month this year lacked the extra selling day enjoyed last February in a leap year. The effect can be significant: for example, if results for Feb. 29, 1992, were excluded from last year's figure, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. would have shown a 6 percent increase in same-store sales for February this year instead of the flat sales it reported.
Mr. Barnard said the strongest sectors were furniture, home furnishings, appliances and electronics. He said chains with strong sales included Bed, Bath and Beyond, which was up 6 percent, and Heilig-Meyers, a Southern furnishings chain, which was up 8 percent.
Among the weakest sectors was apparel. Filene's Basement reported a 10 percent decline, and the Limited Inc. sales fell by 6 percent. Sears, Roebuck & Company, on the other hand, posted same-store sales gains of 2.2 percent.
 
Retailers' Sales Detailed
By The Associated Press

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Mark Trading But Is Stronger Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against European currencies yesterday after Germany's central bank failed to make an expected cut in interest rates. But the dollar gained on the yen on hints of Japanese intervention to prop it up.
Gold prices were mostly lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $329.00, unchanged from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped 5 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $328.75 an ounce. 
 After advancing against the mark in European trading on expectations of a German rate cut, the dollar fell sharply when the Bundesbank left key rates unchanged.
Analysts said markets had been fairly active, with speculative dollar buying in anticipation of Bundesbank action that would have narrowed the gap between German and United States interest rates.
But "when it didn't happen, we saw the dollar trade down against the mark," said Kevin Lawrie, foreign exchange manager for the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
 
Japan Seen Intervening
 Overnight in Tokyo, traders said, the Bank of Japan called dealers to check currency rates. This was seen as a precursor to intervention to prevent a further slide of the dollar against the yen, which Japanese officials feel could wreak further havoc on the country's stagnating economy.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 116.98 yen, up 0.23 yen from Wednesday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 116.75 yen. In New York, the dollar ended at 116.75, up from 116.65 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.4540, from $1.4505 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.4560 to buy one pound, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.4510.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6380 German marks, down from 1.6460; 1.5195 Swiss francs, down from 1.5235; 5.5590 French francs, down from 5.5860; 1,563 Italian lire, down from 1,565, and 1.24365 Canadian dollars, up from 1.24225.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6340 German marks, down from 1.6459; 1.5165 Swiss francs, down from 1.5262; 5.5555 French francs, down from 5.5865; 1.8380 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8508; 1,563.00 Italian lire, down from 1,568.00, and 1.2424 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2472.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Boeing Sees Plane Orders Increasing

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
The Boeing Company said yesterday that it expected world air travel and demand for new airplanes to recover from the current slump, resulting in substantial growth by the end of the decade.
The Boeing 1993 Current Market Outlook, released yesterday, predicted that worldwide passenger travel would grow at an average annual rate of 5.4 percent from now through 2010. As a result, at least 12,000 commercial airliners, from all manufacturers, will be needed during those 18 years to accommodate growth and to replace older airplanes, according to the report.
 
$45 Billion in Annual Sales Seen
 Boeing estimated the value of the 12,000 aircraft at about $815 billion in 1993 dollars, averaging $45 billion a year in industrywide sales until 2010, compared with $21 billion annually for the last 20 years. The estimate did not represent a significant change from Boeing's projections of a year ago, and Boeing shares closed yesterday unchanged at $34.50 on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Boeing's optimistic outlook comes after two months in which the Seattle company announced plans to scale back production of all of its commercial aircraft, and to eliminate 28,000 jobs within the next 18 months. Boeing had said the cuts were necessary because of canceled and delayed orders from carriers suffering from the global economic slump.
Speaking at a news conference in Washington yesterday, Richard R. Albrecht, executive vice president of the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group, said that from an overall traffic decline in 1991, air travel improved during 1992.
"However, especially in the case of the domestic carriers," he said, "some of this growth came at the expense of yield," which is revenue per passenger-mile, because of the recession and the airlines' ruinous fare wars.
Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst with UBS Securities, said Boeing's "macro-forecast remains plausible." But he added that uncertainty remained as to whether "the global trade and investment framework remain as dependent on global transportation in the next 20 years as in the last 20 years."
Boeing said the Asia/Pacific region, especially China, would enjoy the highest future growth rates. Japan and China are the second- and third-largest aircraft markets, respectively, after the United States.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Antitrust Exemption Is Targeted In Senate

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
In a long anticipated move, Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum today introduced legislation that would eliminate major league baseball's 71-year-old exemption from Federal antitrust laws.
The Democrat from Ohio said the 1922 Supreme Court ruling, which exempted the major leagues from antitrust laws on the ground that the game could not be considered interstate commerce, no longer applies. 
 Repeal of the exemption would allow major league teams to move between cities without the permission of other major league clubs.
"Baseball is big business," said Metzenbaum, chairman of the Subcommittee on Antitrust, Monopolies and Business Rights of the Senate Judiciary Committee. "It's a billion-and-a-half-dollar business, and it doesn't need nor does it deserve any special treatment under our antitrust laws."
Metzenbaum said that because baseball affects the public's taxes, the economies of local communities and the cost of cable television service, it should abide by the same rules that govern other industries. He said the 28 owners conduct themselves "like selfish barons lording over their personal billion-dollar domains," and should comply with federal monopoly laws as must professional basketball, football and hockey teams.
 
Tampa Bay 'Jilted'
 He and Senators Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, and Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, who co-sponsored the bill, pointed to the recent situation in which owners blocked Tampa Bay's $115 million offer to buy and move the San Francisco Giants. A San Francisco group allowed to bid on the team by the National League offered $100 million to Bob Lurie, and the league decreed that Lurie sell the Giants to the San Francisco group.
The Tampa Bay area, which also failed in its a bid for an expansion franchise when Miami and Denver were added to the National League, was "jilted" by the owners, Mack said.
Bud Selig of the Milwaukee Brewers, who leads the executive committee and in effect runs the major leagues, said the move was not unexpected. He defended baseball's use of the exemption.
"If you look at history," he said at a news conference after an owners' meeting today in Phoenix, "the antitrust exemption protects the public. If you asked Baltimore or Oakland football fans about having an exemption, that would give you the answer. What does it do for you if you take away the exemption. The fact of the matter is when all is said and done, the antitrust exemption has been a protection for the fans and baseball hasn't abused it."
Since Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes wrote the 1922 opinion granting the exemption, the high court has refused to overturn the decision. In 1971, however, the Court stated that Congress should reconsider it if there is "any inconsistency or illogic" to the exemption.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Who Sold What?
It looks as though it will take a trial to determine the power of a handshake between an artist and a gallery. 
 For those who are just tuning in, there's a new chapter in the continuing lawsuit against the artist Peter Halley, the dealer Larry Gagosian and the Gagosian Gallery, which has branches on Madison Avenue and in SoHo. The suit was filed eight months ago in State Supreme Court in Manhattan by the Sonnabend Gallery, which is in SoHo. Last week, the court released Justice Carol H. Arber's decision to deny a motion, filed by Mr. Gagosian and his gallery, to have the suit dismissed.
In February 1992, Mr. Halley left Sonnabend, where he had been represented for six years, and moved to Gagosian. He took with him 11 works, which Sonnabend says the artist made for a show scheduled to open last May. The exhibition at Sonnabend never took place; instead Mr. Halley's show opened at Gagosian's Wooster Street gallery in June. When the show was announced, Sonnabend filed the lawsuit, charging breach of contract and seeking damages. Sonnabend also sought, unsuccessfully, a temporary restraining order against Mr. Halley's show at Gagosian.
 
Buyers, but No Works
 According to court documents, Sonnabend is contending that although it had no written agreement with the artist, it had presold 11 of the works in the show. Sonnabend said that as of Feb. 27, 1992, the day Mr. Halley sent the gallery a letter to announce his departure, its director, Antonio Homem, had buyers for the 11 works and had paid Mr. Halley advances against the sales.
In June, Justice Arber ruled that Sonnabend had insufficient evidence that the 11 works had already been bought. Ten of the paintings were then sold by Gagosian for $75,000 each. According to court documents, a diptych priced at $150,000 was bought by the Whitney Museum of American Art. The Sonnabend Gallery contends that they had first showed the work to the Whitney; however, Mr. Gagosian got the commission. Sonnabend claims that the commissions belong to them. In her decision, Justice Arber said, "If plaintiff demonstrates at trial that the sale occurred prior to Halley's departure from Sonnabend, then plaintiff may be entitled to commissions resulting from these sales."
But in denying the motion to dismiss the suit, Justice Arber has decided that Sonnabend's complaint, despite the absence of a written contract, must go to trial. If Sonnabend can prove that Mr. Halley's oral agreement was as binding as a written contract, it could receive substantial punitive damages.
 
Incentive Is Denied
 If, as Sonnabend charges in court documents, the Gagosian Gallery gave Mr. Halley $2 million as an incentive to join it, the court could interpret that as economic duress. Both Mr. Halley and Mr. Gagosian deny it. "It's total fabrication," said Martin Wasser, Mr. Gagosian's lawyer and a partner at Phillips, Nizer, Benjamin, Krim & Ballon. "It will be impossible for them to prove."
Mr. Wasser added that he was pleased that the court had thrown out one of Sonnabend's claims, in which Ileanna Sonnabend, the gallery's owner, said she was promised a diptych for her own personal art collection for half the $150,000 retail price. As for the rest of the decision, Mr. Wasser said he doesn't think "Sonnabend will be able to substantiate its claims or that they will be successful in proving any of the allegations."
In a broader context, the case is yet another illustration of the big money that's now involved in handling a successful artist. Sonnabend Gallery charges that Mr. Halley left Sonnabend because he was able to get a written contract from Gagosian that promised him a stipend larger than the $40,000 he had received from Sonnabend.
"The judge is letting the court decide the practices of the art market," said Daniel Shapiro, Sonnabend's lawyer.
Whether the case goes as far as a trial remains to be seen. Stay tuned.
 
A Successful Art Show
 Everyone was surprised by the brisk business at the fifth annual Art Show, which ended Monday after a five-day run at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue. The press office for the show, which is organized by the Art Dealers Association of America, reported 13,500 visitors, the largest crowd in three years. "Not only was attendance up, but about 80 percent of the exhibitors made sales," said O. Kelly Anderson, director of the Art Dealers Association.
Art experts suggested that the dealers this year had been careful to price works conservatively. And that being realistic had paid off.
Noting that he had come to the show "prepared for a disappointment," Richard Gray, a Chicago dealer, said, "Although business in the gallery has been better recently, I thought the news from Washington about Clinton's proposed economic plan would have taken the wind out of our sails, since the rise in taxes will affect my customers." But much to Mr. Gray's surprise, he sold more than $5 million worth of art, including works by Picasso, Paul Klee, Alberto Giacometti, Henry Moore and Anselm Kiefer.
William Beadleston, a New York dealer, also reported some important sales, including a painting by Jean Dubuffet. "People seemed more optimistic," he said. "There were lots of new buyers. It seemed the art world had gone back to the way it was years ago, when collectors buy for their pleasure, not for their purses."
 
Non-Traveling Shoes
 Since 1958, van Gogh's "Shoes" has been on loan to the Metropolitan Museum of Art from an unidentified private collector. Happily for the Metropolitan, "Shoes" isn't going anywhere. Walter H. Annenberg, the publisher, philanthropist and former United States Ambassador to Britain, who two years ago promised to bequeath roughly $1 billion worth of paintings to the Metropolitan, bought the painting from the collector and has added the 1888 van Gogh to his list of gifts.
Philippe de Montebello, the museum's director, confirmed Mr. Annenberg's most recent donation but declined to disclose what Mr. Annenberg had paid for the painting.
" 'Shoes' will be one more van Gogh in the Annenberg collection," Mr. de Montebello said. It brings the total to six. At the moment, "Shoes" is on view in the temporary exhibition space in the European Paintings Galleries, which are under renovation. It will eventually join the other 53 paintings from the Annenberg collection that are scheduled to go on view beginning Sept. 21 when the 19th-century European Painting and Sculpture galleries reopen.
 
Higher Commissions
 Phillips, the world's third largest auction house, based in London, has caved in, too. Last week it announced that it would follow Sotheby's and Christie's and increase its buyer's premium to 15 percent on lots sold for 30,000 (about $42,000) or less. The buyer's premium, a fee the purchaser pays to the auction house in addition to the final bid, will remain at 10 percent on any portion of the price above 30,000.
Phillips will also keep the old premium of 10 percent for specialized sales of stamps, coins, metals and wine in London.
In addition to the buyer's commission, auction houses also charge a seller's commission, a negotiable fee paid by the seller that can range from nothing to 15 percent of the final price. A higher buyer's premium means that an auction house can shave more off the seller's premium, and thereby attract more consignments.
"We were strongly opposed to raising the premium," said Christopher Weston, the chairman of Phillips. "In 1975, when our competitors first introduced the buyer's premium, we held out for three years and eight months. It ended up helping everyone except Phillips." Now, Mr. Weston said, he feels that Phillips has been "backed into a corner."
The last straw he said, was an attempt last year by Sotheby's to snatch away a Phillips client by offering to sell a painting without charging her a seller's commission. At stake was "The Promised Land" by the English painter Charles Spencelaugh; it eventually sold at Phillips for 91,000 (or about $127,400).
Diana Phillips, who heads Sotheby's press offices in New York and London, conceded that Sotheby's had made such an offer. "While the auction business is a competitive business, we do respect the consignments from other firms," she said. "This is not our normal practice."
Mr. Weston, who said Phillips's market share in London was in excess of 10 percent, added: "Sotheby's has really given us no choice. We have to maintain a competitive stance or we'll lose the opportunity to sell top-flight items, as well as market share."

HEADLINE: Where Stardust Dreams Are, Always

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
THE image of a Manhattan nightclub for many people will always be synonymous with the impossibly glamorous fantasies of New York nightlife imagined by Hollywood movies of the 1930's and 40's. And when Mary Cleere Haran, a singer who cultivates a sophisticated but wholesome 1940's look, performed for the first time at Rainbow and Stars recently, she evoked that mythical ambiance with a wistful good humor.
"It's not exactly what I had envisioned it would be like when I saw those movies with nightclubs," she observed of Rainbow and Stars, which represents the top of the line in New York City cabarets. 
 "As beautiful and romantic as this room is, it's so small compared to those vast Hollywood soundstages where they used to build those gorgeous white Art Deco nightclub sets. And for another thing, I have to sing more than one song per show.
"If you've seen any of those movies, the lights would dim, there would be a drum roll or a fanfare, a spotlight would hit the bandstand, and out would come Rita Hayworth or Veronica Lake or Lizbeth Scott, who would proceed to sing one song. Then she'd get to sit down at a ringside table with the likes of Alan Ladd or Glenn Ford, engage in some light flirtatious banter laced with double-entendres. And then our male protagonist would say something that hit a little too close to home, she'd get insulted, bolt up, and run out of the room in tears."
If the nightclub dream world that Ms. Haran conjures so wittily never existed in real life, what is surprising is how many New York clubs offer small but delicious pieces of that world, each one with its own special flavor.
New York, moreover, is the only city left in the country that offers anything resembling the old-time nightclub entertainment where the songs of Cole Porter or Richard Rodgers or George Gershwin live on. Cabaret's continued existence, despite perilous economics, owes much to the proximity of Broadway, which, while having its own problems, still draws a pool of performers to New York. Failing a show, these singers and musicians have to find some place to develop their skills and be seen by one another. What better forum than a cabaret, a crowded field in which all but a dozen performers do it more for love than money.
This March has been designated Cabaret Month by the Manhattan Association of Cabarets, an organization of performers, club owners, bookers, managers and press agents founded 10 years ago to stir up business. On March 22 at Symphony Space on Broadway, the group will distribute awards for excellence in the field. The continuance of the MAC Awards, as they are known, testifies to the spiritual hardiness of an entertainment genre that despite economic hardship and devastation from AIDS is holding its own.
During Cabaret Month, two Manhattan cabarets that had been dark have ambitious plans to reopen. The 80-seat Blue Room at the Supper Club, at 240 West 47th Street, will begin its cabaret season on March 18. Its roster of forthcoming talent includes Morgana King, Little Jimmy Scott, Rosalind Kind and Chip Zien. Club 53 at the New York Hilton Hotel in midtown will also reopen, on Thursday, with previews of "Back to Bachrach and David," a revue of songs by the famous 60's songwriting team that had a brief but successful run last year at Steve McGraw's in Manhattan.
And this October, the fourth Cabaret Convention, sponsored by the Mabel Mercer Foundation, will increase its number of gala concerts in the Town Hall series in Manhattan to a full week of events.
Here is a selective guide to Manhattan cabarets. The list omits comedy clubs and piano bars. And clubs like the Blue Note, Fat Tuesday's, J's and the newly opened Five Spot that cultivate a jazz audience but sometimes feature pop talent are also not included. A significant difference between Manhattan's jazz clubs and its cabarets is the quality of the sound. The jazz clubs, most notably the Blue Note, have much more sophisticated sound systems. While none of the city's cabarets has inadequate sound, the audio systems tend to be designed to suit a more modest, non-rock technology.
 
Rainbow and Stars
 With its spectacular view looking north over Central Park, its superb food and its comfortably lush accommodations, Rainbow and Stars, on the 65th floor of the G.E. Building, probably comes the closest of any New York club to resembling the old-time Hollywood ideal of Manhattan nightclub glamour. The club, which opened in January 1989, is one of the jewels of Rockefeller Center's handsomely refurbished Rainbow complex, which is a major New York tourist attraction.
Seating is spacious with most of the tables situated on either side of a small platform stage that silhouettes the performers in front of windows overlooking Central Park. The most dramatic views are to be had from a row of tables nestled along the curved walls directly facing the stage. A flashing fiber-optic rainbow designed by Milton Glaser blinks its reflections on the windows behind the performer. Sight lines are good, and the sound is clear and well directed. But it is a little spread out: in this case closer to the stage is better.
In its programming, the club has tried quite successfully to appeal both to tourists and to the discriminating cabaret audience. Rosemary Clooney, who appeals to both, recently sold out the club for a month. A series of revues celebrating great American songwriters has had its artistic ups and downs. But the latest edition, a salute to Rodgers and Hammerstein, featuring talented younger theater singers, is one of the ups.
Rainbow and Stars is expensive; dinner for two will cost over $100. And for its most popular attractions, dinner is often required for the early show.
 
Cafe Carlyle
 The Cafe Carlyle, in the Hotel Carlyle on East 76th Street, is the only New York cabaret to exude a distinct aura of East Side chic, and performances can have the hushed, formal atmosphere of a drawing-room concert. The recently expanded menu features pricey elegant cuisine; entrees run in the $20 to $30 range. The club's ambiance is enhanced by the sumptuous Vertes wall murals and upholstered love seats interspersed among the tables.
For more than two decades, the Cafe Carlyle has been almost synonymous with Bobby Short, who now performs there four months of the year and whose attitude of high-toned playfulness perfectly matches the decor. Mr. Short is not the cafe's only regular inhabitant. Eartha Kitt, who is playing there now, has become a regular, as has Barbara Cook. The magnificently raucous Dixie Carter, another regular, opens there later this month.
 
Bemelmans Bar
 Also in the Hotel Carlyle is Bemelmans Bar, a piano bar. Across the hall from the Cafe Carlyle, Bemelmans has a more informal, post-collegiate atmosphere. Its most frequent denizens are Barbara Carroll and Ronny Whyte (its current occupant), both staid pop-jazz singers and pianists whose performances frequently have to compete with conversation.
 
The Ballroom
 If the Ballroom weren't in one of the seedier areas of Chelsea, it would probably be a roaring success, for it is one of the best-run cabarets in New York. As it is, the club has had to struggle to survive. The Ballroom, which was in SoHo in 1973 and moved uptown in 1981, is a small theater with table seating. It charges extra for ringside seating, which is usually well worth the money. Its front room is one of New York's more acclaimed Spanish restaurants, renowned for its tapas.
Three years ago, with the introduction of a winter series of Brazilian concerts, the club underwent a dramatic change in programming philosophy. The series, now in its third year, has been quite successful and has prompted a more international approach to booking talent. A high point last year was the appearance of the Fassbinder film star and chanteuse Ingrid Caven, who is scheduled to return later this year. The club has the best sound and lighting system and engineer (Steve Visscher) of any New York cabaret.
 
The Oak Room
 The Oak Room in the Algonquin Hotel in midtown, which was recently refurbished so as not to tarnish its traditional image, is a comfortably moody landmark of an earlier era. With its orange lanterns on wood-paneled walls, the club has a quietly romantic ambiance that is perfectly suited to Andrea Marcovicci, who has become to the Oak Room what Bobby Short is to the Cafe Carlyle. Last fall, she sold out her entire four-month engagement there.
A popular nightclub before World War II, the Oak Room was used only for dining in more recent times. Then in 1981, the singer and pianist Steve Ross reintroduced live entertainment, and it has since become a full-time cabaret. Its sight lines are good, but the food is quite expensive and stodgy. Daugherty and Field, the room's current inhabitants, bring a vaudevillian sense of fun to a program of songs by Harold Arlen.
 
Russian Tea Room
 One of New York's successful recent nightclub ventures has been the transformation of an upstairs back room of the Russian Tea Room into an elegant part-time cabaret that has attracted a loyal and growing audience to its weekend and Monday evening performances. It has a smaller, separate menu from the main restaurant; the well-prepared, Russian-accented entrees run in the $22 to $34 range. And the intimate 80-to-100 seat room, which suggests a warmer version of the Cafe Carlyle, inspires an atmosphere of camaraderie. The club has slowly been expanding its schedule. Last year, Julie Wilson became the first performer to be booked for an extended run, and did well. And Amanda McBroom, the composer of "The Rose," has been booked into the club in May for a three-week engagement.
Winter events include a Sunday night series that features two shows this weekend by Ann Hampton Callaway. On Monday evenings, Ascap, the song-licensing agency, is presenting a showcase for singers and songwriters.
 
Michael's Pub
 One of the city's longest-running clubs, Michael's Pub has been in existence since 1954 and moved to its present home in midtown in 1971. For the last two decades, it has been the site of Woody Allen's Monday evening performances with the New Orleans Funeral and Ragtime Orchestra. Mel Torme is an annual fall attraction. One of its most successful shows ever, Vernel Bagneris's tribute to Jelly Roll Morton, is about to end a run that has lasted 22 weeks. On March 16, Mickey Rooney will make his cabaret debut there in a show of songs and stories.
The club has very good sight lines, but the food is basic pub fare. And when the most popular acts appear, it can be too tightly packed.
 
The Chestnut Room
 The Chestnut Room, one of the New York's newest clubs, is still getting its footing, but its future looks promising. Situated in the heart of the Tavern on the Green complex in Central Park, it has the feel of being in a spacious, elegantly appointed greenhouse. With seating for 160, it has the same expensive dinner menu as the main restaurant: entrees range from $11 to $32. Its programming mixes traditional jazz groups with pop-jazz singers. On Tuesday, Chris Connor begins a two-week engagement.
One of the club's musical features is its $80,000 Hamburg Steinway Model D concert grand piano. The atmosphere is comfortable and friendly, and although the food is expensive, the entertainment fees are very reasonable: cover charges are $10 to $15 a person.
 
Eighty Eight's
 Eighty Eight's, a two-tiered Greenwich Village club operated by Erv Raible (the president of the Manhattan Association of Cabarets), has been an important launching pad for talent that has included Jeff Harnar, the Wise Guys and Daugherty and Field. The Richard Maltby-David Shire revue "Closer Than Ever" also originated here. And a show of songs by Mary Rodgers, conceived by Mr. Maltby, will have its first performance there on March 17.
The showcase club, which seats 65, is upstairs. The downstairs room is a clubby piano bar frequented by Broadway choristers and musical comedy aficionados.
Acts are booked (two a night, except for four on Sunday beginning with a 3 P.M. brunch show), for one night on consecutive weeks, down the calendar. Two of the more popular singers to appear there this weekend are Sara Zahn and Baby Jane Dexter. The only food served is brunch on Sunday. Cover charges are very reasonable: $10 to $12 a person.
 
Steve McGraw's
 This 135-seat, second-floor cabaret theater on the Upper West Side was opened four years ago on the site of what used to be Palsson's Supper Club. It is the present home of the long-running revue "Forever Plaid." Late last year, the same stage saw a limited run of an early version of a revue of the songs of Burt Bacharach that is soon to have another life at Club 53.
In and around the schedule of "Forever Plaid" this month will be woven a number of benefit concerts featuring Broadway names. The room has the atmosphere of a post-college hangout for Broadway babies. The club has just inaugurated a downstairs piano room that is open seven nights a week.
 
Danny's Skylight Room
 The cabaret in this very small, intimate, reasonably priced club in the back room of Danny's Grand Sea Palace Restaurant in the theater district was inaugurated in 1987, and is singer-oriented. Jill O'Hara, Jill Corey and Monica Lewis made their returns to nightclub performance at the club, which is known for its discriminating taste in talent that is little known but worthy. The room, with its distinguishing skylight, is comfortable but spare.
 
Judys'
 This cozy little club with mirrored walls and a tiny stage almost has the feel of a boutique. Established by the semi-legendary cabaret proprietor Jan Wallman in the mid-1980's, it was taken over two years ago by Richard Hendrickson and re-named Judys' -- after famous Judys, from Garland to Holliday. Under its new owner, it introduced a piano bar in the front room. There is entertainment sevennights a week. The place remains a hub for a circle of veteran performers, including Arthur Siegel and the team of Judy Kreston and David Lahm, who are appearing on Saturdays through March. The menu is Italian and reasonably priced, with entrees in the $8.95 to $15.95 range.
 
Don't Tell Mama
 This midtown cousin of Eighty Eights, with a clientele that is heavily show-business oriented, recently subdivided into two small functional showcases with little elbow room. The quality of talent is generally a notch below that of Eighty Eight's. Two of the more popular long-running shows are a revue about voyeurism, "Beyond the Window," which plays Thursday evenings, and "The Heat Is On," a salute to Rita Hayworth featuring Quinn Lemley, which plays on Saturdays.
 
Tatou
 Tatou, a glitzy restaurant, dance club and cabaret, has had several notable earlier incarnations. At one time the midtown spot was the Versailles, a ballroom and supper club where Desi Arnaz led an orchestra and Edith Piaf would appear. More recently, it was the Club Ibis, which featured bellydancing. After several years of inactivity, it reopened in 1990 as Tatou. Its main event these days is the "The Tatou Follies," a Tuesday evening revue presented by R. Couri Hay and Robert Frye that features guest celebrity impersonators. With a noise level comparable to a disco, it is anything but intimate.
 
The Duplex
 A small, often crowded upstairs club, the Duplex, on Christopher Street in Greenwich Village, has a high turnover of acts of varying quality. The entertainment runs from comedy to drag acts to a continuing talent show, "Stars of Tomorrow," which has its final round on March 26. The Gotham City Improv performsits show "Politically Erect" on Saturday nights at 8.
The club, which used to be on Grove Street, is a strictly functional showcase that offers minimal comfort. During crowded performances, it can feel like a school cafeteria.

SECTION: Section B; Page 14; Column 4; Weekend Desk; Word and Image Page

LENGTH: 748 words

HEADLINE: TVWeekend;
A Series That Just Might Be for Real

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
Tonight at 9:30, network television comes up with still another comedy series featuring still another group of very talented black American performers. Apparently, the black experience in America is fine for prime time if it can be milked for a few laughs. Occasionally, though, there is substance lurking in the comedy. That was true of NBC's "Cosby Show." And it just might turn out to be true of ABC's new "Where I Live."
A couple of years ago, the producer Michael Jacobs ("Dinosaurs") was devising a version of Thornton Wilder's "Our Town" that would be set in a black community. Meanwhile, Ehrich Van Lowe (a producer of "The Cosby Show") was developing a series based on his experiences growing up in the Bronx. The two eventually got together with Disney's Touchstone Television to develop "Where I Live." It is set in Harlem, though it is filmed on an elaborate street set in Burbank, Calif. 
 At first glance, the show looks unpromisingly like too many current sitcoms about blacks, with monotonously suggestive humor laid on with the broadest of brush strokes. Doug E. Doug ("Hangin' With the Homeboys"), the star, plays Doug St. Martin, a dreadlocks-topped 17-year-old with a platinum attitude and a habit of talking directly to the camera. His two best friends are Reggie (Flex) and Malcolm (Shaun Baker). This trio is sometimes joined by 10-year-old Kwanzie (Jason Bose Smith), who, as the standard cute sitcom kid, is ardently wooing Doug's 14-year-old sister (Yunoka Doyle). "I loves you," he shouts up to her window, "and I will have you, baby".
But the street goofing does give way to real issues, usually set off by Doug's Caribbean-born parents, James, a cab driver (Sullivan Walker), and Marie (Lorraine Toussaint). In tonight's premiere, Doug learns from his father that Reggie has won a basketball scholarship to St. John's University. But Reggie himself hasn't even told Doug. Worse, Doug is now hassled by his father for spending too much time on the street at the "University of the Stoop." Doug's proposed solution: drop out of school altogether and, getting a jump on Reggie, find a job. No way: not with these parents.
The producers say they want to "take a look at the people, community and culture of Harlem." These are working people, economically several rungs below the upper-middle-class "Cosby Show" denizens, but safely above those whom sociologists call the despairing underclass. And obviously, these are people with compelling stories to be told. A comedy series, especially one as carefully thought out and appealingly acted as "Where I Live," is one quite promising way of doing it. Next week, the St. Martin family tackles the thorny issue of incendiary rap lyrics.
 
'The Bob Dylan 30th Anniversary Celebration' 'Part 1'
PBS
 (In New York, Channel 13, tomorrow at 8 P.M.)
This concert was recorded at Madison Square Garden in October, and was offered live at the time on pay-per-view television. Now it kicks off "In the Spotlight," a new series aimed at baby boomers (read: aging baby boomers). The premiere is crammed with stars paying homage to Mr. Dylan and his music. Among the numerous highlights: John Mellencamp's version of "Like a Rolling Stone," Tracy Chapman's "Times They Are a-Changin'," Eric Clapton's "Don't Think Twice, It's All Right," Willie Nelson's "What Was It You Wanted" and Sophie B. Hawkins's "I Want You."
On the down side, there's the audience, lustily cheering the songs and their own early years of anti-establishment protest, and then briefly turning into a mob to boo Sinead O'Connor off the stage; apparently, her anti-Pope rebelliousness on "Saturday Night Live" went too far for many at this middle-age hootenanny. A festive and even historic occasion ends up with an unsightly smudge. Part 2 of the celebration will be broadcast on Channel 13 next Saturday.
