HEADLINE: Overhaul Set for Domestic-Help Rules

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
Shaken by the trouble over Zoe Baird, Congress began steps today to make it easier for well-off people to pay Social Security and unemployment insurance taxes for their domestic help.
Two subcommittees of the House Ways and Means Committee held a joint hearing on legislation that would raise the amount of wages that must be paid before taxes are due and permit employers of household help to file the required forms just once a year. 
 The current law, unchanged since 1950, has been mostly honored in the breach and disregarded by lawmakers. But it came into public attention this year when Ms. Baird, President Clinton's first nominee to be Attorney General, was forced to withdraw, in part because she had not paid the required taxes for her nanny and chauffeur, who were illegal immigrants.
"Single-handedly, Ms. Baird has done more to publicize the law which provides Social Security coverage for domestic employees than the I.R.S. or the Social Security Administration has ever managed to do," said Representative Jim Bunning, Republican of Kentucky.
 
Easing Burden on Employers
 Most of the testimony today dealt with the need to lessen the burden employers face to comply with the law, but a first-term lawmaker from Florida offered a different perspective.
"I was once a domestic worker," said Representative Carrie Meek, a Democrat from Miami. "My mother was a domestic worker. All my sisters were domestic workers."
Household workers, she said, should not be denied the retirement benefits and protection against disability and unemployment that all other employees have. She said it was important to keep the wage threshold low enough so maids who work one day a week for several different families would be covered.
Under the 1950 law, employers must pay Social Security and Medicare taxes for every household worker who is paid more than $50 in a calendar quarter, even the teen-ager who occasionally baby-sits or mows the lawn. If the worker is paid more than $1,000 in a quarter, the unemployment insurance tax is due.
The Social Security and Medicare tax is 15.3 percent of wages, of which half is supposed to be paid by the employer and half withheld from the employees' pay, but many employers of household help pay both halves themselves. The unemployment tax varies but is generally about 2 percent of the first $7,000 of wages in a year, all paid by the employer.
Marshall V. Washburn, an official at the Internal Revenue Service, told the lawmakers that only about 500,000 taxpayers paid taxes for their household help, while "more than several million households should be reporting."
When the Social Security law was expanded in 1950 to include domestic workers, he said, the $50 threshold was set to exempt "casual labor," but inflation has made that meaningless.
Employers must file five to eight separate Federal forms each year to comply with the law, and often state forms must also be filed. One reason so few taxpayers comply, Mr. Washburn said, is the amount of record-keeping and paperwork.
Lawmakers who want to change the law believe that if the wage threshold is raised to a more realistic level that exempts the casual baby sitter and if the paperwork is made minimal, more employers will comply with the law and more household workers will eventually become eligible for Social Security benefits.
The proposed legislation was introduced this year by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the Ways and Means Committee, and it is almost certain to become law in one form or another.

HEADLINE: Clinton Signs Measure Extending Jobless Pay

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
The House gave final Congressional approval today to emergency unemployment benefits for the long-term jobless, and this evening President Clinton signed the bill, the first piece of his economic revival program to become law.
The measure, which will cost $5.7 billion, extends through Oct. 2 a Federal program that gives unemployed Americans who have already exhausted the standard 26 weeks of benefits as much as six months in additional aid. Without the extension, the program would have expired at midnight Saturday. 
 In a signing ceremony at the White House, Mr. Clinton said, "With this bill becoming law, 1.5 million unemployed Americans who need help making the rent and buying groceries and paying for school clothes will receive it."
Under the new law, unemployed workers who have exhausted their standard benefits will receive additional benefits for either 20 or 26 weeks, depending on the unemployment level in their state. At present, only Alaska, California, Oregon, Rhode Island, Washington State, West Virginia and Puerto Rico have unemployment rates high enough for their residents to qualify for the 26 weeks. Unemployed workers elsewhere qualify for only 20 weeks.
 
Freezing Congressional Pay
 The law also imposes a pay freeze on members of Congress, a provision stemming from Mr. Clinton's call for a freeze on the salaries of all Federal workers as a gesture of sacrifice.
As a result, the lawmakers' annual salaries will remain at $133,600 next year instead of rising to the $136,405 that would have taken effect through an automatic 2.1 percent cost-of-living increase.
The House had earlier passed the unemployment benefits bill without the salary-freeze provision. The freeze was adopted by the Senate when it passed the bill on Wednesday, and the House quickly added the Senate language today.
The House vote to extend the unemployment benefits was 247 to 156. A separate vote of 403 to 0 added the pay freeze.
In both chambers, Republicans complained that the unemployment bill would mean a $5.7 billion addition to the Federal budget deficit. They said that the bill was an omen of things to come and that Mr. Clinton and his Democratic allies in Congress were not really serious about reining in the deficit.
"Where's the beef?" said Representative Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania. "Where's the funding so we don't continue to put burdens on our children?"
But Democrats argued that the extended benefits would be paid for by the economic revival promised by Mr. Clinton's larger economic plan. They held ranks and defeated Republican efforts to start enacting Mr. Clinton's plan piecemeal and to finance the $5.7 billion now with spending cuts.

HEADLINE: Trade's New Sheriff

 BODY:
Both Clintons were on view last week. In full campaign mode, he bustled out to a Boeing plant to berate European governments for unfairly subsidizing Airbus, Boeing's main rival. On Friday he sounded more conciliatory. "We must compete, not retreat," he told a university audience. "The truth of our age is this: Open and competitive commerce will enrich us as a nation."
Mr. Clinton is hardly the first President to sing the good-cop, bad-cop tune: Free trade is fine as long as it's fair. What's interesting about his rendition is its timing. Only six weeks on the job and he's already announced that there's a new sheriff in town, one who's not afraid to swagger a bit on the international stage. 
 That's probably not a bad strategy for a man who, for all his domestic expertise, is probably viewed as a novice by the trade mandarins in foreign capitals. And some threats against unfair practices could well be useful should Mr. Clinton seek further concessions in the forthcoming resumption of the Uruguay Round trade negotiations.
Fearful of losing access to the rich U.S. market, trading partners might agree to knock down more barriers to American exports like food, movies and services. The Bush Administration played that card well, mixing retaliation and negotiation to begin prying open the Japanese market to American semiconductors and the European market to soybeans.
But history also suggests that retaliation misapplied can start a commercial war. If Mr. Clinton backs up his threatening rhetoric at the Boeing plant by imposing tariffs or quotas, Europe is quite likely to respond in kind. And the United States could come out on the short end. Boeing has sold more aircraft to Europe than Airbus has sold to America.
Mr. Clinton breaks no new ground when he threatens reprisals against countries that trade unfairly. That's existing U.S. policy, condoned by international rules. Under normal procedures, trade violations are submitted to international panels as a prelude to retaliation. But when those mechanisms fall short, or don't apply, some in Congress urge unilateral retaliation: The U.S. decides on its own what foreign practices are unfair and what sanctions are in order -- even if the sanctions violate U.S. trade commitments.
Because the U.S. is the 800-pound gorilla of international trade, it can get away with a lot of bullying. But if the process gets out of hand, reciprocal warfare can result. Furthermore, the U.S. does not come to the debate with entirely clean hands. It imposes tariffs or quotas on dairy products, textiles, apparel, sugar, peanuts and scores of other products.
Nevertheless, many Americans feel that their country has been a trade wimp. Mr. Clinton's tough talk can help ventilate voters' demands for protectionist measures and also help educate trade partners about the political necessities faced by an American President.
The key question involves Mr. Clinton's larger objective. Is it to expand trade by opening markets abroad? Or is it to protect American industry by closing markets at home? The President knows that open markets have enriched America in the past. He also knows that his plans for economic growth depend heavily on widening those markets while restoring American competitiveness.
He is within his rights, and on solid philosophical ground, to challenge discrimination wherever he finds it -- to make the playing field as level as he can. The trick is to do so by bargaining patiently, even relentlessly, and by staying within the rules unless other nations make it impossible. There's a big difference between a tough sheriff and a rogue cop.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Greatest Challenge

BYLINE: By Richard Nixon; Richard Nixon, the former President, recently returned from his third trip to Russia in three years.

 BODY:
Those who would disagree, as I do, with some of the specific proposals in President Clinton's economic program must give him credit for his boldness and political courage in advocating them and for his indefatigable efforts to sell them to the American people.
If he demonstrates the same leadership qualities in addressing the major foreign policy issue of our time, he can secure his place in history as a great President. That issue is the survival and success of political and economic freedom in Russia. 
 That is not to say that the Mideast, Iraq and Bosnia are not also important, or that the nations of Eastern Europe and the other former Soviet states do not also deserve priority attention where they have democratically elected governments and have initiated serious free-market economic reform. But what happens in Russia will have an enormous effect on those nations, on our allies and on the United States.
Without a substantial increase in aid from the West, the Yeltsin Government will not survive. The U.S. must lead in providing it. It is a very tough sell for the President. The last Gallup poll showed that only 4 percent of voters considered foreign policy to be an important issue. In Mr. Clinton's nationally televised town meeting, there was only one question concerning foreign policy. It was about Bosnia. His political advisers understandably will tell him, as they did in the campaign, "It's the economy, stupid!"
But foreign and domestic policy are like Siamese twins -- one cannot survive without the other. If Boris Yeltsin's democratic Government collapses and is replaced by an aggressive, hard-line nationalist government, this will have a far greater impact on the American economy than all the Clinton domestic programs combined. The peace dividend will be down the tubes. The defense budget will have to be increased by billions of dollars rather than cut. This would mean that the President's plan to cut the deficit would have to be taken off the table.
The Russian democracy is going through a deadly crisis. The negative factors are frightening. Russia has 31 republics and provinces that have declared their sovereignty and 132 nationalities. Before the peaceful revolution of December 1991, the Russian people had never known either political or economic freedom. What works in Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary will not work in Russia.
Russia is going through an economic downturn worse than the Great Depression of the 1930's in the United States. In 1992 inflation was 25 percent a month, the gross national product was down 20 percent, and living standards were down 50 percent. There has been an alarming increase in crime and corruption. Separatist tendencies and nationalistic conflicts which had been cooled by the cold war are getting hot again, ranging from bloody war in the Transcaucasus and Central Asia to confrontation over minority rights in the Baltic states.
But despite these overwhelming odds, the conventional wisdom of most of the American media that the Russian democracy is doomed is off the mark. There is still strong support for reform among political leaders and the Russian people. The real political battle today is not between reformers and reactionaries, but between different kinds of reforms.
There are those like Mr. Yeltsin who prefer to act swiftly and decisively, and those like the Civic Union which would rather move more gradually. The fact that all political leaders except for the extreme reactionaries pay at least lip service to a free market economy means there will be no turning back to Communism.
The negative news from Russia has completely obscured the positive news. Just as Washington is not America, Moscow is not Russia. While political infighting is big news in Moscow, privatization and growth are proceeding irreversibly in other parts of Russia. Twenty percent of the G.N.P. is now produced by private enterprise. More than 30 percent of Russian workers are in private enterprise. The press is free. Privatizing the economy has helped to eliminate shortages. No one talks about the possibility of starvation, as was the case when I was in Moscow just nine months ago.
Most important, as experts like James Billington and Gerald Corrigan have pointed out, the caricature that Russian workers are not responding to economic incentives is false. In a meeting in St. Petersburg two weeks ago, private entrepreneurs unanimously agreed that, when given the opportunity to enjoy the benefits of a free society, Russian workers are among the best in the world. They are also among the best educated: Ninety percent have graduated from high school -- a higher percentage than in the United States.
Can Boris Yeltsin survive? Some Western leaders I talked to question it. Some of his opponents in Russia doubt it. Most shocking, the State Department officer who was in charge of aid to Russia publicly predicted last month that he would not last. With friends like that, Mr. Yeltsin needs no enemies.
His approval rating is down sharply because of the economic downturn. But he is still the most popular politician in Russia. He has made serious mistakes in dealing with the Parliament he inherited from Mikhail Gorbachev. But while revolutionary leaders are generally good at destroying old orders but not good at governing new ones, Mr. Yeltsin has surprised even his critics by his political skill in handling what must be the most difficult political position in the world.
To his credit, he is attempting to find a compromise with the Parliament rather than becoming authoritarian, as many predicted. Those who would count him out should bear in mind that he has remarkable recuperative powers. He is a fighter. When he seems to be down and out, he gets up and continues the battle.
Most important, President Yeltsin shares our values. Unlike Mr. Gorbachev, he has repudiated both socialism and Communism, believes in a free market and supports the private ownership of property. Mr. Yeltsin unequivocally supports a non-aggressive foreign policy. After meeting all the major leaders in Russia, I am convinced that our choice is not between him and somebody better, but between him and someone worse. He deserves our help, both to further our interests as well as his.
In addition to increasing aid, President Clinton should consider calling for an emergency meeting of the Group of Seven major nations. The crisis in Russia should be at the top of the agenda. He should take the lead in persuading our allies, particularly the Germans and Japanese, to join us in rescheduling for 15 years the $84 billion debt Mr. Yeltsin inherited from Mr. Gorbachev.
Shortsighted Western governments and bankers have to face up to the fact that if the debt is not rescheduled, they are likely to get nothing from any government which replaces Mr. Yeltsin's. We should demand that the bureaucrats running the International Monetary Fund not treat Russia like a third world country.
We should insist that the allies we helped recover from World War II now help Russia and the other independent nations in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union recover from the cold war. The Germans have their plate full with eastern Germany. But the Japanese participation in the multilateral aid program is shockingly inadequate. The Japanese should quit conditioning aid on Russia's return of four tiny northern islands. If Mr. Yeltsin fails, they will never get the islands back.
Why should we even consider aid to Russia in view of our problems at home? Because aid to a non-aggressive democratic Government in Russia is an investment in peace. Russia is the only nation which has the power to destroy the United States. Russian diplomatic support in hot spots like Iraq, the Mideast and Bosnia is indispensable.
During the cold war, many thought the Soviets were evil. None thought they were crazy. That can't be said for some of the smaller nations trying to acquire nuclear weapons. Russia and America, as the only two nuclear superpowers, must play the crucial role in preventing proliferation of nuclear weapons.
Aid to a free-market economy in Russia is an investment in prosperity for the United States. Consider these facts. Russian G.N.P. last year was seven times as great as China's. China's trade with the U.S. was eight times as great as Russia's. Why? Because China's private enterprise produces over one-half of its G.N.P. Russia's private enterprise produces only one-fifth of its G.N.P. As Russia's private sector grows, this will mean thousands of jobs and billions in trade for the U.S.
Even greater stakes are involved. For 75 years, Communist Russia, as a major Soviet state, tried to export Communism to the rest of the world. Today, democratic Russia can serve as a powerful example of how political and economic freedom is the best choice for nations who want to progress. If political and economic freedom fails in Russia, this will encourage the reactionary leaders of other nations to resist reform. If it succeeds, this could have a major impact on a nation like China, which has significant economic reform but no political reform.
Above all, it is time to quit treating Russia like a defeated enemy. Russia did not lose the cold war. The Communists did. The U.S. and our allies deserve great credit for maintaining the military and economic power to resist and turn back the Soviet aggression. A democratic Russia deserves credit for delivering the knockout blow to Communism in its motherland. Russia should be treated as a proud struggling friend, not as a weak former enemy looking for a handout.
The demise of Soviet Communism was one of mankind's greatest victories. But the victory will not be complete until Russia and its neighbors can enjoy the benefits of political and economic freedom. It would be tragic if, at this critical point, the United States fails to provide the leadership only it can provide. By leading abroad as he has so effectively at home, President Clinton will establish himself as the world's pre-eminent statesman.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Low Interest on Margin Loans Makes Them Attractive

BYLINE: By Andree Brooks

 BODY:
Many new investors in stocks, bonds and mutual funds do not know that there may be untapped borrowing power in their assets.
So-called margin loans against the value of a portfolio may be made for any purpose. Once established, such a loan operates like a line of credit. "It's an excellent way to borrow money," said Lewis J. Altfest, president of L. J. Altfest & Company, financial planners in New York City. 
 The interest rate, which varies according to the size of the loan, is lower than the rates on almost any other kind of borrowing. Currently, margin loans are being offered at around 6.75 percent for sums under $25,000 and 5.75 percent for over $50,000.
This compares with unsecured personal loans averaging 15.77 percent, credit card balances at 18.24 percent and auto loans at 8.72 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor of North Palm Beach, Fla. And monthly interest can be added to the balance or paid from the portfolio's dividends and interest.
It's also easy to qualify because the broker retains the right to liquidate the pledged portion of the portfolio any time the maximum allowable debt-to-assets ratio is exceeded.
In addition, the interest charges may be tax deductible, but this advantage is linked to a complex set of Internal Revenue Service regulations that tie deductibility to the use of the funds. Thus deductibility should never be the prime reason for choosing a margin loan, Mr. Altfest said.
If you intend to use the money to finance other investments, the interest charges should be tax deductible, said James Sharp, a tax partner with Arthur Andersen & Co. But if the loan is financing a car, the interest is not likely to qualify. Since other restrictions also apply, a tax adviser should be consulted before making any assumptions. "So much will depend on your personal financial circumstances," Mr. Sharp said.
Margin borrowing is also limited by Federal Reserve Board regulations to around 50 percent of the value of a portfolio. A portfolio of $100,000 would generate around $50,000 worth of borrowing power. The $50,000 limit however, could rise or fall with market fluctuations and additional limits set by the brokerage.
If the value fell below acceptable levels, the broker could insist that the borrower add to the portfolio or reduce the size of the loan, said Donna Morris, a senior vice president at Fidelity Investments.
Financial advisers advocate conservative use. "I don't recommend going above 25 percent of whatever's available," Mr. Altfest said.
Margin borrowing is not usually permitted against retirement accounts like I.R.A.'s and Keoghs.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Comparing Loans" shows interest rates on consumer and margin loans. (Sources: Bank Rate Monitor, Fidelity Investments)

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
The Clinton Stake in Rostenkowski's Fate

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
In public they talk about economic stimulus, energy taxes, Medicare cuts and the proper ratio of tax increases to spending reductions.
But in the privacy of White House offices and Capitol cloakrooms, President Clinton's top economic advisers and the senators and representatives responsible for pushing the Clinton economic plan through Congress express a bigger worry: Will Dan Rostenkowski be indicted? 
 "The fate of the plan could lie in the balance," said a top Administration official.
 
Out of Their Control
 A Congressman called it "the Damocles' sword that hangs over everything ahead."
What they find most frustrating is that they have no facts about the situation and no control over it.
Mr. Rostenkowski, a Democrat from Chicago and the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, is probably the single most important lawmaker on economic and social policy issues. All legislation on taxes, Social Security, health care, welfare, unemployment compensation and most other items high on Mr. Clinton's agenda must originate in Mr. Rostenkowski's committee. A masterly legislator and unwavering supporter of Mr. Clinton, he is also perhaps the President's strongest hand in Congress.
But for a year Mr. Rostenkowski has been under investigation by a grand jury led by Jay B. Stephens, the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia, a Republican who once worked in the Reagan White House.
If Mr. Rostenkowski is indicted, he must step aside as committee chairman, and the consensus in the Administration and in Congress is that no one else is remotely his equal when it comes to managing a fractious committee and handling controversial legislation.
Representative Sam M. Gibbons would become acting chairman in Mr. Rostenkowski's absence. He is a Democrat from Florida in his 16th term who has specialized in trade issues and has never become heavily involved in matters like taxes and health policy.
The Rostenkowski case initially involved his office's purchase of an unusually large number of stamps from the House post office and the apparent suspicion by the authorities that this was part of a money-laundering scheme to convert campaign donations and office expenses into personal funds. Recently, the investigation seems to have been expanded into other financial areas. Subpoenas have been issued for virtually all of Mr. Rostenkowski's financial records, personal and political.
Mr. Rostenkowski, who is 65, says he has done nothing wrong, has no idea what the prosecutors are looking for and is the victim of a political witch hunt. He says his lawyers have been told that he is not a target of the investigation. Indeed, no solid evidence of illegal activity by Mr. Rostenkowski has become public.
His friends say they cannot imagine that he had his hand in the petty-cash drawer. He could have retired and not run for re-election last year and kept more than $1 million in leftover campaign funds, the last year it was legally possible to do so. If he were crooked, supporters said, he could have found lobbyists in town who would have backed up a Brinks truck to his office and dropped off whatever loot he wanted.
 
An Aggressive Prosecutor
 But Mr. Stephens, who has said little about the case publicly, appears to have something, and he is pursuing it with an aggressiveness that seems to indicate that he thinks he can win an indictment. Time magazine reported last week, without saying where the information came from, that an indictment was expected this spring or summer.
If it happens, Mr. Clinton will lose the strong arm of perhaps Congress's most skillful manipulator of the legislative process. "Rostenkowski has an enormous talent for moving Congress in the direction he wants to take it," said a Senator who has dealt with him for years in House-Senate conferences to work out the differences in important legislation.
The situation is so ticklish that this Senator and the other officials and lawmakers interviewed would discuss it only on the condition that their names not appear in the article.
The main source of Mr. Rostenkowski's strength is the loyalty his fellow Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee feel toward him. Years of mastering the substance and politics of the tax code, of passing out political rewards and punishment, of carefully testing the waters so he knows where each member stands on every issue have left him in a position in which he almost never loses a vote in his committee.
With Mr. Rostenkowski as chairman, it is a safe bet that the House will approve Mr. Clinton's economic plan mostly the way the President proposed it. But if Mr. Rostenkowski is indicted, all bets are off.
Under the rules of House Democrats, committee chairmen who are indicted on felony charges must give up the chairmanship until the matter is settled, and the Democratic committee member with the most seniority automatically becomes acting chairman. That is Mr. Gibbons.
The current thinking is that if Mr. Rostenkowski is forced to step aside, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, a member of the Ways and Means Committee until he was elected majority leader in 1989, would move in and become the chairman in fact, though not in name.
But even Mr. Gephardt does not have Mr. Rostenkowski's ability to force his will on the committee. And no one knows whether Mr. Gibbons would willingly turn over authority to the Democratic leader or how the Rostenkowski loyalists on the committee staff would respond.
What frustrates Administration officials most is that they do not have any feel for the prospects of an indictment. With no Attorney General, no one can go to the prosecutor and get a rundown. Officials said that it would be improper for Mr. Clinton or others in his Administration to put pressure on Mr. Stephens or even to learn the facts of the case and that no one in the Administration would do so. But they said that as a practical matter an Attorney General might be able to get a general idea of the likelihood of an indictment.
"We need to know whether we have to have a Plan B," an official said.

HEADLINE: Some Senate Democrats Push More Spending Cuts

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
Moderate and conservative Senate Democrats, who hold the swing votes to pass or modify President Clinton's economic package, are pressing the Administration for more budget cuts.
Specifically, they want Mr. Clinton to slash his proposed $31 billion package of new spending and tax cuts intended to stimulate the economy, and they want him to tie any new spending to further budget cuts. 
 The Democrats in question, who number about a dozen, still publicly support the Administration plan, and even the most critical have so far shunned alliances with Republicans. But behind the scenes they are organizing a quiet effort to change the plan, leveraged by the unspoken threat of a defection if they do not win concessions.
The group is important because Democrats hold a 57-to-43 majority in the Senate, and Democratic leaders do not expect any Republican support for Mr. Clinton's plan. So far, public opinion polls have shown widespread approval of the package, and Democratic Senators have gone out of their way to express firm support for it.
But the group of conservative-leaning Senators, led by David L. Boren of Oklahoma, is now warning the Administration that its economic plan will not cut the deficit enough to convince voters two or four years from now that tax increases were worth the pain.
"The bloom will wear off by the time the votes come," said Senator Dennis DeConcini of Arizona. "If it's a party vote, the President can't afford to lose eight votes. I think there are four votes already in question."
The Senators insist that they want to help Mr. Clinton, but they say they also need compromises.
"My vote is secure, but I have not made a blood oath to anybody," said Senator Charles S. Robb of Virginia.
Some in the group, facing tough re-election fights in 1994 and fearing that the public will turn on Democrats after taxes go up, want to be seen as fiscal hawks. Others oppose particular projects like the space station and the superconducting supercollider. Still others oppose a proposed energy tax, or would like to reduce new Social Security taxes along with new spending. The most conservative of the group would eliminate the spending package entirely, while others would attach it to spending cuts.
On Tuesday, eight of the Democratic Senators sent a letter to President Clinton, urging him to retreat from his strategy of passing tax cuts and spending programs before taking up legislation known as the reconciliation bill, which includes the budget cuts and tax increases.
 
Timing Is Questioned
 "The trust and support of the American people is fragile," the letter warned. "The timing and sequence of a series of actions can be critical to the success or failure of the effort."
The White House signaled today it had no intention of bowing to these Senators. "I don't think it is a big deal," a senior Administration official said of the letter. "It's an honest difference on tactics."
But it was clear that the initiative by these Senators is only the first warning shot in what are certain to be concerted efforts to satisfy constituents and regional concerns. Five western Democratic Senators are organizing to alter the proposed energy tax and cuts in agricultural subsidies, and the westerners are discussing the option of joining forces with the conservatives to increase their bargaining power.
 
Support From Liberals
 Despite the Democratic rumblings and the drop in the unemployment rate in February, President Clinton, meeting with mayors today, reaffirmed his commitment to the full stimulus package. His position has been bolstered by Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the powerful chairman of the Appropriations Committee, and by liberals who favor creating jobs with programs like Head Start.
The group of Senators who are pushing for changes are framing their efforts as an attempt to protect the President from the left wing of the party.
"We want to let Clinton be Clinton," said Mr. Boren, who convened a meeting of eight conservative Democrats on Feb. 25 to establish a united front for negotiations with the Administration. "We don't want to let the traditionally entrenched, big-spending liberals steal the momentum away from the President's commitment to deficit reduction."
Mr. Boren was careful to compliment Mr. Clinton for preparing what he called the most honest budget created by any President in years, adding that he is convinced that Mr. Clinton is serious about reducing the deficit.
So far, Democratic leaders have managed to hold onto the votes of moderate and conservative Senators. Some of them considered voting for a Republican amendment this week that would have tied budget cuts to the extension of unemployment compensation, but they demurred after Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said the vote was vital to the President.
After the party-line vote, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, said he thought several Democrats would eventually cooperate with his party's push for more budget cuts and fewer taxes.
The core of the group of Democratic Senators includes Mr. Boren, Mr. DeConcini, Mr. Robb, Jim Exon of Nebraska, Herb Kohl of Wisconsin and Richard C. Shelby of Alabama. They are being supported, to varying degrees, by Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, Howell Heflin of Alabama, Kent Conrad of North Dakota, John B. Breaux of Louisiana, J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina and Sam Nunn of Georgia.
Mr. Boren said in an interview on Thursday that he believed the Administration was listening and that the White House would make changes in an energy tax. He said in its current form, the tax would burden independent oil and gas operators and would be "devastating" to his state. "I'm the swing vote on the Finance Committee," he said, smiling but not joking.
Mr. Boren said he was confident the President's economic program would eventually pass, but he added, "What could stop it from flying is if the public perceives that we're slipping back in our old ways of spend now and cut the deficit later, if ever."

HEADLINE: U.S. PLANNING AID TO HELP SHORE UP YELTSIN'S POSITION

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
In an effort to bolster President Boris N. Yeltsin's political position, the White House is considering offering him loan guarantees to house demobilized Russian troops and an enterprise fund to support emerging Russian capitalists, senior Administration officials said today.
These ideas are being considered as part of what President Clinton said would be "some innovative solutions" for aiding Russia that he will propose to President Yeltsin when the two meet next month, officials said. Mr. Clinton announced today that the meeting would be held in Vancouver, British Columbia, on April 3 and 4. 
 "I will try to be rather specific at that time in terms of what the United States will be prepared to do," Mr. Clinton said in announcing the location.
 
Concern About Yeltsin
 Administration officials said Mr. Clinton's early thinking on Russian policy is being guided in part by an assessment that President Yeltsin is in an increasingly perilous political state, and that both he and the Russian reformers allied to him need a commitment of assistance that will be visible and whose impact will be felt reasonably quickly.
The President said he shares the views being expressed by former President Richard Nixon about the need for a much more forceful American response to help Mr. Yeltsin. Mr. Clinton telephoned Mr. Nixon two days ago, and the two spoke for 30 minutes about the fate of Russia. Mr. Clinton invited Mr. Nixon, who recently visited Russia, to meet him in the White House on Monday to present some concrete proposals, aides said.
Administration policy makers say that the Clinton approach to Russian-American relations will place a strong emphasis on sending Americans to Russia to help develop private businesses and democratic institutions rather than on waiting for the huge, multinational assistance packages. Mr. Clinton's approach reflects an assessment that the only way change is going to come to Russia is from the ground up -- "by changing the way that people there do business," as one official put it.
"The idea," the official added, "is to promote real markets, real capitalism and private businesses on the ground. While the Russian Government has been having its problems, the fact is it has also allowed an enormous amount of privatization to take place and we have to nurture that."
 
Loans for Housing
 Among the ideas being considered by the Administration to offer Mr. Yeltsin at the summit, the most ambitious would be to establish an enterprise fund for Russia. The Bush Administration set up similar funds for Eastern European countries.
Another option under consideration would be housing loan guarantees -- similar to those granted to Israel last year -- to allow Russia to obtain low-interest loans from private banks to alleviate the critical shortage of housing for the hundreds of thousands of Russian soldiers demobilized from Eastern Europe, officials said.
Both of these options could be paid for out of the $300 million in additional assistance for Russia that Mr. Clinton is seeking in his new budget.
In addition, say aides, the President is likely to offer Mr. Yeltsin an increase from the 200 Peace Corps volunteers who have been sent to Russia and a large expansion of the farmer-to-farmer program, which sends American farmers to Russia to work directly with their Russian counterparts.
Also likely to be expanded will be the number of American advisers being sent over to teach Russians how to privatize a business and how to set up democratic institutions.
In part, this approach is making a virtue of necessity. While Mr. Clinton has called for increased world financial support for Russia, his aides have already discovered how complicated that is, given the number of donor nations involved, Russia's default on its debts and the limited resources available.
"These guys came in with the greatest will in the world," a holdover from the Bush Administration said of Mr. Clinton's advisers on Russia. "But they have learned very quickly that it is all much harder than it sounds."
For instance, due to infighting in Russia and disputes over who is responsible for the Soviet Union's debts, a key element of the $24 billion assistance package promised last year by the United States and the other Group of Seven industrial democracies has never been delivered: the $6 billion fund to stabilize the ruble.
 
Conditions for Commitment
 Clinton aides insist that the President is committed to taking the lead in widening the Group of Seven aid package and in working more aggressively to reschedule the $80 billion Russian foreign debt.
But Mr. Clinton has told aides he is not going even to consider funding any huge financial schemes unless the allies support them and unless Russia sets up a viable monetary structure to insure that American taxpayer dollars will not be siphoned off by mismanagement, inflation or corruption.
All this leaves a classic chicken-and-egg situation, aides say: Mr. Yeltsin is unwilling to close down bankrupt state enterprises and to stop printing money unless he is certain that he has the Western safety net. The United States and its allies have been insisting that on reform first.
In discussions with American officials involved in Russia policy, though, it is possible to hear the faint beginnings of a debate on the question of how many conditions should be attached to large-scale financial aid to Russia. Mr. Nixon and some policy makers are beginning to muse aloud that Mr. Yeltsin's situation is becoming so desperate that the United States and its allies should consider "lowering the goal posts a bit," as one official put it.
"It may mean we have to take some more risks than we did before, because the situation is so dangerous, and so close to the brink," said an American diplomat.
Some diplomats say the real policy issue Mr. Clinton is going to have to face is whether to risk losing a portion of American aid in an effort to rescue Mr. Yeltsin before he is washed away on a tide of debased Russian currency. No one disputes that nurturing capitalism and democracy through grass-roots projects will have a major impact in the long run, these analysts add, but the whole process could be undercut if Mr. Yeltsin were to be toppled by nationalists or old-line Communists.

HEADLINE: Unemployment Declines to 7% In Payroll Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
Surpassing all expectations, employers added 365,000 workers to their payrolls in February, the biggest jump in four years, as the unemployment rate edged down a tenth of a point to 7 percent, the Labor Department said today.
The report, the first broad gauge of the economy's performance last month, ran counter to recent doubts about the vigor of the economic expansion, in which job growth has lagged behind improvement in other areas. 
 Bond prices fell, raising interest rates, and stocks rose after the report came out, but both markets closed little changed. [Pages 35 and 36.]
 
Unemployment Drops in City
 The New York City job picture also brightened in February. In January, the city jobless rate had hit the highest level in 25 years. [Page 47.]
Today's figures brought fresh optimism about an economy that had appeared of late to be losing much of its momentum. Consumer confidence, which soared after Election Day, has ebbed, and growth of incomes and personal spending slowed in January while home sales slumped. And an Agriculture Department survey published early this week found that 10.4 percent of the American population was relying on food stamps in December, the highest percentage since the program began in 1964.
But today's report particularly impressed private analysts because of the breadth of the labor-market improvement last month and the fact that the increase in jobs was reflected in the two separate Labor Department surveys. Job gains shown in the results of surveys taken of individual households matched those found in surveys of employers.
The strong numbers also sharpened the debate over President Clinton's proposed $31 billion package of tax cuts and spending to stimulate the economy. Various economists and Republican legislators seized on the figures to underscore their contention that the stimulus is no longer needed.
 But the President and Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, disputed this view and insisted that they would press ahead.
"That is good news," Mr. Clinton said at a meeting with the nation's mayors, referring to the job growth and the decline in the unemployment rate. "But if you look behind the numbers," he continued, "it also reveals the stark challenges before us, for most of those jobs were part-time jobs and we are still about three million jobs behind where we would ordinarily be in a recovery."
Indeed, the number of part-time workers who said they would have preferred full-time jobs climbed by 348,000 in the month, more than 90 percent of the gain of 380,000 jobs shown in the survey of households.
But most analysts considered this a small caveat in a very strong report, since part-time workers, according to Thomas J. Plewes, a Labor Department official, averaged 27 hours of work a week, close to the department's definition of a full-time workweek: 35 hours or more.
Mr. Reich said at a briefing that there was "absolutely" no intention of retreating from the fiscal-stimulus plan, which, among other things, is to create 700,000 summer jobs for young people.
But Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, called the report "just another reason why we shouldn't threaten the ongoing Bush recovery by adding $16 billion in so-called stimulus spending to the deficit."
 
Peaked at 7.7%
 The jobless rate has now fallen seven-tenths of a point since it peaked at 7.7 percent in June, the last month in which it rose. February's rate was the lowest since November 1991.
The report showed that the number of people out of work six months or more fell only slightly, after dropping 155,000 in January. But those without jobs for 15 to 26 weeks fell by 171,000, and the newly unemployed -- those who were jobless for less than 5 weeks -- fell by 40,000.
Another sign of improvement was a hefty rise in the number of people who quit jobs, rather than losing them through layoffs or discharges. Voluntary resignations are thought to reflect confidence about finding a new job. The number of people who left their jobs totaled 1,046,000 in February, 225,000 more than in January.
While manufacturing jobs rose by a modest 10,000, less than in January, the length of the factory workweek inched up another six minutes, to the highest level since 1966. And factory overtime, up 12 minutes last month, was the most since overtime records began being kept in the mid-1950's.
 When business is picking up, employers tend to add overtime for current workers before hiring new ones. Thus, the report released today was doubly encouraging, analysts said.
"This is the first time when we saw a blockbuster report in which hours worked and employment both rose," said Paul W. Boltz, economist at T. Rowe Price Associates, the Baltimore mutual fund group.
Regionally, the unemployment rate fell three-tenths of a point in the Northeast, to 7.6 percent, and four-tenths of a point in the South, to 6.4 percent. But it was unchanged in the West, at 8.3 percent, and the rate rose two-tenths of a point in the Midwest, to match the South at 6.4 percent.
 
Jersey Rate Is Higher
 Among the 11 populous states for which figures were published today, the jobless rate eased five-tenths of a point in New York, to 8 percent, and five-tenths in Pennsylvania, to 7 percent. The rate moved up four-tenths of a point, to 7.8 percent, in New Jersey. Because of relatively small state samples, however, the changes were not statistically significant.
The jump in national payrolls was concentrated in the retail trade and in services, each of which added 131,000 jobs, and in construction, where a 96,000 rise more than offset small declines related to unusually harsh weather that dampened building from November through January.
Temporary help accounted for much of the growth in business services. Like overtime, expansion of temporary help is often a precursor of new hiring.
"It is clear that the job market strengthened considerably in February," William G. Barron Jr., the Acting Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said in his monthly appearance to interpret the jobs data to the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
January payrolls were revised downward by 46,000 jobs, roughly halving the 106,000 increase that was initially reported.
 
60% Add Workers
 Other figures from the employer survey showed that 60.1 percent of industries added workers in February, up from 55.1 percent in January.
The index of aggregate weekly production hours climbed to 122.5, from 121.9, indicating that industrial output will be up smartly for February when reported in midmonth.
Among the few noteworthy changes among demographic groups, according to the survey of households, was a four-tenths of a point decline, to 6 percent, in the jobless rate for adult women. The rate for blacks fell 1.1 points, to 13.1 percent.
The total jobless ranks thinned by 136,000 in the month, less than the amount of the job gains because the work force expanded by 244,000.

HEADLINE: Poles Get Lessons With Their Loans

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

 BODY:
When Robert G. Faris first went to Poland two years ago with $240 million from Congress to make loans to entrepreneurs, he had to develop a brochure for borrowers that explained what a loan was and the responsibility of paying it back.
He found that Polish builders possessed fantasies about capitalism so grandiose that they designed inappropriately luxurious houses. And when he decided to open a mortgage bank to stimulate badly needed home construction, the Polish Parliament had to be lobbied for a law that allowed the eviction of defaulters. 
 Despite these challenges, his operation, the Polish-American Enterprise Fund, has disbursed $102 million and made commitments on another $78 million. It has been so successful that new investors have been attracted to help it make further investments.
 
More Money Coming
 In December, the pension funds of the General Electric Company and some other American corporations joined with Creditanstalt Bankverein of Austria and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to create a $150 million private equity fund for investment in Poland, called the Polish Private Equity Fund.
"I was very impressed with Poland and its private sector, which is thriving," Rosemary Sagar, a vice president of General Electric Investments, said about her recent visit there. "The Poles are very entrepreneurial. The private sector is larger than in Hungary and Czechoslovakia and is offsetting the shrinking state sector."
She said that even though G.E.'s investment was tiny -- it has put only $5 million in the new fund -- it offered an opportunity to assess business developments in Poland.
With a population of 40 million and a strategic position between the former Soviet Union and Germany, Poland also has an effective Polish-American lobby in Washington. When Congress allocated investment money for Eastern Europe three years ago, it appropriated $240 million for Poland, and only $60 million each for Hungary and Czechoslovakia.
 
Filling the Top Posts

 
 The Bush Administration appointed John P. Birkelund, chairman of the Dillon, Read securities firm, to head the Polish-American fund. Mr. Faris, president of Alan Patricof Associates, a venture capital firm in New York, was made the fund's president.
When Mr. Faris and his colleagues arrived in Warsaw, they were besieged by loan applicants. With Polish banks lending to entrepreneurs at an interest rate of 70 percent, it was hardly surprising that energetic Poles with business ideas lined up for blocks outside those banks that were offering loans from the American fund at 12 percent. Initially, so many credit-starved Poles lined up for loans that overwhelmed bank managers insisted the program be closed.
Both Mr. Birkelund and Mr. Faris said their main criterion in choosing investments was a reasonable likelihood that the business would succeed. It was imperative, they said, that the Poles see examples of capitalism that worked and that the Poles understand that the money from Washington was not a free handout along the lines of a traditional aid program.
"You've got a situation where there was no commercial code, no accounting system, no banking system and no understanding of marketing or financial management," Mr. Faris said.
In two years, the fund has approved loans to more than 1,700 small businesses and made equity investments in more than 30 larger established Polish enterprises. The financings include $15 million for a former state-owned printing plant that was about to be liquidated and $10 million for a furniture maker who managed to survive during the Communist era and needed money to expand.
 
Using Chicago Experience
 To establish the creditworthiness of potential borrowers in a country where creditworthiness was a new idea, the fund brought two officers of the South Shore Bank of Chicago to Poland. The bank has 18 years' experience with lending in inner-city Chicago amid risky financial conditions.
Besides writing the brochure on the A B C's of borrowing, the officers from South Shore helped give lessons in basic customer service to 75 Polish employees at nine regional banks.
The fund's small loans are at a 12 percent interest rate for a maximum of three years.
The fund closed its small-loan program for two months at the end of 1990 because of the large number of poorly qualified applicants, but then reopened it with stricter criteria.
"To qualify for the small loans you have to show capability as a manager, outline a reasonable business plan and demonstrate growth potential and cash flows sufficient to cover the loan and other obligations," Mr. Faris said. "Generally, you have to be more than a beginner."
He was particularly taken by the application of a woman who ran a state-owned laundry that was about to be closed. "She wanted backing for a laundry of her own and demonstrated the demand," he said.
 
A Furniture Entrepreneur
 One of Mr. Faris's favorite investments is the $6 million of equity and $4 million loan provided to Haste International, a furniture manufacturer founded 12 years ago by a tenacious entrepreneur, Stefan Lewandowski. Haste ships products to Germany and Scandinavia and to Ikea, the international household retailer. Ikea's sparkling new outlet in downtown Warsaw is a popular shopping stops for those Poles who have money.
"Stefan Lewandowski is animated and dynamic, a take-charge person," Mr. Faris said. "He has the potential for becoming the biggest furniture maker in Poland; there are state-owned furniture companies up for sale that he can buy. He was short of capital, and this money is for expansion."
Mr. Faris is also optimistic about the fund's equity investment of $350,000 and a loan of $644,000 provided to Qumak International in Cracow in southern Poland. Three young entrepreneurs learned the computer business from Western magazines and started Qumak, a computer distribution business. "I sensed they have management smarts," he said, "and though the computer business is a tough one, I think they are tackling it pretty well."
The fund's equity investments are for long-term capital growth, "typically five to seven years," Mr. Faris said.
As for the small loans, the delinquency rate so far has been low -- just 2 percent. This is a better record than that of most commercial banks in the United States, Mr. Faris said.
Despite the upbeat aspects of frontier entrepreneurship in Poland, there are still many frustrations for Mr. Faris and his associates. Instead of the 60 days it might take to complete a typical deal in the United States, the figure for Poland is more like six months, he said.

HEADLINE: THE TWIN TOWERS: The Suspect;
More Light Is Shed On a Shadowy Life

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, March 5

 BODY:
He apparently lived in this country illegally, squeezed into a small disordered apartment here with three others. Neighbors say he kept to a shadowy life penetrated by few people outside of a tight network of Muslims who shared housing and fraternized with him. Some of these friends seem to have vanished in the last few days.
Mohammed A. Salameh, the 25-year-old man described by the police as an Islamic fundamentalist who was arrested on Thursday morning as the first suspect in the World Trade Center bombing, has lived for about two years in a one-bedroom apartment on an unobtrusive residential street here that he shared with two women and another man, neighbors said. At some point, he may have driven a cab or worked in construction. 
 Neighbors, however, did not know the names of his roommates or what became of them after Mr. Salameh's arrest. The telephone at the apartment, on the ground floor of 34 Kensington Avenue, is listed in the name of Josie Hadas.
Five other Arab men roomed together on the floor above Mr. Salameh's, neighbors said, and were friends of his. The neighbors said those men were evicted from the apartment three or four months ago for not paying their rent. Their whereabouts were also unknown.
 
Many Visitors Recently
 Residents of Kensington Avenue in this working-class neighborhood knew virtually nothing of the lean, bearded Mr. Salameh, other than that he seemed devoutly religious and remote. What English he knew he delivered in a thick accent. He received an intensifying flurry of visitors shortly before the explosion.
Earl Jones, a supervisor for a cleaning company who lives in a house next door to Mr. Salameh's apartment building, said that in the last couple of weeks a number of Arab men frequently visited Mr. Salameh, sometimes in the middle of the night. "There was a lot of night activity," Mr. Jones said. "After one in the morning I would hear the door slam and there would be talking in Arabic that I couldn't understand. This was in the week before the explosion."
Several neighbors in Mr. Salameh's building said they noticed boxes being lugged in and out of his apartment. They assumed it was dishes or papers.
When the Federal authorities searched Mr. Salameh's apartment, they said, they discovered tools, wiring and manuals, implying the presence of a bomb maker. They said that they believe the bomb was planned at the apartment but built elsewhere, and that others were involved.
Last night, investigators found hundreds of pounds of bomb-making chemicals in a locker at a drive-in self-storage warehouse in Jersey City, and Federal officials said that the van rented to Mr. Salameh had been seen by witnesses at the warehouse.
 
Tripped Up by Persistence
 Mr. Salameh was undone by his persistence in trying to retrieve a $400 deposit on a yellow Ryder van that the authorities believe contained the bomb that rocked the World Trade Center. He was arrested Thursday morning after making his third trip to the Jersey City van rental agency.
While some neighbors found Mr. Salameh cordial -- one woman said he would assist her with her groceries -- others said the Arab tenants were frowned on in the building because of unpleasant food odors wafting from their apartments and because of untidy habits.
The extent of Mr. Salameh's connections remain murky, though evidence mounted that he has ties to El Sayyid A. Nosair, an Egyptian in prison for crimes related to the slaying of Rabbi Meir Kahane. One of Mr. Nosair's lawyers said a man named Salameh, who fit the suspect's description, faithfully attended Mr. Nosair's trial in late 1991 in New York.
"When I was in New York for the trial," said the lawyer, Montasser al-Zayat. "I met a young man in his early 20's named Salameh who attended each session with several other young Arab men. I do not know if this Salameh was the man suspected of carrying out the bombing in New York, but the age and the name seem to be the same. The description I have been given of the suspect fits exactly."
When he acquired a New York driver's license last year, Mr. Salameh gave as his address the Brooklyn apartment formerly inhabited by Mr. Nosair. Its current occupant, Ibrahim A. Elgabrowny, a carpenter who is Mr. Nosair's cousin, was arrested Thursday on charges of obstruction of justice. The authorities said he tried to prevent them from searching the apartment.
 
'Liked to Do Favors'
 Lisa Elgabrowny, his wife, said that they had lived in the apartment for nine years and that Mr. Salameh had never visited them. She said she did not know why he gave that address in pursuing a driver's license. "Maybe he was acquainted," she said. She added that her husband liked to do favors for others.
Mr. Salameh worshiped at the Al Salam mosque in Jersey City, and law-enforcement officials believe he is a follower of the blind Muslim cleric who preaches there, Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman. The Egyptian Government maintains that he is the spiritual leader of a movement responsible for dozens of violent attacks in Egypt. The sheik was acquitted in Egypt a decade ago in the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat.
According to a Federal official, Mr. Salameh, who carried a Jordanian passport but whose nationality could not be determined, has presumably lived illegally in the United States for more than four-and-a-half years. He entered the country legally on Feb. 17, 1988, with a six-month visitor's visa that had been issued him in Amman, Jordan, in December 1987. That visa expired on Aug. 16, 1988, but the official said there was no evidence that Mr. Salameh had left the United States.
Before he moved to his latest apartment on Kensington Avenue, Mr. Salameh lived nearby on the second floor of an apartment at 26 Weldon Street, sharing that as well with several others, neighbors said. "There would sometimes be like 10 of them living there at the same time," said Lou Lutrario, a 23-year-old unemployed neighbor. "A lot of them were cabdrivers. The cabs would sometimes park out there at 1 A.M. and the drivers would whistle up."
 
Back to Egypt
 Five Egyptians appear to live there now, and neighbors said the place continued to be a haunt of Arab cabdrivers. The Weldon Street apartment was raided by the Federal authorities on Thursday afternoon and neighbors said that two of its occupants -- a man and a woman named Gladys Noore who said she was visiting her boyfriend -- were brought out and questioned by the authorities before being released. Neighbors said that the authorities removed items from the apartment.
Several Egyptians also occupied an adjacent apartment. Neighbors said they had departed for Egypt last week.
Two of the men who now live in Mr. Salameh's former one-bedroom apartment denied knowing the suspect. Two neighbors, however, said he had been spotted in the building recently.
The apartment was sorely in need of housekeeping. The living room contains a cot and a couch arranged for sleeping. The bedroom has two cots and a mattress plopped on the floor. Packed luggage was strewn around the living room.
Hassan Elkhayat, an Egyptian, was asleep on the couch early this afternoon. He spoke hardly any English, but insisted he knew nothing of Mr. Salameh, other than that he previously lived there. He said four other men lived in the apartment with him.
Another man returning to the apartment with a woman said he had been questioned by the Federal authorities but did not know Mr. Salameh.
Aeisha Harreld, a young woman who lives with her children next door, said that she believed Mr. Salameh had been staying at the apartment as recently as a month or two ago. She said she saw him on and off in the laundry room. "He would put money in other people's dryers if they weren't there and the clothes were still wet," she said. "Otherwise, he didn't mess with anybody."
It was unclear how Mr. Salameh supported himself. He said he was a cabdriver on the rental application for his present apartment. The major cab companies in Jersey City, however, said they had never heard of him.
Frank Ferrari, a general partner in Ferarri Investments in Verona, N.J., who is the landlord of Mr. Salameh's Kensington Avenue apartment, said Mr. Salameh rented the apartment about two years ago and had paid the $560 a month rent on time until last month. That payment is still in arrears.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Employers added 365,000 workers to their payrolls in February, the biggest jump in four years, as the unemployment rate edged down a tenth of a point to 7 percent. The report ran counter to recent doubts about the vigor of the economic expansion. [Page 1.] New York City's unemployment rate fell sharply in February, to 11.3 percent, from January's rate of 13.4 percent, which was the highest figure in 25 years. [47.]
Moderate and conservative Senate Democrats are pressing for more budget cuts in President Clinton's economic package, and they want spending tied to cuts. [1.]
The Resolution Trust Corporation was criticized by its inspector general for doing business with the son of Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen after he defaulted on loans. [45.]
 
Companies
A top weapons laboratory will buy an unproven supercomputer from a British company rather than from one of several American companies. The decision to buy the $15 million computer from Meiko World raised questions about national security and economic competitiveness. [35.]
American Express will sell more than half its majority stake in First Data. The sale could raise more than $1 billion. [37.]
Deutsche Bank agreed to acquire Banco de Madrid for $365 million, which would double its presence in Spain. [37.]
A former top May Department Stores executive was named president and chief operating officer of Neiman Marcus. [37.]
Russia is selling 35 percent of Zil, which has made armored limousines for Communist leaders from Stalin to Gorbachev. [37.]
 
 International
Germany's central bank surprised world financial markets by lowering a short-term money-market interest rate and signaling an intention to continue guiding rates down. [35.]
In disbursing millions of dollars in Poland's shift to a market economy, the Polish-American Enterprise Fund has had to educate Poles in basic capitalism like what a loan is. [35.]
 
 Markets
Treasury prices recovered after falling sharply in response to the strong February employment report. The 30-year bond ended the day with its yield unchanged, at 6.73 percent. [35.]
Investors embraced cyclical stocks and shunned those sensitive to interest rates. The Dow rose 5.67 points. [36.]
The dollar surged in heavy trading, bolstered by a cut in a German interest rate. Gold advanced worldwide. [46.]
Livestock futures soared amid growing concerns that herds were not expanding fast enough to meet demand. [46.]
 
 Your Money
Despite recognition of domestic partners by New York and other cities, unmarried couples must still draw up private legal agreements to protect their property rights. [33.]
As issuers of tax-exempt bonds redeem them to take advantage of lower rates, bond fund managers are putting investors' money into higher-risk issues to maintain high yields. [33.]
Even with their interest rate cut to 4 from 6 percent, savings bonds are still a good investment for many families. [33.]
A Pennsylvania family bought a new car at very low cost through the American Automobile Association. [34.]

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
Clinton Defends Bosnia Airdrops and Vows Tighter Sanctions

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
President Clinton today defended American efforts to provide relief aid to eastern Bosnia and Herzegovina and promised to further tighten sanctions against the delivery of oil and other supplies to Yugoslavia.
"We are exploring and, indeed, are in the process of implementing ways to tighten the embargo, which we will announce very shortly," Mr. Clinton said at the White House. "And I think there are other things we can do." 
 As negotiators at the United Nations continued to work toward reaching a compromise in the peace talks, Mr. Clinton took pains to blame Serbian leaders for any potential derailment.
"I think it will be very interesting for the world to look and see if the Serbians are willing to negotiate in good faith in a process that they have embraced when it suited their short-term strategic interests," Mr. Clinton said. "I hope that they will support it over a longer term. We'll see."
 
Offensive Raises Questions
 The Serbian assault on Muslim towns in eastern Bosnia since the airdrops began has led to questions about their effectiveness.
But White House officials insisted that the existing sanctions and the policy of dropping relief supplies from the air to persuade the Serbs to stop blocking ground convoys have worked.
White House officials announced that the Maria, a vessel carrying Serbian arms that was on its way to deliver them to Somalia, had been detained this morning in the Indian Ocean off the Seychelles. They cited that action as an example of how the embargo was working.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House spokesman, said that four other vessels had been stopped in the last month and that shipments along the Danube had also been slowed.
 
Serbs Seek to Raise Cash
 The American authorities believe that such shipments are used to raise cash and purchase goods in violation of the United Nations embargo.
"The entire effort is designed to crack down on the Serbians, to inflict real pain and real price for the actions they're taking," Mr. Stephanopoulos said.
Mr. Clinton and other officials would not discuss how the existing sanctions might be tightened.
Mr. Clinton said further action in the area depends on the cooperation from European allies and from Russia.
"The United States cannot proceed here unilaterally," he said. "We need the support of the Europeans, who are much closer to the situation and who will be much more immediately impacted by any further adverse instability in the Balkans than we would."
Two teams, from the State and Treasury Departments, have been sent to Europe to devise a plan to intercept both the shipment of goods over land and monetary transfers, Mr. Stephanopoulos said.
"We are producing results when we do anything to limit Serbia's ability to create goods in the long run, when we limit their ability to get finance, financing," he said. "We, over time, will be inhibiting their effort to carry on the aggression."
Mr. Clinton conceded today that the Serbs were making inroads in spite of United Nations embargo and relief efforts. "I don't think there's any question that when the Serbs take an area and then run all the Bosnian Muslims out, then that means that they are succeeding," the President said. "They have succeeded in running some people out of communities."
Mr. Stephanopoulos said: "The aggression is continuing. And it's clearly a matter of concern to the President. There's no question the situation in eastern Bosnia is very serious, and we have to take whatever steps we can to try and pressure Serbia to be good actors at the negotiating table."
 
Airdrop Accuracy Defended
 The White House emphasized today that President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia had expressed support for the airdrops. But Mr. Stephanopoulos said the Administration would continue to review its policies on the aid.
"We will continually reassess our policy," he said. "We talk with our allies. We use our intelligence assessments of what's happening on the ground."
Mr. Clinton stressed, however, that intelligence reports do not support the idea that the airdrops have created more danger than they have relieved.
"The surveillance we've done indicates that there have been actually slightly more accuracy in the drops from the altitude we chose for safety for our pilots than we thought there would be," he said.
"So would I re-examine it if I thought they were doing more harm than good?" the President added. "Of course I would. But I can tell you that I have pressed that point very hard in our meetings, and our people simply dispute the proposition."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
The Siege, Waco Points Out, Isn't Exactly in Waco

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WACO, Tex., March 5

 BODY:
Waco did not plan on this.
But as a doomsday religious cult and its self-proclaimed Messiah kept hundreds of Federal agents at bay for a sixth day today, this central Texas city of 100,000 people was gamely trying to cope with its worldwide fame as the place where the drama was unfolding. 
 Actually, as city leaders here do not tire of pointing out, their hometown is really not the place. The cult's compound is a few miles east of the city limits, in an unincorporated part of McLennan County.
"Because the incident itself is not happening in Waco, we hope that people will not believe there is a siege in Waco," said Elizabeth A. Taylor, director of the Waco Convention and Visitors Bureau. "Waco is not under siege."
That may be true, but it does seem besieged -- by Federal agents walking around hotels and city streets with semiautomatic guns over their shoulders, by Texas Rangers, reporters and camera crews. And because all briefings for reporters, who are not allowed to go anywhere near the actual siege, are downtown, the name Waco is now firmly linked to the standoff and the gun battle that began it. Four Federal agents and an undetermined number of cult members were killed in the shooting when the authorities raided the compound on Sunday morning.
Many people here concede that the notoriety is inevitable, but they are still unhappy about it. "We're sitting here being the victims, very much like Dallas was with J.F.K.," said John Fletcher, a board member of the Waco Chamber of Commerce. "The people of Waco didn't do anything."
To help counteract bad impressions, city officials posted a notice at the F.B.I. briefing today that provided the local tourist information number. Employees of the visitor's bureau circulated in the crowd to describe the city's 14 museums, a new zoo and other attractions.
And with workers from news organizations being ejected from their hotel rooms by Federal agents or by guests arriving for long-planned conventions here this weekend, the notice offered some Texas-sized hospitality. "Wacoans are opening up their homes to put people up!" it said.
 
Good for Business
 The standoff may be bad for Waco's image, but it has been undeniably good for business.
Every hotel room for miles around is booked, and even with the tension,people have to eat. Local restaurants are often filled. Nobody has an exact count of the law officers, news workers and worried relatives who have thronged the town, but it may be 2,000 and perhaps many more.
"Any time this many people are in town, it has a dramatic impact on the economy," one city official said. "You all are here and you all are spending money."
If anything, there is too much business. Hotel operators have been told to let Federal agents remain in their rooms even if that means bumping people with reservations.
This weekend alone, the Texas Association of Baptist Schools is holding a conference here; the Texas-New Mexico Junior College Basketball Tournament, which drawn 16 teams along with their fans, is being fought in town and an Arabian Horse Show is on at the Texas State Fairgrounds.
 
Mystery Truck
 Out along a rural highway, at the edge of a pasture that is the closest to the compound that reporters are allowed to go, there are long stretches of quiet punctuated by an occasional burst of frenzy when a vehicle zooms away from the compound, about two miles away, and heads toward the crowd of waiting reporters.
The other night, a large white-paneled truck could be seen in the distance, making its way from the compound area in a chilly drizzle. Camera crews took to the ready, and rumors started whirling. It was children being released; it was adult cult members who had surrendered; it was a makeshift hearse carrying bodies of Branch Davidians killed in the shootout.
As it turned out, the truck belonged to Michna's Barbecue (Catering and Custom Cooking), which had made a delivery to a shift of hungry Federal agents watching the compound.
 
Metaphorical Messiah
 His business card says, "Messiah." He told his followers on audio tape: "If the Bible is true, then I'm Christ." But in recent days, negotiators who have spoken by telephone with David Koresh, the cult's leader, say he has taken considerable offense at the portrayal of him as man who believes he is Jesus.
"He describes himself as a prophet," Bob Ricks, an F.B.I. agent, said at a news briefing today. Although Mr. Ricks did not elaborate, other officials trying to work out an end to the crisis said Mr. Koresh had suggested that in comparing himself to Jesus, he was speaking metaphorically, not literally.
Negotiators confirmed that they had brought in biblical scholars to help in talks with Mr. Koresh. "There are long discussions regarding religion, long readings of the Scriptures," said Jeffrey Jamar, the F.B.I. agent in charge of the entire field operation.
Mr. Koresh seems most interested in discussing the Bible, officials say, and frequently becomes angry or even hangs up when the negotiators try to steer the conversation back toward releasing people inside or ending the entire affair. The cult leader, who reneged on a promise to surrender after his 58-minute monologue was broadcast on Tuesday, insists that he will go only when he hears God tell him to.
 
Uncertain Body Count
 How many dead are inside the compound? Some newspapers, quoting people familiar with accounts from children who were inside, are saying the number could be as high as 20.
Officials of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms have confirmed only two deaths inside, in addition to the four agents outside. On Thursday, the authorities used armored vehicles for cover when they went to recover the second body, that of a man near the compound who was found still clutching a gun.
On Friday morning, an arrangement was worked out for Federal agents to remove the bodies of two dead dogs killed in the gunfire, after Mr. Koresh reportedly said some of his followers were complaining about the smell and unsanitary conditions.The agents also took away a live goose that escaped at the time.
But aside from Mr. Koresh's early unconfirmed report that a 2-year-old child had died in the shootout, Federal officials have offered no formal count, first- or second-hand, of how many people may be dead inside, and the truth seems to be that the people in charge simply do not know.
