HEADLINE: Unemployment at 11.3% As New York City Gains

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
New York City's unemployment rate fell sharply in February, to 11.3 percent, Labor Department figures showed yesterday. That was a significant improvement from the January rate of 13.4 percent, which was the highest figure in 25 years.
While February's rate was still in line with the recessionary levels that have persisted since summer, it was a strong indication that January's rate was a seasonal spike caused by layoffs after the Christmas season in the retail and construction fields and the continued shrinkage of the financial and service industries, Federal labor officials said. 
 "We're still bumping along the bottom that was reached last summer, and our fears that January was a new bottom were happily not realized," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "But we do find that February's figures are more encouraging and show a slight improvement in the economy, even though they are half again higher than the national average."
 
 
Not Seasonally Adjusted
 The city's unemployment figure, unlike those for states, is not seasonally adjusted and thus does not include the statistical smoothing that compensates for seasonal jumps or monthly variations in the labor force or the economy.
But the Office of the New York City Comptroller calculates an adjusted unemployment figure for the city, which it said was 11.2 percent in February, down sharply from the 12.8 percent it reported for January.
"Just as we predicted, the January rate was a fluke," said David Neustadt, a spokesman for the comptroller's office.
All told, there were 379,000 New Yorkers out of work in February, down from 447,000 in January but nearly the same as the unemployment levels that have prevailed for the previous five months. The figures exclude those who have dropped out of the city labor market and are not actively seeking work.
The number of employed increased by 82,000, to 2,982,000, after a decrease of similar magnitude in January. The total labor force, including both the employed and unemployed, and those actively seeking jobs, totaled 3,361,000, little changed from January.
 
 
A Tie for Highest Rate
 Compared with other metropolitan areas, Mr. Ehrenhalt said the eight counties in lower New York that make up the Labor Department's New York metropolitan regional grouping ranked with the Riverside-San Bernardino region of Southern California as having the highest unemployment levels in the country.
"The New York metropolitan region is at, or close, to the top," Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
The national unemployment rate in February was 7 percent, down slightly from 7.1 percent in January. The rate in New Jersey was 7.8 percent, compared with 7.4 percent in January, and 8 percent in New York State, compared with 8.5 percent in the two previous months.
The February unemployment rate in Connecticut was unavailable. But the January figure, released yesterday, was 7.5 percent, and did not reflect the thousands of imminent layoffs announced by some of the big military contractors in the state.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
British Sell Computer To U.S. Lab

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 5

 BODY:
In a controversial decision that raises national security and economic competitiveness issues, one of the nation's leading weapons laboratories is buying an unproven supercomputer from the American branch of a British company rather than from one of several American companies.
The decision by the Lawrence Livermore Laboratories, an Energy Department scientific research and weapons-design center east of here, to buy the $15 million computer from the British company, Meiko World Inc., sent shock waves through the highly competitive supercomputer industry. 
 The super-fast computers are capable of the billions of calculations a second required by weapons designers, scientists and commercial engineers. It had been widely believed that only American and Japanese manufacturers were in the race to build such machines.
 
Deal With Israel
 Livermore's decision, which was disclosed by several computer industry officials today, raised particular questions about national security. In 1991, Meiko sold supercomputers to an Israeli educational institution that was reportedly involved with the design of nuclear weapons. The United States has been unsuccessful in trying to persuade European governments to sign a treaty between the United States and Japan that controls the export of supercomputers to foreign governments.
The Livermore contract is seen as contributing to Meiko's ability to develop machines that foreign countries can use to develop nuclear weapons.
"These are American tax dollars that shouldn't be spent in lowering our national security by pumping up a company that has a bad export record," said Gary Milhollin, director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control in Washington. "The result of the sale is going to make this dangerous exporter more of a danger."
In late January, Livermore notified several American supercomputer makers that it had selected a massively parallel supercomputer designed by the Meiko Scientific Corporation, based in Waltham, Mass., for a classified weapons-related application.
Livermore refused to identify the other bidders for the contract or discuss its details, but industry executives familiar with the program said that in addition to Meiko, a number of United States companies -- including the Thinking Machines Corporation, the Intel Scientific Corporation, the Ncube Corporation and several other computer makers -- had made bids.
Meiko Scientific is a wholly owned subsidiary of Meiko World, which also owns Meiko Scientific Ltd., a supercomputer maker in Bristol, England. Meiko World is owned by six British citizens and has some 140 employees.
"I'm stunned that they would make this choice," said Jack Dongarra, a computer scientist at the University of Tennessee who is an expert in measuring computer performance. "Meiko doesn't have an established track record compared to others in the field."
 
Meets Components Test
 The decision to select Meiko satisfies the Federal law requiring that the component content of such a machine be more than 50 percent American made. But the move has led several competitors to charge that the deal is an economic threat to the United States supercomputer industry, already facing heavy competition from Japan.
"We're blown away that Meiko won," said one United States supercomputer executive, who insisted that he not be identified. "It's one thing to lose a sale in Europe, it's another thing to lose at a national laboratory right after Vice President Gore has made a speech saying that we're going to use the power of the Government to make United States industry more competitive."
The award also raises concerns about the control of advanced computer technologies that could potentially be used by foreign countries to design nuclear weapons or other advanced weapons.
Mr. Milhollin of the Wisconsin Project said that the sale of two moderately powered supercomputers by Meiko to the Technion, an Israeli University, in 1991 had permitted the Israelis to obtain machines that could be used for weapons design. The sale came after Washington had denied Cray Research and Intel Scientific licenses to export supercomputers to Israel because of fears their machines would be used to design nuclear weapons.
Government officials said that companies like Meiko fall in a gray area.
"We have struggled in the Government over the issue of what makes an American company," said Jonathan Streeter, a Commerce Department official who is an expert on supercomputers. "It does open up a real can of worms; this is something we will be hearing about from the Japanese."
Livermore officials said that they were still negotiating the terms of the contract and would review a variety of issues before the contract was formally awarded.
David Schwoegler, a spokesman for the laboratory, said that one of the issues the Energy Department is reviewing is whether Meiko Scientific should be considered American or British. He indicated today, however, that Livermore was confident that the company would meet the domestic-content test.
"Meiko Scientific is a U.S. company," Mr. Schwoegler said. "The Meiko system under consideration is U.S. designed and 85 percent of the hardware is manufactured in the United States."
The president of Meiko Scientific, David Alden, said that the CS-2 supercomputer had been designed in both the United States and Europe.

HEADLINE: O'Rourke Rejects Offer of Judicial Bid

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, March 5

 BODY:
Andrew P. O'Rourke, Westchester's County Executive, today wistfully turned down the offer of a nomination for a Federal judgeship. He will seek re-election to the job he has held for 10 years.
The decision came as something of a surprise since Mr. O'Rourke, a Republican, had been longingly waiting for a seat on the bench ever since President Bush nominated him in November 1991. 
 That nomination was allowed, with maddening suspense, to expire when Democrats in the Senate sensed an impending victory by Bill Clinton. But it was revived this week when Senators Alfonse M. D'Amato and Daniel Patrick Moynihan put Mr. O'Rourke's name forward once more for a vacancy in Federal District Court in Manhattan.
 
Senators Divide Nominations
 Under a system set up in the 1970's, New York's senators have agreed to divide judgeship nominations, with three going to the senator whose party is in power and one going to the member of the other party. So, although the Democrats are now in power, Mr. D'Amato was able to submit Mr. O'Rourke's name again.
Mr. O'Rourke said today that despite Mr. Moynihan's assurances, he was not prepared to see his nomination languish once more in a capital dominated by Democrats.
"There are only 900 Federal judgeships and it's a very elite club," he said at a news conference here. "I could see myself there, but in all honesty I see myself more clearly as a county executive serving the people of the county."
Despite his decision today, his flirtation with the judgeship is already a campaign issue as he battles one of two Democratic contenders -- Andrew J. Spano, the County Clerk who announced his candidacy in January, and Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky of Greenburgh, who has yet to make an official announcement. Some Democratic officials had predicted that Mr. O'Rourke would reveal the new judgeship offer, then turn it down as a ploy to show the people of Westchester that he remains eager to manage their affairs.
"I think Andy's tired of the job," Mr. Spano said earlier this week. "I think he wants out and there has been a natural malaise that has enshrouded government."
 
Tough Battle in November
 Mr. O'Rourke will have a tough battle in November in a county once dominated by Republicans where Democrats have achieved an edge in voter registration of 181,360 to 157,774. There are also 10,515 Conservatives and 119,126 independents.
The 59-year-old Mr. O'Rourke, a centrist Republican, beat Mr. Brodsky four years ago with 52 percent of the vote, drawing support from moderate Democrats as well as Republicans in his onetime political home of Yonkers and in most of the county's towns and villages. His strongest base is among Italian and Irish Catholic voters, but he has drawn Jewish support as well.
Mr. O'Rourke is an avuncular man with elegant silvery hair and considerable charm and wit. He can tell salty tales of a welfare childhood in Manhattan's Hell's Kitchen or chuckle over his appearances on the television show "Quiz Kids." His hard-to-ruffle manner has made the running of a county for 875,000 citizens seem easy. He is probably the nation's only county executive to have published two adventure novels while in office.
Mr. O'Rourke maintains that he has been a good fiscal steward. He has not raised taxes since a one-cent increase in the sales tax two years ago. And he claims to have saved taxpayers money by demanding tougher investigations of welfare eligibility and work programs for 600 of the 1,500 people on home relief. He has, he says, cut the number of homeless cases from 4,553 in January 1991 to 3,542 in December 1992, though advocates for the homeless counter that the homeless have been forced to improvise in often-bruising ways.
Mr. Spano, a genial Democrat of 56, has long pined for Mr. O'Rourke's job. He is given high marks for computerizing the clerk's office so that residents seeking mortgage documents will no longer have to leaf through dusty ledgers. He needs to convince voters that he can tackle tougher policy issues, such as housing. To counter any impressions of provincialism, Mr. Spano has exhorted the county to awaken to a global economy and the age of information.
 
Nimble Intellect
 Mr. Brodsky, a blunt, hard-charging, 46-year-old Harvard Law School graduate, is regarded as the most nimble intellect. But his almost exclusive experience as a legislator has raised questions about whether he can manage an intricate administration and whether he has, as Mr. Spano diplomatically puts it, the personal "skills in bringing people together."
"The county government has been corruptly and unintelligently managed," Mr. Brodsky said at his 300-year-old house in Greenburgh. "The net result is skyrocketing taxes, a breakdown of service delivery."
Mr. O'Rourke swats at such mosquitoes. "Brodsky is like a guy sitting on the shore hoping this great ship will go on the rocks so he can claim salvage rights," he said.
Westchester is one of the nation's most affluent counties, with a median household income of $50,872. Despite its reputation as an emblematic suburb, 40 percent of its residents live in four cities -- Yonkers, New Rochelle, Mount Vernon and White Plains. Ethnically, its people just about mirror the nation: 79.4 percent are white, 13.7 percent are black, 9.8 percent are Hispanic and 3.7 percent are Asian.
The county's political arrangement has sometimes left county authorities gasping for identity. Most people think of themselves as living in the county's 19 towns, 23 villages or its small cities, places that collect their garbage, teach their children and protect them against crime. For many people that is about all the government they want or need.
"The county government tends to be remote from people and provides services that people don't understand are provided by the county," said S. J. Schulman, former president of the Westchester County Association, a business group.
Yet the county government spends $1.2 billion of their money and employs 10,000 people. It runs a large network of parks, treats the towns' sewage, operates a world-class medical center and, as an agent of the state, provides welfare and Medicaid payments to its poorest citizens.
Indifference to the county's problems may have permitted Westchester to develop a reputation for patronage, making its politics sometimes seem as feudal as Huey Long's Louisiana.
Leonard N. Spano, the Republican leader of Yonkers and no relation to Andrew Spano, has 18 relatives on the county payroll. Three years ago, the innocence of Playland Amusement Park, a county-run park in Rye, was shattered by a state report that found that Playland's director was a Republican operative who tacitly squeezed $80,000 for the party's coffers from 21 amusement vendors.
Mr. O'Rourke rejects any responsibility for these indiscretions, noting, for example, that many of Mr. Spano's relatives were hired before he became executive in 1983.
 
Problems of Affordability
 Westchester's Aaa bond rating is better than that of Nassau or Suffolk. Still, the county faces serious problems. Its population is aging, and senior citizens, who may own large homes but have reduced incomes, cannot afford the property taxes needed to sustain the county's well-regarded schools and other services.
Young men and women who grew up in Westchester cannot buy or rent homes here. Many towns find that their volunteer firefighters cannot afford to live within their boundaries.
One criticism leveled at Mr. O'Rourke is that he was slow in recognizing his powers to intervene in the housing crisis until a year ago when he proposed a plan to have the county assist villages in building homes for families earning up to $64,000.

HEADLINE: Haitian Refugees Find Welcome Wears Thin

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE

 BODY:
When Jean Silien Talabert came to New York last year, his brother eagerly gave him a place to live.
But now his brother says he cannot support him any longer, and the 26-year-old Haitian refugee is staying with a woman he barely knows. He must leave the house daily at 8 A.M and return at 6 P.M. when she does. She does not allow him to bathe at her place, although he does at night when she is asleep. 
 "I don't blame her," Mr. Talabert said matter-of-factly. "If my brother can't help me, she has done enough for me -- and at least I have a place to sleep."
Mr. Talabert, like many of the 1,000 Haitian refugees who ended up in New York after fleeing their violence-torn homeland in 1991, is finding the welcome wearing thin.
 
Late-Night Calls
 Some refugees who were taken in by relatives or other immigrants are being turned out, their hosts unwilling or unable to keep supporting them. Caseworkers at social service agencies that assist refugees say it is not unusual to receive telephone calls in the middle of the night from clients who have been kicked out.
"Now we're dealing with something harder: sponsorship breakdown," said Harold Pirem, a caseworker at Church World Services, an agency in Brooklyn. "My job is to make sure that they have a place to sleep. It's a giant job."
After the ouster of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in September 1991, more than 40,000 Haitians risked their lives aboard rickety boats on the high seas fleeing the country. They were picked up by Coast Guard cutters and taken to the Guantanamo Naval Base in Cuba. More than 10,000 were found to have some basis for seeking political asylum and were allowed into the United States, where most of their asylum applications are still pending.
 
Asylum Argument
 While Mr. Talabert tries to survive in this country, the Supreme Court is considering whether political asylum seekers like him should be allowed into the country at all. The Government argued this week that it should have the right to pick up Haitians at sea and return them to their country without asylum hearings. An appeals court has upheld the refugees' right to seek haven.
Most Haitian refugees who came to the United States after the coup settled in South Florida, where many are having the same problems as the Haitians in New York.
Reynold Delatour, a supervisor at Catholic Community Services in Miami, said that when the refugees were taken to South Florida from Guantanamo, many declared casual acquaintances as sponsors, people they had known in Haiti, because they feared deportation if no one sponsored them. But many of those relationships have broken down.
"They are bouncing around," Mr. Delatour said. "They eat here and eat there."
About 1,000 Haitians came to New York, in many cases relying on relatives and friends who had been in the United States only a short time themselves and were barely making a living.
For newcomers who had no relatives to help them, private agencies such as Church World Services and Catholic Charities, which receive money from the Federal Government, provide services to the refugees. The agencies try to find sponsors who will provide room and board until the refugees can fend for themselves. The agencies also help refugees find jobs and apply for Medicaid and other benefits.
 
Grants Are at Risk
 But social-service agencies helping the newcomers fear that their Federal grants may be reduced, even as the refugees' needs keep growing. The agencies are currently renegotiating their contracts with the Government.
Last year, the Community Relations Service of the Justice Department, the Federal agency in charge of resettling refugees, had threatened to cut more than 80 percent of the refugee resettlement financing, but that proposal was rescinded after pressure from refugee advocates.
If financing is reduced this year, the advocates say, many refugees will be left on their own and some may end up homeless.
"It's a very stressful situation," said David Ferdinand, a caseworker at Catholic Charities. "You don't know if you're going to have a job from one day to the next, and above all, who will take care of the refugees."
Ron Tomalis, a spokesman for the Community Relations Service, would not comment on the budget while contract negotiations were under way.
Social workers at Catholic Charities in Brooklyn said the agency's budget for resettling 365 Haitian refugees is $238,000 this year, including staff salaries and supplies.
The agencies help the refugees in various ways, including employment, housing and legal counsel. Because many of the refugees speak only Creole and have no relatives in the United States, they often rely on staff members at the center to translate and explain documents.
"We don't know what we'll do, because without this center there will be no hope and we will have to sleep in the subways," said Paulanne Paul, who at 20 is the matriarch in charge of three teen-age cousins and a younger brother.
Some refugees have been more fortunate. Evina Jean Louis, 42, said she had been able to depend on relatives.
On the day she went to apply for Medicaid, her cousin drove from New Jersey and took her to the Church World Services office to make sure she was safe. "I have been treated nicely by my family," she said. "They trust me inside their home."
Unemployed, she said that her relatives often collect donations for her, which she sends to her husband and three children, who are still in Haiti.
But others have not been so lucky. Mr. Pirem's small office at Church World Services in Flatbush, Brooklyn, is crowded with stacks of folders, and the phone rings incessantly. On one recent day, Mr. Pirem was so busy that he picked up the phone from the fax machine and talked with two clients simultaneously.
As soon as he hung up, he had five refugees and three other visitors to accommodate. In all, he is responsible for 250 refugees in Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island. Another Church World Services office in Manhattan deals with refugees living there and in the Bronx and Westchester.
One refugee, Herold Abraham, 26, who was wearing a light jacket on a frigid day, asked Mr. Pirem for a coat.
Since arriving eight months ago, he has quickly learned many American ways. His hair is cut in a fade, a hairstyle rare in his native Cap-Haitien. He has a "J" carved into his hair, and when asked why, he answers: "It means I have no problems."
But he does. He called a reporter aside and peppered him with questions.
"When do you think Aristide will return?"
"Do you think they will force us back to Haiti?" He paused.
"You know, I want to stay here," he said.
Mr. Abraham said he would like to go to school, make a decent living and support his family.
"I don't want to sell drugs or something like that," he said. "I have two children in Haiti and I want to take care of them."
Mr. Abraham and many other refugees, dreading the possibility that they might be returned to Haiti, are especially concerned about their legal status. Fewer than 1 percent of the 10,000 refugees admitted after the 1991 coup have been granted asylum.
Many of the refugees tell chilling tales of escape from soldiers who came looking for them. Mr. Talabert said that his sister Marie Nicole and brother Jean Destin were killed when armed soldiers came to his home. He said he never returned home and went into hiding until he found a boat leaving for the United States.
"The only reason that I am alive is because I was not home," Mr. Talabert said. "I would have been dead like the others."

She fears that Catholic Charities in Brooklyn may not receive enough money to continue to help the refugees. She stood outside the center with other Haitians. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: More Borrowing in January

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
After spending heavily at Christmas, Americans took out their credit cards again in January, increasing their borrowing for the fifth straight month, the Government reported yesterday.
Consumer installment credit outstanding rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.5 percent, to $727.6 billion, the Federal Reserve said. That followed a 5.3 percent increase in December, the largest jump in two years. The December increase had previously been estimated at 4.1 percent. 
 The last decline in consumer borrowing came in August, which marked the seventh consecutive drop. The new level of credit outstanding is the largest since February 1992.
Economists expect consumers to continue to increase their spending this year, although perhaps at a somewhat slower pace than at the end of 1992.
Preliminary indications are that consumer spending faded a bit in February. Big retail chains said this week that bad weather in some parts of the country had depressed sales somewhat.
In January, revolving credit -- which includes credit cards -- soared at an annual rate of 9.4 percent, to $253.2 billion. That offset declines in auto loans and other kinds of consumer borrowing.
Auto loans fell at an annual rate of 2.5 percent, to $259.6 billion. But that followed an 11 percent increase in December. Other kinds of consumer loans fell at a 2.9 percent rate, to $214.8 billion.
The Fed's consumer credit report includes all household debt not secured by real estate. It does not include home-equity loans or mortgages.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Surges on Reduction By Germany of Interest Rate

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar surged in heavy trading yesterday, bolstered by a cut in a German interest rate and a large increase in American jobs last month.
Gold prices also advanced worldwide. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $329.80 a troy ounce, up 80 cents from Thursday. The Republic National Bank said gold added 85 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $329.60. 
 The dollar began climbing in European trading after the Bundesbank of Germany cut the money market rate. The move, which took the market by surprise because it came a day after the central bank's policy-making committee met and took no action, could pave the way for further easings.
Lower rates abroad make yields on American securities more attractive, thereby increasing investors' need for dollars.
The dollar was firm when trading shifted to domestic markets. But it began to soar after the Labor Department reported nonfarm payrolls swelled by 365,000 in February, about three times greater than the increase analysts had been expecting and an indication of American economic strength.
 
High for Year Against Mark
 The dollar surged about 3 pfennigs against the German mark to a high for the year and also rose sharply against the Swiss franc.
Its "overall strength spilled over and even allowed it to strengthen against the Japanese yen," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the investment advisory firm IDEA. The dollar has been losing ground steadily against the yen in recent weeks.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 116.47 yen, down 0.51 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, it rose to 117.75 yen. In New York it settled at 117.60 yen by 4 P.M., up from 116.75 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.4458, from $1.4540 late Thursday. In New York at 4 P.M. it cost $1.4470 to buy one pound, less expensive than Thursday's $1.4560.
Other dollar rates in New York at 4 P.M., compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6685 German marks, up from 1.6380; 1.5445 Swiss francs, up from 1.5195; 5.6580 French francs, up from 5.5590; 1,578.00 Italian lire, up from 1,563.00, and 1.2466 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2437.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6685 marks, up from 1.6340; 1.5465 Swiss francs, up from 1.5165.

HEADLINE: Savings Bonds: Lower Rates, but Still Safe

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
The surprise drop this week in the minimum rate on United States Savings Bonds to 4 percent from 6 percent caused immediate concern among many Americans who invest in these Federal securities through payroll deduction or direct purchase. Yet even with the lower rate, when the bonds are compared with other guaranteed investments, they remain an attractive option for investors.
The Treasury Department lowered the rate for both Series EE and Series HH bonds, effective last Monday. It said that this action was taken in response to the substantial decline in market rates over the last year or so. 
 "Buying savings bonds used to be a no-brainer as an alternative to cash," said Joel S. Isaacson, a partner in Clarfeld & Company, a New York accounting firm. "And even now, for a conservative investor, they are still not a bad investment."
Mr. Isaacson ticked off some of the advantages of savings bonds: the Government guarantee that principal will be repaid; the deferral of Federal income tax on the interest until a bond is redeemed; the ease of purchase at no cost, and the exemption from state and local income taxes.
The 4 percent minimum means bondholders will get no less, but they could very well get more. Every six months, the Government sets a market-based rate for the bonds equivalent to 85 percent of the average return on marketable five-year Treasuries. If that market-based rate is higher than the minimum, it will be paid to holders of savings bonds, as long as they have owned their bonds for at least five years. This market-based rate is now 5.04 percent.
The average yield for bank money-market accounts is 2.66 percent, while average C.D. yields range from 2.76 percent for three months to 5.25 percent for five years. The rate for a three-month Treasury bill is about 2.9 percent and for a five-year Treasury note around 5 percent.
Investors willing to assume more risk, however, can probably achieve higher returns by putting their money into securities that are not federally guaranteed. "Most people can do better than savings bonds," said Lewis J. Walker, an Atlanta financial planner. "A 4 percent return adjusted for taxes and inflation puts you in a negative position."

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Declining Rates" shows rates for U.S. Savings Bonds held five years or more, 1983-1993. (Source: Treasury Department)

HEADLINE: Dispute Over Insurance Imperils a Barnes Show

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
The opening of long-awaited exhibition of French paintings from the Barnes Collection in Merion, Pa., scheduled for early May at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, has been thrown into doubt after a Government lawyer said a Federal agency had acted unlawfully in approving Government insurance for the show.
David Fisher, a lawyer for the Federal Council on the Arts and the Humanities, notified the 14 council members last week that their approval in private of an application by the National Gallery for $300 million of insurance for the show had violated the Sunshine Act, which requires Federal agencies to conduct their business in public. 
 >The exhibition, called "Great French Paintings From the Barnes Foundation: Impressionist, Post-Impressionist and Early Modern," is scheduled to open May 2.
The council's action has also been criticized because it would offer Government insurance to a mainly domestic exhibition, and the Federal program for insuring art was intended to cover works of art coming from abroad.
 
Challenged in Congress
 The propriety of the council' action was questioned at a Congressional hearing Thursday on the budget for the National Gallery. Representative Sidney Yates, Democrat of Illinois, who conducted the hearing, said the action constituted "a major policy shift" and required further study.
The National Gallery had asked the council to approve Government insurance of the 81 works in the show in transit to Washington and while on view there. Eighty of them would come from the Barnes Collection; one painting would come from Paris.
This would be the first time the Arts and Indemnity Act of 1975, which was intended to facilitate international loans of artworks, would be used to insure a domestic one.
Jerry Martin, the acting chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, who is also a member of the Federal council, said on Wednesday that he had voted with the minority against extending coverage because "it is bad policy to make an exception for the National Gallery which is not available to others."
Another member of the council is J. Carter Brown, the former director of the National Gallery, who applied for coverage of the Barnes show before leaving office in September. Mr. Brown said he had been seeking "to correct an anomaly in the original legislation" in order to "expand one of the most broadly beneficial programs Congress has ever created." He added that the cost of the program to the Government was "virtually nil."
The Government's insurance of the Barnes show would save the National Gallery about $600,000 in insurance costs, Mr. Brown said.
 
A Product of Inflation
 The Indemnity Act was passed by Congress at time when art prices were soaring. As a consequence, insurance became so costly that international loan shows seemed no longer feasible for many institutions. There is no specific language in the act that excludes domestic shows from coverage.
Under the act, the Government buys no insurance, but covers art shows for a maximum of $300 million. Museums must still buy insurance to cover the value in excess of $300 million. The Barnes show is valued at more than $1 billion. Nevertheless, the Indemnity Act has been a boon to American museums in arranging loans from overseas.
Since 1975, about 175 shows have been insured by the Indemnity Act.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Escape From New York?

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK

 BODY:
It started when Gov. Mario Cuomo irresponsibly gave Staten Island the go-ahead to pursue secession. Then came similar rumblings from Queens, followed by a borough-based rebellion that toppled the Schools Chancellor. And now the Brooklyn Borough President is campaigning for more local control of government in what is either a power grab or a misguided attempt at reform.
There's a temptation to dismiss this latest wave of New York-bashing as a silly nuisance. In all likelihood, after all, the union will stand. But in what condition? Elected officials are making malicious mischief by encouraging the balkanization of a city that, for all its faults, works. Their threat to sound government distorts reality, ignores history and could do plenty of damage. 
 The Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, hints darkly that without a shift of power to the boroughs the city will secede from itself, and asks for a government commission. Stop secession, he says, by giving boroughs more control over services, development and spending.
Sounds reasonable. But wait. Borough presidents used to control local services more than 30 years ago. They lost that power when evidence of waste, inefficiency and corruption persuaded New Yorkers to strengthen the central government and weaken borough leaders.
Now champions of the boroughs want to return to the old days, arguing that the city government is out of touch, bloated and inefficient. The city bureaucracy clearly does need streamlining and could be more responsive to the public. But history suggests borough control would make matters worse, not better.
And why borough control anyway? It's a fallacy that Brooklyn defines Brooklynites. That romantic notion seems more appropriate to the days of Ebbets Field, and probably wasn't true then either. In today's increasingly diverse city, certainly, people identify themselves more by economic class, race and ethnicity than by geography. The Orthodox Jewish population of Borough Park (Brooklyn) has more in common with the Orthodox Jewish community of Riverdale (the Bronx) than with largely Italian Carroll Gardens (Brooklyn).
Moreover, how would the city ever build essential facilities if, as Mr. Golden suggests, borough halls wielded more control over capital projects? Any city needs jails, homeless shelters, incinerators, sewage plants. The City Council now has final say over siting such facilities. With 51 members from the five boroughs, it manages, however imperfectly, to balance need and fairness. What borough would unilaterally impose a sewage plant on itself?
The perception of lost power underlies the unhappiness of Mr. Golden and some of his colleagues. They pine for the days when they used their one vote on the now-defunct Board of Estimate as leverage. After the Supreme Court found the board's voting system unconstitutional because each borough had only one vote regardless of its population, a City Charter change eliminated the board. Its key powers went to the City Council, where each borough has representation based on population.
Brooklyn actually has more voting power today. Even Staten Island, which complains about having only three Council members, cannot deny a recent state report showing that the borough actually gets more back in city services than it provides in taxes. In fact, all the boroughs retain plenty of power. The Speaker of the Council is Peter Vallone, a Queens homeowner, not a Manhattan elitist; the revised Charter gave each borough president an appointment to the City Planning Commission; each still names a Board of Education member and appoints all community board members; each has a piece of the capital and expense budgets and significantly expanded planning departments.
To go further and create borough-wide fiefs makes no sense, especially since the city is still experimenting with its new form of government. It's been only two years since the Council expanded from 35 to 51 members and took full advantage of its new powers. Clearly that's too soon to judge how it's working, or to reconfigure government yet again.
The idea of secession is even more troubling. It risks a race and class war of dreadful dimensions. First overwhelmingly white Staten Island threatens to leave. Then what -- Howard Beach? Douglaston? Bay Ridge?
Maybe today nobody would invent a city of over seven million people, living in five boroughs that cover 320 square miles. But it has existed since 1898, and a centralized, representative government can take most of the credit. The flawed but awesome experiment that is New York City will always need reinventing. It does not need obliteration.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Drug Companies Finance Much of Medical Research in the U.S.

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Drug Companies' Profits Finance More Promotion Than Research" (front page, Feb. 21): As a clinician and scientist who worked with some dozen and a half pharmaceutical companies as board member, consultant, information source, clinical and basic researcher, I think readers are entitled to an alternate opinion from that presented by a professor of pharmacy administration, professors of pharmaceutical economics and the Food and Drug Administration commissioner. 
 Drug development goes through a series of steps; from phase I, when a product undergoes basic investigation, to phase IIIA, when it is applied to large clinical trials. Once a product enters the phase IIIA, IIIB region, a union between research and development and marketing occurs. In the final stage of drug development, the research and development and marketing departments may contribute funds from both their budgets to carry out clinical studies for approval.
The pharmaceutical industry is criticized for spending on "promotion." What is promotion? It involves sending young scientists and clinicians to national meetings to present research; giving textbooks to residents and medical students; subsidizing publication of national symposiums; funds for resident educational activities for medical schools; scholarship endowment for clinical investigators; subsidy of clinical journal publication, and distribution of drug samples to patients.
Most important, it involves paying for the vast majority of basic and clinical research in United States medical centers. This results in the training of graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, clinicians and clinical subspecialists, and the creation of a forum for the pharmaceutical industry to carry out its clinical studies.
This union between industry and the university has resulted in the development of one of the most competitive industries in the world, one that should be nurtured by the public and the Government, rather than restricted.
The pharmaceutical industry and physicians have not created this country's health care problems. Increased drug costs are the result of inflation, product liability litigation and an obstructive Food and Drug Administration. Increasing drug use can be traced to an aging population trying to maintain its health.
We would be well advised to deal with the difficult issues of finding funds for immunization, adequate prenatal care and wellness programs, rather than deluding ourselves that the pharmaceutical industry and medical profession are to blame for our health care problems.
 
RICHARD E. BLACKWELL, M.D.
Prof. of Obstetrics and Gynecology, University of Alabama
Birmingham, Ala., Feb. 22, 1993

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
H & R BLOCK TO OFFER CUSTOMERS A CREDIT CARD

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
H & R Block Inc., the country's largest preparer of individual tax returns, said yesterday that it was joining the growing list of businesses offering credit cards. A user of H & R Block's Mastercard would earn a $5 rebate on tax preparation services for every $500 charged on the card in a year. Applications for the card are being distributed this month at H & R Block offices in 14 states. 
 Block joins General Motors, A.T.& T., General Electric and others in the increasingly competitive business of credit cards designed to increase customer loyalty. The Block Valuecard, issued by Columbus Bank and Trust of Columbus, Ga., has a $9 annual fee and a 15.9 percent variable interest rate.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 24; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 901 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER

 BODY:
THE OVERWORKED AMERICAN: The Unexpected Decline of Leisure, by Juliet B. Schor. (Basic Books, $12.) If your job seems to take up too much time, it's probably not your imagination. The author, an economist, asserts that declines in both living standards and the power of unions have led to increased work hours, as has capitalism itself. "Her book is systematic enough to satisfy the scholar, yet it is witty and engaging for the lay reader," Robert Kuttner said in The Book Review last year.
AT WEDDINGS AND WAKES, by Alice McDermott. (Dell, $5.99.) Three children observe the mysteries and rituals of the adult world while their mother, in the company of her three sisters and her stepmother, learns to cope with marital disappointment and middle age. Last year our reviewer, Verlyn Klinkenborg, praised Alice McDermott as a writer who "has taught us to expect something extraordinary." In this, her third novel, "her sentences have been lengthened and elaborated, without becoming unduly sinuous, without losing their immediacy," he said. "They have a harmony all their own -- grave, decorous, moving." 
 A FULL SERVICE BANK: How BCCI Stole Billions Around the World, by James Ring Adams and Douglas Frantz. (Pocket Books, $10.) What can you say about a bank that had both Manuel Antonio Noriega and the terrorist Abu Nidal as its clients? Basically, that the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, in matters criminal, was as global as its name implied. "What distinguishes 'A Full Service Bank' from so many other books about outrageous scandals is its penetrating treatment of the underlying forces at play," Jeffrey E. Garten said here last year.
WILDERNESS TIPS, by Margaret Atwood. (Bantam, $6.99.) In her latest collection of short stories, Margaret Atwood shows how men and women often make fictions of their pasts in order to live more comfortably in the present. In 1991 our reviewer, James Wilcox, found the best of these 10 pieces "complex, beguiling stories," fiction that "conjures up a sense of the mysterious in even the most banal relationships."
WHITEOUT: Lost in Aspen, by Ted Conover. (Vintage, $11.) The author had a certain Faustian experience in Aspen, Colo., but still escaped with his soul. Living there first as a cabdriver, then as a reporter and finally as a sybarite, he was able to analyze how the resort town has become the capital of shallow chic. "Mr. Conover has done the near-impossible," Tim Sandlin said here in 1991. "He has created a book about Aspen that is fair and interesting at the same time."
A CASE OF CURIOSITIES, by Allen Kurzweil. (Ballantine, $10.) This novel invites the reader to experience the Enlightenment through one of its more humble geniuses, a watchmaker whose obsession with invention parallels the writer's own. Last year our reviewer, Malcolm Bradbury, found this a "brilliantly bookish book" that is also filled with "considerable wit."
THE EDWARDIAN TURN OF MIND, by Samuel Hynes. (Pimlico/Trafalgar Square, $22.95.) Britain's twilight of empire was a time of great social change, when the country was caught between the rigidity of the Victorian period and the progressiveness of emerging modernism. "There will be many more studies of the age," Michael Holroyd said in The Book Review in 1969. "But few of them are likely to be so well constructed and compulsively readable." Also out in paperback is Mr. Hynes's examination of the Edwardian period's aftermath, A WAR IMAGINED: The First World War and English Culture (Collier/Macmillan, $15), where he analyzes the war's effects on authors and artists. "He himself unravels the postwar dilemmas: how to interpret the war, whom to blame, where next to go," said our reviewer, Peter Vansittart, in 1991.
SARAH CANARY, by Karen Joy Fowler. (Zebra, $5.99.) The Pacific Northwest in the 1870's is the setting for a strange visitation by an apparent madwoman who irrevocably alters the fortunes of a Chinese immigrant and several other characters. "This is an extraordinarily strong first novel, the product of an unusually fertile imagination," Barbara Quick said here in 1991.
THE TRIUMPH OF PIERROT: The Commedia del l'Arte and the Modern Imagination, by Martin Green and John Swan. (Pennsylvania State University, $16.95.) The authors show that the informal, unscripted "low comedy" of the commedia dell'arte had wide-ranging influences on modern creative minds, from Charlie Chaplin to Samuel Beckett. While our reviewer, Walter Kendrick, found some of the book's conclusions too broad, it "may point the way toward rewriting the history of 20th-century art," he said in 1986.
SUGAR CAGE, by Connie May Fowler. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $10.) Mysticism and romance entwine the lives of several Florida families, white and black, from 1945 to the 1960's. Different characters take turns narrating this first novel, into which "Ms. Fowler has inventively worked the notion of 'sweet poison,' " Roy Hoffman said here last year.
HE, SHE AND IT, by Marge Piercy. (Fawcett Crest, $5.99.) Isaac Bashevis Singer meets "Terminator 2." In this novel, Marge Piercy draws parallels between the creation of a guardian golem for a Jewish ghetto in the 16th century and the invention of a powerful, protective cyborg in 2059. Although our reviewer, Malcolm Bosse, found the book flawed, it is "ambitious" and "confronts large issues," he said in 1991.

LENGTH: 1168 words

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Dog's Breakfast

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
Grown dogs don't eat breakfast. Oh, I give my Bernese Mountain dogs, James and Heidi, a hard cookie apiece to shut up their racket in the morning, but they know that one session a day wolfing down their kibble is their lot, which is called their "meal."
That is why I wondered at this figure of speech in a report by Michael Wines in The New York Times during last fall's campaign: "Aides repackaged a dog's breakfast of White House trade and fiscal policies into an 'agenda for American renewal.' " 
 "How did a repast not usually associated with our canine companions," asked Thomas Zekov of New York, "come to represent a repackaging of old ideas into a new program?" Added Mary Lou O'Brien of Brooklyn: "A dog's breakfast? I love it. Where does it come from?"
Since it came from Mike Wines down the hall, I asked him for an explanatory memo. He wrote: "A dog's breakfast is any kind of smorgasbord prepared, in haste or at random, from life's castoffs. In this case, it was the chicken bones and half-eaten pizzas of policies that the Administration had proposed earlier and Congress had rejected. . . . Cat people wouldn't understand, but anyone who has ever walked a dog down an alley would."
A Scottish terrier would say the phrase has a long pedigree. The slang lexicographer Eric Partridge cited Glasgow circa 1934 as its place and time of origin, though he noted that Australians also used the phrase with the same meaning as "confusion, mess, turmoil." (After a three-dog night, one so cold it required three dogs to keep you warm, a dog's breakfast could be quite a mess.)
About the same time, a dog's dinner appeared with a quite different sense. "Why have you got those roses in your hair?" asked a character in "Touch Wood," a 1934 novel by C. L. Anthony. "You look like the dog's dinner." This expression was defined by the Oxford English Dictionary Supplement as "dressed or arranged in an ostentatiously smart or flashy manner," probably derived from the 1871 usage "to put on the dog."
The early 30's, a time for many canine coinages, also saw the expression dog's bait appear in the Ozarks, with a meaning of "too much to eat," as in "Enough's enough, but too much is a dawg's bait."
While we're going to the dogs, here's a query from Alan Geller of Elmwood Park, N.J., who attached an article in The New York Times by John Darnton, writing from Sinj, Croatia: "Another town official . . . brought out a dog-eared diary."
Many a dog's ears do not stand up straight, but lap over. (Heidi, when especially alert to the prospect of leftovers from what she must call a master's breakfast, seems to perk up her ears, but they still lap over; German shepherds' ears are different.) The two words were first used together as a verb in the mid-17th century in a book of essays by Francis Osborne: "To ruffle, dogs-ear, and contaminate by base Language and spurious censures the choicest leaves."
When you turn down the corner of a page in a book, you dog's-ear it. "Lady Slattern Lounger," wrote Richard Brinsley Sheridan in his play "The Rivals" in 1775, ". . . had so soiled and dogs'-eared it, it wa'n't fit for a Christian to read." Thus, a book that has had many pages turned down is dog's-eared, or as it is more frequently written, dog-eared.
We have strayed. What alternatives are there to a dog's breakfast for the writer who wants to describe a mixed bag?
Farrago is a favorite of mine, a 1632 noun rooted in the Latin for "mixed fodder." Mishmash also does the hodgepodgian trick: it's a reduplication of the German mischen, "to mix," which some say was introduced into English via Yiddish (while others hold it was a reduplication of the English mash, but if that's true, how come it's pronounced mish-mosh?). The aforementioned hodge podge, also known as hotchpotch, comes from the French hocher, "to shake," and pot (similar to olio, from the Spanish olla podrida, "rotten pot"). Another term formed of rhyming syllables is ragbag, while another French-based word for "jumble, tangle, muddle" is gallimaufry, "hash."
Taken together, this synonymy amounts to a dog's breakfast.
 
FAT CHAUNCE
 TO GO DOGGIN', according to "Trash Cash, Fizzbos and Flatliners" by Sid Lerner and Gary S. Belkin, is teen-age slang for "to cheat on a partner." Thus the term derogates the fidelity of dogs, who can be more faithul than teen-age hookups.
A hookup, according to Washingtonian magazine, is no longer a radio network; now it means "a person with whom one is romantically involved." In its quick look at college slang, the magazine defines alter nateen as "teen-ager deeply into the counterculture," the verb chaunce as "to leave someone hanging," sick as "cool," nectar as "very cool" and wizard as "exceptionally sick."
Time for the Lexicographic Irregulars, Campus Division, to weigh in with reports on campus slang, the fastest-changing language in Babel's tower. If your prof is crunchy, don't feel schwag: send your local lexicon to Safire's Buzz-kill, The New York Times, 1627 Eye Street N.W., Washington, D.C. 20006.
 
N.M.I.
 THE CLASSIC CASE OF the Law of Unintended Consequences was the decision by the War Department in the early 1940's to require all personnel without middle names or initials to declare that inadequacy on documents. A corporal named Joe Sadsack would become Cpl. Joe N.M.I. Sadsack, the initials standing for "No Middle Initial" -- thereby defeating the intent of Joe's parents to avoid the letters between given name and surname.
We have come full circle: middle initials are regaining popularity, and whole middle names are in fashion, especially among women. A generation ago, some militant feminists refused to adopt the surname of their husbands; in time, a compromise was found in the use of both names, like Josephine Jones Sadsack, sometimes hyphenated in the British style, Josephine Jones-Sadsack.
Recently, the preference expressed by the First Lady to include her maiden name in her identification pushed this usage to the fore. Hillary Rodham Clinton is the name accepted by most publications on first reference, with "Mrs. Clinton" (rather than "Ms. Rodham Clinton") on subsequent references.
This is a good idea. A name is intended to supply information about a person, and the more background a name offers, the better. Names of males used to add "son" or, in Hebrew and Arabic, be preceded by "ben"; it helped put a person in the context of a family.
For example, as Louis Jay Herman of New York notes, the current fashion, if applied a few generations ago, would have asserted the relationships of a Presidential family: "If Eleanor Roosevelt were alive today, she would be known as Eleanor Roosevelt Roosevelt." (To be painstakingly accurate, her maiden name was Anna Eleanor Roosevelt; her married name was Anna Eleanor Roosevelt Roosevelt.)

SECTION: Section 2; Page 13; Column 4; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 894 words

HEADLINE: FILM VIEW;
Some Holes Don't Come From Bullets

BYLINE: By Caryn James

 BODY:
Michael Douglas's life in "Falling Down" is a critical mass of all-American problems. Divorced, unemployed, caught in traffic on a sweltering morning, he walks away from his car to face gang violence, vagrants begging for money, bad service at a fast-food joint.
These things could happen to any of us. But would any of us respond by: beating a Korean grocer, shooting a Latino street gang, stabbing a neo-Nazi, terrorizing a Whammyburger restaurant and using a rocket launcher to blow up a construction site? Even if we were having a really, really bad day? 
 There are movies that honestly hit a raw nerve and others that cynically push your buttons, and "Falling Down" is a push-your-buttons film. It may also be the last big Bush-era movie, custom-made for the rabidly conservative Rush Limbaugh crowd that sees social blight as proof that America is lost in a liberal wilderness.
The film catalogues urban disasters and goes out of its way to manufacture "controversy," yet it falls apart on the basic level of common sense. The Douglas character is depicted as both an ordinary Joe and Travis Bickle from "Taxi Driver." That idea is illogical -- you either have it in you to be Travis Bickle or you don't -- but it sells. Hollywood may have voted for Bill Clinton, but "Falling Down" masterfully exploits conservative sentiments.
With his ragged crew cut, short-sleeved white shirt plus pocket protector, and a license plate that reads "D-FENS," Mr. Douglas's character is not part of any cultural elite. The tough-minded performance encourages sympathy yet never asks viewers to like him. Joel Schumacher's vivid direction depicts the harsh reality of urban Los Angeles while letting the film slip into black humor with ease. It's too bad this savvy direction and acting bolster Ebbe Roe Smith's disingenuous script, which evades the fundamental question: Was the main character always crazy, or did society make him snap?
The anonymous D-FENS character starts out as a surrogate for the frustrated working and middle classes. When the Korean grocer mispronounces "five" as "figh," D-FENS shouts, "They don't have v's in China?" He expresses what a segment of the audience might guiltily think but wouldn't dare say. Soon he is threatening the shopkeeper with a baseball bat. The film doesn't ask viewers to condone his behavior, but it assumes they will sympathize with its source.
The character's response to crime and unemployment implies: "Don't blame me. I'm the victim." There is an audience for this opinion, which is the attitude Rush Limbaugh promotes on his radio show and in his best seller, "The Way Things Ought to Be." Just as Mr. Limbaugh's book suggests that the homeless bear some blame for their condition ("I hadn't done anything to cause his homelessness," he complains of a man living in a shelter), so D-FENS rails against a vagrant and snarls at him to get a job.
Like Mr. Limbaugh, the film is smart enough to use satire instead of logic to make political points. A man who asks D-FENS for money says, "I haven't eaten for days," though he happens to be holding a sandwich. When D-FENS shoots up the Whammyburger, he has reason to be annoyed; he wants breakfast and is three minutes too late.
If "Falling Down" were content to be an absurdist black comedy, this sleight-of-mind would make sense. But the film also pretends to be seriously provocative. When a neo-Nazi (played by Frederic Forrest) appears, the story takes a turn that leads to utter nonsense.
The deranged neo-Nazi has an arsenal behind his military-surplus store and sees D-FENS as a kindred spirit. "We are not the same," D-FENS says. "I'm an American. You're a sick . . . " Then he puts on a brown shirt and comes a step closer to becoming the neo-Nazi.
It turns out that D-FENS was probably one sick puppy long before any Whammyburger workers got on his nerves. His ex-wife has been so worried about his violent temper that she has gotten a restraining order against him. Home videos show him bullying his wife and daughter years before the pressures of urban life supposedly made him crack.
Yet the film depicts him as if he were some socially relevant missing link between the audience and the neo-Nazi. This is a master stroke of movie manipulation. Conservative viewers can identify with D-FENS as long as it is cathartic to do so; liberals can debate whether he is the cause or the symptom of social problems; and when he turns into a madman, the entire audience can distance itself. To wonder whether we are like D-Fens is simply to fall for a question as contrived as a high-school debate issue.
The film's duplicity is evident in smaller touches as well. The Douglas character is listed in the credits as "D-FENS." But the police learn his name, Bill Foster, and use it when questioning his mother. She is called Mrs. Foster; the credits coyly list her as "D-FENS's mother."
Even Charles Bronson's exploitative "Death Wish" movies are more honest. That series may be vile in its admiration for the vigilante Mr. Bronson plays, but at least it has the courage of its vileness. "Falling Down" wants its madman to be Everymadman, too. "I'm the bad guy?" he asks at the end, sincerely baffled (though no more than the audience). By then viewers might feel as jerked around by the movie as poor Bill Foster is by urban America.

HEADLINE: CRYING WOLF OVER ELEPHANTS

 BODY:
Thank God that "elephants are sexy" (as indicated in Ray Bonner's article "Crying Wolf Over Elephants," Feb. 7). 
 If elephants didn't have popular appeal, they would have to fall in line with the current political and economic principle of "sustainable utilization." Forgive us mere animal-loving types if we are not adept at sympathizing with sophisticated concepts like that.

HEADLINE: Going to School in Harlem -- To Live

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE gem of housing redevelopment in Central Harlem has gone on the market on St. Nicholas Avenue, bringing adults back to an elementary school transformed.
The school is the former P.S. 157, between 126th and 127th Streets. It served for more than 70 years and closed in 1975, gradually deteriorating thereafter amid failed attempts at redevelopment. But Elzee Construction of Flatbush took it in hand four years ago and has rebuilt it as rental apartments to standards befitting its status on the National Register of Historic Places. 
 Now its 73 units, with soaring arched windows and ceiling heights of 15 feet, are renting for $550 to $950 a month, or less for the handful of units reserved for low-income tenants. "The building is like an oasis, taking up the whole block," said Robert Molock, a salesman at Bloomingdale's who rented a one-bedroom on the fourth floor for $675 a month.
If P.S. 157 is an oasis, it is also one more example of housing production in Harlem, where rehabilitations of formerly vacant city-owned buildings into housing have been strong since the middle 80's. The money has come primarily from New York City itself.
The city has poured $600 million into gut rehabilitations and some new construction in East, West and Central Harlem over the last six years, according to Department of Housing Preservation and Development figures. Supplemented by about $200 million from private investment and state and Federal governments, the money has produced 10,200 units of new housing.
Harlem and the South Bronx have been the principal recipients of funds for housing under the 10-year, $5 billion housing program set in motion by former Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1986 and continued by Mayor David N. Dinkins. So far, $3 billion has been spent citywide. Although new buildings are involved, especially in the small-homes phase of the program, most of the new units are in gut rehabilitations of vacant buildings that were once in city ownership through tax foreclosure. Other rehabilitations are in former public buildings.
Central Harlem is the broad area north of Central Park to 155th Street, stretching from Fifth Avenue to Morningside Avenue. It had a generous share of tax-foreclosed properties, so a heavy investment in getting buildings back to productive use is hardly surprising.
In the Central Harlem area roughly $486 million has been spent for housing development or renewal. This has produced 6,660 units in the rental or homeownership form, for a spectrum of income levels. Part of the production has been new market-rate condominiums. Some are still on the market at prices between $85,000 and $235,000. There are also low-income rentals, low- to moderate-income rentals, moderate- to middle-income rentals, and mixed-income condominiums.
In all, a complex and diverse housing production program, carried on in the face of a drastic decline in the 80's in Federal housing programs that directly subsidize -- at a cost in New York City of about $8,000 a family per year in a long-term mortgage -- new housing construction for low-income people.
THE P.S. 157 reconstruction, the fulfilment of 12 years of development effort, is individually noteworthy among the about 600 properties touched by the renewal program in Harlem, and not for its architectural and historic characteristics alone. It is the first school in New York City to be converted to residential use with help from both the Federal tax credits for low-income housing and the tax credit for restoration of a historic property. Together they made it possible to raise $1.3 million in private equity for the development.
Its cornucopia of public and private financings also shows the scope of financing tools that must be used to get new housing priced in New York City at a level affordable to the market in which it is rented or sold.
The P.S. 157 project uses a $2.2 million housing development action grant from the Federal Government; a $2.8 million loan at 1 percent interest from New York City; an additional 1 percent loan of $896,000 from the city for asbestos removal alone and a $964,000 construction loan from the Community Preservation Corporation, the bank consortium that lends citywide for multifamily housing reconstruction in moderate-income neighborhoods.
It all adds up to $8.1 million for 73 apartments, or $111,000 an apartment.
That is about $50,000 an apartment more than the typical gut renovation, and the product is not coincidentally something special. Yet it might never have come about if Phillip Morrow didn't live in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn.
Mr. Morrow is the director of development of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, the state-financed subsidiary of the Urban Development Corporation that is closely involved in planning and development activity in Harlem. In some instances H.U.D.C. has itself been the developer of new housing.
In the middle 80's Mr. Morrow watched as two private developers tried and failed to raise the private financing needed to get the P.S. 157 project started. Even with the action grant and city-financed asbestos removal there was construction risk that lenders were not ready to bear.
In the late 80's, from his home on Cambridge Place, Mr. Morrow also watched admiringly as the city-financed gut rehabilitation of the old Mohawk Hotel into 84 apartments proceeded on Washington Avenue. Who was doing that excellent historic restoration, he wondered.
It turned out to be Leo Zisman,a contractor who runs Elzee Construction Inc., on Coney Island Avenue. Mr. Zisman came into the picture at P.S. 157 in 1988 when the project was about to lose its action grant for want of a developer capable of bringing in the private financing required.
Mr. Zisman had that capability, and also the capacity to execute the preservation-oriented architectural design from the firms of John Ellis & Associates and Hirsch/Danois Architects, both of Manhattan.
BOTH inside and out the reconstruction has respected features of the old school, which was built in the final years of the 19th century to a design by Charles B.J. Snyder, the city's school superintendent at the time. He designed more than 100 elementary and high schools, including Erasmus Hall High in Brooklyn, Morris High in the Bronx and Flushing High in Queens.
The New York Landmarks Conservancy, the private nonprofit organization that works to preserve distinguished properties in the city, described P.S. 157 in its submission to the Secretary of the Interior supporting its inclusion on the National Register as "a transitional and vernacular reworking of Chateauesque motifs with those of the slightly later Classical Revival."
Respectful to all things Chateauesque the building remains. Most of the 385 windows, 10 feet tall and weighing 80 pounds each, were removed window by window and taken to Norbert Morris, who runs the Morris Window Company in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. At $1,000 a window he restored the frames with a hand tool and replaced the old glass with thermally insulated glass. Special weights were installed so that residents would be able to lift the windows from the bottom.
Some windows had to be built new because they were excessively deteriorated or missing entirely. Jay Winston at Englander Millwork in the Belmont section of the Bronx did the construction, replicating the old windows -- and the old entrance and vestibule doors as well.
Then there was the copper cornice. S.&J. Tinsmith in the Bronx knew exactly how to replicate a missing 10-foot section. And Eddie Rubenchik, a Russian-born carpenter in Brooklyn, restored the large decoraive panels that adorn the walls near the elevators on the upper floors.
"He has hands of gold but I couldn't afford him so I used him only for the historic things," said Mr. Zisman.
From the roof and the edge of the roof 200-pound stones were delivered to Sal and Phil Stagliano at Utica Cast Stone Company in East Flatbush. They made casts for 65 new stones to replace others that were missing or damaged. The replacements are indistinguishable from the originals, says Mr. Ellis, the architect. At one point after the new stones were in place he trained his binoculars on a row of stones on the arches above the cornice and proclaimed the color of one stone unacceptable.
The contractor was sufficiently amused to recount the tale last week. The offending stone was an original.
Some of the most interesting aspects of the restoration are inside the building, where only the tenants will be able to appreciate them. The halls resemble classroom halls, though they are more warmly lit. Doors have been built at regular intervals even when there are no apartments behind them, the better to retain the look of a schoolhouse. Ornamental wrought-iron safety screens run along the fire stairs, and wood wainscotting lines the public halls.
"The double arched windows in the central part of the living room were the selling point for me," said one new tenant, Nancy Haseley, a 34-year-old landscape architect who moved out of a studio apartment in the Chelsea section of Manhattan into a $675-a-month one-bedroom a week ago. She was also struck by the speed of her commute to a job at 40th Street and the Avenue of the Americas. The D and A trains stop outside the door of P.S. 157. The D gets her to work in 14 minutes.
The development is about half rented. The income mix is 20 percent low income and 80 percent market rate, usually people in the $25,000-to-$35,000 income bracket.
DATA prepared by the Harlem Urban Development Corporation indicate that the average income of the general population in Central Harlem is rising. The 1980 census showed there were only 2,000 households in Central Harlem with incomes over $40,000 a year. The 1990 figures (unadjusted for inflation) show there were 16,900 households with incomes over that figure.
New arrivals to the condominium and higher-price rental housing are a key reason for this. The Harlem corporation alone developed 140 condominiums on three major sites and various scatttered brownstones in the 80's. There were also 2,000 new apartments under the Vacant Building Program, financed by the city and Community Preservation Corporation, for middle-income renters, with 1,500 more in construction.
The Harlem Development Corporation is now trying to market 21 condominiums, some of them with 1,600 square feet and the finishes associated with luxury housing, at prices of $110 to $150 a square foot.
"We are not sure they will all be sold," said Mr. Morrow, "but the true test is in front of us. The market seems to be pretty strong for large units."
As a middle-income rental, the P.S. 157 project is itself something of a test. It passed that test for Dr. Olivia Stokes, a consultant in education and family relations who is retired from the faculty of Lehman College of the City University of New York.
Dr. Stokes attended P.S. 89 in Harlem, as well as Junior High 119 and P.S. 136, before going on to Hunter College, City College and N.Y.U. Now she is back in P.S. 157, in a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment, in a move from a Mitchell-Lama co-op in the Bronx.
"The beauty of the building brought me here," she said.
