HEADLINE: The Economic Czar Behind the Economic Czars

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
Roaming the narrow halls of the White House in perpetually loosened ties and gray suits, Robert E. Rubin looks more like a graying college professor than the titan of Wall Street he once was or the power behind the throne that he is now.
As one of a handful of advisers who meet with the President every day, Mr. Rubin, the head of the National Economic Council, holds the keys to the issue Bill Clinton cares most about: fixing the economy. 
 And as the main conduit between the President and the expanded -- and potentially unwieldy -- economics team he has created, Mr. Rubin has become a sort of West Wing funnel to the President's ear on everything from trade to taxation to one of his own pet interests, urban policy.
His potentially tricky job puts him in charge of a new power center in the Executive Branch that was previously scattered among various Government agencies and within the office of the White House chief of staff. A primary challenge for the organism he created for the new President is to sidestep the temptation to trample over exclusive territory that normally belongs to Cabinet members and department heads.
 
Office Near Mrs. Clinton
 Balancing his slight weight on the rear legs of a straight-backed chair in his cluttered office on the second floor of the West Wing that shares a reception area with Hillary Rodham Clinton's office, Mr. Rubin, 54 years old, described the start-up period for the National Economic Council as a political and logistical challenge.
"We had to define it," he said in an interview. "We had to create its acceptance within the government process, and then we had to staff it, all at the same time that we were working on the economic plan.
"It has not been a relaxing period," he said in the understated manner that belies the reputation he built as the aggressive co-chairman of the Goldman, Sachs investment firm.
A multimillionaire with degrees from Harvard College and Yale Law School, Mr. Rubin supervises a staff of 28 economists, policy experts and support people. White House officials describe him as a broker among competing interests who brings private-sector instincts to Government work. Mr. Rubin said his main task was to distill the wide-ranging demands of the Administration's economic program into workable form.
 
Broker Among the Powers
 "Almost all issues have cross-agency ramifications," Mr. Rubin said. "So you have to have some mechanism for getting the views of the different agencies, or you wind up with the President making a decision based on the perspective of one agency and not knowing what six other agencies might think about it."
On paper, the new council is made up of the secretaries of the Treasury, Commerce and Labor Departments; Vice President Al Gore; Leon E. Panetta, the budget director; Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the Council of Economic Advisers, and a handful of deputies.
But Mr. Rubin is the first among equals -- the facilitator, in the words of Mr. Panetta.
"He doesn't have his ego injected into this thing," Mr. Panetta said. "He presents options to the players and gives the President the broadest scope of comment on issues so the President can ultimately make up his mind on what needs to be done."
 
Being 'Totally Neutral'
 For meetings with Mr. Clinton on issues from foreign trade to new taxes, Mr. Rubin prepares exhaustive memos outlining differing points of view. Recently, the council has been searching for deeper spending cuts to offset the new money the Administration wants to spend.
"You have to make sure that you are dealing with the President -- and with everybody else in the economic team and in the Administration -- in a totally neutral way," Mr. Rubin said. "That you express the pluses and the minuses, and then totally separate that from the expression of your opinion."
This approach carries its own weight. "The fact that he didn't weigh in made it more important when he did," one White House official said of Mr. Rubin's role in creating the economic plan.
In part because of his assumption of the broker's role, Mr. Rubin's own opinions remain something of a mystery. But as a fierce New York City booster who raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for the Clinton campaign and was instrumental in bringing the Democratic National Convention to Madison Square Garden last summer, he has not hesitated to put his stamp on Clinton policy by agitating on behalf of urban policy -- or community development, as the Clintonites call it -- within the White House.
 
Trade Policy and the Pentagon
 His handling of that subject, which in past Administrations remained strictly within the province of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, is an example of the council's interdisciplinary emphasis. Mr. Rubin has created a task force that is being run by Gene B. Sperling, a Clinton campaign adviser who is now Mr. Rubin's liaison to the White House political team, and Bruce Reed, a deputy to Carol H. Rasco, a domestic policy adviser.
Among the council's main tasks now is to coordinate trade policy with interagency groups that include representatives from several departments, including Commerce, State and the office of the trade representative.
Similarly, the council has brought economic and military officials into a task force overseeing efforts to find a peacetime role for unneeded parts of the military machine.
In these tasks, aides said, Mr. Rubin is the council's intellectual disciplinarian. Before the economic team's first meeting in Little Rock, Ark., he insisted on a rehearsal in which he threatened to cut off anyone who talked too long.
 
Seat on Security Council
 Aides said Mr. Clinton admired President George Bush's foreign policy team and hoped to focus on economic issues in much the way that Mr. Bush turned his sights abroad. Toward that end, Mr. Rubin has a place on the National Security Council, and Samuel R. Berger, the deputy national security adviser, sits on the economic council.
As the economic council takes shape, much of its actions are determined by the forces of the day. On the day stocks tumbled after word of Mr. Clinton's plan to propose new taxes got out, aides said Mr. Rubin threw up his hands when he was pressed to explain why it was happening.
Instead, he pointed nervous aides to the performance of the long-term bond market, which had remained stable. Later, Mr. Clinton and his advisers dutifully recited those indicators when asked about the stock market dip.
One adviser remembers a disagreement with Mr. Rubin about an element of the economic plan that he felt would be bad politics. After consulting with Roger Altman, a friend and the Deputy Treasury Secretary, Mr. Rubin confessed error.
"The so-called players in Washington would never have done that," the adviser said later.
 
A Softer, Subtler Darman
 Mr. Rubin is often compared -- favorably by Democrats -- to Richard G. Darman, the combative director of President Bush's budget office whose personality and intellect drove much of the Administration's economic policy and politics.
"The problem with the Darman model, the danger of it, was it was not an open process in representing views," said Mr. Darman's successor, Mr. Panetta. "It was basically an ego game between Darman and Treasury about who could replace who in fashioning policy."
Unlike Mr. Darman, Mr. Rubin leaves most of the public exposure on talk shows and in interviews to Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, Ms. Tyson and Mr. Panetta.
The new economic model, the officials said, has worked because of the personalities of its leaders. Mr. Rubin once served as Mr. Bentsen's personal financial adviser and is also close to his deputy, Mr. Altman, another former Wall Street consultant. He also consults regularly with Mr. Panetta and his deputy, Alice M. Rivlin.
When it works well, several of the President's economic advisers said, the new council will slice through the interagency rivalries that slow governing, insuring that Mr. Clinton's policies are carried out with clear orders from the top.
"The tugs, the natural forces will tend to cut the other way," said Mr. Rubin. "Each agency has its own perspectives. And the history of Washington is for things not to work together as well as they might."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We had to define it," Robert E. Rubin, head of the National Economic Council, said of the council's start-up. "We had to create its acceptance within the government process, and then we had to staff it, all at the same time that we were working on the economic plan." He stood in his West Wing office. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: As New Taxes Hover, the Rich Shrug

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
Jim Clayton, the owner of a Knoxville, Tenn., company that builds mobile homes, is one of the millionaires whose taxes would soar under President Clinton's economic recovery plan. His personal tax bill would probably increase to $3.5 million, from the $2.8 million he paid last year.
But he's not complaining. "The proposed tax increase is clearly livable," said Mr. Clayton, whose net worth was estimated by Forbes magazine at $370 million. 
 What does bother Mr. Clayton, and many other wealthy taxpayers, is the nagging worry that Congress will not be able to reduce spending, that the deficit will continue to grow and the economy worsen.
Polls show that a majority of Americans support the President's plan, but that 4 of every 10 people are concerned that it may turn out to be just another way to raise taxes.
 
Gloomy Expectations
 And a dozen affluent taxpayers who were interviewed last week said much the same thing. None objected to paying higher taxes as long as the Government used the money to reduce the Federal deficit or to stimulate the economy. But almost all of those interviewed said the plan did not go far enough in reducing Government spending -- and most predicted that the plan would fail because Congress would be incapable of cutting back on lawmakers' favorite programs and projects.
Accountants say that if the Clinton plan is enacted, and the top income-tax rates are raised to 36 percent and 40 percent, wealthy taxpayers would most likely respond by shifting investments from companies that pay high dividends to companies with more potential for long-term growth. They would do that to take advantage of the suddenly more attractive 28 percent tax rate on long-term capital gains, said Sol Upbin, a New York partner with Arthur Andersen & Company.
"There is nothing in Clinton's proposal that opens the door for people to chase the kind of nonproductive investments that were around before the 1986 tax act," Mr. Upbin said. But that could change, he added, if Congress is unable to resist the impulse to add tax shelters and loopholes for pet projects.
Most of the affluent taxpayers interviewed said they believe the Clinton plan is fair.
"I basically feel the President's plan is necessary," said Noel D. Ginsburg, 33, who owns a plastics factory in Denver and expects to pay $50,000 to $100,000 more in taxes if the tax plan is approved. "People in lower income-tax brackets will be willing to pay more taxes only if they realize that the people in the higher brackets are paying their share and don't have a lot of loopholes."
 
Forgoing a New Mercedes
 As a practical matter, the tax increases would have little effect on the lives of the richest taxpayers, whose numbers continued to swell in recent years despite the recession, said John J. DeMarco, senior vice president of PSI, a Tampa, Fla., marketing-research concern that monitors the behavior of wealthy consumers for financial institutions. "The new taxes would have virtually no impact on their life style," he said. "They'll keep the Mercedes an extra year, or something."
But some of the millionaires who may adopt more frugal habits because of higher taxes say it is the people they stop buying from who will really feel the pinch.
"I probably won't spend many thousands of dollars on designer dresses, and that is not good for designers," said Celia Lipton Farras, a Palm Beach, Fla., resident whose late husband, Victor W. Farras, made a fortune by inventing things like the paper milk carton.
Under Mr. Clinton's plan to increase personal income taxes by $126.3 billion over the next six years, the highest tax rate would increase to 36 percent, from 31 percent. This increase would affect 11 million of the nation's 111 million taxpayers, according to the Treasury Department.
 
Six-Figure Incomes
 Single people with more than $115,000 in taxable income and married people who file joint returns with more than $140,000 in income (or separate returns of more than $70,000 in income each) would pay an average of $60 more a month in income taxes.
A 10 percent surtax, which raises the top rate to nearly 40 percent, would also be levied on individuals with more than $250,000 in income or on married taxpayers filing separate returns with more than $125,000 in income. Those in the highest tax bracket would pay an average of $1,172 more a month, the Treasury Department says.
Some millionaires were cryptic about the tax increase. The comedian Bill Cosby, whose net worth exceeds $300 million, said only, "I am, therefore I pay."
Douglas A. Campbell, an investment banker in Santa Monica, Calif., said, "The bottom line is that the tax package is O.K., but there ought to have been a lot more cuts." Mr. Campbell also said that his earnings fluctuated wildly, from $60,000 to $1 million a year, and that he would probably respond to higher tax rates by working less. "I might go to law school in Mexico City," he added.

HEADLINE: For Gay People, a Time of Triumph and Fear

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ

 BODY:
After enduring weeks of vitriol in battles over homosexuals in the military, the St. Patrick's Day parade and school curriculums, gay and lesbian New Yorkers are taking stock -- many hurt and angry, others scared but defiant.
"It's terrifying that outright bigotry against us is acceptable public discourse," said Howard Cruise, 48, a cartoonist who lives in Jackson Heights, Queens. "People wouldn't dare talk about any other group, blacks or whatever, the way they talk about us." 
 For some homosexuals, the response is a boiling take-to-the-streets anger. For others, it is a visceral despair poured out to analysts and friends. Some are scared, others proud. A few are exhausted, burned out by a lifetime of fighting that began in adolescence with their own families.
Still, though the attacks are scathing -- homosexuals as predators lurking in showers, homosexuals as child molesters -- this is a triumphant time for many gay and lesbian New Yorkers. After years of being relegated to whispers, their issues are being aired. In conversations with some four dozen gay and lesbian New Yorkers, most believe that in the long run, the debate will work to their benefit. Few want to let up.
"There is no going back," said Carmen Altizar, 52, a lesbian and grandmother who lives in Corona, Queens. "This has to be resolved sooner or later. We might as well do it now. If we turn back, we're dead."
For decades, to be gay in New York City has been to be both blessed and troubled. Thousands of gay people, seeking their fortune and fleeing oppression elsewhere, pour each year into New York -- "the Emerald City," as one gay cable show used to call it. Thousands find the freedom to be open about who they are. Yet that freedom varies from job to job.
To be gay in New York means having the city's stamp of approval, in the form of anti-discrimination measures and now a law extending certain benefits to unmarried couples. Yet it also means the occasional slur shouted from a passing car, or worse. It means being a political and economic force. It also means overhearing a colleague's anti-gay joke.
"We think we're O.K. in New York, and I guess we are," said Scott Ballard, 33, a teacher who lives in Brooklyn Heights. "But I can't help feeling it's very fragile."
Indeed, over the past few weeks, every step forward for homosexuals -- support from a President, a Mayor and a Schools Chancellor who champion their cause -- has met with a step backward in the face of vehement opposition.
President Clinton postponed an Executive Order to lift a ban on homosexuals in the military. A Federal judge ruled that New York City's St. Patrick's Day parade organizers had a right to exclude a gay group that wants to march in the parade. The Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, softened his proposal for a curriculum that was to include lessons on tolerance toward homosexuals, a proposal that eventually helped cost him his job.
There has been some good news for New York's gay men and lesbians. Much to their surprise, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a conservative Republican, announced his support for allowing homosexuals in the military. The State Assembly, by an unexpectedly large margin of 90 to 50, passed a gay-rights bill Feb. 1. But its prospects in the State Senate are unclear.
 
Upset at Clinton, Fernandez
 Some homosexuals are upset at the strategies employed, especially by Mr. Clinton, who they believe caused antagonism by putting the issues of homosexuals in the military ahead of the economy, and Mr. Fernandez, who they believe should not have proposed beginning the new curriculum in the first grade. But the objections are only minor grumblings, lost amid the electric feeling that the battle has been joined.
"We're at a crossroads right now," said Jonathan Haymes, 43, a freelance editor. "It's either going to get a lot better, or it's going to get a lot worse."
Several psychiatrists say many of their gay patients, who are often anxious and depressed in the best of times, are coming to them with a focused anger that the psychiatrists fear will lead them to turn against themselves and the gay movement.
 
Taking to the Streets
 "I'm hearing it all the time, people coming in talking about it," said Richard Isay, whose Manhattan psychiatric practice is made up almost exclusively of gay New Yorkers. "We can't overestimate how the hatred and prejudice in society affects gay people generally."
On 35th Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens, the anger is taking a different form. The monthly meetings of Queens Gays and Lesbians United, which used to draw only a handful of people, now attracts between 50 and 100 gay men and lesbians. They are planning a march in Glendale on Saturday to protest what they say are distortions being made about gay people and their objectives. On Staten Island, a protest is planned against the borough's St. Patrick's Day parade today.
"What we're seeing is a stand-up-and-be-proud-of-myself response," said Ed Sederbaum, 47, co-chairman of the Queens group. "I grew up believing I was deficient, unworthy. I don't believe that anymore. Most gay people don't believe that anymore."
 
Collective Anxiety
 Once again, homosexuals are confronted with a familiar choice: Do they press to assert their rights, thereby risking backlash? Or do they quiet down, pulling back from confrontation? For many older New Yorkers, the choice for decades was to recede into the shadows. But in the age of AIDS, that has become intolerable for new generations of homosexuals.
"I think we've been well-served by an examination of our issues," said Gerard Ilaria, 31, who counsels AIDS patients. "The reason we've been oppressed is that people have been able to nail us in the closet. Now people are talking about us. It's out in the open. It only becomes more apparent what needs to be corrected."
Yet underlying that assertiveness is a collective anxiety.
"We really don't know where the country stands on us," said David Steward, 35, general manager of the magazine "Martha Stewart Living." "The vast number of people haven't voted yea or nay on us. I wonder if this is going to haunt us down the road, especially those of us who are out. I fear some sort of McCarthyish period where you go from being considered normal to being purged."
It is hard for gay men and lesbians to calculate how much fears like that are genuine and how much paranoid. In some sections of New York, men can walk arm in arm, women hand in hand, even kiss on a street corner. But in some of those same places -- near dance clubs in Manhattan, near restaurants in Park Slope, off Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights -- teen-agers prowl, looking to attack the nearest homosexual.
Yet it is not the fear of violence that has gay and lesbian New Yorkers troubled right now. Many say they are frustrated that their positions are being distorted, that their issues are not getting a fair hearing.
"I'm tired of people portraying us as wanting to steal their children, as being obsessed with sex, sex, sex," Mr. Sederbaum said. "The more light we throw on our issues, the less it's about the issues."

HEADLINE: How to Beat the Flood: Take the 7:42 Shuttle

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TACNA, Ariz., March 6

 BODY:
It's a strange sight here in the desert of southwestern Arizona: more than 70 bleary-eyed commuters waiting near cattle pens for the 7:42 across the Gila River. Unlike other commuter train stops all over the nation, this one offers not a single glimpse of briefcases, pinstriped suits or Wall Street Journals. And the ride is free.
The Southern Pacific Transportation Company is running Arizona's only rail commuter service: a six-mile, 18-minute emergency shuttle across the Gila, which began overflowing last month, a result of a spillover by a huge storm-swollen reservoir upstream. 
 In addition to inundating thousands of acres of farmland and scores of homes, the flood has wiped out 80 dirt-causeway crossings over the river and closed all nine roadway bridges that span it. But the railway bridge near this town has proved capable of withstanding the rising water.
So unless people here want to take a 120-mile detour or can hitch a helicopter ride, the train is the only way to get from Interstate 8, south of the river, to the north side and the flood-isolated town of Roll, in the Mohawk Valley.
If it were not for the commuter service, "I'd have to draw unemployment," said Stanley Clayton, a tractor driver who lives south of the river but works north of it. "I've been here 22 years. I've seen some wet river. But I've never seen anything like this."
The train provided by the Southern Pacific, normally a freight line, will not be mistaken for the Twentieth Century Limited. It has only four cars: two for passengers, two for supplies.
And the places where the passengers board and disembark are not exactly stations. The train runs from a feedlot near Tacna to a siding near Roll.
But the passengers seem to enjoy the ride, as well as the free coffee and fruit that the railroad provides.
Most of the passengers are dike-building crews for the Wellton-Mohawk Irrigation and Drainage District, along 50 miles of the river. But the ride is also open to National Guard troops, other emergency workers and people who have been driven from their homes.
"It wasn't really our intent to make a daily service for farmers," said David Wickersham, a district engineer for the railroad. "But they show up, and you can't say no."
Mr. Wickersham said the railroad was now trying to arrange to transport students from Roll to Antelope Union High School in the town of Wellton, south of the river.
The train costs about $2,500 a day to run. Mr. Wickersham said the railroad had not determined how it would recover that cost, which is certain to mount: the flooding is expected to last for another month or more.

HEADLINE: Israel Set to Use U.S. Loan Guarantees

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 6

 BODY:
For many months they held center stage in United States-Israeli relations, becoming a barometer of how the countries were getting along.
President George Bush withheld them from Israel to punish one Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, then handed them as a reward to a triumphant new leader, Yitzhak Rabin. 
 Now, with political squabbles set aside, Israel is about to go to market using the much-disputed American loan guarantees, which will make it easier for this country to borrow up to $10 billion over the next five years to help generate jobs for a large influx of new immigrants.
The first $1 billion in these American-backed loans are expected within a month, and Finance Minister Avraham Shohat says they will be used for telecommunications, power generation, roads and other infrastructure improvements.
While the United States is not putting up its own money -- only its assurance that it will cover bad debts should the Israelis default -- it will closely monitor how the borrowed cash is spent. Most of all, American officials say, they want to be sure that none of it winds up in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, as Washington believes was the case under Mr. Shamir two years ago with a smaller batch of American-guaranteed loans.
 
'Under a Microscope'
 Mr. Shohat has reportedly acknowledged to American Jewish leaders that Israel's spending habits "will be under a microscope" for quite a while.
Loan guarantees aside, questions have arisen about how much longer Israelis can count on the substantial amount of regular American aid -- $3 billion a year -- that their leaders have come to expect as their due. In recent weeks, they have heard fresh American warnings that while the aid looks safe for 1994, they had better not take it for granted in following years.
"The commitment of the American Government and people to Israel is not in question, now or in the future," William C. Harrop, the United States Ambassador to Israel, said on Thursday. "But it may prove difficult to maintain our economic aid at its current high level."
On Friday, the State Department distanced itself from Mr. Harrop's remarks, saying that "he was not speaking on instructions" from Washington. Nonetheless, the Ambassador merely echoed what the Israelis had already heard from others, including members of Congress.
The $3 billion a year amounts to 8 percent of Israel's Government budget and 5 percent of its gross national product, but Israelis disagree among themselves about how indispensable that total is.
 
Rabin to Meet Clinton
 Not vital at all, say some, conspicuously rightists who argue that the less that Israel depends on Washington's largesse, the less vulnerable it will be to American pressure to give up settlement activity and land in the territories. But that is not the view of the present Government, and when Mr. Rabin leaves next week for the United States and a first meeting with President Clinton, one of his priorities will be to nail down existing aid levels.
A few weeks ago, staging the equivalent of a pre-emptive strike to protect the assistance, the Prime Minister said Israel "is entitled, more than entitled" to the $3 billion it has been getting since the mid-1980's. Joining the refrain, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres said inflation had cut the value of the aid package by about one-third over the years.
Moreover, Israeli officials note that relatively little of this money ends up in Government coffers.
Of the total, $1.2 billion is considered economic aid, but it goes right back to Washington to repay old Israeli debts for military purchases. Of the $1.8 billion in military aid, more than 70 percent must be spent on United States-made equipment and weapons, and thus, the Israelis argue, it helps create American jobs.
Even so, some Israelis and their American Jewish supporters acknowledge that talk about Israel's entitlement may not sit well in Washington at a time when foreign aid is unpopular and other countries also demand American attention. Israel, the largest single recipient, accounts for 20 percent of the total foreign-aid budget, and even a supporter like Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, has warned against thinking "it will go on forever."
On a recent visit, Mr. Inouye proposed new forms of assistance, like an American-Israeli project to expand the port of Haifa so United States warships in the Mediterranean could berth there for maintenance and repairs.
 
Favorable Terms Given
 Questions about Israeli dependence on Washington also extend to the loan guarantees, which provide Israel favorable bank terms that it probably would not receive on its own: 30-year borrowing, low interest rates and no repayment of the principal for the first 10 years.
The terms are so good that Mr. Shohat recently asked the Israel Bonds organization, which had raised a record $1.2 billion worldwide last year, to scale back its own more costly borrowing by about 20 percent.
But the Israel Bonds president, Meir Rosenne, argues that unlike the case with the money he raises, "there are strings attached" to the American loan guarantees: In future installments, the United States could deduct spending in the territories that it considers unacceptable, and theoretically Mr. Clinton can scrap the guarantees entirely at any point, even out of dissatisfaction with Israel's economic performance.
While the new Administration is considered a friend here, somber possibilities were brought home when Ambassador Harrop observed that the pace of economic change "has been slow, in fact rather disappointing."

HEADLINE: Cuts Threaten Investigations Of Campaigns

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The watchdog commission that investigates political spending chicanery in New Jersey, often held up as a national model of campaign reform, says budget cuts and hiring freezes are making it an ineffective public guardian.
Last year, for example, its only state car was cut from the budget and its lone field auditor, Shreve Marshall, became office-bound, no longer able to crisscross the state conducting random audits on local campaign spending reports. 
 Even as the race for governor cranks up, the two floors occupied by the agency, the Election Law Enforcement Commission, at the top of a downtown bank building here are eerily still. Desks once occupied by auditors are empty and some offices have been converted to storage spaces where boxes stuffed with old campaign reports are stacked against bare walls, their contents largely unexamined.
"We're a thin man going into a famine," said Frederick M. Herrmann, executive director of the agency, which has the job of reviewing more than 20,000 campaign reports in this election year.
 
States and Public Both Give Less
 His complaint echoes across the nation as officials in many states like New Jersey that placed strict limits on campaign spending after the Watergate scandal two decades ago say recession-related cuts have damaged their ability to enforce the law.
"States are experiencing budget problems at the same time the public is cutting back on voluntary contributions to fund campaigns," said Ron Michaelson, executive director of the Illinois State Board of Elections. He said tax-return checkoffs in states that provide matching campaign funds for candidates were steadily declining, as was the similar checkoff on Federal income-tax returns for Presidential campaign spending.
In New Jersey, the Election Law Enforcement Commission has lost a third of its staff and 42 percent of its budget since the last gubernatorial race in 1989, Dr. Herrmann said. In the same period, he said, the commission's workload has shot up because of greater spending by candidates and special-interest groups.
The commission receives additional financing to oversee gubernatorial races, but it gets no such help for the other campaigns it regulates, from municipal, school and county elections to legislative races.
Mr. Marshall is now the agency's only auditor. The four others left and could not be replaced because of a state government hiring freeze.
 
Rise in Campaign Spending
 In the headquarters offices, a lone clerk tries to keep supplies moving. Two minimum-wage keypunch operators enter names from documents into an eight-year-old computer. Dr. Herrmann says it lacks the speed and functions needed to cross-index campaign reports and sort out the clouded layers of political contributions from individuals, corporations, lobbyists and political action committees.
The commission had a budget of $1.255 million and a staff of 34 in the last gubernatorial election year, Dr. Herrmann noted. Today the budget is $895,000 and the staff is down to 21.
Meanwhile, campaign spending has exploded, driven by inflation and the rising costs of advertising. In the 1989 gubernatorial election, the commission paid a total of $15.3 million in matching funds in the primary and general election races, nearly equal to the $17 million given to all candidates in the three previous gubernatorial years, Dr. Herrmann said.
Some 25 states have some form of public campaign financing provisions, said Mr. Michaelson, who collects national information for the Council on Governmental Ethics Laws, a professional group of those involved in campaign finance and lobby-law regulation. Illinois has campaign disclosure laws, but unlike New Jersey and Connecticut, it has no provisions for limiting campaign spending or contributions.
 
Training Cut in Connecticut
 In Connecticut, where the state Elections Enforcement Commission has experienced a 35 percent reduction in nonsalaried items since 1990 and a 10 percent staff cut this year, spending on training, education and publication has been virtually eliminated, said Jeffrey B. Garfield, the executive director and general counsel. These programs are necessary, he said, to inform thousands of campaign treasurers on compliance and reporting procedures.
"The cuts threaten to paralyze us," Mr. Garfield said. "If these campaign spending laws are to be of any meaning they have to be exempted from budget cuts inflicted on other agencies."
New York State has relatively lax controls on campaign spending. "The state is stuck in the mud back where the U.S. Government was before the Watergate scandals, an embarrassment and a disgrace," said John D. Feerick, dean of Fordham University School of Law, who was co-chairman of a commission on government ethics several years ago. The panel's recommendations on public campaign financing and spending limits went largely ignored, he said.
 
No Money With New Bill
 New York City, by comparison, introduced public financing of campaigns in the 1989 elections, and received high marks for a system that imposed a spending limit of $3.6 million for mayoral candidates in party primary races and another $3.6 million in the general election. That cap has been raised to $4 million in each election for candidates who accept public financing, said Nicole A. Gordon, executive director of the New York City Campaign Finance Board.
In New Jersey, Dr. Herrmann said the Legislature's recent passage of a new campaign-finance revision bill, which Gov. Jim Florio said he would sign on Monday, was in a practical sense meaningless because there was no accompanying appropriation for enforcement.
"We already are swamped by an increased workload and a reduction in staff," he said, explaining that since the 1974 law created the commission and the nation's first public financing of campaigns new legislation expanded its duties without additional financing. There was the Lobbying Act of 1981, the Personal Financial Disclosures Law of 1981, the P.A.C. Reporting Amendments of 1984 and a measure passed late last month that controls spending in legislative elections.
Under the guise of change, he added, the latest bill, which would apply to the November election, makes it harder to impose penalities for civil violations of campaign regulations. It states that an individual or organization had to "knowingly" violate the law, a criminal standard not previously applied to punish sloppy record-keeping or other civil transgressions.
The commission's chairman, Owen V. McNany 3d, took the unusual step of asking Mr. Florio to veto the bill.
The commission "cannot possibly administer or enforce" the measure, Mr. McNany told the Governor. "It would be a fraud on the public."

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
When Men Hit the Women They Love

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

 BODY:
"I WAS a real basehead," said Juan Rios, 27. "Then I got off drugs, I started doing good. I got myself a nice girl." That was Eve. They'd grown up friends in the Chelsea part of Manhattan. Their mothers played dominos together. For some reason, three years ago, Eve decided to call Juan's beeper. They started hanging out, then dating.
"I'm like wow -- do you see what I see happening to us?" said Eve. "He said, 'It's definitely not like before.' " 
 They liked the same music -- rap, reggae, house. "Out of all the clubs in Manhattan," said Juan, "We went to all of them. You know what it is? Eve can dance."
"People would see us laugh," says Eve, 31. "They'd say, 'Are you guys friends or are you together?' "
If Juan felt tempted by drugs, he'd call Eve. "I'd be cooking, doing seven things, I'd say, 'Juan stay on the line.' We'd talk for three hours. He'd say, 'I'll come over, we'll go dancing.' "
Two years ago they moved into a nice apartment on Staten Island. He's an art director on film projects. She's a credit manager. Then she lost her job because of the economy. He was getting less work. He'd grown up in a traditional Puerto Rican home. "I thought I was supposed to take care of everything," he says. "Her unemployment ran out, we had a baby on the way, I was frustrated. Christmas was coming, I didn't have money."
They argued constantly. They can't even remember about what. "I woke up," says Juan, "I had an attitude and then she had an attitude."
"He'd swing at me and I'd be so scared," she says. "He'd smack me with an open hand in the face, a full swing. I never been hit by a man. This went on one month, two months, three." A December day was worst. "It went on 15 minutes, and he hit me, and he hit me, and he hit me. And he had our son in his arms when he was hitting." She phoned her sister, who called the police.
The police walked in and Juan was sitting at the kitchen table with baby Jason in his lap. "They seen me, they saw her black eye, they said they had to arrest me," says Juan. "My son was screaming. He was only a month but he knew something was wrong. I was having a flashback to my father beating my mother. He's changed, but he used to come home and she'd have dinner and he'd smash it on the floor and she'd have to make it again to keep peace. Once my father hit my mother and I ran across the room to stop it. He picked me up and threw me against the refrigerator and I passed out. I thought if I don't stop, the same will happen to Jason. He'll beat girls, too."
Eve put on sunglasses and went to talk to a social worker with Victim Services about therapy for battered women. Eve told the woman, "Out of all this, I do still love him. I am still madly in love with him. I don't know." She did not press charges, but moved in with her family.
Juan hated the empty apartment. "He tells me, 'It's torture being here without you and the baby,' " says Eve. "He says, 'What do you think, I don't love you? I love you. I have a problem.' He was crying. I was crying. When you read between the lines he wanted a second chance."
Juan joined a program for abusive men. They watched movies. He listened to the group leader talk about exiting the highway of domestic violence before you murder your spouse.
On Feb. 23 they had a big one. "I don't even know what it was about," says Eve. "I was having my menstrual." She thought: "This is the test, he's going to hit me, but God, I'm going to say what I feel. Usually he'd shout, 'Shut the hell up.' I'm female, but I have to say my part, too. I said it and walked away. Instead of hitting, he just left. He was gone for three hours."
"I knew if I stayed I'd do something," Juan said. "I was just driving around thinking. I had that feeling in my chest to get high."
"He came home and didn't speak," says Eve. "He went to bed. I said, 'Wow, he's trying.' I went in the room. I said, 'My God, how could a person who sleeps so sweetly have such a bad temper?' I kissed him. He woke up. I said, 'Thank you so much for what you did.' He's changing and I seen it."
For a decade, John Aponte, a former police psychologist, has run a program for abusive men for Victim Services, the nation's largest domestic violence agency. Most of the men are required to take it by the courts in exchange for having charges dropped. Mr. Aponte makes no grandiose claims. Once he tried a follow-up study of 100 batterers. Half had disappeared. Of the 50 he found, 23 had the same partner. Only 15 would be interviewed. Two said the violence was the same; one said worse; 12 said the 16-week course had helped. Last week he talked about not overloading your spouse's anger bank. Juan's homework for Tuesday is to define the difference between an emotion and a thought.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Battered City Gets Visitor: Baseball

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla., March 6

 BODY:
The bruising gales of Hurricane Andrew stopped battering south Florida last Aug. 24. But the tremendous chunks the storm ripped out of properties and lives are still apparent in the Dade County communities south of Miami.
Evidence of the severe damage still lingers in cities like Homestead, where there are huge piles of debris and pitted buildings. Farms that produce winter crops for the entire nation will not be able to grow limes, avocados and mangoes for at least three more years, as farmers replant the thousands of trees that blew away. 
 Many of the 65,000 employees temporarily thrown out of work in Dade County are still at loose ends, as are the 5,000 to 6,000 people who were uprooted like so many acacia trees. And the impact of the loss of $2.9 billion in goods and services over the next year is now being felt by a local economy already ravaged by the bankruptcies of the Eastern and Pan American airlines.
So how is it that a game can capture this area's rapt attention and provide a wisp of good fortune for a city of 26,000 used to nothing but ill winds since Andrew?
The game is baseball. And it is bound to leave a signature mark on Homestead this weekend, showing how a sport can rival government in intertwining with a community for better or worse.
The Cleveland Indians came to Homestead to play two games against the Florida Marlins -- today and Sunday -- with the proceeds to go to hurricane-relief efforts. Sponsorships, ticket sales and program sales are expected to raise $250,000. The major leaguers are playing at the 6,000-seat Homestead Sports Complex, their very presence a vivid reminder of how fate keeps intervening in Homestead's fortunes.
The Indians -- who lost, 9-3, to the Marlins today while making six errors -- were scheduled to move their spring-training headquarters to the new $22 million sports complex this spring. But Andrew blew through, taking the stadium's roof and much of its upper deck with it. The complex has since been repaired, at the cost of $7.5 million. But the Indians have moved to Winter Haven for the time being, and the restoration in Homestead has not guaranteed that the Cleveland club will move here next spring.
Homestead originally built the complex in the hope that a major league team would move its spring-training operations here, and that tourists would follow. Cleveland bit. After more than four decades in Arizona, the Indians were looking to move to Florida and they signed a deal with Homestead.
But the contract was not an ironclad one; at this point, Cleveland's commitment to Homestead consists of nothing more than single option years for 1994 and 1995, followed by two 10-year options.
 
Park Not the Only Issue
 "We're clearly sensitive to the situation here," said Dennis Lehman, an Indians vice president, who said the team might still end up in Homestead. "The city has made tremendous progress, but I don't think it's our right to press them any more than we have."
For the Indians, the issue is not just the state of the ball park, but the overall condition of the community, and whether it could support a spring-training team at this point.
What would it take to bring the Indians here? "If we're satisfied with what happens, if the baseball people are satisfied, then we'll be back," Lehman said. "We just don't want to make any judgments right now."
 
A Jewel Amid the Destruction
 The ball park, reflecting the colors of Florida, with its coral walls and teal seats, was festive and full today. But as the fans -- most of them wearing Marlins colors -- looked out over the grass field, they could not help seeing beyond the complex to wooded areas torn up by the storm.
Though the Indians have not yet said they won't return, J. W. DeMilly 3d, the mayor of Homestead, fears the worst. He knows that Winter Haven, located in central Florida and formerly the springtime home of the Boston Red Sox, is now trying to convince the Indians to remain there.
"I'm angry with Winter Haven," DeMilly said. "The whole country came to our aid, but because of our misfortune, Winter Haven is making an effort to capitalize. That disappoints me. This could be an incredible blow. And we don't see that there is any reason why this community should be subjected to any more kicks in the shin."
A decision by Cleveland to stay in Winter Haven would indeed be a rejection of immense proportions here. Yet it is hard for all the residents of Homestead, or Florida, to look at baseball as a totally fickle friend. After all, an expansion franchise -- the Marlins -- was awarded to Miami. And within days of the hurricane, major league baseball owners voted to donate $1 million to the area's hurricane-relief efforts.
In addition, youngsters in Homestead will play their varsity, intramural and summer-league games on fields and sandlots reconstructed with $100,000 in grants given to the city by Coca-Cola, major league baseball and the Marlins.
"They answered our calls immediately," said Bob Richardson, a teacher at Centennial Middle School in Homestead, who personally contacted Leonard S. Coleman, executive director of market development for major league baseball, to request help for the area's playing fields.
"I cannot say enough about Len and major league baseball," Richardson said. "When phone lines were mangled, when there was hardly any way to keep the communications going, they persevered. Now, where there were no fields, four are back and functioning."
By Richardson's estimates, the restored fields have already been used by 250-300 varsity players for about three weeks. Countless other children, whether in physical-education classes or summer leagues, will also benefit.
"These are the things that help restore a sense of order in lives that have all but lost that sense," Richardson said. "For our kids, baseball was the first thing they could go back to, the first thing they could touch with their hands that was normal."
 
A Warning by Cisneros
 Normality to most Homestead residents is still a strange, far-off concept.
Two weeks ago, Henry Cisneros, the United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, warned that the area, with its large immigrant populations from Haiti, Mexico and Central America as well as white and black Americans dependent on blue-collar and agricultural industries, could degenerate into "a vast tangle of poor communities, uncoordinated and haphazardly constructed."
On Friday, Cisneros again declared the south Florida region to be greatly troubled and informed reporters in a telephone interview that he had made a series of recommendations to President Clinton to help solve those problems. Cisneros said his report conveyed "a picture of the job ahead and its massiveness, in fairly graphic language so that he could understand the immensity of the problem."
 
Evidence on the Roadsides
 Like any visitor to the region, Cisneros could not have helped but notice the still-exisiting crisis. Many parts of Homestead's residential areas resemble small independent dump sites, as the valuable accumulations of people's lifes -- washers and dryers, refrigerators, pickup trucks -- collect dust at the sides of the roads.
Graffiti spray-painted on houses as well as boarded-up businesses telegraph the stress that remains. One building's ominous message says, "OCCUPIED & ARMED -- PLEASE." But signs of hope are also appearing, signs that say, "Food -- Open In Rear," "Hang In" and "God Bless."
That an indomitable spirit is loose here is also evidenced in the small army of trucks and vans loaded with construction equipment that invade the area each day. And by the nails that litter almost every parking lot and street, the roofs stockpiled with tile and the sounds of heavy machinery either demolishing the old or building the new.
But for all the activity, there still are major and obvious struggles that have yet to be addressed completely. According to DeMilly, 15-20 percent of Homestead's families have relocated, temporarily or permanently.
In addition, 80-90 percent of this town's businesses were adversely affected by the storm, with 30 percent totally destroyed. For too many, trying to do business while ensconced in tents or trailers in the shadows of gutted or caved-in strip malls is a definition of stress itself.
"There are a lot of places going down, a lot of places being rebuilt," said Rebecca See, who cuts hair at the new locale for Woody's Barber Shop -- a trailer in the parking lot of a deserted outdoor mall on U.S. 1. "We don't know when things are going to reopen," she said.
 
The Base Outside Baseball
 Obviously, that is still too common a complaint, one that could apply not only to landlords, but to baseball, businesses and governments as well.
To this day, no one knows what will be the fate of Homestead Air Force base. The base was the area's largest single employer, pumping $450 million a year into the local economy. The 3,300-acre facility, where 8,400 civilian and military personnel worked, was effectively destroyed when Andrew chewed up more than 1,000 buildings on sight or linked to its operation.
The Federal Government estimated it would cost $480 million to reopen it as an Air Force facilty, and last year the Senate rejected President Bush's request to do so. Only on Friday did the Pentagon agree to release $76 million for partial reconstruction in order to allow the U.S. Customs Service, the Drug Enforcement Administration and Air Force reserve units to use the facility.
But today it was learned that the Clinton Administration has put Homestead on a list of 30 major military installations that are to be either closed or scaled back.
Meanwhile, Homestead is clawing away at the Florida Legislature for an estimated $600 million in state sales tax excesses generated by the sales of desks, cars, clothing and everything else needed by people to restock and rebuild this area. This is the sort of fight De Milly admits rips at his soul.
"I'm angry that what we are being asked to do is go back and renegotiate so many things that we thought were secure," DeMilly said. "And I'm not limiting that to the Cleveland Indians. We have to spend so much time revisiting these subjects, so much energy watching our backs."
It's an anger that two baseball games will do little to permanently diminish. But even the little respites are welcome in a town where Andrew left a large gash in a region's psyche.
"If I could ask one thing of people out there, I guess it would be to be patient," DeMilly said. "We don't want handouts, just the kind of love that was displayed right after Andrew. The needs here still exist and they will for some time to come."

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Looking for a Good Player? The Padres Will Give Him to You Wholesale

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YUMA, Ariz., March 6

 BODY:
Most general managers spend the spring scouring rosters for players who could add to the talent on their teams. San Diego's Joe McIlvaine has spent his spring seeking ways of subtracting money from the payroll of his team. Yet McIlvaine remains determined to overcome the built-in economic problems buffeting the Padres.
"There are a lot of things here I can't control," McIlvaine said, "but come hell or high water, we're going to put a good team out there." 
 High water has come to the Padres; the flooding Gila River has rampaged through Yuma County in Arizona for the last week. Hell could be next the way the Padres are operating.
By order of the ownership, McIlvaine traded Craig Lefferts last season and Tony Fernandez and Mike Maddux in the off season and let Randy Myers and Benito Santiago go as free agents. Now he is faced with trading Bruce Hurst and Darrin Jackson to reduce the payroll to the ownership-stipulated level.
"You don't trade a player July 31 when you're in a pennant race, but we had to do that with Lefferts," McIlvaine said. "We're just on the cutting edge of what's happening in baseball. By next year, there will be others doing the same thing. There are now; they're just hiding it better."
 
The Mariners, Too
 The Seattle Mariners are not hiding it. Woody Woodward, their general manager, is playing McIlvaine's game, looking for ways to reduce his payroll. Their circumstances are not comparable, though.
The Mariners had a 1992 payroll of $25 million and currently stand at slightly more than $34 million. The owners want to reduce that to $32 million. The Padres had a $28 million payroll at the end of last season, total about $25.5 million now and look to drop to $21 million. To put the Padres' plight in perspective, if they had retained all of their players, they would have had a payroll totaling around $36 million, meaning their reduction is $15 million, not $7 million.
McIlvaine became the Padres' general manager in October 1990 after 10 years with the Mets.
"Before I took the job, I asked two questions," McIlvaine said, sitting in the bright sun and watching his players take batting practice. "Are you interested in winning here and are you willing to provide the funds necessary to produce a winner? Of course, the answers were affirmative. The first year that was the case. Since then, we've had to change and now we have to adjust to it."
McIlvaine tried to trade Jackson, his $2.1 million center fielder, to Boston, but the Red Sox wanted to sign the player to a multiyear contract before completing the trade and were unable to do that. The general manager has also talked with Detroit.
 
Feel Better? Good, You're Gone
 Hurst, a $3 million pitcher, would be the Padres' No. 1 starter if he were completely recovered from shoulder surgery. But as soon as he shows he is recovered -- he probably won't be able to work in a game for another week or so -- Hurst will very likely be on his way elsewhere.
Dick Freeman, the Padres' president, who was speaking for Tom Werner, the team's managing partner, said that $21 million isn't necessarily a magic number.
"We've said low 20's," Freeman said. "But we won't get down to it if it means not getting fair value for a player. We wouldn't trade him in that case. If it means we're $1 million over, it's O.K."
Ownership didn't seem to be even that flexible last October when McIlvaine was directed to trade Fernandez because the Padres didn't plan to exercise the $2.3 million option in his contract. The club had to act on the option within 48 hours after the World Series and wanted the star shortstop gone by then.
"That's been my biggest bone of contention with ownership, that I had to make that deal then," McIlvaine said. "I begged them to let me take him to the winter meetings, but they wouldn't take the risk. They were afraid because last year they wanted me to trade Santiago and I couldn't. No one wanted him. You see Florida signed him. None of the established teams wanted him."
McIlvaine traded Fernandez to the Mets, getting Wally Whitehurt, D.J. Dozier and Raul Casanova for him.
 
Wait a Minute, Says Piniella
 Most teams would like to make a trade like that with the Mariners for Randy Johnson, their No. 1 pitcher, who with his $2,625,000 salary instantly became the No. 1 trade possibility when the club's payroll problem was disclosed. But not so fast, the Mariners have said.
"I told Woody we have the makings of a good pitching rotation," Lou Piniella, Seattle's manager, said. "I have Johnson penciled in as my opening-day pitcher. It would be tough to trade a front-line pitcher. We're going to look at it and see where it would least hurt us."
Asked if he would trade a significant player, Woodward said: "I don't know yet. If we do, we'll have to get a good return. We're not giving anybody away. I've got ways I can get down without giving away players."
Like Freeman with the Padres, John Ellis, the Mariners' chief executive officer, indicated that the budget number has some flexibility. "I haven't drawn a line," Ellis said. "That would be a big mistake."
He further said he wouldn't tell the general manager what to do with the team's players.
"The management of the team is up to Woody," Ellis said. "He knows we're trying to operate within this budget area, but specifics are up to him. What we've tried to do is come up with a number that is reasonable. Clearly, it will mean a loss, but it will be a way of fulfilling a commitment to the county to have a winning team."
 
The Misgivings Mount
 When teams set out to reduce payrolls, other people wonder if they really are committed to winning. One is Donald Fehr, head of the players' union.
"It depends on how they do it," he said. "If they get down by trading, that's one thing. If they do it by releasing players, that's another. You can't make any judgments on it until after the season starts."
There is a growing perception among fans in San Diego that the Padres have placed economics first and winning a distant second.
"There are those who have been critical of us, who feel we're not committed to winning," Freeman said. "But there are others who understand the situation and are supportive."
Two of the Padres' remaining stars have mixed feelings about the situation.
"It's frustrating, because I felt we were pretty close last year," Tony Gwynn said. "If we could have kept our team intact, I think we would have been right in the thick of it. I could be negative about what has happened, but that wouldn't do any good. I'm not happy with the way things have gone the last few years, but I can understand it."
Fred McGriff echoed Gwynn, saying: "Last year we felt we were close to being able to play with the Braves. When they make all those changes, it's different. But I can't worry about the changes. It could affect my play on the field. I have to keep a positive attitude."
McGriff, however, said that the Padres' direction could influence his decision to stay or leave when his contract expires in two or three years, depending on the team's decision on his option year.
"I want to play on a winner," the first baseman said. "My goal is to get to the World Series. I don't care how I get there."
Gwynn, on the other hand, said he would be prepared to remain after his contract expires in three years.
"This is where I want to be," the right fielder said. "I'd much rather be a part of something here. I don't know what's going to happen three years down the road, but I'm going to try not to let money be a factor."
 
The Looooouuuu! Is From Valle
 Dave Valle, the Mariners' catcher, is 32 years old and has been a major leaguer for seven years. But this spring he has been taken back to his youth. Lou Piniella, his new manager, has done that.
"Of course, I remember the things he did," Valle said, recalling Piniella the player. "I was a big Yankee fan."
Valle was a junior at Holy Cross High School in Flushing, Queens, when the Yankees won the first of three consecutive pennants in 1976. Piniella, of course, was an integral member of those teams.
"He was always the guy who came up and got the big hit when they needed it," Valle said, smiling appreciatively at the recollection. "He always reminded me of a guy who played hard, kind of like a blue-collar player, diving for balls, running into walls. He was a great hitter."
Valle remains enthralled with Yankees history. "Every time I go to Yankee Stadium, I walk out to the monuments," he said. "I remember the dream of an 11-year-old kid. Joe DiMaggio was my favorite player, but I never saw him play. I've read everything there is about him."
 
Scioscia Is a Witness
 Mike Scioscia, the Los Angeles Dodgers' catcher for a dozen years, left the team when it was down, but he said, "I don't think they're as far away as people think they are." He acknowledged, though, that the Dodgers' defense will have to improve drastically for the team to improve.
"You're not going to win too many games playing that kind of defense," said Scioscia, who moved south to San Diego because he wasn't ready to serve as a backup to a young catcher. "You couldn't get a better pitching staff than we had, but the defense hurt it."
In 1992, the Dodgers committed 174 errors, an average of more than one a game and 43 more than the National League's next most porous defense, Philadelphia's. Shortstop Jose Offerman made the most errors of any National League fielder, 42. In all at short, the Dodgers committed 52 errors, the most in the league, and they also led the league with 32 errors at second base.
The Dodgers' third basemen combined for 22 errors, but that total was one less than Matt Williams made for San Francisco. Scioscia himself made nine errors, third most among catchers.
 
Old Tricks for Steinbrenner
 George Steinbrenner didn't take long to remember how to obfuscate. On his third day back as an active owner, he held a 20-minute meeting with Dick Williams at a Phoenix hotel. Asked afterward what the meeting was about, Steinbrenner said it had nothing to do with a job, that he and the long-time major league manager were old friends and they were talking baseball.
"He lives around here," the Yankees' principal owner said.
Williams, however, lives in Las Vegas, Nev. He said he was in the area visiting spring-training camps, accompanying winners of a contest sponsored by the Major League Baseball Players Alumni. He acknowledged that he had spoken with Steinbrenner about a job, but none apparently is available.

HEADLINE: Reading Reagan's Favorite Arabic Sage

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Ronald Reagan ends his Feb. 18 Op-Ed article with a quotation from the 14th-century Arab historian Ibn Khaldun, implying that Ibn Khaldun was advising that tax rates should be kept low. When President Reagan first misused Ibn Khaldun in 1981, an alert reader, Manfred Halpern, pointed out in a letter you published Oct. 11, 1981, that Ibn Khaldun was merely observing his contemporary reality. 
 Ibn Khaldun was not being prescriptive at all, but as the great social scientist he was, he was concerned not with preserving the riches of the rich, but, as Mr. Halpern pointed out, with encouraging the government to care for the poor.
This is, I fear, another instance of President Reagan's loving the anecdote more than the truth. It is a pity to see his misunderstanding appear again, uncorrected, so many years later.
 
DANIEL C. SNELL
Prof. of History, U. of Oklahoma
Norman, Okla., Feb. 19, 1993

HEADLINE: Reading Reagan's Favorite Arabic Sage

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Ronald Reagan, in "There They Go Again," his Feb. 18 Op-Ed response to President Clinton's economic proposal, quotes the Arab historian Ibn Khaldun. When Ibn Khaldun wrote the words (from his study of history, "The Muqaddimah") that the former President cites, he was on the periphery of government, attempting to regain an official position. 
 Ibn Khaldun's statement "At the beginning of the empire, the tax rates were low and the revenues were high. At the end of the empire, the tax rates were high and the revenues were low" leaves out an important part of Islamic economic growth.
Revenues were high at the beginning of the empire because the Arab expansion brought in enormous wealth from the civilizations they were conquering. When the conquests subsided, so did the revenues from taxation. The possible base for taxation had dwindled, and the assessments had to be increased. Also contributing to the decline in revenue was the tax break given to Muslims, that is, those who gained large revenues from the booty of conquest.
The same logic applies today. If tax breaks are given to those who gained the booty, the only way to increase revenue is to increase taxes on those possessing less. If we continue with Mr. Reagan's source, "eventually the taxes will weigh heavily on the subjects and overburden them."
This is our state of affairs. To reach this point, someone must have been levying the taxes that overburdened the subjects before President Clinton.
I can offer Mr. Reagan one more quotation from his source to aid in his search for that someone: "Prejudice and partisanship obscure the critical faculty and preclude critical investigation."
 
DAVID A. WARD
Westwood, N.J., Feb. 18, 1993

HEADLINE: Why Doesn't Gaffney Act to Preserve Water?

 BODY:
When are we going to elect a Suffolk County Supervisor who really understands the connection between sound economic development on Long Island and the safety of our ground water? Robert J. Gaffney is supporting efforts by certain shortsighted business groups to gut Article 7 of our County Health Code, praised nationally as a model safeguard for areas that depend solely on underground aquifers for their drinking water.
He wants to take away the only legal protection we have left to keep industry from warehousing dangerously large amounts of toxic chemicals on top of Suffolk's Special Ground Water Protection Areas. This includes (coincidentally?) the one in Melville, where Parr Development would like to build a facility for the Olympus Corporation, which would be permitted to store photographic chemicals at its site. 
 Does Mr. Gaffney still not understand that Long Island's drinking water lies under our feet? We don't have it piped in from some upstate reservoir like New York City does. It is sheer insanity to increase the risk of industry's spilling poisonous substances into our deep ground-water recharge areas.
Now we must count on Suffolk Health Commissioner Mary Hibbard to block Mr. Gaffney and his tunnel vision, jobs-at-any-cost supporters from weakening Article 7. We need a County Executive who really understands what we must have for sustainable growth, and completely assured safe water is basic to this. Who will pay the millions of dollars to clean up accidental spills into our aquifer? Our aquifer experts don't even know if it's possible to do it for any amount of money -- like trying to put toothpaste back in the tube!
At this moment there are 92 federally designated toxic-waste sites here in Suffolk County alone, waiting (seemingly forever) to be cleaned up. Hundreds of others of less severity dot the maps in our county health department. It is doubtful if more such evidence will persuade many Long Island industries to stop their penny-wise-and-pound-foolish development approach to business. Weakening Article 7 regulations will only make an already dangerous situation even worse.
 
LOIS BLUSH
Dix Hills

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: For New Haven, No More Macy's. Maybe No More Hockey.

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
When the New Haven Nighthawks minor league hockey team was faced with the prospect of being moved to another city at the end of the 1986-87 season, the chairman of the team's advisory board, developer Joel Schiavone, decided on a flamboyant, attention-grabbing gesture in an effort to save the franchise.
For one full week in April, Mr. Schiavone, a former owner of the American Hockey League club, camped out on the roof of the Veterans Memorial Coliseum. Wearing a Nighthawks' jacket and sleeping in a small plywood shack, Mr. Schiavone left his aerie only after the Nighthawks were able to guarantee the sale of 1,300 season tickets for the 1987-88 season. As a result, the Nighthawks' parent club, the Los Angeles Kings of the National Hockey League, allowed the local ownership to keep the team in New Haven. 
 For a while last summer, after the team had drawn poorly at the gate under a new owner and playing without an affiliation to a major league team, it appeared once more that the state was going to lose its only minor league hockey team. But in an 11th-hour drive to sell at least 450 tickets within 48 hours, the club sold 497, largely because of the efforts of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce.
Now, though, it appears that nothing can save the franchise, which appears certain to move to somewhere in eastern Canada next season. That would leave New Haven without a professional hockey team for the first time since 1971 and put an end to 48 consecutive years of minor league hockey in the city. It also would leave Connecticut with only two professional sports teams -- the Hartford Whalers of the National Hockey League, who many insiders believe may soon leave the state because of dwindling attendance, and the New Britain Red Sox, the Double-A farm club of the Boston Red Sox. (Another Double-A baseball team, the New Haven Ravens, is scheduled to start playing at Yale Field in New Haven in the spring of 1994).
 
Move to Canada Expected
 Citing poor attendance as a major factor, Peter Shipman, a businessman who has owned the New Haven team for two seasons, recently sold the club to the Ottawa Senators, and the now New Haven Senators serve as the main farm team for the Canadian club.
In a recent interview, Randy Sexton, president of the Ottawa club, which is in its first season in the National Hockey League, indicated it was virtually certain that the franchise would be moved to Canada. "The odds are strongly in favor of not being in New Haven next season," Mr. Sexton said.
"Because of the currency exchange, it costs us much more to keep a team in the States. The other major reasons are attendance and logistics."
Logistics was also a problem with the New Haven franchise's previous parent club, the Los Angeles Kings, which had been affiliated with New Haven from 1980 until 1991. By contrast, the team -- known as the Nighthawks from 1972 until this season -- had fared much better in attendance during previous affiliations with, first, the New York Islanders, and later the New York Rangers.
"Local fans have a hard time relating to a team affiliated with Los Angeles or Ottawa," said Harmon Corey of Branford, a longtime season ticket holder for minor league hockey games in New Haven. "It was much easier relating to the Rangers because you could follow young players when they went up to the N.H.L. or were sent back to New Haven for a while."
In those days, as Mr. Corey pointed out, the Nighthawks also drew fans from New York who were unable to buy tickets for the Rangers' games at Madison Square Garden. That situation has not applied in recent years, since there are relatively few Los Angeles or Ottawa fans in the New York metropolitan area.
 
Perceptions of Unsafe Downtown
 Mr. Shipman, who has homes in Rye, N.Y., and in Branford, said he believed that "fear of the city" had kept attendance down at the Veterans Memorial Coliseum. "I think there's a perception of downtown New Haven as being unsafe, and that has kept people away," he said in an interview.
Indeed, the decline of New Haven was made more evident last week when Macy's announced it was closing its downtown store.
But Mr. Corey and some other faithful fans attribute the poor attendance to a bad team, which has been in last place for most of the season in the Northern Division of the American Hockey League, which is regarded as the primary minor league in professional hockey.
"We all expected a bad season, since it's an expansion team's farm club, but they haven't done anything to improve the team," said Tom Bauer, a season ticket holder from Middletown. "If they had made an effort to sign some free agents who played for New Haven last season and were among the team's best players and were available, they could have had a better team."
Attendance at New Haven Senators' games has been averaging about 1,785, the lowest in the American Hockey League, where the average is around 4,000. It is also the lowest since New Haven returned to the league in 1972. Attendance peaked during the first season at the Veterans Memorial Coliseum when the team, then the New Haven Nighthawks, averaged 4,914 fans a game. Those were glory days for the franchise, which was then the top minor league affiliate of the New York Islanders and included such prospects as Bobby Nystrom, who developed into an all-star right wing in the National Hockey League.
 
Coliseum's Main Tenant
 As recently as five seasons ago, New Haven was averaging more than 3,000 fans in the Coliseum, which seats 5,636 for hockey and up to 10,500 for a rock concert. But attendance fell to an all-time low of 2,683 last season, which was still about 900 more than this season.
The loss of the hockey team would be a severe blow to the Veterans Memorial Coliseum, where the team has been the main tenant since the building opened in 1972. On average, the team plays about 40 home games from October through early April and pays a rental fee of $2,900 a game. Those games account for about 30 percent of the bookings at the Coliseum, which is situated close to Interstates 95 and 91 and within walking distance of Union Station.
"If we lose the hockey team, it will have an emotional effect and it will hurt financially," said James E. Perillo, the Coliseum's executive director. "But it will enable us to do more weekend convention business, since the team plays at home on Fridays and Sundays."
It is highly unlikely, though, that the Coliseum will fill all of the hockey team's dates at a time when it has been steadily losing business. After averaging about 200 bookings a year, the Coliseum has only 145 dates booked this year, including the Senators' games. "That's an all-time low for us, and I think it's because of economic factors," Mr. Perillo said. "For example, concert business is down considerably, not just here, but all over. We used to do anywhere from 22 to 25 concerts a year; this year, we'll do from 6 to 8."
Besides professional hockey and an occasional rock concert, the Coliseum's main attractions have been, and still are, the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, the Ice Capades, Disney on Ice, occasional wrestling cards and tractor pulls and an annual appearance by the Harlem Globetrotters.
 
In Need of Repairs
 Though the Coliseum is owned by the city, which is obliged to pay the existing debt service, it is self-sustaining and, over the years, has been profitable. Three years ago, the General Assembly allotted $20 million to repair the deteriorating four-story garage atop the Coliseum. But that was $3 million less than had been requested. As a result, Mr. Perillo said, not all of the necessary repairs could be accomplished. Only two of the four garages were completely repaired, and only one of the two helixes -- the entry and exit ramps -- is usable. "As a result, if we get more than 1,000 cars to an event, it's a problem," said Mr. Perillo, who has requested $5 million more from the state to complete the necessary repairs.
Mr. Shipman agreed. "The place is in bad need of a facelift," said Mr. Shipman, who owns Howe Sports Data, a statistical service based in Boston, and who is an owner of the Raleigh, N.C., Ice Caps of the East Coast Hockey League. "We thought they were going to make some improvements, but they haven't."
Mr. Shipman said that when he bought the franchise from the Los Angeles Kings in 1991, he had hoped to at least break even. "I knew that in 20 years only one owner had made a profit here, and it was a modest one," he said. "But I lost $910,000 last season and will lose money this season, although not as much. And we spent more money on marketing than any team in the league. But I think our biggest problem is that people are afraid to come into New Haven."
Bryan McGrath, the development administrator for the city, challenged that assessment. "No one has any reason to be afraid to come to the Coliseum," Mr. McGrath said. "It's an excellent facility, and it's perfectly safe. The security is very good."
 
End of an Era
 Mr. McGrath acknowledged that the loss of the hockey team would have an adverse effect on the city. "The whole notion of having a pro team helps your town," he said. "It contributes to a better impression of the city. It's a matter of image."
If the Senators do leave New Haven, it would mark the end of an era. Except for two seasons during World War II -- 1943-44 and 1944-45 -- the city has had a professional hockey team since 1936, when New Haven became one of the original members of the American Hockey League. Playing in the old New Haven Arena, the team, the New Haven Eagles, was a member of the American Hockey League until it folded early in the 1943-44 season. New Haven returned to the league as the Ramblers from 1945 until 1951. Then from 1951 until 1972 the city was represented in professional hockey by the New Haven Blades of the Eastern Hockey League.
"I'm going to miss coming into New Haven to see a hockey game," said Mr. Bauer, the season ticket holder from Middletown. "The tickets are a lot cheaper than they are at a Whalers' game ($12 for general admission compared with $17 for the Hartford Whalers), and the parking is a lot easier. And it's fun to watch young players developing. I'm sorry they're going to leave after all these years."
