HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
Piquant Dishes, Turquoise and Pink Decor

BYLINE: By PATRICIA BROOKS

 BODY:
What once seemed a marathon of new Thai restaurants has slowed to a walk. The latest (and first in more than two years) to open in Fairfield County is Siam Rialto in South Norwalk.
Ensconced in a fin de siecle building that was once a theater (the Rialto), the restaurant replaces one named Old Rialto. The decor now combines light tones of Thailand with turquoise walls and turquoise-and-pink tablecloths and napkins. A small turquoise fountain bubbles away in the lower dining area, and a brick wall is hung with Thai art and photos of Thai kings. Upstairs is a balcony with additional tables. 
 Both lunch and dinner menus pay homage to many familiar Thai specialties, with several newcomers as well. New to us was wild boar basil, a three-star (for spiciest) entree of pan-fried slices of pork combined with generous slices of mushroom, red pepper strips, baby corn and thin slices of jalapeno peppers. Well-seasoned, if not as incendiary as the stars indicated, it was a fortuitous choice.
Consistency in its star system was a problem at Siam Rialto. On one visit, the member of our party who likes spicy dishes with no holds barred asked if the starred dishes were really hot. "You want them hot?" asked the waitress. "Oh, yes!" Well, so much for requests. The dishes in question were peppery, though by no means four-alarm. Another time we made no special request, yet several dishes were blazing hot.
Especially so were the three-star piquant squid (a medley of tender sauteed squid, mushrooms, onions, red and green peppers, and fresh basil) and two-star pik king shrimp (combined with string beans, green and red peppers, and pine nuts in a red-hot pepper oil sauce, edged with coconut milk) and kgang-pa (slices of beef in a green chili sauce with eggplant, asparagus and basil). What differentiates Thai food from other Asian cuisines is its juggling act of hot, sweet, sour, bitter and salty flavors. This makes almost every dish a gustatory adventure with depth, complexity and subtlety. Siam Rialto's most noticeable weakness was its lack of all three.
Four key elements of Thai cooking were missing altogether -- coriander (cilantro), ginger (galanga) and a kind of lime leaves -- or in short supply, like lemon grass, whose tangy touch was evident only in pik king shrimp. There were hints that a Chinese cook might even be at the kitchen range: the rampant use of baby corn (a local Chinese favorite) and an appetizer-like shrimp wrapped in an egg roll skin and deep-fried.
Appetizers were mostly disappointing. Satay, barbecued beef on bamboo skewers, was generous but bland, and its peanut sauce was underspiced. Golden katong -- petite flowers of crisp, fried spring roll filled with chopped shrimp, ground chicken, black mushrooms, corn, carrots and frozen peas -- was Thai in origin, but lacked fresh coriander and other spices that give zing to the classic dish.
Soups usually illuminate the balancing act of Thai cooking. But the chicken coconut soup lacked any assertive undertow and though the menu mentioned galanga, none could be tasted. Desserts at Siam Rialto are modest. Of three ice creams, coconut was superior to the green tea and too-sweet ginger.
A three-course dinner for two cost $32.50 before tip, tax and drinks. Skipping appetizers (the least successful part of the menu) would bring the price still lower. Even with three courses, this is one of the area's better values for a decidedly different meal in attractive surroundings, attended by a friendly staff. There is a full bar, an almost nonexistent wine list and several beers, including Thai Singha, our choice for a Thai meal. If it can iron out its inconsistencies and fear of flavoring, Siam Rialto has the potential to be a mainstay for budget watchers and anyone seeking an unusual dining experience.
Comings and Goings: The recession continues to be felt in Connecticut. Among recent restaurant closings are Nantucket (New Canaan), Oslo (Stamford), Thai Gardens (Cromwell) and Whitfield Alley (Guilford). In Westport, Chop Chop American Grill, Hong Kong Taste, Oriental Seaport, Fuddruckers and Le Paradis are gone, though the last reportedly may reopen under new ownership, and a fire at Onion Alley will keep it closed for repairs until July.
 
 
 
SIAM RIALTO

 
 Satisfactory
 
 128 Washington Street (between Main and Water Streets), South Norwalk. 855-7855.
 
 Atmosphere: A spacious dining room on two levels, with balcony above, decorated in turquoise and pink, with Thai art and artifacts.
 
 Service: Eager and good-humored.
 
 Recommended dishes: Wild boar basil, kgang-pa, pik king shrimp, piquant squid, coconut ice cream.

HEADLINE: President Asserts His Opponents 'Lack the Vision' on the Economy

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
President Clinton, seeking to counter accusations that his Administration is more interested in spending money than in cutting the deficit, said today that his critics "lack the vision" to improve the economy.
In his weekly radio address, Mr. Clinton followed through on an offensive he began on Friday, laying out the features of a spending plan that he says will put Americans to work and insisting that these programs are still needed despite signs that jobless rates are dropping and consumer confidence is up. 
 His remarks appeared to be aimed as much at members of Congress as at weekend radio listeners. Some Democrats and many Republicans have said that the $31 billion in new spending that Mr. Clinton calls a stimulus package should be trimmed until more budget cuts can be found.
"There are those who actually lack the vision to support these investments because they say that we shouldn't spend any new money trying to grow this economy," Mr. Clinton said. "It's not that they have a plan to make the economy grow, but they just dismiss the investment portion of our program by calling it more Government spending."
 
Seeing a 'Profound Difference'
 "There is a profound difference between spending and investment," he said. "It's the difference between the status quo and change."
The White House has tried to sell its economic plan in three stages. Officials struggled first with the notion of convincing Americans that sacrifice, in the form of new taxes, would be necessary to balance the deficit. Then Mr. Clinton took to the road promoting the 150 spending cuts in his plan, pledging that he would not support any spending increase that was not accompanied by a cut.
Now, Administration officials are seeking to define good spending and bad spending. Allocating more money in roads, bridges, research and incentives for small business is investment, not spending, they insist.
"Every investment is designed to make us smarter, safer and more secure, now and in the long term," Mr. Clinton said today.
The rebounding economy has not helped Mr. Clinton make his case for economic stimulus. On Friday, the Labor Department released new statistics showing that unemployment dropped a tenth of a percent in February, the biggest jump in employees added to the nation's payrolls in four years.
But Mr. Clinton declared today that the nation's unemployment rate of 7 percent still remains higher than it was during the recession and does not reflect the number of employed Americans who are working part time or who do not receive benefits like health care.
 
Aiming at Democrats
 "If this anemic recovery is the best we can do, it's further proof that real changes are needed to produce a better economy and a better life for our people," Mr. Clinton said.
Selling Mr. Clinton's economic plan to Congress has become the chief task for the President and his advisers. In recent days, aides to the President have challenged Republican critics to come up with budget-cutting alternatives, but the aides have rejected suggestions forwarded to the White House by partisan foes like Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas.
But today's challenge appeared to be aimed at the wavering Democrats. The White House has been sending subtle warnings to the members of the President's party who have spoken out against the plan, and few have publicly denounced the plan. But the White House must also compromise with these Democrats, who have the power to derail the package.
In remarks made at a news conference with mayors on Friday, Mr. Clinton emphasized the elements of the package that will provide incentives to small business. And today, he said the Administration would announce plans next week to change regulations to make it easier for small- and medium-sized businesses to qualify for loans.
"The issue is not whether there should be more budget cuts," he said Friday. "The issue is whether under the general shield of saying we need to reduce spending, we'll step away from investment. Just because a mayor wants to do it doesn't make it wrong, doesn't make it pork, doesn't make it useless."

HEADLINE: Focus: Chicago;
Seeding a Huge Project on an Old Railyard

BYLINE: By CHERYL KENT

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
MUCH of this city's Near South Side is just acres of vacant industrial land and underutilized railyards. But in 1989 developers took in hand a 72-acre tract, named it Central Station and trumpeted it as a $3 billion development that would include commerce, houses, stores, hotels and exhibition halls.
Allotments to each category would be determined by demand. Current zoning calls for a maximum of 19.5 million square feet of developed space. 
 What meets the eye four years later is a far cry from what the developers envisioned. But a residential development has started in the form of three-story town houses and apartments, with the Loop and Lake Michigan each about a half mile away. People are expected to start moving in in June.
The land developer of Central Station is Forest City Enterprises, a national real estate company based in Cleveland, in partnership with the Chicago-based Fogelson Properties. The Illinois Central Railroad sold land and air rights to the partners in 1989, retaining control only over the few active rail lines still on the property, which is named for the Illinois Central Depot, which once stood on the site.
To the developers, a key element of the future Central Station is back-office development for downtown companies. A problem is that with 26 million square feet of office space in Chicago vacant, back-office rates can be negotiated in new downtown high rises.
Nevertheless, Gerald Fogelson, chairman of Fogelson Properties, said he was still pursuing deals for large spaces with four prospective tenants. "The bad news is there are fewer deals," he said. "The good news is fewer guys are chasing them."
Other good news was that in November a builder started work on 40 town houses and 44 condominium apartments on a five-acre site. They are envisioned as the first stage in a 160-unit, $30 million development called Burnham Place. The builder is MCL, a 15-year-old Chicago development company. There have been 60 buyers so far.
The apartments will be in four L-shaped stone and brick three-story buildings on a square 2.5-acre lot, embracing two U-shaped buildings within. Apartments are 1,400 to 2,200 square feet and sell for $170,000 to $259,000. Roy H. Kruse & Associates of Chicago is the architect.
The town houses, in a similar configuration on an adjoining 2.5-acre lot, range from 2,200 to 3,400 square feet and are priced at $259,000 and $439,000. Pat Fitzgerald & Associates of Chicago is the architect.
AS a residential location, the Near South Side is relatively young. The North Side, north of the Loop, is the place of choice for many city residents, but little land is available there and development costs are comparatively high. Development in the Near South Side began when construction of Dearborn Park housing began in 1974. With the completion of its second complex within a year, there will be a total of 1,900 units.
Services for residents are still fairly scarce. The Printers' Row development, a half mile west of Burnham Place, has spawned an abundance of convenience and other service stores, but there are few supermarkets and restaurants.
The buyers at Burnham Place focused on the housing itself, however. Many said they had looked elsewhere but could not find what they wanted. Dan McLean, president of MCL, said the units were selling for about $125 a square foot, not substantially less than comparable units on the North Side, where housing of this kind is more typical.
George Cullen, one of the buyers, said he had looked for 18 months on the North Side before buying a $390,000, 3,420-square-foot town house in Burnham Place. Comparable units were hard to find to the north, he said. To him, the relative lack of services is a minor inconvenience. "The truth is we usually get in our cars and drive to a restaurant anyway," he said.
Mr. Cullen, a 57-year-old lawyer, is a lifelong South Sider. As a boy, he went to the beach at 12th Street to dive off the rocks into Lake Michigan. He said would be able to walk to that same swimming spot from his new house, this time with his five grandchildren, aged 2 to 8.
MCL plans to begin construction this summer on the 56 units that will complete the first phase of the development. It also has plans for 23 attached homes on an adjacent one-acre site, which it has an option to buy from the Central Station joint-venture partners.
Mr. McLean said many of his buyers -- like the Cullens -- are couples with adult children. Others are young professional couples without children; 30 percent of the total are single professional women. One problem that may deter couples with children is the lack of reputable schools in the area.
SCOTT FROMM, a 37-year-old, single divorce lawyer who bought an apartment in Burnham Place after a year-long search for a new home, said he cared little about the lack of service stores and shopping.
"I'm very mobile," he said. "I cook on average once a month and I shop maybe four times per year."
He sees the possibility of higher-than-average appreciation in the value of his 2,200-square-foot unit with garage for which he paid $259,000 with $17,000 in upgrades. And, he said, he was strongly motivated by mortgage interest rates, currently a shade under 8 percent.
Mr. McLean left investment banking 15 years ago to begin his career as a developer, starting out with renovations and moving to new construction. He has made something of a speciality of buying underutilized urban industrial land and building town houses. His first such project, in 1985, was Lakewood Commons on the North Side, with 108 town houses stretching along three blocks occupied by the Lincoln Towing Company before its bankruptcy. Four similar projects followed, one with 124 units in Dearborn Park.
In all, Mr. McLean has built 515 homes in Chicago since 1985.
GREG LONGHINI of Chicago's Department of Planning and Economic Development said the city was trying to focus development on the Near South Side, and it has shown its interest with the issuance of $4.5 million in tax-free bonds toward construction of Central Station's infrastructure, including sewer lines, roads, and landscaping.
In addition, the city has agreed to issue an additional $36 million in bonds over 22 years for infrastructure as the Central Station project proceeds. Buyers of the bonds will be reimbursed from property taxes paid on the site. For their part, the Central Station developers have paid more than $10 million toward the improvements.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A rendering of the condominium development of Burnham Place at Central Station shows an apartment complex in the foreground and town houses behind. The Chicago skyline rises in the background. (Doug Radke)

LENGTH: 1138 words

HEADLINE: A Bowling Film Shatters Illusions

BYLINE: By MARJORIE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
"WHEN you hear thunder, God is bowling," is how a new seriocomic thriller, "Spare Me," by Matthew Harrison, begins.
The audience is confronted by a dark and twisted story, and initially wonders whether to laugh or cry. 
 Mr. Harrison, 33, who once lived in Bay Shore and now lives in New York City, practices what Preston Sturges once recommended, "Make it strange."
"Spare Me," Mr. Harrison's first full-length feature, is a faintly tongue-in-cheek played-straight sendup of a post-World War II film noir, the style and attitude characterized by a dark melodrama of crime, corruption and disordered psyches.
 
Drawing on Film History
 Christopher Cooke, director of the Suffolk Film Bureau in Hauppauge and co-producer of "Spare Me,' said a return to film noir, along with other genres, may be just another way for independent film makers to draw on history in an effort to return to basics. Another way, Mr. Cooke said, is forming film cooperatives to "network" and cut production costs.
In 1985, Mr. Harrison founded Film Crash in Manhattan, an informal collective that Christopher Grimm once of Ocean Bay Park and co-writer of "Spare Me," has described as "like gangs of director-driven film makers who help each other out instead of fighting."
Film Crash has developed into a philosophy and model for other groups of independents in Suffolk.
Especially among young film makers, low-budget movies created out of pooled resources are like returning from designer to work clothes, Mr. Harrison said. "Spare Me," filmed in 18 days on a $38,000 budget, substituted ingenuity for capital, with Robert Moses State Park and a bowling alley in Mineola helping to maintain the small budget.
 
A 'Social Experience'
 "Spare Me" was screened at the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington last month, and it has been accepted for the Sao Paulo International Film Festival in Brazil. On Thursday the film makes its Long Island debut at 8 P.M. at the New York Institute of Technology in Central Islip.
"In 'Spare Me' bowling becomes the 'Paradise Lost' of the American optimism and vitality of the 50's and 60's," Mr. Grimm said. "The postcynical 90's is a time for returning to working-class values and traditions like bowling. The low-tech, yet highly social experience of rolling a big black ball down a perfectly polished lane at 10 symmetrical white pins might just symbolize the new world order."
Mr. Grimm, who attended the State University at Purchase and Brown University, said he learned film making the blue-collar way -- by doing.
"This gives our films a different feel than those coming out of the film schools," he said. "The advantage is a fresh foundation and approach."
Mr. Harrison said "Spare Me" had been modeled after "Repo Man," a nightmarish black fantasy made in 1984 by Alex Cox. Highly stylized in writing, acting and technique, the images and symbolism are purposely abstract and intense, with rapid cuts.
In "Spare Me," a "down and dirty" film dealing with fractured relationships, a "bad boy of bowling" starts a crusade to find his lost father while falling in love with a pyromaniac waitress and cyclist whose brother has escaped from a mental institution.
 
The Sport's Toughest Shot
 Bowling metaphors like the "mixer ball" and the "7-10 split," the hardest shot in the game, are common in the film. "The protagonist is faced with one of those impossible 7-10 splits of life," Mr. Harrison said. "Bowling is like faith. Now and then it ends up in the gutter."
"Spare Me" is based on an incident in a bowling alley where Mr. Harrison learned about the intensity and passion of the sport. "It may be a product of where I am economically, and also where our society is at," he said. "But I think we are partly in a revisionist period returning to working-class values."
According to Mr. Harrison, the bowling industry provides a built-in audience. The American Bowling Congress said 82 million people bowled in 1991l. On Long Island, the A.B.C. lists 58 bowling centers and more than 55,000 registered league bowlers. The organization says the Island has 27,000 female bowlers and 28,000 male participants. Although the target audience for "Spare Me" is college students, Mr. Harrison hinted at a potential mass appeal similar to that of the "Rocky Horror Picture Show."
Mr. Harrison and Mr. Grimm, friends since childhood, have tried to demystify movies as a costly and imposing process.
"We're filling a gap for struggling independent film makers left by museums, festivals and repertories," Mr. Harrison said. "The main focus of Film Crash has been creating our own audience. We started organizing screenings with a party angle to show our own Super-8 shorts on a regular basis and encouraged audience feedback."
What began as a celebration of their films on the Lower East Side, at sites like Public School 122 and projections on a brick wall for an audience seated in a restaurant, has progressed to screenings at the Angelika Film Center at 18 West Houston Street, as well as in Los Angeles.
"At first to attract people, we encouraged anything with sprocket holes," Mr. Harrison said. "But now we've had to turn people away. Our criteria is limited to film makers beginning to find their own voice. We're not interested in looking slick or showing resume films. We can show our films and then get on to making the next one."
For Mr. Harrison, that includes more than 50 shorts, including an underground hit in 1989, "Bonehead."
Mr. Harrison was born in Manhattan, the son of a graphic designer. At 9, he made a two-minute black-and-white movie about a corrupt detective that was filmed at 14th Street and Ninth Avenue. Summers on Fire Island brought together Mr. Harrison as director, Mr. Grimm as screenwriter and Danny Brenner as composer in the ultraviolent "Kiddie Massacre."
"We used to show our films at the firehouse in Ocean Bay Park," said Mr. Harrison, a graduate of the Cooper Union School of Art. For more than 20 years he has continued to make films with his friends, who, with members of his family, helped finance "Spare Me."
 
Lured by 'Splatter' Films
 While growing up, Mr. Harrison was attracted to genre movies, especially the violent and slow-motion "splatter" films directed by Sam Peckinpah like "Straw Dogs." Most of those films were "revisionist westerns," Mr. Harrison said, in that they no longer had the classic western heroes who wore black or white hats but, instead, led the way for the antihero movement of the 70's.
Mr. Harrison agrees with Alfred Hitchcock, who said, "Films should be stronger than reason." His own philosophy for making movies follows Francis Ford Coppola, who said, "Just start marching down the avenue with a flag, and pretty soon you'll have a whole parade behind you."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Matthew Harrison preparing camera shot for his first full-length feature, "Spare Me," a seriocomic thriller. (Andreas Rentsch)

TITLE: SPARE ME (MOVIE)

PERSON: HARRISON, MATTHEW; KAUFMAN, MARJORIE

LOAD-DATE: March 8, 1993
